Customer Feedback Form 
Purpose
Collect post-ride customer feedback, surface critical incidents in real time, and automatically create ClickUp tasks for follow-up and quality improvement.
Primary goals
Capture quick ratings and short comments.
Flag safety/security or luggage issues instantly.
Auto-create ClickUp tasks with priority and evidence (photos, recording links).
Offer a pre-book CTA on the landing page to convert satisfied customers.

Feedback form fields (web + in-app)
Booking ID (required, text)
Ride date & time (auto-filled, read-only)
Driver name / Agent name (auto-filled, read-only)
Overall rating (required, 1–5 stars)
NPS question (Would you recommend Shuttle Plus? Yes / Maybe / No)
Primary issue type (required, radio): None; Delay; Luggage damage/loss; Security; Driver conduct; App/payment; Other
Short description (required if Primary issue ? None, 30–500 chars)
Attach photo or screenshot (optional, single file, JPG/PNG, max 8MB)
Request follow-up (checkbox)
Preferred contact method (conditional if Request follow-up: Phone / Email / In-app)
Optional quick satisfaction toggles (checkbox group): On-time pickup; Courteous agent; Secure luggage; Clear communication
Consent checkbox (required): I consent to Shuttle Plus contacting me about this feedback.
Validation rules
Booking ID and Rating required.
If Primary issue ? None, Description required and min 30 chars.
File types and size validated client-side.
Rate-limit submissions to 1 per Booking ID per 24 hours.
UX details
Short[E93] two-step experience: Rating + quick follow-up prompt if rating ? 3 or issue selected.
Inline microcopy explaining next steps when user requests follow-up.
Show Booking summary[E94] (pickup address, ETA, agent photo) above the form to reduce friction.

Automation flags, thresholds, and actions
Immediate Critical Flag — Condition: Primary issue == Security OR Primary issue == Luggage loss/damage OR Rating ? 2. Action: Create ClickUp task as Priority: Urgent; assign to Ops Manager; send SMS to customer acknowledging receipt; escalate email to CEO if issue type == Security.
High Priority Flag — Condition: Rating == 3 OR Primary issue == Driver conduct OR Request follow-up checked. Action: Create ClickUp task Priority: High; assign to Customer Experience lead; schedule same-day callback.
Standard Follow-up — Condition: Rating == 4 OR Primary issue == None but Request follow-up checked. Action: Create ClickUp task Priority: Normal; assign to CX team for 48-hour resolution.
Auto-Closure Rule — Condition: Issue resolved in ClickUp and customer confirmed resolution. Action: Update ticket status to Closed; send thank-you SMS/email and optional discount code.
Repeat Offender Detection — Condition: >2 complaints[E95] linked to same Agent in 30 days. Action: Create Audit task for Ops with aggregated evidence and trigger coaching workflow.
NPS Sweep — Condition: Weekly aggregation of NPS < target. Action: Generate weekly KPI report task and notify Ops Manager.
Automation technical actions (ClickUp + integrations)
Create Task (ClickUp API): include fields, attachments URLs, booking metadata, screenshots, and transcript/recording URL if available.
Send SMS/email acknowledgment (Twilio/Telebirr or preferred SMS provider).
Add candidate evidence (photo links) to task description and set custom field Issue Type.
Add webhook to incident tracker (if Security flag) for legal and insurer alerting.



ClickUp mapping and webhook payload (example)
Essential ClickUp fields to create or ensure exist: Booking ID (text), Issue Type (dropdown), Rating (number), Priority (dropdown), Status (Open/In Progress/Closed), Assigned To (user email), Evidence URLs (text), Request Follow-up (checkbox), Contact Method (dropdown).
Example minimal payload (JSON) to POST to ClickUp create-task endpoint:
{
  "name": "Feedback: {BookingID} — Rating {Rating}",
  "description": "Issue: {IssueType}\nCustomer notes: {Description}\nContact: {PreferredContact}\nEvidence: {EvidenceURLs}",
  "status": "Open",
  "priority": "{Priority}",
  "assignees": [{ "id": "{assignee_id}" }],
  "custom_fields": [
    { "id": "{field_id_booking}", "value": "{BookingID}" },
    { "id": "{field_id_issue}", "value": "{IssueType}" },
    { "id": "{field_id_rating}", "value": {Rating} },
    { "id": "{field_id_followup}", "value": {RequestFollowup} }
  ]
}
Implementation notes
Resolve ClickUp custom-field IDs before wiring automation.
Upload files to your secure storage first, then include signed URLs in the task description.
Log timestamp and user consent in the task metadata.

Landing page + pre-book CTA (structure & copy)
Layout (single-scroll landing page)
Hero section: headline, 1-line value prop, logo, primary CTA button (Pre-book shuttle) styled in Shuttle Plus colors (#183251 background for header, CTA in #20A4F3 with white text).
How it works (3 steps): Book ? Pickup ? Handoff (icons + 1-line each).
Social proof: 3 short testimonials + average rating and NPS.
Key features: Tamper-evident luggage, Verified agents, Real-time tracking, Refund SLA.
Pricing & zones: Simple table or cards with base fares and luggage add-ons.
Pre-book CTA section: date/time picker, pickup zone, phone number input, quick confirm button.
Footer: Contact, privacy/recording policy link, partner hotels.
Pre-book CTA behavior
Minimal form: Name, Phone (with country code), Pickup zone (dropdown), Preferred pickup date/time, Luggage count, Quick consent checkbox, Submit.
On submit: show Booking ID, “We’ll confirm within X minutes” and a button to “Give feedback after ride” that links to the feedback form.
Track conversion events for CAC measurement.
Landing copy examples (short)
Headline: “Guaranteed airport pickups. Dignified care for every bag.”
Subhead: “Book a Shuttle Plus and relax — we handle luggage, identity checks, and secure handoff.”
CTA: “Pre-book your shuttle” (primary) and secondary “See how it works”.
Design & branding
Use brand fonts (Inter/Helvetica Neue) and color tokens from your style guide.
CTA buttons use accent #20A4F3; headers use #183251; cards use #c4cbdb backgrounds with subtle shadows.
Place the official logo in the top-left header and the footer.

Implementation checklist & quick test plan
Create ClickUp custom fields matching mapping table.
Build feedback form endpoint that: validates Booking ID, stores files securely, returns signed file URLs, records consent timestamp.
Implement automation engine (Zapier/Make/Node webhook): evaluate rules, set Priority, create ClickUp task with mapped custom fields, send acknowledgements.
Wire landing page pre-book CTA to booking backend (Booking ID generation) and to dispatcher flow.
Run test scenarios (end-to-end): 
Submit a 5-star feedback ? no task created, thank-you message.
Submit a 2-star Security feedback ? Urgent ClickUp task created, SMS ack sent, CEO/Legal notified.
Submit photo evidence ? verify file URL appears in ClickUp description and is accessible via signed URL.
Submit repeat complaints for same Agent ? verify Repeat Offender detection creates Audit task.
Monitor first 14 days and tune thresholds (Rating cutoffs, repeat offender window, SLA response times).




Customer Tracking App User Flow
A clear, customerfacing flow that guides passengers from booking to shuttle dropoff, focused on simplicity, trust, and actionability in Amharic and English.

Summary
Single linear experience: Booking confirmation ? Realtime shuttle tracking ? Handoff verification ? Postride feedback and receipts. Minimal taps[E96], clear status states, localized microcopy, and visual evidence for luggage chain of custody.

Flow Steps
Booking Confirmation Screen[E97]
What user sees: booking summary card with route, pickup time, vehicle ETA, driver name and photo, concierge name, and luggage tag ID.
Primary action: View Tracking.
Microcopy examples: 
EN: “Booking confirmed. Your shuttle picks up at Gate 4 at 16:40.”
AM: “?? ?????? ???? ?16:40 ??? 4 ?????.”
Visuals: small map thumbnail, countdown timer to pickup, addons purchased list, contact buttons (Call Driver, Message Concierge).
Live Tracking Screen
What user sees: fullscreen map with shuttle icon, ETA, route line, stop markers, and expected boarding zone.
Primary actions: Share ETA, Contact Driver, Add Photo Evidence.
Status states: On route, Arriving, At pickup, Delayed, Completed.
Microcopy examples: 
EN: “Shuttle C3 — 6 min away. Driver: Tesfaye.”
AM: “??? C3 — 6 ??? ??? ?????? ???? ???”
UX touches: progress bar for ETA, accessibility larger button for Contact, photo upload attaches directly to booking.
Arrival and Handoff Verification Screen
Trigger: driver/concierge taps “Arrived” in ops app. Passenger receives arrival notification and CTA to confirm.
What user sees: photo of driver/concierge, vehicle plate, luggage tag code, quick verify button, and chainofcustody photo if available.
Primary actions: Confirm Identity, Report Issue.
Microcopy examples: 
EN: “Is this your shuttle? Confirm to receive your luggage.”
AM: “?? ????? ??? ??? ????? ??????”
If confirmed: generate digital receipt and luggage tag acknowledgement stored in user account.
In Ride Screen
What user sees: trip progress, estimated arrival, ability to request stops[E98], contact ops, and view purchased addons.
Actions: Request assistance, report urgent issue.
Microcopy: brief, actionoriented prompts and confirmation to avoid ambiguity.
Dropoff Confirmation and Receipt Screen
Trigger: driver marks trip complete and logs luggage handoff.
What user sees: receipt with fare breakdown, addon list, 1% commission note if applicable, downloadable receipt option, and feedback prompt.
Primary actions: Rate trip[E99], Add comment, Download receipt.
Microcopy examples: 
EN: “Trip complete. Please rate your experience.”
AM: “??? ?????? ????? ????? ?????”
Post Ride Feedback and Dispute Flow
What user sees: quick 1–5 star rating, onetap common reason buttons, optional comment box, and evidence upload for disputes.
If dispute filed: automatic SLA message with owner and expected resolution time, and option to chat with Ops.
Microcopy: reassure user of timely resolution and next steps in local language.

Interaction Details and Edge Cases
Offline Booking or Payment Pending 
Show pending badge and offline instructions: “Payment pending — arrival requires verification” with CTA to retry payment or use alternative method.
Driver Not Found or Wrong Vehicle 
Immediate “Report Wrong Vehicle” flow sends photo and live location to Ops and triggers escalation.
Lost Luggage Report by Passenger 
Provide structured report form, allow photo evidence, and show expected SLA and owner.
Duplicate Notifications or Missed Push 
Inapp Alerts inbox stores all missed notifications and provides last seen ETA.

Localization and Tone
Default language detection: use device locale[E100]; allow manual switch in profile.
Tone: professional, concise, reassuring. Use Amharic first for local users then English for international passengers. Keep action verbs frontloaded.
Example bilingual microcopy card: show Amharic line first then English.

Accessibility and Usability
Large tap targets for primary actions; high contrast UI; voice prompts for visually impaired[E101]; readout of driver name, plate, and ETA.
Low bandwidth mode[E102]: simplified map (static tile), text updates only, and image compression for uploads.
Quick accessibility shortcuts: singletap call to driver, vibration on arrival for hearingimpaired users.

Metrics and Monitoring
Adoption and reliability KPIs: Tracking opens per booking, push delivery rate, ETA accuracy P95, handoff confirmation rate, dispute resolution time, and NPS per trip.
Ops signals: failed confirmations, repeat missed pickups, high dispute clusters by zone or staff ID.




Dashboard Ops Monitoring Plan
A compact[E103], audit-ready plan to design and deploy an operations dashboard that gives Shuttle Plus realtime visibility into concierge, driver, and shuttle performance, sales, safety, and exceptions.

Objectives
Provide a single pane of truth for day-to-day operations, sales performance, and exceptions.
Surface actionable issues (late starts, lost luggage, payment disputes) with owner and SLA.
Track incentive-related metrics (commissions, tier progress[E104], teamwork pool shares).
Enable quick coaching, shift rebalancing, and daily stand-up decisioning.

Key metrics (must-haves)
Operational status 
Active shuttles; on-time departures (%)
Shuttle readiness (vehicle checks completed)
Concierge/Driver activity 
Trips completed per staff; average turnaround time
Luggage handoffs processed; handoff accuracy (%)
Sales & incentives 
Add-on sales (ETB) by concierge/driver; 1% commission earned
Tier progress % toward next sales bonus; top performers list
Teamwork pool size and projected payout per member
Service quality & safety 
Passenger satisfaction (NPS/ratings); complaint count and severity
Safety incidents; incident TTL and owner
Exceptions & finance 
Payment disputes and refund volume; chargeback alerts
Lost/misrouted luggage log; chain-of-custody exceptions
Workforce health 
On-shift headcount vs. schedule; absenteeism rate
Overtime hours and coverage gaps

Data sources and integration
Booking & payments system: trip revenue, add-ons, payment status.
Mobile app/POS: concierge/driver sales tagged by staff ID.
Dispatch/telemetry: shuttle location, departures, ETA, readiness checks.
CRM/feedback tool: passenger ratings and complaints.
Shift roster/HRIS: schedules, attendance, tenure eligibility.
Incident/Lost-and-Found logs: handoff exceptions, chain-of-custody records.
Payroll system: prior payouts for audit and dispute reconciliation.

Dashboard layout and tiles
Top row — Executive snapshot (single-number tiles)
Active shuttles; Today’s revenue (net); Avg passenger rating; Teamwork pool value.
Second row — Operational health (cards)
On-time departures (%) with 24h trend sparkline
Shuttle readiness % with list of non-ready vehicles (click to owner)
Open exceptions count (lost luggage, disputes, incidents) with SLA buckets
Third row — Sales & incentives (leaderboard + progress)
Concierge sales leaderboard (ETB) with commission column
Driver sales leaderboard with commission column
Individual tier progress bars (click to open monthly breakdown)
Fourth row — Quality & safety (alerts + trend)
Passenger rating heatmap by shift/station
Open complaints by severity and owner
Safety incidents timeline and open corrective actions
Fifth row — People & coverage
On-shift vs rostered (heatmap by hour)
Absenteeism & late-start alerts; overtime forecast
Right-hand rail — Action center and quick workflows
Live alerts feed (exceptions prioritized by SLA)
Quick actions: assign replacement, open incident, issue spot bonus, flag dispute
Owner contact cards with call/message buttons
Detailed panels (drilldowns)
Trip-level drilldown: view booking, payments, staff IDs, add-ons, handoff logs, photos, chain-of-custody evidence
Staff profile: sales history, incentive earned YTD, feedback, recent incidents
Monthly payroll preview: calculated commissions and teamwork distributions for approval

Alerts, SLAs, and operational workflows
Alert types: Red (SLA breached), Amber (near SLA), Green (info).
Example SLAs: lost-luggage acknowledged in 30 min; payment dispute triaged within 48 hours.
Owner assignment: automated owner based on shift/zone with manual reassign option.
Escalation path: 1st owner ? Shift Lead (15 min) ? Ops Manager (60 min) ? Head Ops (4 hr).
Action buttons on alerts: “Dispatch Replacement”, “Initiate Refund”, “Open Incident”, “Award Spot Bonus”.

Implementation roadmap (8 weeks)
Week 0–1: Finalize KPIs, data model, and owners.
Week 2–3: Build ETL connectors from booking, POS, dispatch, HRIS, CRM.
Week 4: Prototype wireframe (interactive) for ops leads; iterate with 3 pilot users.
Week 5: Build dashboards (prod), define alert rules and SLA logic.
Week 6: Integrate action center (quick workflows) and audit logs.
Week 7: Pilot for one station (2 weeks of live data); collect feedback and tune weights.
Week 8: Fleet-wide rollout, ops training, and launch kit.

Governance, controls, and auditability
Immutable audit trail of incentive calculations, disputes, and adjustments retained 12 months.
Read-only and role-based access: ops lead, station manager, finance, HR.
Approval flows for payroll-affecting adjustments (2-step approval recommended).
Regular monthly reconciliation between dashboard totals and payroll exports.

Minimal viable deliverables (first release)
Executive snapshot, Operational health cards, Sales leaderboards, Exceptions feed, Trip-level drilldown, Alerting with SLA assignment, Staff profile with incentive history, One-page ops playbook.




Data Protection Policy Plan — App and Database Compliance (Shuttle Plus)
Purpose
Define the governance, controls and operational steps Shuttle Plus will apply to protect customer and employee personal data processed by the mobile app, backend databases and supporting services so the company meets Ethiopia’s PDPP, applicable sector rules (e.g., PCI DSS for payments) and international best practice.

1. Scope and Applicability
Scope: All personal data collected, stored, processed or transmitted by Shuttle Plus systems (mobile apps, APIs, backend databases, analytics, payment flows, CRM, logs, thirdparty services).
Data subjects: Customers, drivers, employees, contractors, suppliers.
Processing activities covered: Registration/KYC, booking and routing, telemetry (GPS), payments, customer support, marketing, profiling, background checks.
Exemptions: Aggregated anonymised data used for analytics (only after formal verification of irreversibility).

2. Governing Principles
Lawful, fair and transparent processing — document legal basis (consent, contract, legal obligation, legitimate interest) per processing activity.
Purpose limitation and minimisation — collect only necessary attributes and retain them only as required.
Accuracy — maintain capability for subjects to update or correct data.
Storage limitation — retention schedules defined by data class.
Integrity and confidentiality — technical and organisational protections against unauthorised access or loss.
Accountability — documented decisions, DPIAs, logs and audit trails.

3. Roles and Governance
Data Protection Officer (DPO) / Privacy Lead: overall accountability for PDPP alignment, DPIAs, regulatory liaison and breach notification.
Data Controller: Shuttle Plus PLC (legal entity) — defines purposes.
Data Owners: Business unit leads (Product, Ops, Finance) — approve retention and access.
Data Stewards: Engineering/DBA, Security, Support — implement controls and operate processes.
Privacy Steering Committee: Legal, IT, Product, Ops, HR — monthly review of highrisk projects and incidents.

4. Data Inventory and Lawful Basis Mapping
Create and maintain a live data map (data elements; source; flow diagram; storage locations; processors; retention period; legal basis).
Tag highrisk datasets: GPS telemetry, identity documents, payment card data, criminal/conviction checks. These require DPIA and elevated controls.
Classify data sensitivity: Public / Internal / Confidential / Highly Confidential; apply controls accordingly.

5. Technical and Organisational Controls
Identity & Access Management 
RBAC with least privilege; enforce role separation and periodic access reviews.
MFA for admin and ops access; strong password policies.
Encryption & Key Management 
TLS for data in transit; AES256 (or equivalent) for PII at rest.
Dedicated key management (KMS) with separation of duties; rotate keys per policy.
Database Hardening 
Disable unused services; enforce parameterised queries; enable DBlevel encryption, rowlevel encryption for sensitive fields where appropriate.
Read replicas and backups encrypted and accessrestricted.
Network & Infrastructure 
Network segmentation (app tier, DB tier, admin), private subnets for databases, strict firewall rules.
WAF for APIs and rate limiting.
Logging, Monitoring & Detection 
Immutable audit logs for data access and administrative actions; central SIEM with alerting on anomalous access patterns.
Retain logs per legal/forensic needs; protect logs from tampering.
Application Security 
Secure coding standards; static and dynamic scanning in CI/CD; dependency vulnerability management.
Input validation, output encoding, and strict session management.
Payment Card Data 
Isolate cardholder environment; comply with PCI DSS controls (tokenisation, no storage of CVV, segmented networks).
Data Minimisation & Pseudonymisation 
Use pseudonymisation for analytics; store identifiers separately where feasible.
Backups & Resilience 
Encrypted backups, tested restore procedures and retention aligned to policy.
Vendor & ThirdParty Controls 
Written processor agreements (security obligations, audit rights, breach notification, subprocessor rules). Vendor security risk assessments and annual reassessments.

6. Data Subject Rights and UX
Rights supported: Access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability, automated decision review.
Operational workflows: Selfservice portal for simple requests; authenticated support channel for complex requests. Verify identity before fulfilment; log requests and responses with timestamps to meet statutory SLAs.
Consent & Preference Management: Granular consent capture (profiling, marketing); store consent records with versioning; allow easy withdrawal.

7. DPIA, Risk Assessment and Change Control
Mandatory DPIA for highrisk processing: GPS realtime tracking, profiling, largescale KYC, automated decisioning.
Threat modelling for new features; security/privacy signoff gate in product lifecycle.
Change control: every schema change or new thirdparty integration requires privacy/security review before deployment.

8. Incident Response and Breach Notification
Incident response plan with defined roles (Incident Lead, Communications, Legal, Forensics, DPO).
Triage timeline: Initial containment within hours; 72hour regulator notification threshold for reportable breaches (or as specified by PDPP). Notify affected data subjects where likely risk to rights.
Forensics & remediation: Preserve evidence, rootcause analysis, corrective measures and postincident report to Steering Committee.

9. Retention, Deletion and Archival
Retention schedule per data class (e.g., booking logs: 3 years; payment records for tax: statutory period; KYC: 5 years after relationship ends) — publish internal schedule and automate deletion where possible.
Secure deletion: use cryptographic erase or DB record purge; maintain tamperevident deletion logs.
Archival: encrypt and restrict archived datasets; limit access and periodically rereview necessity.

10. CrossBorder Transfers
Default rule: Avoid transferring PD to jurisdictions without adequate protections.
When necessary: apply safeguards — regulator approvals, standard contractual clauses, Binding Corporate Rules or equivalent contractual commitments; document transfer legal basis in data map.
Data localisation: where permitted/required, use local processing and storage.

11. Training, Awareness and Culture
Mandatory privacy & security training for all staff at onboarding and annually; rolebased advanced training for engineers, ops and customer support.
Simulations: tabletop breach exercises quarterly; phishing exercises for staff.
Reporting channels: anonymous reporting for suspected misuse with no retaliation.

12. Monitoring, Audit and Continuous Improvement
KPIs: % of data mapped; DPIAs completed for highrisk features; mean time to detect (MTTD) and mean time to respond (MTTR) for incidents; DSAR SLA compliance; encryption coverage.
Audits: quarterly internal technical audits and annual external privacy/security audits (include PCI attestation where applicable).
Policy review cadence: Policy and data map reviewed at least annually or after significant legal/architectural change.

13. Implementation Roadmap (90 days, prioritized)
Days 1–14
Appoint DPO/privacy lead and form Privacy Steering Committee.
Start live data inventory and classification; list all processors and payment flows.
Run urgent PCI DSS gap check on payments.
Days 15–45
Deploy RBAC, MFA for admin access; encrypt PII in transit and at rest; enable DB audit logging.
Publish user privacy notice and consent UI; implement consent storage.
Begin DPIAs for GPS telemetry and KYC.
Days 46–75
Integrate DSAR workflows (support portal + templates); implement retention automation for lowrisk data.
Vendor contractual updates and security questionnaires completed for top 10 vendors.
Implement SIEM alerting for abnormal DB access; schedule first tabletop breach exercise.
Days 76–90
Complete remediation actions from DPIAs; finalize backup encryption and tested restore.
Run internal audit of access rights; remediate excessive privileges.
Produce regulatorready documentation pack (data map, DPIAs, breach plan, vendor register).
14. Practical Controls Checklist (quick)
Enforce RBAC + MFA; periodic access review.
TLS everywhere; AES256 at rest; KMS for keys.
Parameterised queries + ORM protections; secrets management.
PCI tokenisation for cards; avoid storing CVV.
Centralised SIEM and immutable audit logs.
Vendor contracts with processors’ obligations.
DSAR UI, verification workflow and SLA tracking.
DPIA template and signoff process for new features.

15. KPIs and Success Metrics
100% of critical data elements mapped within 30 days.
0 unresolved highrisk findings after 90 days from DPIAs.
MTTD < 24 hours and MTTR < 72 hours for security incidents.
DSAR SLA compliance ? 95%.
Quarterly reduction in excessive privileged accounts by 30%.

Data Protection Policy(company level)
Purpose
This Data Protection Policy establishes Shuttle Plus’s commitment, governance and requirements for protecting personal data processed by the mobile app, backend systems and supporting services. It ensures compliance with Ethiopian data protection law, applicable sector rules and international best practice while safeguarding the privacy rights of customers, drivers, employees and partners.
Scope
This policy applies to all personal data processed by Shuttle Plus PLC and its subsidiaries, contractors and processors. It covers data collected, stored, transmitted or processed through mobile applications, APIs, databases, analytics systems, payment gateways, CRM, logs and manual records. It applies to all employees, contractors, vendors and third parties acting on Shuttle Plus’s behalf.

Definitions
Personal data: any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
Processing: any operation performed on personal data including collection, storage, use, disclosure, erasure and transfer.
Controller: Shuttle Plus PLC when determining the purposes and means of processing.
Processor: any third party processing personal data on behalf of Shuttle Plus.
Data subject: the individual to whom personal data relates.
Principles
Shuttle Plus commits to process personal data in line with the following principles:
Lawful, fair and transparent processing.
Purpose limitation and data minimisation.
Accuracy and uptodate records.
Storage limitation and secure deletion.
Integrity and confidentiality through appropriate technical and organisational measures.
Accountability and demonstrable compliance.
Roles and Responsibilities
Board of Directors: ultimate accountability for data protection governance.
Data Protection Officer Privacy Lead: oversees compliance, DPIAs, regulatory liaison and incident reporting.
Data Owners Business Unit Leads: approve purpose, retention and access for their datasets.
Data Stewards Engineering Security Operations Support: implement and operate technical controls.
All staff: follow policies, report incidents and complete required training.
Lawful Basis and Transparency
All personal data processing must have a documented lawful basis (contract, consent, legal obligation, legitimate interest, or other lawful basis under applicable law). Clear privacy notices must be provided at point of collection describing purpose, lawful basis, retention period, recipients and data subject rights.

Data Inventory Classification and Retention
Maintain a live data inventory recording data elements, sources, flows, storage locations, processors, legal basis and retention.
Classify data sensitivity into tiers: Public Internal Confidential Highly Confidential. Apply stricter controls for higher tiers.
Implement retention schedules by data class and automate deletion or archival where possible. Record deletions in tamperevident logs.
Data Subject Rights
Shuttle Plus will enable and support the exercise of data subject rights including access rectification erasure restriction objection portability and rights related to automated decision making. Procedures must verify requester identity, log requests, meet statutory SLAs and record outcomes.
Consent and Preference Management
When relying on consent, consent must be freely given specific informed and revocable. Consent records must be stored with timestamps and contextual metadata. Preference management must allow customers to opt out of marketing and profiling where required.
Data Protection Impact Assessments
DPIAs are mandatory for highrisk processing such as GPS telemetry profiling KYC and large scale personal data analytics. DPIAs must identify risks mitigations residual risk and require privacy steering committee signoff before deployment.
Security Controls
Shuttle Plus will maintain appropriate technical and organisational measures including but not limited to:
Role based access control least privilege and periodic access reviews.
Multi factor authentication for administrative and remote access.
Encryption of personal data in transit and at rest with secure key management.
Secure development lifecycle code scanning and dependency management.
Parameterised queries and protections against injection attacks.
Network segmentation firewalls and WAF protection for public APIs.
Centralised logging SIEM and monitoring for anomalous access.
Encrypted backups secure retention and tested restore procedures.
PCI DSS controls for cardholder environment tokenisation and no CVV storage.
Third Party Processors
All processors must sign contracts requiring lawful processing technical and organisational measures breach notification and restrictions on onward transfers. Vendors must complete security and privacy assessments prior to onboarding and annually thereafter.
Cross Border Transfers
Transfers of personal data outside Ethiopia must have documented legal basis and safeguards such as regulator approvals contractual safeguards or equivalent measures. Data localisation requirements must be followed where law or contract requires.
Breach Notification and Incident Response
Shuttle Plus will maintain an incident response plan with roles escalation and forensic procedures. Reportable breaches will be notified to the regulator and affected data subjects within the statutory timeframe. All incidents will be logged investigated remediated and subject to postincident review.
Training and Awareness
All staff will receive data protection and security training at onboarding and annually; role based advanced training for engineers ops support and leadership. Regular phishing and tabletop exercises will be run.
Monitoring Audits and KPIs
The company will run periodic internal and external audits technical assessments and compliance reviews. Key metrics include percentage of data mapped DPIAs completed DSAR SLA compliance MTTD and MTTR for incidents and privileged access hygiene.
Enforcement and Sanctions
Violations of this policy may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination and may trigger contractual or legal remedies.
Policy Review
This policy will be reviewed annually and whenever legal regulatory or material business changes occur.
Technical Annex for Engineers and DBAs
Purpose
This annex translates policy requirements into actionable technical controls and configuration guidance for app developers SREs DBAs and security engineers.
Data Inventory and Tagging
Maintain a canonical schema registry and data catalogue (fields tables topics). Tag fields as PII Sensitive Payment KYC or Telemetry.
Implement schema validation in CI/CD to prevent unchecked schema drift.
Access Control and Authentication
Enforce RBAC with IAM groups mapped to least privilege roles.
Admin console and DB access require MFA and just in time privileged access via approved PAM solution.
Automate quarterly access reviews; orphan accounts disabled.
Encryption and Key Management
Use TLS 1.2+ for all transport. Enforce HSTS for web endpoints.
Encrypt at rest using AES 256 with cloud KMS or hardware module. Use envelope encryption for databaselevel keys.
Rotate keys quarterly or on compromise; log key usage with restricted access.
Database Hardening
Use parameterised queries or ORM prepared statements only. Prohibit string concatenation for queries.
Enable DB auditing to log SELECT INSERT UPDATE DELETE on PII tables; ship logs to immutable storage and SIEM.
Use row level encryption for highly confidential fields such as national ID or biometric tokens where performance permits.
Implement least privilege DB accounts: application read/write account limited to necessary schemas; no direct access to production from developer workstations.
Secrets and Configuration Management
Store secrets in a managed secrets store not in code or config repos. Inject secrets at runtime with short TTL tokens.
Enforce static analysis to flag accidental secrets in commits.
Application Security
Integrate SAST and DAST into CI/CD. Block builds with critical or high severity findings.
Enforce content security policy secure cookies HttpOnly SameSite and short session lifetimes with refresh tokens.
Rate limit endpoints and user actions to mitigate abuse and data harvesting.
Telemetry and Location Data
Minimise location precision where business does not require exact GPS. Use coarse geohashes for analytics.
Store raw highprecision GPS only when necessary with explicit lawful basis and additional encryption.
Implement retention automation to purge old telemetry per retention schedule.
Payment Card Handling
Use PCI validated payment processors. Tokenise card numbers. No storage of PAN unmasked or CVV. Segment card environment and apply enhanced logging and monitoring.
Logging and Monitoring
Log all administrative and schema changes and PII access events with user id timestamp and source IP.
Define SIEM alerts for anomalous read volumes unusual time access or crossregion access to PII.
Retain logs per forensic policy and protect against tampering with write once storage.
Backup and Restore
Encrypt backups and restrict restore operations to authorised personnel with multi party approval.
Test restores quarterly with verification that PII deletion processes are effective in restored copies.

Vendor Integrations
Use narrow scoped API keys per vendor with IP whitelisting and mutual TLS where feasible.
Require vendors to attest to minimum encryption and access controls and permit security assessments.
Data Subject Requests Implementation
Expose authenticated API endpoints for subject requests with rate limits and verification checks.
Implement job queue for DSAR processing produce audit trail of actions taken and ensure deletions cascade to backups and caches within policy constraints.
CI/CD and Change Control
Schema or data flow changes must submit a privacy/security impact checklist. Block deploys without required approvals for high risk changes.
Deploy feature flags to allow rapid rollback of features that cause privacy regressions.
Incident Playbook Highlights
Immediate containment isolate systems rotate keys disable compromised accounts and preserve volatile evidence.
Trigger notification workflow DPO Legal Communications Forensics and escalate to regulator if threshold met.
Produce post incident report with root cause remediation timeline and code or config fixes.
Next Steps
Approve this policy and annex for legal review and Board sign off.
Appoint DPO and form the Privacy Steering Committee.
Begin implementing the technical controls in the annex starting with RBAC MFA encryption and DSAR workflows.


Database tools and cloud planning — redundancy-first guide
Below is an operational, decision-focused plan you can use immediately to select database tools, design redundancy, and plan cloud deployment for Shuttle Plus 

Quick comparison of candidate tools (key attributes)
ToolTypeHigh-availabilityOffline/Edge supportCost profileBest forPostgreSQL (managed like RDS/AzureDB/GCP Cloud SQL)RelationalPrimary-replica, multi-AZLimited offline; local read replicas possibleLow–MediumACID transactions, reporting, joinsMySQL / MariaDB (managed)RelationalPrimary-replica, multi-AZLimited offline; local replicasLow–MediumWeb apps, simpler relational workloadsCockroachDBDistributed SQLBuilt-in geo-replication, survivableGood (local nodes)Medium–HighGeo-distributed strong consistencyCassandra / ScyllaWide-columnTunable replication; multi-datacenterExcellent offline/resilient writesMedium–HighHigh write throughput, eventual consistencyDynamoDB / Cosmos DBCloud-native NoSQLFully managed global replicationOffline via local SDKs / DAXMedium–High (pay per RU)Serverless, variable scale, low opsSQLite + Sync (e.g., Realm, Couchbase Mobile)Embedded + syncLocal-first; sync to cloudExcellent offline-firstLow–MediumMobile/edge with intermittent connectivityRedis (HA with Sentinel/Cluster)In-memoryActive-passive/clusterLimited persistence; good cachingLow–MediumFast cache, ephemeral state, leaderboardsTemporal / Event store (e.g., Kafka + ksqlDB)Event/logReplicated clustersGood with local bufferingMedium–HighAudit trail, guaranteed replay, asynchronous workflows
Design goals and trade-offs (pick these first)
Consistency vs availability: choose strong consistency for financial/booking flows; choose eventual for telemetry and bulk ingest.
Latency vs durability: local writes (edge) reduce latency but need robust sync/merge strategies.
Operational complexity vs vendor lock-in: managed cloud services reduce ops but increase coupling; distributed DBs add ops burden.
Cost predictability vs elasticity: provisioned clusters cost more but are predictable; serverless scales but can spike costs.

Recommended architectures by use-case
Booking, payments, critical state (Shuttle reservations)
Primary: Managed PostgreSQL (multi-AZ) or CockroachDB for geo resilience and strong consistency.
Redundancy: Synchronous or semi-synchronous replicas within region; async cross-region replicas for DR.
Backup: Automated PITR (point-in-time recovery) + daily snapshots stored in a separate region.
Telemetry and trip logs (high-write ingest)
Primary: Cassandra/Scylla or DynamoDB for high write throughput and multi-DC replication.
Redundancy: Multi-AZ with replication factor 3; tombstone and compaction tuning.
Archival: Batch export to cold storage (S3/Blob) for compliance and analytics.
Mobile/edge sync (drivers, kiosks)
Primary: SQLite or Realm/Couchbase Mobile on device + conflict-aware sync to cloud (Sync Gateway / Realm Sync).
Redundancy: Local-first UX; server reconciler and authoritative conflict resolution rules.
Offline policy: allow local bookings with provisional IDs, reconcile on sync.
Caching and ephemeral state
Primary: Redis Cluster with AOF + RDB persistence and Sentinel for failover.
Use for session data, rate limiting, queue offsets.
Event-driven orchestration and audit
Primary: Kafka or managed equivalent (MSK/Event Hubs) for durable event log and replayable workflows.
Redundancy: Replication across AZs/regions, retention and consumer groups for reprocessing.

Redundancy patterns and how to implement them
Multi-AZ replication: ensures single data-center failure tolerance; combine with automated failover and health probes.
Multi-region replication: protects against region-level outages; choose async replication for cross-region to avoid latency impact.
Synchronous vs asynchronous replication: use sync inside region for zero data loss; use async cross-region to limit write latency.
Quorum and replication factor: tune RF >= 3 for Cassandra; configure write/read quorums to balance durability vs availability.
Read replicas and promotion: use read replicas for scale and a safe promotion path (avoid split-brain with fencing / leader leases).
Backup + PITR: schedule frequent incremental snapshots, weekly fulls, and test restores quarterly.
Blue/Green and failover playbooks: automate DNS TTL reductions, traffic shifting, and runbooked DB promotion steps.

Cloud planning checklist (operational steps)
Inventory data types and SLOs: RTO/RPO for each dataset (bookings, telemetry, profiles).
Choose primary and secondary regions based on latency and regulatory requirements.
Select DB technology per dataset (map from section above).
Define replication topology, backup cadence, retention, and encryption-at-rest + in-transit.
Plan capacity: baseline throughput + headroom for 2x peak with autoscaling policies.
Observability: metrics (lag, replication health, commit latency), alerts, and synthetic checks for failover.
Disaster Recovery drills: scheduled failover tests, data-restore dry runs, and SLA reviews.
Cost control: reserved instances or committed use where applicable, and budget alerts for egress/IO spikes.
Security/compliance: RBAC, IAM, network isolation (VPC/NSG), DB auditing, and key management.
Define offline sync and reconciliation strategy for edge devices (idempotency, merge rules, loss handling).

Migration and DR playbook (one-page summary)
Pre-migration: freeze window, take full snapshot, validate schema compatibility, communicate stakeholders.
Cutover: dual-writes for a trial window; monitor divergence; promote new system once divergence < threshold.
Rollback: keep old system writable until post-cutover validation; maintain rollback snapshot.
DR test: annually simulate region loss; execute failover to secondary region and validate end-to-end app flows within RTO.
Post-incident: run root-cause analysis, update runbooks, and cadence for follow-up fixes.

Operational recommendations tailored for Shuttle Plus
Critical booking state: Managed PostgreSQL (multi-AZ) with read-replicas and PITR; implement a short synchronous replica in-country for low-latency bookings and an async cross-region replica for DR.
Driver/mobile offline flows: SQLite or Realm on-device with deterministic conflict resolution and server-side reconciliation service; grant provisional booking IDs and a reconciliation queue for duplicates.
Telemetry: Use a time-series optimized store or DynamoDB/Cassandra with batching at the edge; ship compressed batches when connectivity resumes.
Event sourcing: Append key state changes (booking created, confirmed, boarded) to Kafka for replay, audits, and rebuilding projections after restores.
Budget: start with managed services to reduce ops overhead; when scale justifies, evaluate CockroachDB or Scylla to reduce cross-region costs.
Dispatcher Dashboard Prototype
Purpose
Simple, lowlatency dashboard for dispatchers to assign drivers, monitor live statuses, and update trip state. Designed for quick decisions at airport hubs with minimal clicks and clear audit trail.

Top-level layout (single screen, responsive)
Header bar: company logo; current hub (dropdown); quick search (Booking ID / passenger name / plate); Ops priority button (Panic).
Left pane (30% width): Queues & filters.
Center pane (50% width): Active assignments map + list.
Right pane (20% width): Driver pool and driver details card.
Bottom bar: Activity feed / recent alerts / quick actions.

Left pane — Queues & Filters
Queues (clickable counts): 
Unassigned pickups (red badge)
Assigned, not en route
En route to pickup
Waiting at pickup
In transit
Completed today
Exceptions / Incidents (P1/P2)
Filters: 
Time window: Next 0–2h / 2–6h / 24h
Tier: Corporate / Private / Shared
Vehicle capacity: 4 / 6 / 12 / Wheelchair
Special flags: wheelchair, child seat, VIP, heavy luggage
Partner vs owned vehicles toggle
Quick actions: 
Auto-assign (runs optimization for visible queue)
Create standby vehicle (reserve)
Export current queue (CSV)

Center pane — Map + Assignment List
Split view: Top = interactive map (Google/Mapbox) showing vehicles, pickups, hotspots; Bottom = sortable list of active unassigned pickups.
Assignment list columns (click to sort): 
Booking ID (tap opens booking modal)
Pickup time (local)
Passenger name / party size / luggage count
Pickup location (short text)
Priority score (numeric) + badges (VIP, wheelchair)
Suggested vehicle (auto-suggest icon)
Status (Unassigned / Assigned to [Driver] / En route)
Actions: Assign (button), Message driver (chat), Hold (button)
Map pins: 
Color-coded by status: red = urgent unassigned; orange = assigned; blue = en route; green = waiting; gray = completed.
Vehicle icons show driver initials and plate; click opens Driver Card overlay.

Right pane — Driver Pool & Details
Driver list with live filter (search by name/plate): 
Each row: Driver name | plate | status badge (Available / Assigned / On Break / Offline) | last ping (mins) | capacity icon
Draganddrop driver onto booking in center pane to assign.
Driver detail card (on select): 
Photo, name, phone, languages, certifications (wheelchair trained), shifts, last inspection pass (yes/no), current trip ID (if any), ETA to pickup (if assigned), vehicle plate, fuel status, odometer, outstanding incidents.
Quick driver actions: 
Send message/voice; Call driver; Reassign; Mark unavailable; Add note (internal).

Booking modal (opens from list)
Top summary: Booking ID, passenger name, flight, pickup window, tier, priority score.
Middle: Full address, map snippet, passenger contact, special requests, luggage count, notes.
Right: Suggested vehicles (3) with ETA, capacity match, driver rating, last trip end time.
Bottom actions: Assign (select vehicle + confirm), Auto-suggest (re-run), Put on hold (reason code), Cancel booking (with fee code), Add internal note, Send passenger SMS with ETA.

Assignment workflow (fast path)
Select booking row (keyboard: J/K to navigate)
Press A to open Assign quick view (shows top 3 vehicle suggestions)
Press 1/2/3 to choose suggestion or drag driver from right pane
Confirm (Enter) — system logs assignment event, pushes notification to driver, updates map and booking status to Assigned.
If driver rejects within N minutes, reassign or escalate to standby (auto-trigger).

Status updates & actions
Drivers update status via driver app: Available ? En route ? Waiting ? In transit ? Completed. Dispatcher can override.
Auto-update on geofence: entering pickup geofence toggles to Waiting; departure toggles to In transit.
Manual override: dispatcher can mark Incident (P1/P2) and create incident ticket (pre-filled with booking, driver, timestamp).
SLA flags: late-to-pickup amber alert at T+10min, red at T+20min — shows in list and sends Ops priority if critical.

Activity feed & audit trail (bottom bar)
Real-time chronological log of assignments, status changes, messages, incident creations, and reassignments.
Each entry: timestamp, actor (dispatcher/driver/system), short description, link to booking/driver, undo button (5 min window).
Exportable for daily QA.


Keyboard shortcuts (for speed)
J / K — navigate bookings up/down
A — quick assign selected booking
D — open driver card for selected booking
M — message driver
H — hold booking with reason
/ — focus search
G — goto map center on selected booking

Colors, badges & visual language
Status colors: URGENT red (#E53E3E); Warning amber (#DD6B20); Active blue (#3182CE); OK green (#38A169); Offline gray (#A0AEC0).
Badges: VIP (gold), Wheelchair (blue + wheelchair icon), Heavy-luggage (suitcase icon).
Use clear typography, high contrast for quick reading under bright airport lighting.

Data fields & API endpoints (examples)
Booking object fields: id, pickup_time, pickup_window_start, pickup_window_end, pickup_lat, pickup_lng, passenger_name, phone, party_size, luggage_count, tier, special_flags[], priority_score, status, assigned_driver_id, notes.
Driver object fields: id, name, phone, plate, vehicle_type, capacity, status, last_ping, location{lat,lng}, certifications[], on_duty_until, last_inspection_pass.
Suggested endpoints: 
GET /api/dispatch/bookings?hub=XXX&status=unassigned
GET /api/dispatch/drivers?hub=XXX&status=available
POST /api/dispatch/assign {booking_id, driver_id, dispatcher_id}
POST /api/dispatch/status {driver_id, status}
POST /api/dispatch/message {driver_id, message}
GET /api/telemetry/vehicle/{driver_id}/latest



Tech stack & infra suggestions
Frontend: React or Vue with real-time updates via WebSocket (Socket.IO) or Server-Sent Events.
Map: Mapbox or Google Maps with clustering for dense areas.
Backend: Node.js / Python (FastAPI) with Redis for queues and caching.
Realtime: Redis pub/sub or Kafka for scaling events.
Auth & audit: SSO (Azure AD / Google Workspace), role-based access, immutable audit logs in DB.
Hosting: Cloud or local data center; ensure low-latency to Addis region; use CDN for static assets.
Optional: Integrate with existing fleet telematics (Traccar/GpsGate) and booking system (webhooks).

Minimal viable implementation (MVP) — priorities
Core list + assign button + driver pool (drag-and-drop) — build first.
Real-time driver status updates (polling every 10s or WebSocket).
Map integration for situational awareness.
Activity feed and basic incident creation.
Auto-suggest algorithm (simple: nearest available with capacity match).
SLA alerts and Ops priority push.

UX notes and accessibility
Large clickable targets for mobile/tablet use in busy dispatch hubs.
High-contrast mode for bright sunlight.
Screen reader labels and keyboard-first navigation for power users.
Low bandwidth fallback: condensed list-only view with update polling.

Example quick scenario (flow)
Dispatcher opens Unassigned queue (10 bookings). Booking SP-2005 marked urgent (VIP + wheelchair). Dispatcher filters wheelchair, sees 2 drivers certified. Drag driver Tesfaye onto SP-2005, hits Enter. Driver receives assignment; map updates; booking moves to Assigned; Activity feed logs assignment; SLA timer starts.
Drivers Incentive Plan Overview
A compact, audit-ready incentive plan that combines a 1% sales commission on applicable transactions with measurable teamwork rewards to drive revenue, punctuality, safety, and collaboration.

Eligibility
Who: All full-time Shuttle Plus drivers with ?90 days tenure.
Exclusions: Temporary contractors and drivers on active disciplinary action.
Qualification window: Commissions earned from trips completed while eligible; teamwork rewards assessed monthly.

Components
1. Sales commission
Rate: 1% of net revenue from each qualifying booking the driver completes or directly closes (fare + add-ons; excludes taxes, processing fees, chargebacks).
Qualifying activity: Bookings where driver is logged as assigned and passenger completes trip; driver-confirmed add-on sales recorded in app or POS.
Payment cap: No cap by default; company may set promotional caps for specific campaigns.
Example: If a completed booking’s net revenue = 2,000 ETB, driver commission = 20 ETB.
2. Teamwork rewards
Monthly pooled bonus: A fixed pool funded as a percentage of monthly ground-ops revenue (recommend 0.5%–1.5% of net ground revenue).
Distribution criteria: Pool split among eligible drivers using a scorecard combining: 
Shift reliability (35%) — on-time starts, shift coverage, absenteeism.
Customer feedback (25%) — average passenger ratings and complaint resolution.
Operational compliance (20%) — vehicle checks, luggage chain-of-custody logs, incident reports.
Peer/lead assessment (20%) — short qualitative score from shift lead or teammates.
Minimum threshold: Drivers must meet a baseline reliability score (e.g., 75%) to receive any share.

Scoring and Calculation Example
Team pool: 30,000 ETB for month.
Driver A scores: Reliability 90, Feedback 80, Compliance 95, Peer 85 ? weighted score = 0.3590 + 0.2580 + 0.2095 + 0.2085 = 88.5.
All drivers’ combined weighted scores = 8,850.
Driver A share: 88.5 / 8,850 = 1% of pool ? 300 ETB.

Payout Schedule and Reporting
Frequency: Commission and teamwork bonuses paid monthly with payroll.
Reporting: Drivers receive a simple line-item statement showing: trip-level commissions, teamwork score, pool share, deductions, and final payout.
Dispute window: Drivers may raise disputes within 14 days of statement; HR/Operations resolves within 10 business days.

Controls and Safeguards
Verification: Commissions only paid for bookings with confirmed passenger completion and valid payment.
Fraud prevention: Automated flags for suspicious activity (repeated cancellations, duplicate bookings, unusually high add-on sales) trigger review.
Behavioral guardrails: Bonuses withheld for safety violations, disciplinary actions, or incidents causing reputational/financial loss.
Audit trail: All commission calculations and teamwork scores stored for 12 months for audit.

Implementation Roadmap (30 days)
Finalize pool funding percentage and reliability threshold.
Update driver agreement and payroll rules.
Configure app/POS to tag driver-closed sales and record trip completion.
Pilot for one month with 10–20 drivers; collect feedback.
Roll out fleet-wide with training and one-page scorecard cheat sheet.

Communication and Motivation
Launch kit: One-page explainer, example payslip, and a quick 10-minute huddle script for leads.
Recognition: Public monthly shout-outs for top performers and “team MVP” to reinforce collaboration.
Continuous improvement: Quarterly review to adjust pool percentage, weights, and thresholds based on results.




Driver refresher training - 2-hour mandatory session (overview)
Duration: 2 hours (compact, mandatory)
Audience: All active drivers with priority enrollment for drivers on the next 3 shifts (see roster template and enrollment steps)
Goal: Improve customer-facing tone, reduce CSAT complaints, standardize escalation and luggage care, and certify drivers for service compliance.

Training objectives (clear, measurable)
Restore a friendly, professional verbal tone in 90% of observed ride interactions.
Ensure drivers can follow the escalation script and resolve or escalate issues within 5 minutes.
Standardize luggage handling so 100% of loaded trips record correct bag counts and no complaints about damage.
Pass a short roleplay and checklist audit at the end of the session.

2-hour session agenda (timed)
00:00–00:10 — Opening and purpose (expectations, QA targets)
00:10–00:30 — Customer service tone and language (scripted phrases, short drills)
00:30–00:50 — Meet-and-greet & luggage care practical (demo + hands-on)
00:50–01:10 — Escalation script and incident logging (walkthrough and examples)
01:10–01:40 — Roleplay scenarios (3x 8-minute scenarios, group feedback)
01:40–01:55 — Short written/phone quiz + practical checklist sign-off
01:55–02:00 — Close, certification, and next steps

Customer service script (concise, audit-ready)
Use short, calm phrases. Speak slowly, match passenger language when known.
Arrival greeting (approach, smile, badge visible):
“Good [morning/afternoon/evening]. Welcome to Addis Ababa. I’m [Name] from Shuttle Plus. May I help with your luggage?”
Confirmation and comfort check:
“Are you [Full name]? I have you to [Hotel/Address]. Would you like airconditioning or a window open?”
During loading:
“I’ll put your luggage in the trunk; please tell me if anything is fragile or needs special handling.”
En route (short):
“Estimated travel time is [X] minutes. If you need anything—phone charge, WiFi—let me know.”
If a passenger is dissatisfied or complains:
“I’m sorry you feel that way. Let me resolve this for you right now. May I [offer immediate remedy: move seat, adjust AC, check luggage]? If I can’t resolve it, I’ll escalate this to operations and share their contact.”
Drop-off close:
“We’ve arrived. I’ll load your luggage. Do you need any assistance with check-in or directions? Thank you for choosing Shuttle Plus.”
Tone cues (trainer to practice): calm volume, even pace, no slang, 2–3 second pause before asking sensitive questions.

Escalation script (clear steps driver must follow)
Immediate response (0–2 minutes): Acknowledge and attempt simple fix. Phrase: “I’m sorry — I’ll fix this now.”
If unresolved after 2 minutes or safety-related: Call Dispatch/Operations on priority line and state: 
Driver name, vehicle plate, booking ID, brief issue, and immediate action taken.
Example: “Dispatch, this is [Name], plate [ABC123], booking #12345. Passenger reports excessive heat in vehicle; I turned on ventilation and called head office; passenger still unhappy.”
Dispatch response (within 5 minutes): Reassign, send standby, or instruct driver. Driver follows instruction and updates passenger.
Incident logging: Driver records incident code, short description, timestamps, and passenger consent for notes in app before trip completion.
Follow-up: Customer Care will call passenger within 30–60 minutes; driver documents any passenger requests for refund or credit.
Escalation priority codes (for logging)
P1 — Safety or medical; immediate stop and call ops.
P2 — Service critical (AC failure, large luggage damage).
P3 — Minor complaint (tone, small delay); log and offer small remedy or discount as policy allows.

Luggage care standard (step-by-step)
Pre-load: Confirm luggage count with passenger aloud and log number in app.
Handling: Use proper lifting posture; handle fragile tags carefully; avoid dragging over rough surfaces.
Securement: Place heavier bags first; use straps if available; close trunk fully and test.
Delivery: Hand luggage to passenger, visually confirm transfer, and record transfer in app (passenger initials or confirmation).
Damage procedure: If any visible damage, note item, take timestamped photo, notify Dispatch immediately, and log in incident report.
Quick checklist (to use before each trip)
Ask and confirm luggage count.
Verify fragile or special items.
Use two-person lift for heavy/oversized when available.
Close and secure trunk; test latch.
Confirm passenger has personal items before departure.

Roleplay scenarios (3 core, 8 minutes each)
Tone complaint: Passenger says driver was curt earlier; driver must de-escalate and remedy.
Luggage damage suspicion: Passenger reports a scuff on suitcase; driver follows damage procedure and logs incident.
Flight delay and schedule stress: Passenger angry about longer wait; driver uses ETA scripts and offers small immediate remedy.
Scoring rubric (pass/fail threshold)
Tone and language: 0–5 points (goal ?4)
Escalation correctness: 0–5 points (goal ?4)
Luggage handling & logging: 0–5 points (goal ?4)
Pass if total ?12/15.

Quiz and certification
6 short multiple-choice or true/false items (tone, escalation, luggage care).
Practical sign-off: trainer observes one loading and one scripted greeting.
Certification: digital badge added to driver profile valid for 90 days; failure requires remedial 1-hour session within 7 days.

Training roster and enrollment (next 3 shifts)
I don’t have your live driver list; below is a ready-to-use roster template and enrollment process you can apply immediately. Fill driver names and assign based on upcoming shifts.
Roster template (example format — shift times local EAT)
Shift A (04:00–12:00) — Enroll drivers: [Driver 1], [Driver 2], [Driver 3] — Mandatory (yes)
Shift B (12:00–20:00) — Enroll drivers: [Driver 4], [Driver 5], [Driver 6] — Mandatory (yes)
Shift C (20:00–04:00) — Enroll drivers: [Driver 7], [Driver 8], [Driver 9] — Mandatory (yes)
Enrollment steps (3 quick actions)
Pull the next 3 scheduled shifts from the dispatch sheet and list active drivers per shift.
Mark training as mandatory and block a 2hour window at start or end of each driver’s next shift (recommended: before shift start for 04:00 drivers; mid-shift for day drivers; before shift end for night drivers).
Send SMS/WhatsApp + in-app notice with time, location (hub or zoom link), and compliance note; require reply “ACK” within 2 hours. Non-responders escalate to Shift Lead.
Suggested immediate schedule (example; adapt to your hub)
For Shift A drivers: Training 02:30–04:30 at Hub A (before shift start)
For Shift B drivers: Training 10:00–12:00 at Hub B (start of shift)
For Shift C drivers: Training 18:00–20:00 at Hub C (start of shift)
Attendance policy
Mandatory; failure to attend without approved reason results in suspension from next two shifts until make-up training complete.
Trainers record presence, pass/fail, and notes in driver profile.

Training materials & trainer notes
Provide these to trainers:
One-page script card (greeting, trouble phrases, escalation bullets).
Luggage care checklist card (laminated for trunks).
Roleplay scenario cards and scoring sheet.
Short quiz (paper or Google Form).
Certificate template and digital badge process.
Trainer tips
Use live examples from recent CSAT comments (anonymized) to roleplay.
Encourage drivers to speak slowly and practice a neutral, friendly tone.
Reinforce that apologies + immediate remedy are more effective than explanations.

Follow-up and QA
Mystery checks: Ops to run 10 random ride monitoring checks per week for first month.
CSAT monitoring: aim for measurable CSAT improvement in 30 days; review trends weekly.
Re-certification: every 90 days or after any P2/P1 incident.




Drivers Tools Training Notes — Language and Conduct Integration
Brief, operational training notes for Shuttle Plus drivers that integrate practical language guidance, professional conduct, and tool usage. Designed for quick classroom delivery (30–60 min), on-shift micro-coaching, and inclusion in onboarding packs.

1. Training objectives
Primary: Ensure every driver communicates clearly, professionally, and consistently across Amharic and basic English while using Shuttle Plus tools (app, POS, incident log).
Outcomes: Reduced complaints, higher passenger satisfaction, accurate handoff/sales logging, and consistent enforcement of safety and service standards.

2. Core conduct standards (must-follow)
Appearance: Clean uniform, badge visible, shoes polished, hair/tidiness neat.
Punctuality: Be at the vehicle 10 minutes before shift start; notify ops if >15 minutes late.
Respectful greeting: Stand, make eye contact, greet passenger, confirm booking.
Privacy & dignity: Do not discuss passenger details aloud; handle personal items respectfully.
Safety first: Follow vehicle checks, seatbelt policy, and luggage loading protocols every trip.
No escalation: De-escalate calmly; if unresolved, hand to shift lead and open an incident report.

3. Language scripts — Short, actionable phrases
Greeting & handoff (Amharic first, then simple English)
Greeting (Amharic): “Selam, Shuttle Plus yibelachu — abet hizb aydelem?”
Greeting (English): “Hello, Shuttle Plus — is this [name]? I’ll help with your luggage.”
Confirm booking (Amharic): “Wede mehaber? Ticket number yiblachu?”
Confirm booking (English): “May I see your booking or name for verification?”
Tagging luggage (Amharic): “Amesegenallo — tag yibelachu, beka yenor?”
Tagging luggage (English): “I’ll tag your bag for this route; please keep the receipt.”
Offer add-ons (Amharic): “Betam wadagim — wede snack/water/premium seeting interest new?”
Offer add-ons (English): “Would you like a snack, water, or priority boarding today?”
Handling delays/issues (Amharic): “Yiqirta — I’ll inform dispatch and we’ll resolve it quickly.”
Handling delays/issues (English): “I’m sorry for the delay. I’ll contact dispatch and get this fixed.”
Closing (Amharic): “Amaseginalesh — shiftoch genzeb yemiwedek.”
Closing (English): “Thank you — have a safe trip. Call us if you need anything.”
Use the Amharic line first, then repeat in English if passenger appears international or requests English.


4. Tool interaction phrases (app/POS/incident logging)
When selling add-on (spoken): “I’ll add this to your booking now — it’s ETB [X].”
When confirming POS success: “Payment received; here’s your receipt.”
If POS fails: “Payment didn’t go through — I’ll try again or we can use another method.”
When creating an incident: “I’ll log this now and the ops team will update you within [SLA].”
When handing photo evidence: “I’ll attach a photo to your record for fast resolution.”
Always speak what you’ll do next (action + timeframe).


5. Role-play scenarios (3 short exercises)
Quick handoff + upsell (5 min)
Driver: greet, verify booking, tag bag, ask about snack/water, record sale in POS.
Coach: observe language clarity, POS entry, and handoff speed.
Payment failure + calm resolution (5 min)
Driver: handle POS decline, retry, offer refund or alternate method, log incident if needed.
Coach: score on de-escalation and tool use.
Lost tag / misroute (10 min)
Driver: accept passenger concern, collect details, take photos, create incident with chain-of-custody notes, explain next steps and SLA.
Coach: evaluate empathy language, accuracy of log, and SLA communication.
Scoring rubric: greeting (10%), verification (20%), safety/lifting (20%), tool accuracy (25%), closing/explain next steps (25%).

6. Micro-coaching playbook (on-shift)
2-minute huddle before shift: Lead reminds team of today’s KPIs, oddball events, and priority passengers.
Spot coaching: Lead observes 1 handoff per driver per shift, gives 1 improvement + 1 praise in under 3 minutes.
Weekly short review: Pull two trip records with low ratings; review language and logs, practice improved phrasing.

7. Enforcement and incentives link
Include language/conduct checks in teamwork scorecard: Punctuality (35%), Customer feedback (25%), Operational compliance (20%), Peer/lead assessment (20%).
Use spot bonuses for excellent conduct calls (ETB 100–300) and public recognition in the monthly ops shout-out.


8. Quick reference card (one-line prompts for pocket)
Greet: “Selam — Shuttle Plus, are you [name]?”
Verify: “May I see booking or name?”
Tag: “I’ll tag your luggage; keep the receipt.”
Upsell: “Snack or priority boarding today?”
POS fail: “I’ll retry or use another method.”
Incident: “I’ll log this; update within [SLA].”
Close: “Thank you — safe trip.”
Provide laminated pocket cards in Amharic and English for every driver.

9. Measurement and follow-up
Track: passenger rating, complaint count, POS success rate, incident accuracy, and handoff accuracy.
Review cadence: daily ops dashboard highlights; weekly coaching roundup; monthly competency sign-off for each driver.

Expense tracking plan for Shuttle Plus
A practical, operational expense tracking plan tailored for a transport/logistics platform. Focus: accurate cost capture, timely reporting, control, and decision-ready dashboards. Use the roles and cadence already in your operating model (Finance Lead, Ops Lead, Procurement Lead, Fleet Manager, PM, GC/CCO for legal/insurance items).
Goals and principles
Goals: capture all operational costs accurately; allocate costs by route, vehicle, city zone and product line; detect overruns early; support pricing, forecasting and insurer/audit evidence.
Principles: single source of truth for transactions; timely (weekly) reconciliation; role-based approvals; granular tagging (trip, vehicle, supplier, cost type); immutable evidence for audits.
Core categories to track (mandatory tags)
Fleet: fuel, maintenance, tires, spare parts, depreciation, lease payments, parking, tolls.
People: driver wages, benefits, training, recruitment, incentives.
Platform & Tech: hosting, maps/routing fees, SMS/calls, payments fees, software subscriptions, CLM/LMS line items.
Operations: dispatch costs, call centre, rider refunds, driver incentives, cleaning.
Insurance & Legal: motor/public liability premiums, D&O, cyber, claims, retainer fees.
Procurement & Supplies: uniforms, PPE, office supplies, charging/energy for EVs.
Regulatory & Licensing: permits, inspections, fines and renewals.
Marketing & Commercial: promos, corporate account discounts, partnerships.
Contingency & Claims: incident payouts, customer remediation, arbitration/legal settlements.
Always tag each expense with: date, invoice number, vendor, GL code, project/trip ID (if applicable), vehicle ID, zone/city, and approval owner.
Tools and data flows
Use a cloud accounting system (e.g., Xero, QuickBooks) integrated with: 
Expense capture app for drivers and staff (mobile receipts, OCR).
Fleet management telematics (automatically log fuel, vehicle km, service events).
Payments and gateway feeds (auto ingest transactions and fees).
CLM/contract repo for periodic vendor payments and insurance schedules.
Master data sources: vehicle register, supplier master, driver roster, route catalogue. Sync nightly to avoid stale tags.
Expense capture process (day-to-day)
Capture: vendor invoices, driver claims, card transactions, and payment batches enter system within 3 business days. Mobile receipts must be uploaded within 24 hours.
Auto-tagging: apply vendor ? category rules; telematics feed auto-attach vehicle ID and km to fuel/maintenance lines.
Manual review: Finance reviewer inspects exceptions and untagged items daily.
Approval: owner-level approval for expenses above thresholds (e.g., >ETB X) before payment. Approvals routed through accounting tool.
Reconciliation: weekly bank and card reconciliation; match payments to invoices and trips.
Archive: store PDF scans and contracts with immutable timestamps; link to expense line.
Allocation and cost models
Direct allocation: tie fuel, maintenance, and driver wages to vehicle and trip IDs for per-trip costing.
Shared costs allocation: split platform, regional office rent, and shared tools by driver-hours, trips, or revenue share per zone. Document allocation keys in accounting policy.
Depreciation: apply straight-line vehicle depreciation with salvage values recorded in fixed assets.
Cost per km and cost per trip: compute both as primary operational metrics.

Approval thresholds and controls
Low-value (? ETB X): team lead approval (Ops/Procurement).
Medium-value (ETB X–Y): Department Head + Finance review.
High-value (> ETB Y): CFO/CEO sign-off plus GC for legal/insurance exposures.
Singleuse or unusual vendors require vendor onboarding (KYB proof, insurance certificate) before payment.

Reporting cadence and deliverables
Daily (ops dashboard): cash in/out summary, top 10 exceptions, fuel burn / km, live contingency drawdowns.
Weekly (ops finance sync): P&L flash vs budget by major category; top 5 variances with root causes; outstanding invoices >30 days; driver payout reconciliation.
Monthly (management pack): month P&L, cash flow, burn vs plan, cost per km/trip by zone, vendor performance, insurance claim activity, open PO and contract obligations.
Quarterly (board / Legal Risk Committee): deeper variance analysis, audit sampling results, insurance adequacy review, contingency adequacy, and action plan.
Adhoc: incident cost report within 72 hours of material event (accident, major outage).
KPIs and thresholds to monitor
Cost per km (all-in) and cost per active km (operational).
Cost per trip and contribution margin per trip.
Fuel cost variance and average fuel efficiency (L/100km).
Maintenance cost per vehicle per month; % of fleet out-of-service days.
Driver labour cost as % of revenue.
Days payable outstanding (DPO) and days sales outstanding (DSO) for corporate customers.
Invoice exception rate and late payment frequency.
Contingency reserve vs 90day liquidation needs (target: 1–3 months of legal/compliance burn).
Trigger alerts: set automated alerts for KPI breaches (e.g., cost per km > plan +10%; fleet downtime > threshold; single vendor spend > 20% monthly).
Audit, reconciliation and verification
Weekly sample testing by Finance: select 20 expense lines, verify invoice, GL coding, approval, and evidence.
Monthly supplier statement reconciliation for top 20 vendors.
Quarterly external spot-check by internal audit or third party for high-value categories (insurance reconciliations, claims reserve accuracy).
Maintain immutable evidence pack for auditors: contracts, insurance certificates, signed approvals, incident remediation invoices.

Integration with pricing and forecasting
Feed nightly cost-per-km/trip metrics into pricing model. Use rolling 30/90-day windows for fuel, maintenance and wage cost inputs.
Scenario stress tests for fuel spikes and permit-related stoppages; include tax/regulatory cost sensitivity in 12-month forecasts.
Monthly review of pricing tiers if cost-per-trip drifts outside tolerance band.

Roles and RACI (summary)
Finance Lead: owns accounting system, reconciliations, monthly pack, approvals.
Ops Lead / Fleet Manager: inputs telemetry and vehicle events, raises maintenance POs, approves operational exceptions.
Procurement Lead: vendor onboarding, KYB/KYC, supplier contracts, supply-side disputes.
Project Manager: runs weekly remediation of exceptions and ensures evidence capture.
Legal / GC: review contracts, claims, insurance coverage and approvals for high-risk spend.
CEO/CFO: approve high-value contingency draws and changes to allocation policy.

Quick-start checklist (first 30 days)
Set up chart of accounts with categories above and mandatory tags.
Integrate telematics, payments, and expense capture apps to accounting system.
Create vendor master and require KYB/insurance documents for top 50 suppliers.
Launch mobile receipt policy and 24-hour upload rule.
Configure weekly reports and automated KPI alerts.
Run first-week reconciliation and present one-page cost heatmap to leadership.
