Fleet management software — shortlist and recommendation (free-first)
Below are 12 fleet management software options (free or low-cost prioritized), summarize their selling points, where they beat the market, limitations for Shuttle Plus in Ethiopia, and a clear recommendation with an implementation path.

Shortlist (12 products; free / open-source options first)
Traccar (open-source, free)
OpenGTS / OpenFleet (open-source, free)
Odoo Fleet (community edition — free core)
FleetOps / FleetSharp (low-cost options / local vendors vary)
GPSWOX (freemium)
Fleetio (paid; free trial)
Samsara (paid; market leader for telematics)
Verizon Connect (paid; enterprise)
Teletrac Navman (paid; enterprise)
KeepTruckin / Motive (paid; strong dashcam/ELD integration)
GpsGate (hosted or self-hosted; flexible pricing)
CalAmp / Mix Telematics (paid; regional presence)

Quick one-line positioning
Traccar: Best no-cost GPS tracking and self-hosting control.
OpenGTS: Classic open-source telematics platform for full customization.
Odoo Fleet: Lightweight fleet module as part of a wider ERP (free community edition).
GPSWOX: Freemium option with quick setup and mobile apps.
Fleetio: Excellent fleet lifecycle, maintenance, and procurement workflows.
Samsara: Full-stack telematics + dashcams + analytics at scale.
Verizon Connect / Teletrac / CalAmp: Enterprise-grade reliability, compliance, and support.
KeepTruckin/Motive: Strong on compliance, driver safety, and dashcams.
GpsGate: Flexible self-hosted or cloud; good for integrators.
FleetOps/FleetSharp: Regional/SMB-focused solutions with local support.

Feature comparison (what matters to Shuttle Plus)
GPS tracking & live location — essential for airport ETAs. Traccar, GpsGate, Samsara, and Fleetio provide strong solutions (Traccar/GpsGate allow self-hosting).
Maintenance & TCO workflows — Fleetio and Odoo Fleet excel at maintenance scheduling, parts, and procurement.
Driver behavior & safety (harsh braking, speeding) — Samsara, Motive, and Verizon Connect have mature driver scoring and dashcam integrations.
Offline / low-connectivity support — Traccar (self-hosted) and Odoo can be tuned for intermittent connectivity; many enterprise cloud platforms struggle without reliable mobile networks.
Integration & APIs — GpsGate, Traccar, Fleetio, and Samsara offer robust APIs for booking apps and dispatch systems.
Cost & deployment flexibility — Open-source (Traccar, OpenGTS) and Odoo Community provide lowest licensing cost; hosted enterprise solutions carry high recurring fees.
Local payments, SMS/WhatsApp, mobile-money events — Most open platforms allow custom integrations; SaaS vendors may require paid connectors.
Dashcam and video telematics — Samsara, Motive, and CalAmp are leaders; costly but valuable for claims and safety.
Multi-tenant / partner fleet governance — GpsGate and some enterprise platforms support multi-tenant accounts for franchise/partner oversight.

Where each option beats the market (concise)
Traccar — unbeatable price (free), self-hosting, and support for many GPS devices; best for bootstrapped operations that want full data control.
OpenGTS — mature open stack for custom telematics; good for integrations but requires heavy dev.
Odoo Fleet — best if you already plan to use Odoo ERP for HR, accounting and operations; low-cost integration across modules.
Fleetio — market-leading maintenance workflows, audits, inspections, and inventory tracking.
GpsGate — flexible deployment; strong multi-tenant and reseller features for partner fleets.
Samsara — best-in-class telematics + video + analytics; premium pricing but reduces claims and improves safety rapidly.
Motive / KeepTruckin — best where driver compliance and video evidence are primary concerns.
Verizon Connect / Teletrac / CalAmp — strong enterprise SLAs, regional support, and compliance for large-scale ops.

Best fit for Shuttle Plus (recommended stack and why)
Recommendation: Start with a hybrid stack combining Traccar (self-hosted) or GpsGate (self-hosted/cloud) for real-time tracking + Odoo Community for fleet & maintenance workflows, then selectively add paid telematics/dashcam services (Samsara or Motive) for specific high-value vehicles.
Why this combination works for Shuttle Plus in Ethiopia:
Cost-sensitive: Traccar + Odoo Community has minimal licensing cost and avoids heavy recurring SaaS fees.
Control & data sovereignty: Self-hosting keeps location and passenger-related telemetry under company control and avoids costly international bandwidth/SaaS contracts.
Offline resilience: Open platforms can be configured for intermittent mobile connectivity and local SMS/WhatsApp integration for ETAs.
Modular scale: Start small (GPS tracking + inspections) and add premium telematics/dashcams for core corporate or high-liability routes only.
Integration with existing operations: Odoo gives a lightweight route into HR, maintenance, asset management, and invoicing without building an entire ERP from scratch.
Partner governance: GpsGate or Traccar + custom dashboards allow multi-tenant views to audit partner/franchise fleets.

Implementation plan (practical, phased)
Phase 0 — Decisions and procurement (Week 0–2)
Choose primary tracking platform (Traccar or GpsGate) and confirm hosting (on-prem server in Addis or low-cost cloud region).
Choose Odoo Community for fleet/maintenance or evaluate Fleetio paid plan if budget allows.
Phase 1 — Pilot (Week 2–8)
Equip 10–15 core vehicles with reliable GPS trackers (Teltonika, Queclink, Meitrack are common and supported).
Deploy Traccar (self-host) and connect devices; configure geofences for Bole Airport, hotels, and hubs.
Set up Odoo Fleet: vehicle records, maintenance schedules, DVIR templates, and driver profiles.
Integrate basic webhook/API between booking app and Traccar for live ETAs and SMS/WhatsApp alerts.
Phase 2 — Expand & add governance (Week 8–16)
Add analytics dashboards: utilization, on-time pickup rate, idle time, and geofence breaches.
Onboard partner fleets with multi-tenant views; enforce vehicle acceptance checklist via Odoo inspections.
Run 90-day QA and maintenance KPI review; adjust trackers and workflows.
Phase 3 — Add premium telematics where needed (Quarter 2–4)
For corporate contracts, add Samsara or Motive devices/dashcams on assigned vehicles; use their safety analytics for incentive programs.
Add automated incident evidence flow: dashcam clips attached to incident tickets in Odoo.

Costs and device notes (practical guidance)
GPS trackers: basic Teltonika/Queclink units (LTE/GPS) cost ~USD 30–90 per device; choose models with battery backup.
Hosting: a small cloud instance for Traccar can run ~USD 10–40/month; on-prem adds hardware CAPEX but reduces foreign recurring costs.
Odoo Community: free for software; expect implementation time and modest hosting costs; paid Odoo apps or consultants add cost.
Samsara/Motive: device + subscription per vehicle can be costly (USD tens/month); reserve for high-value assets.

Risks and mitigations
Device theft / tampering — use tamper alerts, VIN registration, and immobilizer integration where possible.
Mobile connectivity gaps — configure trackers to store data offline and upload when connected; use SMS-based fallback for ETA notifications.
Local support — prioritize vendors with local partners or reliable remote setup guides; plan for spare device inventory.
Data privacy / regulatory — store audit logs, anonymize PII when not needed, and document local compliance for airport/transport regulators.


Fleet strategy overview
Shuttle Plus manages fleet across small, large, and seasonal scenarios with a single unified playbook that emphasizes modular capacity, cost predictability, safety, and rapid scalability. The playbook has three pillars: Rightsizing (match capacity to demand), Resilience (maintenance, backups, supplier diversity), and Operational agility (datadriven dispatch, dynamic rostering, rapid onboarding/offboarding of vehicles and drivers).
1. Small fleet scenario (up to ~25 vehicles)
Organizational model
Centralized ops: Fleet Manager + combined roles (dispatcher, maintenance lead, admin).
Multiskilling: Drivers perform basic checks; one oncall technician for repairs.
Procurement & composition
Mix of 12–15 seat minibuses and 4–8 seat sedans for flexibility.
Prefer owned vehicles for reliability; hold 1–2 leased backups.
Maintenance & reliability
Preventive schedule: weekly checks by drivers, monthly technician inspection, 3,000–5,000 km minor service cadence.
Spare pool: 1 dedicated spare vehicle; rotate to avoid age clustering.
Operations
Central dispatch with manual surge rules; simple routing templates (airport, hotel loops).
Fixed rosters with floaters to cover sick leave and peak windows.
Cost controls
Tight fuel tracking, consolidated supplier invoicing, simple telematics for fuel and idling metrics.
KPI targets
Availability ? 92%; ontime pickup ? 90%; preventive compliance 100%.
2. Large fleet scenario (25–200+ vehicles)
Organizational model
Distributed hubs: multiple dispatch hubs; Hub Managers, Fleet Supervisors, Maintenance Team, Regional Planner.
Dedicated teams: procurement, parts inventory, training, QA.
Procurement & composition
Diversified mix: minibuses, 12–18 seat shuttles, sedans, and a small number of larger coaches for bulk runs.
Blend of ownership and longterm leases to optimize capex vs opex.
Maintenance & lifecycle
Tiered maintenance program: daily driver checks, weekly shop checks, mileage/time based services, scheduled midlife refurb.
Inhouse workshop for routine work; external authorized partners for heavy repairs. Central parts inventory with reorder automation.
Operations & capacity management
Advanced dispatch platform with dynamic routing, load balancing across hubs, and automated peak rules.
Demand forecasting models (hourly/day-of-week/season) feed rostering and vehicle staging.
Dedicated rapid response team for breakdowns and VIP relief runs.
Resilience & vendor strategy
Multiple fuel suppliers, thirdparty maintenance partners, and leasing partners to avoid single points of failure.
KPIs & analytics
Fleet utilization target 70–85%; mean time to repair (MTTR) < 120 minutes for roadside; preventive adherence 99%; cost per vehicle km tracked weekly.
3. Seasonal / peak scenarios (holidays, events, tourism peaks)
Scaling model
Hybrid capacity: mix permanent fleet + shortterm leased vehicles + thirdparty operator partnerships for overflow.
Use flexible contract terms with vetted partners to ramp up quickly and scale down without longterm exposure.
Demand planning
Use historical demand windows + event calendars + partner forecasts (hotels, airlines) to build 2, 4, and 8week capacity plans.
Trigger thresholds (e.g., forecasted occupancy +20% vs baseline) automatically unlock leasing and hiring actions.
Operational playbook
Prestage vehicles at highdemand nodes; publish adjusted pickup templates and temporary geofenced zones.
Temporary surge fare rules, prioritized dispatch lanes, and dedicated hotlines for event partners.
Staffing
Shortterm contracts for drivers, accelerated onboarding with condensed OSATs, and dedicated supervisors for seasonal cohorts.
Prearranged standby lists of trained drivers who have completed seasonal certification.
Quality & safety
Short seasonal vehicles must meet same safety and telematics standards; require partner audits and spot checks.
Daily briefings, incident focus for event risks, increased supervisory ratio.
Cost management
Prenegotiate seasonal rates and minimum guarantees with partners; maintain a decision matrix for when to deploy leased vs partner assets.
KPIs
Shortterm SLA adherence target ? 90%; incident rate not exceed baseline +10%; cost per incremental seat-hour measured.
4. Common operational systems (applies to all scenarios)
Telematics and diagnostics: realtime GPS, fuel, idling, engine fault codes; automated alerts to maintenance.
Fleet dashboard: live availability, utilization, MTTR, cost per km, and driver hours with rolebased access.
Vendor & contract library: standardized SLAs, insurance, driver vetting, and inspection checklists.
Inventory & parts: automated reorder thresholds, slow/fast mover classification, critical spares kit for roadside fixes.
Compliance & records: digital logs for inspections, driver certifications, incidents, and service history stored for audits.
5. Scaling playbooks (quick operational checklists)
Small ? Large ramp
Create hub structure and appoint Hub Manager.
Implement centralized parts inventory and inhouse workshop plan.
Deploy advanced dispatch software and forecasting models.
Recruit Fleet Supervisors and expand training cadre.
Normal ? Seasonal surge
Run demand forecast and trigger leasing/partner procurement.
Activate accelerated onboarding for seasonal drivers and staff.
Prestage spares, fuel cards, and mobile workshop kits at surge nodes.
Increase supervisory ratio and daily performance reporting cadence.
Unexpected demand spike
Invoke rapid response: deploy partner operators and floaters.
Rebalance vehicles via dynamic dispatch to highvalue corridors.
Send field techs for triage; rotate newly returned serviceable spares into fleet.
6. Risk mitigation and financial controls
Risk controls
Maintain critical spare ratio (1 spare per 15–20 active vehicles).
Stagger vehicle purchase/lease cycles to avoid age/maintenance cliffs.
Insurance layered by vehicle type and use case.
Financial controls
Weekly cost per km and monthly profitability by route/cluster.
Breakeven analysis for leased vs owned decisions; total cost of ownership (TCO) model for 3–7 year horizons.
Threshold approvals for expensive repairs vs replacement with escalation to Ops Director.
7. Fleet KPIs cheatsheet (operational dashboard essentials)
Availability: % vehicles fit-for-service.
Utilization: active hours vs available hours.
Ontime pickup: % pickups within SLA.
MTTR: mean time to repair for breakdowns.
Preventive compliance: % services done on schedule.
Cost per vehiclekm: fuel + maintenance + leasing amortization.
Incident rate: safety events per 10,000 km.
Driver hours compliance: % adherence to duty limits.


90day fleet scaling playbook — Addis Ababa launch
Summary
Goal: field a reliable, auditable, and scalable shuttle operation in Addis Ababa that meets airport transfer demand and scales through early growth and seasonality.
Timeframe: 90 days (Weeks 0–13).
Primary output: phased vehicle counts, staffing templates, procurement & maintenance actions, operational playbooks, and daily/weekly KPIs.

Phase structure (high level)
Phase 0 — Ready (Days 0–7): approvals, contracts, core hires, initial vehicles.
Phase 1 — Launch (Days 8–30): soft launch at priority sites; validate ops, refine SOPs, certify staff.
Phase 2 — Scale (Days 31–60): add vehicles, expand hubs, formalize partner agreements.
Phase 3 — Stabilize & Optimize (Days 61–90): reach target utilization, refine forecasting, finalize seasonal playbook.

Target vehicle counts (recommended baseline and scale triggers)
Baseline (Day 0–7) — Minimal viable fleet 
6 x 1215 seat minibuses (airport/core shuttle)
3 x 45 seat sedans (VIP/corporate/lastmile)
1 x spare vehicle (any type) for immediate swap
Total baseline = 10 vehicles
Launch target (Day 8–30) — Reliable coverage for primary airport and hotel clusters 
Add 4 minibuses + 2 sedans
Total = 16 vehicles
Scale target (Day 31–60) — Support growing bookings, add CBD pilot and bus terminal 
Add 6 minibuses + 3 sedans (or 1 coach for group runs) via lease or partner ops
Total = 25 vehicles
High demand / seasonal readiness (Day 61–90) — 20–30% overflow capacity via partners 
Activate 5–8 leased or partner vehicles (minibuses) staged at demand nodes
Operational control total = 30+ vehicles (mix of owned + leased + partner)
Scale triggers (automatic actions)
+20% weekoverweek bookings for 2 consecutive weeks ? deploy 4 leased minibuses and recruit 6 drivers.
Average pickup wait >12 minutes for 3 consecutive days ? add 2 vehicles to affected hub or reallocate floaters.

Staffing templates (roles, counts, and rotas)
Baseline staffing (10 vehicles)
Fleet Manager (1) — overall accountability (day shift).
Dispatchers (2) — 24/7 coverage via shift split; primary dispatcher + night floater.
Drivers (14) — 1.4 drivers per vehicle to cover shifts, rest, and sick leave.
Technicians / mechanic (1 fulltime) + oncall partner.
Kiosk / Customer attendants (4) — split across airport & hotel; staffed peak windows.
Onboarding/Account Success (1 parttime) for early corporate signups.
Supervisor (Operations) (1) — gapcover and QA.
Launch staffing (16 vehicles)
Add 6 drivers (total 20 drivers).
Add 1 dispatcher (total 3).
Add 1 technician or upgrade to 1.5 FTE via partner.
Add 2 kiosk attendants (total 6).
Add 1 rostered field supervisor per major site (airport).
Scale staffing (25 vehicles)
Fleet Manager (1) + Assistant Fleet Supervisor (1).
Dispatch hub staff: 1 Hub Manager + 4 dispatchers (rotate 24/7).
Drivers: 1.6 drivers per vehicle ? ~40 drivers.
Maintenance: 2 technicians + mobile roadside tech (contract).
Kiosk attendants: 8–10 across sites.
Training & QA lead (1) to maintain OSAT throughput.
Sample shift model (for drivers and dispatchers)
Driver shifts: 10–12 hour shift; rotate 5 days on / 2 off; provide peak overlap windows (05:00–11:00 and 16:00–22:00).
Dispatcher shifts: three 8hour shifts to ensure continuous monitoring; oncall supervisor overnight.
Hiring and onboarding cadence
Week 0–2: hire Fleet Manager, 40% of drivers (for baseline + launch), 1 dispatcher, 1 technician, core attendants.
Week 3–6: hire remaining drivers to meet launch target; begin accelerated seasonal roster recruiting.
Week 7–13: recruit for scale target and maintain standby pool of precertified drivers.
Driver vetting and certification
Minimum: valid driving license, background check, medical clearance, vehicle safety OSAT (practical), customer service micromodule.
Certification: Level 1 Verified Operator required before solo duty.

Procurement and sourcing plan
Vehicle procurement mix
Owned: 60% of baseline fleet (minibuses & sedans) for operational control and long term TCO.
Leased: use 12–24 month operating leases for quick capacity and cash conservation.
Partnered: vetted thirdparty operators for 15–30% of seasonal overflow.
Procurement actions by week
Week 0: finalize vendor list, confirm specs (telemetry, seat count, branding), place orders or secure lease MOUs.
Week 1–4: accept initial deliveries for baseline vehicles; fit telematics, safety kits, branding.
Week 4–8: finalize leasing for scale vehicles; negotiate shortterm seasonal rates.
Week 8–12: validate partner operator SLAs and perform spot audits.
Critical kit for each vehicle before service
Telemetry unit (GPS + engine faults + idling).
Emergency kit and first aid.
Branded signage and safety decals.
Fuel card or approved payment method.
Driver folder with manifest templates, incident log, and inspection checklist.

Maintenance and workshop plan
Preventive schedule
Daily driver pretrip checklist (fuel, lights, brakes, tires).
Weekly minor checks by technician (fluids, belts, battery).
Mileage/time service: every 5,000 km or 3 months for minor; 15,000–20,000 km for major service.
Workshop setup (initial)
Week 0–4: outsource heavy work to vetted local workshop; hire 1 onsite technician for routine checks.
Week 31–60: plan and budget for small inhouse workshop for routine maintenance.
Spare strategy
Maintain spares ratio: 1 spare per 12–15 active vehicles.
Critical spares kit for roadside (belts, fuses, hoses).
Breakdown response
MTTR target: <120 minutes for roadside triage; deploy mobile tech and spare vehicle swap.
Roadside SOP: driver logs incident ? dispatcher sends mobile tech or relief driver ? swap & repair within shift.



Dispatch, staging, and hub operations
Hub design
Primary hub: airport staging for inbound/outbound; capacity to hold 6–8 vehicles.
Secondary hubs: hotel cluster and CBD minihub with 3–5 vehicles each.
Staging rules
Preposition vehicles 45–60 minutes before scheduled flight peaks.
Peak windows: 05:00–11:00 and 16:00–22:00 local; increase staging 60% during known event days.
Dynamic rostering & routing
Use simple demand forecast (rolling 7day average) during Weeks 0–30; transition to integrated forecasting tool by Week 45.
Implement priority lanes for pickup during airport surge and VIP accounts.
Partner ops integration
Prior vetting checklist, SLA, insurance copies, telematics sharing if possible, and monthly reconciliation of runs.

Financial and cost assumptions (highlevel for planning)
Baseline CAPEX (vehicle fit/branding/telemetry) per minibus estimate: budget for local market pricing; include contingency for import duties.
Fuel & OPEX: track cost per vehiclekm daily; set breakeven bookings per vehicle per day for Addis Ababa demand profile.
Leasing: negotiate flexible shortterm add/drop clauses for seasonal capacity.
Recommend immediate action: create a simple TCO and breakeven spreadsheet using your local fuel, driver wage, and lease rates to inform go/nogo on additional leased vehicles.


KPIs and dashboards (daily / weekly cadence)
Daily (operations)
Active vehicles vs scheduled vehicles.
Bookings per vehicle (last 24h).
Average pickup wait time.
Number of breakdowns; MTTR.
Driver availability (on duty vs scheduled).
Weekly (management)
Fleet utilization % (active hours / available hours).
Cost per vehiclekm and cost per trip.
Preventive maintenance compliance %.
Incident rate per 10,000 km.
Customer CSAT for rides.
Escalation thresholds
Utilization >85% sustained 3 days ? trigger leasing + recruitment.
Pickup wait >12 minutes sustained 3 days ? reallocate vehicles and invoke surge roster.
Preventive compliance <95% ? stop new vehicles entering rotation until remediation.

Daybyday 90day checklist (condensed)
Days 0–7
Secure permits, insurance, and initial leases.
Hire Fleet Manager, core dispatch, 40% driver cohort, 1 technician.
Receive and fit baseline vehicles (10 total).
Configure telematics, payment devices, and incident logging.
Days 8–30
Soft launch; operate at reduced capacity; run daily debriefs.
Complete training and certify remaining drivers.
Implement daily KPI dashboard and run 7day forecasting.

Days 31–60
Add vehicles to reach 25 count via lease/partner delivery.
Stand up secondary hub (hotel/CBD).
Scale dispatch team and maintenance support.
Execute seasonal readiness tests and partner audits.
Days 61–90
Stabilize operations; optimize roster and routing rules.
Finalize seasonal surge playbook and standby partner list.
Achieve target KPIs and document lessons learned into SOP updates.

Risks and mitigation (top items)
Vehicle delivery delays ? maintain partner operator pool and expedite leases.
Technician shortage ? contract local workshop and crosstrain drivers for basic triage.
Demand forecast misses ? conservative triggers + flexible leasing.

Fleet management overview
A fleet strategy for Shuttle Plus must balance cost control, reliability, regulatory compliance, and scalability for Ethiopian operations (airport-heavy, peak inbound/outbound demand, variable road and fuel conditions). Below are practical fleet models, where each wins, their risks, and a clear recommendation tailored to Shuttle Plus.

Fleet model options (what they are and when they beat the market)
Ownership (buy fleet outright)
Wins when you need full control over service quality, branding, and scheduling reliability.
Risk: high capital expenditure (CAPEX), depreciation, maintenance overhead.
Finance / Hire-purchase (asset financed long-term)
Wins when you want ownership benefits but spread CAPEX; preserves control.
Risk: debt service, asset collateral requirements.
Operating lease / long-term rental
Wins for predictable monthly costs and lower maintenance responsibility.
Risk: higher long-run cost; limited asset customization.
Short-term rental / on-demand fleet (rent-as-needed)
Wins for seasonal demand, pilots, or market testing.
Risk: unreliable availability during peak days; weaker branding.
Franchise / vetted partner fleet (asset-light network)
Wins for rapid geographic scale with low CAPEX; leverages local knowledge.
Risk: variable service quality; more complex SLAs and audits.
Driver-partner marketplace (platform model)
Wins on variable urban demand and low fixed costs; fast market entry.
Risk: weaker control over vehicle standards, legal classification issues.
Managed fleet services / third-party fleet operator
Wins when you want predictable SLAs with outsourced ops and fleet expertise.
Risk: cost premium; dependence on vendor performance.
Hybrid (mixed owned + partner + lease)
Wins by combining control for core routes with flexibility to scale; reduces single-point exposure.
Risk: operational complexity; requires strong governance systems.

Comparison snapshot (key attributes)
ModelCapEx impactControl over qualityScalability speedBest forOwnershipHighHighMediumCore high-frequency routes and corporate contractsFinance / Hire-purchaseMedium-HighHighMediumScaling core fleet while preserving controlOperating leaseLowMediumMediumShort-to-mid term growth with fewer maintenance headachesShort-term rentalLowLowHighSeasonal spikes, pilots, event supportFranchise/PartnerLowMedium-Low (but can be improved by SLAs)HighRegional expansion without heavy capexDriver-partner marketplaceMinimalLowVery HighUrban on-demand services; price-competitive runsManaged Fleet ServicesLow (op-ex heavy)Medium-HighMediumFast operational maturity without owning assetsHybridVariableHigh (if governed)HighBalanced growth with risk diversification
Recommendation for Shuttle Plus (best-suited model and why)
Recommended core model: Hybrid — controlled owned/financed core fleet + vetted partner/franchise fleet + short-term rental buffer.
Why this fits Shuttle Plus in Ethiopia:
Core airport routes require strict SLA, branding, and predictable uptime — best served by owned or financed vehicles you can audit and brand.
Regional expansion and off-peak scaling are faster and capital-light via vetted partners/franchise operators who meet Shuttle Plus standards.
Short-term rental or leased vehicles act as surge capacity for holidays, conferences, and unpredictable demand spikes common in airport transfer markets.
This mix balances CAPEX, control, and growth speed while keeping regulatory and compliance obligations manageable locally.

Vehicle-mix recommendation:
Core: 6–12 seater minibuses (for group transfers); 4-seater sedans for executive/corporate; wheelchair-accessible van(s) for special needs.
Surge/partner pool: newer used 4–8 seat SUVs or vans (3–5 years max).
Reserve: 1–2 light cargo vans for luggage overflow, logistics, and incident response.
Fuel and sustainability stance:
Prioritize reliable diesel/B35-compatible engines now (fuel availability), design “EV-ready” fleet policy with charging plan for medium term (3–5 years) if grid and incentives improve.

Implementation roadmap (practical phased steps)
Define core-route footprint and capacity needed (30/60/90-day demand profile).
Determine baseline fleet size: core owned fleet to cover 70–80% of predictable airport demand; partner pool + rentals to cover the rest.
Capital planning: run TCO models for buy vs finance vs lease for core vehicles (include insurance, maintenance, downtime cost).
Partner program design: vetting checklist, SLA contract, audit cadence, branded signage requirements, and penalty/incentive clauses.
Ops & maintenance systems: implement preventive maintenance schedule, spare-part stocking plan, digital vehicle inspection (DVIR) workflows, and a single fleet management dashboard.
Surge & contingency playbook: rental partners, cross-hire agreements, and dynamic dispatch to absorb demand spikes.
Pilot & refine: 90-day pilot on 1–2 airport corridors with hybrid setup, monitor KPIs, tweak governance.
Scale: Roll out phased expansion with staggered vehicle acquisition and partner onboarding.

Governance, tech and people (must-haves)
Fleet management system (cloud): vehicle health, maintenance scheduling, driver hours, incident logging, and fuel tracking.
Centralized dispatch + local hub leads for partner oversight.
Standardized vehicle acceptance checklist and quarterly audits for partner fleets.
Procurement policy: max vehicle age, acceptable makes/models, retrofit rules, paint/branding standards.
Insurance & compliance: comprehensive fleet insurance, driver licensing checks, and regulatory documentation stored auditable.
Training team: driver safety, fuel-efficient driving, and brand service standards.

Key KPIs to monitor (minimum set)
On-time pickup rate (airport window)
Vehicle utilization (%) by route and by hour
Average downtime per vehicle (hours/week)
Maintenance cost per km / per vehicle per month
Incidents per 1000 trips; time to resolution
Cost per trip (broken into fuel, maintenance, depreciation, partner fees)
Customer NPS for ride experience and punctuality




Form feedback collection  
Objective
Collect actionable feedback from applicants about the recruitment form to improve usability, clarity, completion rates, and brand experience.

Key metrics to track
Completion rate — submissions / form starts.
Time to complete — median and 90th percentile.
Abandonment step — field or section where users drop off.
Satisfaction score — Net Satisfaction 1–5 for the form.
Qualitative themes — top 5 pain points from free-text feedback.
Error rate — frequency of validation errors per field.
File upload success — percent of successful file uploads vs attempts.

When and how to ask applicants
Immediate post-submission (mandatory short micro-survey): show in confirmation page and include one-question widget.
Follow-up email or SMS 48 hours after submission for detailed feedback, sent only to applicants who completed the form.
Optional passive prompt on form page after 30 seconds on final section for users who abandon (non-intrusive slide-up asking why they left).
Periodic targeted interview sampling weekly (phone or 10–15 minute Zoom) with 5–8 recent applicants across demographics.

Feedback instruments and sample items
Micro-survey (one-step, post-submit)
Question: "How satisfied are you with this application form?" Rating 1–5.
Optional quick reason: single-line text “If low score, what was hardest?”
Follow-up survey (email/SMS link to short form)
Q1: Overall satisfaction 1–5.
Q2: Time to complete (minutes).
Q3: Which section was hardest? (select: Personal info; License & experience; Uploads; Situational questions; Other)
Q4: Did any validation errors stop you? (Yes/No) If Yes, which field?
Q5: Were file upload instructions clear? (Yes/No)
Q6: One suggestion to improve the form (free text).
Q7: Permission to contact for 10-minute follow-up (Yes/No; phone).
Exit prompt (for abandoners)
Single-select reasons: Too long; Confusing fields; File upload failing; Privacy concerns; Other (text).
Interview guide (10–15 minutes)
Walk through their experience from start to finish.
Ask for concrete examples: field that confused them, step they expected but didn’t find, clarity of consent language, and upload experience.
Ask what would make them finish faster and what would make them trust Shuttle Plus more.

Implementation steps and timeline
Add micro-survey widget to confirmation page and pipe result into submissions CSV within 24 hours.
Build automated follow-up email/SMS template triggered 48 hours after submission; include link to 6-question feedback form. Implement within 3 days.
Implement client-side event tracking for: form start, field-level focus/blur, validation errors, file upload attempts, submit success, abandonment. Deploy within 5 days.
Weekly dashboard: pull metrics (completion, time, abandonment step, satisfaction) and run automated alerts if completion rate drops >10% week-over-week. Start immediately upon tracking.
Recruit interview participants from follow-up survey consent; conduct first 5 interviews in week 2 and summarize findings week 3.


Data capture, storage, and privacy
Store micro-survey and follow-up responses alongside the applicant row in the CSV with columns: Form Satisfaction, Feedback Short Reason, Follow-up Satisfaction, Follow-up Responses, Interview Consent, Interview Notes.
Retain feedback for the same period as applicant data and pseudonymize when used in internal analytics.
Show an explicit privacy line in follow-up messages: feedback is used to improve the hiring process.
Limit access to Recruitment Lead and Ops Admin.

Analysis, prioritization, and closing the loop
Weekly synthesis: prioritize top 3 UX issues based on frequency and impact.
Quick fixes (low dev effort, high impact) deployed within 1 sprint; medium/large items scheduled in roadmap.
After changes, run AB test for two weeks comparing completion and satisfaction.
Close the loop with respondents who gave suggestions and consented to follow-up: send a short note describing what changed and when.
Maintain a change log: date, change summary, owner, and observed impact on metrics.

Templates
Post-submit micro-survey (confirmation page)
Prompt: "Quick question: How satisfied are you with this form?" [1][2][3][4][5]
If selected 1–3, show one-line field: "What was the main issue?"
Follow-up email (48 hours)
Subject: "One quick question about your Shuttle Plus application"
Body: Short thank-you, link to 6-question feedback form, estimated time 2–3 minutes, optional incentive (if you choose to offer one).
Abandon prompt (on-form)
Small notice: "Leaving so soon? Tell us one reason" with single-select options and a continue button.

Frequent User Database Setup
Purpose
Define the data model, capture flows, privacy controls, and operational notes to reliably address repeat customers by name across channels while preserving security, accuracy, and consent.

1. Data model and required fields
CustomerID (unique, system generated) — primary key.
FirstName — canonical preferred given name.
LastName — family name.
DisplayName — what to show in-app/voice (e.g., “Abel”, “Ms. Bekele”).
NameVariants — commaseparated alternates and common misspellings; use for fuzzy matching.
PreferredLanguage — ISO code; influences greeting phrasing.
PreferredHonorific — optional (Mr/Ms/Dr/etc.) for formal channels.
ContactPrimary — phone number (E.164) or primary identifier.
ContactSecondary — email or alternate phone.
Verified — boolean indicating identity verification status.
ConsentForPersonalization — boolean; explicit optin for being addressed by name.
LastSeen — timestamp of last ride/checkin.
UsageCount — integer count of completed transactions.
CustomerTier — e.g., Frequent, VIP, New (optional).
Notes — free text for operational flags (e.g., “prefers text only”).
Source — origin of record (app, kiosk, phone, partner).
CreatedAt / UpdatedAt — timestamps for audit.
Sample singleline CSV header: CustomerID,FirstName,LastName,DisplayName,NameVariants,PreferredLanguage,PreferredHonorific,ContactPrimary,ContactSecondary,Verified,ConsentForPersonalization,LastSeen,UsageCount,CustomerTier,Notes,Source,CreatedAt,UpdatedAt



2. Capture flows and identity verification
Inapp signup: collect FirstName, DisplayName, ContactPrimary, PreferredLanguage, and explicit toggle for personalization consent. Require phone verification (OTP) before marking Verified = true.
Kiosk/phone intake: collect same fields and confirm spelling aloud; if customer declines personalization, set ConsentForPersonalization = false. If agent creates record, set Source = kiosk/phone and note agent ID in Notes.
Backfill from bookings: merge records using deterministic keys (phone, email) and fuzzy match on NameVariants; flag merges for review.
Verification policy: treat Verified = true only after OTP or matched government ID in higherrisk refunds/claims.

3. Personalization rules and safe addressing
Consent check: address customers by name only if ConsentForPersonalization = true. If false, use neutral phrasing (e.g., “Guest” or booking reference).
Channel tailoring: 
App push/inapp: use DisplayName.
SMS: use FirstName if ConsentForPersonalization is true and message length permits.
Phone/Kiosk/Agent scripts: use PreferredHonorific + LastName for formal interactions when Requested or for older customers; otherwise use DisplayName.
Voice assistants: prefer DisplayName and shorter names for natural speech.
Fallbacks: if DisplayName missing but FirstName exists, use FirstName; if no name and consent false, use “Valued customer” + BookingID.
Frequency throttle: avoid overpersonalization in mass messages—limit name usage to highrelevance messages (booking confirmations, incident updates).
Respect cultural naming: respect ordering (family vs given) and diacritics stored in Unicode; show transliterations only if requested.
Personalization example rules (pseudocode):
If ConsentForPersonalization == true and UsageCount >= 2 then Greeting = “Hi {DisplayName},” else Greeting = “Hello,”.


4. Matching, duplicates, and name variants
Primary match keys: ContactPrimary, ContactSecondary.
Secondary fuzzy matching: normalized name comparison (strip diacritics, common abbreviations, whitespace), and compare with NameVariants; require at least one contact match or manual review to merge.
Merge policy: when merging, preserve original records in an audit log, consolidate NameVariants, sum UsageCount, set Verified = true if either record verified, and notify customer by secure channel of consolidation.
Conflict resolution: when conflicting ConsentForPersonalization values exist, preserve the more privacyprotective choice (i.e., false) and flag for agent followup.

5. Privacy, retention, and optout
Explicit consent: store ConsentForPersonalization and timestamp of consent. Use consent for name addressing only.
Optout workflow: immediate effect — update ConsentForPersonalization = false across systems; purge DisplayName from outgoing templates and use neutral identifiers. Log optout event.
Data minimization: keep only fields required for personalization and service delivery. Remove or archive obsolete contacts after retention period.
Retention rules: keep active frequent user records while UsageCount > 0 and LastSeen within 24 months; archive after 24 months of inactivity and delete after companypolicy or legal retention period.
Access control and encryption: restrict read/write to authorized roles; encrypt contact fields at rest; mask names in logs where not required.
Audit trail: log all read/write actions on customer records with staff ID, reason, and timestamp.

6. Implementation checklist and quick tasks
Schema creation in DB and CSV import template using header above.
Implement capture flows: app form with consent toggle + OTP; agent intake form with explicit consent question.
Build matching/merge job: deterministic merges by contact, weekly fuzzy match batch with manual review queue.
Personalization API: endpoint that returns Greeting text given CustomerID, channel, and context; enforce consent/usage rules serverside.
Optout API and UI: oneclick optout in app and agent dashboard; propagate immediately to messaging platform.
Logging and monitoring: dashboards for UsageCount, consent rates, merge conflicts, and optout events.
Training: agent scripts for asking name and consent, and escalation flow for disputes.
Pilot: run a 4week pilot with highvolume users, monitor errors, and refine NameVariants logic.

Examples and agent scripts
Agent script to ask permission: “May I address you by your name in messages and when we call to improve your experience? We will only use it with your permission.” If yes, record ConsentForPersonalization = true and preferred DisplayName.
Sample greeting variants: 
App (friendly): “Hi {DisplayName}, your shuttle will arrive in 7 minutes.”
SMS (concise): “{DisplayName}, your driver {DriverName} is 5 mins away.”
Phone (formal): “Good afternoon, {PreferredHonorific} {LastName}, this is Shuttle Plus.”




Google Maps integration plan — freetier usage for customer & driver tracking
A focused plan to use Google Maps Platform on the free tier for Shuttle Plus customer tracking and driver apps, covering which SKUs to use, expected pressure points, costcontrol patterns, data architecture, caching/fallbacks, monitoring, and a rollout checklist.

1. Key freetier fact to design around
Google’s updated free allocation lets you mix & match across product families; Essentials typically gives up to ~10K free calls per SKU per month, with Pro/Enterprise tiers having different allowances — use this as the planning baseline when sizing traffic Google Maps Platform.

2. Recommended SKUs and where to use them
Maps JS / Mobile SDK (Map display): client map for customer tracking, driver map view, ops dashboard situational map. Keep tile usage modest by using static/lowdetail map types for hightraffic pages.
Routes (Directions / Distance Matrix): serverside ETA and routing calculations for multistop or driver dispatch logic; avoid doing large numbers of Directions requests clientside. Routes SKUs are the highest cost risk — gate and cache aggressively.
Places Autocomplete (address entry): use session tokens and server session handling to reduce percharacter calls; prefer address pickers that limit autocomplete calls.
Geocoding / Reverse Geocoding: cache responses per address/latlong; only call on first encounter or when data changes.
Design note: treat Routes and Places as “expensive” SKUs to be called sparingly and aggregated serverside.



3. Usage patterns and cost control tactics
Move heavy logic serverside: run Distance Matrix and batch Directions calls on the server; aggregate vehicle ETA pings into a single periodic compute instead of per-client repeated requests.
Cache aggressively: cache geocoding results, route segments, and recent ETAs (short TTLs 30s–5min depending on sensitivity). Use Redis or CDN for tile/route caching.
Throttle & quota per user/station: enforce per-device quotas (e.g., 1 map refresh per 15s, limit route requests per booking) to avoid storms.
Use lowcost tiles / lightweight map styles: for many customer screens, show simplified vector tiles or static map images to reduce interactive map calls.
Session tokens for Places Autocomplete: require one serverbacked session per user search session to reduce SKU counts.
Operational rule: identify Routes and Places first in cost forecasts and gate them behind serverside quotas and caching.

4. Architecture pattern (practical, costaware)
Clients (iOS/Android/Web) ? minimal map renders and local ETA display.
Backend aggregator (serverless or small service) ? collects vehicle pings, computes zonelevel ETAs, queues heavy routing tasks.
Route worker pool ? batched Distance Matrix/Advanced Routing requests; writes precomputed ETAs to cache.
CDN/Cache (Redis + edge cache) ? serves cached route segments, geocode results, and static map images.
Monitoring + billing guard ? alerts when SKU thresholds approach free limits and autothrottles noncritical requests.
Result: clients read shortlifed cached ETAs and map tiles; only backend triggers paid routing/places calls.

5. Driver and customer app patterns (practical UI rules)
Driver app: show lightweight map + navigation link (open device navigation app) rather than continuously rerequesting optimized multistop directions. Send periodic pings (e.g., 5–15s) aggregated serverside.
Customer app: one live tracking map with ETA that updates from server cache; refresh map tiles on user gesture instead of continuous streaming. Provide “lowbandwidth mode” that replaces map with ETA text and lastknown location.
Address entry: use Places Autocomplete only on explicit search interactions; use server session tokens and a max of X predictions per session.

6. Fallbacks and vendor risk mitigation
Implement web fallback tile provider or static tiles (OpenStreetMap/Tileserver) for degraded/rare circumstances to avoid billing spikes during Google outage or unexpected traffic.
Keep canonical booking/payment/dispatch logic decoupled from maps so core ops work if map routing temporarily disabled.
Track usage per SKU and maintain a simple quota throttler to degrade noncritical features gracefully (e.g., suspend promotional route recalculations).

7. Monitoring, alerts, and billing guardrails
Instrument perSKU metrics (calls/minute, monthly cumulative) plus cost estimate and alert at 60%, 80%, and 95% of free threshold.
Build automated throttles: noncritical route recalculations are paused if projected spend exceeds safe threshold; critical webhooks and payment flows remain prioritized.
Add synthetic tests for route and map lifecycle to detect spikes and failures early.
Practical: map billing alerts in Google Cloud + internal dashboards for realtime visibility Google Maps Platform.

8. Testing and sandbox approach
Use Google’s sandbox/test keys and staged accounts to simulate high load and validate throttles during pilot. Validate device behaviors for map rendering modes, Places sessions, and offline fallback.
Run load tests that focus on Routes and Places SKU usage (the most expensive) to ensure caching and batching logic holds under expected and burst traffic.
Implementation tip: create a small “load budget” plan before each major release to validate consumption.

9. Rollout checklist (pilot ? production)
Estimate SKU usage per feature (map loads, route calls, places searches) and forecast monthly totals against free allowances Google Maps Platform.
Implement serverside batching for Distance Matrix/Directions and shortTTL caching (Redis).
Add session tokens for Places Autocomplete and limit client calls.
Build monitoring + alerts for SKU thresholds and cost projections.
Add lowbandwidth & fallback map modes; integrate alternate tiles for emergencies.
Pilot with a single station, monitor usage and costs for 2–4 weeks, tune TTLs and throttles.
Gradually expand, keeping monthly consumption under the free buffer or budgeted spend.

10. Quick reference links and further reading
Google Maps Platform pricing and perSKU guidance (use this to map exact free counts and live pricing) Google Maps Platform.
Practical howtos for obtaining and securing API keys, session tokens, and reducing costs (developer guides and community posts) expertbeacon.com storemapper.com.




GPS fallback planning — offline-first strategy
Below is a compact, operational plan to implement immediately to make vehicle/asset/location-aware systems resilient when GNSS/GPS is unavailable.

Comparison of fallback options (key attributes)
OptionAccuracyDrift over timeComplexity to implementPower / CostInertial navigation (IMU + odometry)Medium initially; degrades with timeHigh (grows with time)MediumLow–MediumWheel/vehicle odometryMedium on flat surfacesMedium (slip, turns)LowLowMagnetometer heading + dead reckoningLow for position; good for headingHighLowLowVisual odometry / SLAM (camera)High (when features present)LowHighMedium–HighLIDAR SLAMVery high (structured environments)LowVery HighHighMap-matching (cached maps)High in mapped areasLow when matchedMediumLow–MediumCellular/WiFi positioning (offline DB)Low–MediumStableLowLowSatellite fallback (Iridium/Globalstar)Low-frequency position updatesN/AMediumHighSources for tradeoffs: engineering best practice and field experience.


Recommended architecture (layers, offline-first)
Primary: GNSS (when available) — maintain usual fixes and integrity checks.
Short-term fallback: Sensor fusion — IMU + odometry + magnetometer using an EKF/UKF for continuous pose estimate.
Medium-term fallback: Visual odometry / LIDAR SLAM (if sensors present) + loop closures to bound drift.
Long-term / global correction: Map-matching to cached maps and opportunistic cellular/WiFi-based fixes.
Emergency: Safe-state behaviour and last-known-position + heartbeat to operator or queued telemetry for later upload.

Sensor fusion and algorithms (practical)
Use an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) or Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF) to fuse: GNSS (when present), IMU, wheel encoders, magnetometer, and barometer.
Add a parallel Visual Odometry (VO) or LIDAR Odometry module that outputs relative pose and covariance; feed its delta to the EKF as a pseudo-measurement.
Maintain an adaptive sensor weighting scheme: lower GNSS weight when dilution or multipath suspected; increase VO/LIDAR in urban canyons.
Implement zero-velocity updates (ZUPT) when stopped to remove IMU bias.
Run periodic map-matching corrections using a particle filter or Dijkstra/Hidden Markov Model (HMM) on cached street/route graph to snap drifted tracks to plausible paths.

Map caching and offline databases
Store tiled map extracts for operational region(s) at multiple zoom levels (vector tiles recommended).
Precompute and cache a sparse landmark database (visual descriptors or LIDAR features) for SLAM relocalization.
Include road/route graph, speed limits, allowed corridors, and known no-go zones as lightweight JSON or protobuf.
Implement storage housekeeping: TTL for stale tiles, progressive download for expanding operating area, and delta updates when online.

Behavioural rules and safety modes
Degraded navigation thresholds: define maximum acceptable horizontal error and heading error. If exceeded, trigger next fallback level.
If estimated drift > threshold or confidence low: (a) reduce max speed, (b) avoid lane changes/complex maneuvers, (c) request operator confirmation or manual control.
If no fix and in unknown area: hold position (if safe), move to last-known safe waypoint, or follow predefined safe route to nearest recovery point.
Always log sensor streams with timestamps and checksums for post-incident audit and map improvement.

Testing, validation, and operational checklist
Unit tests: EKF consistency, sensor dropout simulations, VO/LIDAR failure injection.
Field tests: planned GNSS-denial runs in representative environments (urban canyon, tunnels, rural) with ground-truth (RTK or surveyed checkpoints).
Acceptance criteria: positional error curves vs time under each fallback; time-to-detect-GPS-failure; bounded drift after X minutes.
Operational runbook: immediate steps for operators, recovery SOP, telemetry thresholds for alerts, and checklist for returning to full-GNSS mode.

Quick implementation recipe (prioritized, minimal viable)
Ensure high-quality IMU + wheel encoder integration and run EKF for immediate short-term fallback.
Cache vector tiles and basic road graph for map-matching.
Implement conservative behavioural rules (speed limit, no complex maneuvers) when GNSS confidence drops.
Add VO or LIDAR SLAM when budget and compute permit to bound drift for longer offline missions.
Run scenario tests and iterate thresholds based on measured drift.




GPS integration planning 
Objectives and success criteria
Primary objective: Provide reliable real-time vehicle location and ETA for operations, drivers, and customers.
Success criteria: location updates ?10s frequency for ops, ETA accuracy ±2 minutes for pickups, 99.5% uptime for the tracking service, and full audit trail of location events for 30 days.

High-level requirements
Device layer: driver mobile app (iOS/Android) or dedicated OBD/GPS unit that supplies lat/lon, heading, speed, timestamp, device ID, and trip ID.
Connectivity: cellular data with retry/backoff and store-and-forward for offline periods.
Backend: ingestion API, stream processor, location store, ETA service, and webhooks/notifications.
Access: driver app, ops dashboard, customer ETA links (short-lived), and Logs/Audit UI.
Privacy & compliance: anonymized public links, opt-in tracking consent, data retention policy, and secure transport (TLS).
Monitoring: availability, latency, missing heartbeats, and location anomaly detection.

Recommended architecture (components)
Device telemetry (driver app or hardware) — publishes location pings every 5–15s.
Ingestion API (HTTPS) — authenticates devices and accepts batched pings.
Stream processor — validates, deduplicates, enriches with map-matching, and emits events.
Location store & time-series DB — fast reads for ETA and historical audit.
ETA & routing service — calculates live ETA using road network and traffic.
Notification layer — SMS/Push/Email ETA updates and ops alerts.
Ops dashboard & customer ETA link — map, vehicle list, filters, and replay.
Logging, security, and retention services.
Data model (minimum fields)
device_id; trip_id; timestamp (UTC); latitude; longitude; heading; speed_kph; accuracy_m; provider; battery_pct; network_status.
trip record: booking_id; passenger_count; pickup_address_gps; dropoff_address_gps; driver_id; vehicle_id; scheduled_pickup_time.

Integration options (tradeoffs)
Use driver mobile app GPS (fast, low cost; depends on driver phone quality and battery).
Use dedicated OBD/plug-in tracker or hardwired telematics (higher reliability, cost, installation).
Use third-party fleet telematics platform via API (fast to deploy; recurring cost; possible vendor lock-in).
Choose based on fleet size, budget, and desired reliability.

Implementation roadmap (12 weeks sprint plan)
Week 0 — Kickoff, clarify device choice, and finalize requirements.
Weeks 1–2 — Data model, API spec, security, and retention policy.
Weeks 3–5 — Build ingestion API, authentication, and stream processor (map-matching).
Weeks 6–7 — ETA/routing integration (use open-source routing or vendor API); build location store.
Weeks 8–9 — Driver app updates (ping logic, retry/backoff, battery rules) or hardware pilot procurement.
Week 10 — Ops dashboard and short-lived customer ETA link generator.
Week 11 — End-to-end pilot with 5–10 vehicles; collect metrics and iterate.
Week 12 — Ramp to full rollout, monitoring, and SOP updates.
Testing and validation plan
Unit tests for API and stream processor.
Synthetic replay of routes to validate ETA accuracy and map-matching.
Field pilot on representative routes and vehicles for at least 7 days.
Failover tests: simulate offline devices, high latency, and malformed pings.
Acceptance criteria: heartbeat misses <1% per driver per day; ETA error median <2 minutes.

Ops controls and SOP changes
Add a Driver App checklist: GPS enabled, location permission granted, low-power mode disabled, app background refresh allowed.
Add fault response SOP: unverified location for >5 minutes ? Ops calls driver; >15 minutes ? reassign or escalate.
Customer communications: link to live ETA with clear privacy notice and expiry.
Logging requirements: store raw pings for 30 days, aggregate metrics for 90 days.

KPIs and alerts
Location ping rate per device (target 1 ping / 5–15s).
Missing heartbeat rate (alert at 5% per hour).
ETA accuracy median and 95th percentile.
Ingestion API error rate and latency.
Map-matching failure rate.

Quick implementation checklist (actionable)
Decide device strategy: driver app vs hardware.
Define data model and retention period.
Build secure ingestion API with device auth.
Implement map-matching and ETA service.
Update driver app or deploy hardware pilot.
Create ops dashboard and customer ETA page.
Run 7–14 day pilot and collect KPIs.
Update SOPs: driver onboarding, shift handover, and incident response.

Hiring timeline for drivers and concierges
This 10week, executable recruitment schedule is tailored for Shuttle Plus launching airport and city services. It covers sourcing, screening, on boarding, and earlystage performance checks for drivers and concierges. Roles and owners use your existing labels: Recruitment Lead, Ops Lead, Fleet Manager, HR Lead, Training Lead, Background Check Vendor, and Hiring Panel (Ops + HR + Fleet). Adjust volumes and exact dates to your launch timeline.

Summary timeline (10 weeks)
Weeks 0–1: Planning and role setup
Weeks 1–3: Sourcing and outreach campaign
Weeks 2–4: Application screening and phone interviews
Weeks 3–6: Assessments, practical driving checks and inperson interviews
Weeks 4–7: Background checks, documentation, offers issued
Weeks 6–8: Onboarding and basic training (classroom + elearning)
Weeks 8–10: Ridealong mentoring, probation monitoring and certification

Week 0–1 — Role definition and operational planning
Tasks: 
Finalise job descriptions (drivers: licence requirements, shifts, luggage handling; concierges: customer service, passport handling, POS) and competence matrix. Owner: HR Lead + Ops Lead.
Set hiring targets by location/shift and required start dates. Owner: Recruitment Lead.
Define pay bands, incentive schemes, guaranteed minimum payout for early ops, and offer template. Owner: Finance Lead + HR Lead.
Choose background check vendor and testing sites for driving/skills. Owner: HR Lead.
Deliverables: JD pack, hiring targets, approved budget envelope, vendor agreements.
KPI: JDs approved within 3 days; budget signoff.

Weeks 1–3 — Sourcing and outreach
Tasks: 
Post jobs on local boards, driver groups, union offices, community centers, and social media; run targeted SMS/WhatsApp outreach to driver networks. Owner: Recruitment Lead + Ops Lead.
Field recruitment events at fleet depots and transport hubs (weekend popups). Owner: Recruitment Lead.
Apply referral bonus for existing drivers and concierge hires. Owner: Ops Lead.
Deliverables: candidate pipeline dashboard with source tags; event schedule.
KPI: receive target applications (e.g., 5× hires target); cost per applicant tracked.

Weeks 2–4 — Initial screening and phone interviews
Tasks: 
Autofilter applicants: licences, experience, smartphone capability, background red flags. Owner: Recruitment Lead (ATS).
Conduct structured phone screens (30 min) checking availability, language skills, basic scenario screening (customer service, safety). Owner: Hiring Panel delegates.
Schedule practical assessments for shortlisted candidates. Owner: Fleet Manager / Ops Lead.
Deliverables: screened shortlists and assessment calendar.
KPI: % screened within 72 hours; shortlist to interview conversion rate.

Weeks 3–6 — Practical assessments and inperson interviews
Tasks (Drivers): 
Onroad driving assessment (30–45 min): defensive driving, parking, luggage handling, route/navigation test. Owner: Fleet Manager + Driving Assessor.
Vehicle safety and basic maintenance check demonstration. Owner: Fleet Manager.
Tasks (Concierges): 
Roleplay scenarios: passport handling, checkin flow, conflict resolution, POS transaction simulation. Owner: Ops Lead + Training Lead.
Short customerservice assessment and English/Amharic language check if needed.
Deliverables: scored assessment sheets, recommended hires list.
KPI: pass rate target and time to assess per candidate.

Weeks 4–7 — Background checks, verification and offers
Tasks: 
Initiate background checks: licence validation, criminal record checks (where permitted), identity, right to work, and reference checks. Owner: Background Check Vendor + HR Lead.
Verify medical fitness where required and drug screening policy if applicable. Owner: HR Lead.
Issue conditional offers with clear T&Cs (probation, uniforms, training requirement). Owner: HR Lead.
Deliverables: cleared candidate roster and signed offer letters.
KPI: % checks completed within 5 business days; offer acceptance rate.

Weeks 6–8 — Onboarding and core training
Tasks: 
Admin onboarding: payroll setup, contracts, ID badges, device provisioning, insurer/insurance brief. Owner: HR Lead + Finance Lead.
Classroom modules: company policies, safety/HSE, luggage handling, data protection and passport custody SOPs, service standards. Owner: Training Lead.
Elearning modules: route app usage, fare rules, incident reporting. Owner: Training Lead + IT.
Uniform and equipment issuance (PPE, POS devices, tamper tags). Owner: Fleet Manager + Ops Lead.
Deliverables: completed training checklists and competence signoffs.
KPI: training completion rate (target 100% before ridealong).

Weeks 8–10 — Ridealong mentoring and probation monitoring
Tasks: 
Pair new hires with experienced mentor for shadowing (3–5 shifts), gradually moving to independent duty. Owner: Ops Lead.
Daily shift handover logs, mentor signoffs and competency checklist at shift end. Owner: Mentor + PM.
30day probation review: quality, punctuality, customer feedback, safety incidents; set remediation plan or confirm ongoing employment. Owner: HR Lead + Ops Lead.
First 90day performance check and incentive eligibility confirmation. Owner: HR Lead.
Deliverables: mentor logs, probation review forms, initial performance KPIs.
KPI: % pass probation (target 85–90%); average customer rating for new hires.

Ongoing: rostering, retention and scale
Roster ramp: build rosters to scale supply by 10–15% above forecasted demand to maintain service levels. Owner: Ops Lead.
Continuous recruitment: maintain evergreen pipeline and monthly recruitment minidrives to replace attrition. Owner: Recruitment Lead.
Retention programs: monthly performance bonuses, recognition, upskilling and flexible shift options. Owner: HR Lead + Ops Lead.
Quarterly recertification: defensive driving refreshers, SOP refreshers, and customerservice refreshers. Owner: Training Lead.
KPI: monthly attrition rate (target < 8% initially), timetofill for replacements (target < 21 days).

Documents and templates to prepare before launch
Job description templates; assessment scorecards; offer letter templates; background check consent forms; training curricula and checklists; mentor checklists; probation review forms; roster templates; payroll onboarding checklist.

Metrics dashboard (track daily/weekly)
Candidates in pipeline by stage; timetohire; pass rates by assessment; background check clearance time; training completion; probation pass rate; firstmonth incident rate; average customer rating for new hires.

Immediate action checklist
Secure evidence now
Contact the passenger by phone and request photos of the damaged bags; ask for one wide shot and close-ups of each damage point.
Ask for the booking ID, pickup/dropoff photos (if available), and any witness names.
If agent/driver is available, ask them to take time-stamped photos of the vehicle area where handoff occurred and upload to shared folder.
Contain the issue (same hour)
Ask the passenger whether they want repair, replacement, or compensation; confirm expectations and record their preference.
Tell the passenger you’ve opened an incident and will follow up within 24 hours; give a single Ops contact name and phone number.
Preserve dashcam/cellphone video and driver notes; mark vehicle and agent as related evidence.
Create a complete incident record (in ClickUp task) — fill these fields immediately
Task Title: URGENT — Damaged luggage (Booking BKG-2025-0112) — Passenger name
Status: Open; Priority: Urgent; Assignee: CX owner
Fields/details to add in description: Booking ID, Ride datetime, Pickup/dropoff location, Passenger contact, Agent/driver name, Vehicle ID, Short timeline (what happened), Passenger’s stated outcome (repair/replacement/comp), Photos URLs (passenger + driver), Video URL (dashcam), Witness names, Consent timestamp.
Attach evidence links (signed S3/Drive URLs) rather than large files.
Triage and decision within 24 hours
Ops/CX reviews evidence and chooses one of three remedies: repair coordination, replacement, or monetary compensation.
If repair: provide numbered list of approved repair vendors and timeline (e.g., 3–7 business days) and organize courier/pickup.
If replacement or compensation: calculate settlement using clear matrix (see “Compensation guide” below) and obtain Ops Manager approval.
Execution and confirmation (48–72 hours)
Fulfill agreed remedy, obtain proof of repair/receipt or payment, and confirm with the passenger (photo or signed receipt).
Update ClickUp task with resolution notes, supporting docs, and close only after passenger confirms satisfaction or acceptance of remedy.
If passenger declines proposed remedy, escalate to Ops Manager and Legal.

Root cause & prevention (post-resolution)
Run quick RCA: Was luggage handled correctly? Driver behavior? Timing? App handoff instruction missing? Vehicle damage?
Add a one-line preventive action to the ClickUp task (e.g., retrain driver on handoff checks; update SOP; change packaging advice).
If trend detected (same agent/vehicle multiple incidents), flag for coaching or vehicle inspection.

Photo and evidence checklist for quality

Compensation guideline (simple matrix to apply quickly)
Minor cosmetic damage (scuffs, scratches): Offer repair up to $20 or 20% of small bag replacement value.
Moderate damage (broken handle/wheel, but bag usable): Repair or partial compensation up to $50–$100 depending on bag type.
Major damage (bag unusable, internal loss/damage): Replacement or full compensation up to declared bag value or a maximum company cap (e.g., $250) pending verification.
Lost or stolen items: Escalate to Security/Legal; do not offer immediate full settlement without investigation.
Record exact amounts, approvals, and receipts in the ClickUp task.

Incentive Plan for Luggage Concierges
A compact, audit-ready incentive plan that blends direct sales rewards with performance and teamwork incentives to drive upsells, accuracy in handoffs, and excellent guest experience.

Eligibility
Who: All full-time and part-time Shuttle Plus concierges after 30 days of employment.
Exclusions: Temporary contractors and concierges on active disciplinary action.
Qualification window: Sales and performance measured monthly.

Components
1. Direct sales commission
Rate: 1% of net value of qualifying add-on sales the concierge closes (add-ons = baggage protection, priority boarding, snack/water packs, premium seating, luggage assistance fees; excludes taxes and refunds).
Qualifying activity: Sales recorded in the app/POS under concierge ID at point of sale or confirmed by driver/dispatch.
Pay mechanics: Calculated per booking and aggregated monthly.
2. Sales performance tiers
Tier 1: Monthly sales ETB 0–5,000 ? no additional bonus.
Tier 2: Monthly sales ETB 5,001–10,000 ? +5% bonus on total commission earned that month.
Tier 3: Monthly sales > ETB 10,000 ? +12% bonus on total commission earned that month.
3. Monthly individual bonus for top performers
Top 10% sales performers: Fixed additional bonus (recommend ETB 1,000) split among top performers in the station.
4. Teamwork and accuracy pool
Pool funding: 0.5% of monthly ground-ops revenue allocated to concierge teamwork pool.
Distribution criteria: Weighted scorecard — Handoff accuracy 40%, Customer feedback 30%, Shift reliability 20%, Peer/lead input 10%.
Eligibility threshold: Minimum reliability score of 75% to receive any share.
5. Spot and safety bonuses
Spot bonus: Supervisors may award small instant bonuses (ETB 100–500) for exceptional service, recovered lost luggage, or high-value upsell salvages.
Safety bonus: Monthly safety-compliant staff who complete all vehicle/luggage checks and incident-free shifts receive a small fixed reward (ETB 300).

KPIs and Measurement
Sales conversion rate (sales closed ÷ passenger interactions).
Average add-on value per sale.
Handoff accuracy (no lost/misrouted bags; log reconciliations).
Customer satisfaction (post-ride rating).
Shift reliability (on-time start, coverage, attendance).
Compliance incidents (safety or procedure violations).

Example Calculation
Concierge monthly net add-on sales = ETB 8,000 ? base commission = 1% = ETB 80.
Tier 2 bonus = 5% of ETB 80 = ETB 4 ? sales commission total = ETB 84.
Teamwork pool share (example) = ETB 300.
Spot/safety = ETB 300 ? Monthly payout = ETB 684.

Payouts, Reporting, and Disputes
Frequency: Monthly with payroll.
Statement: Line-item breakdown showing trip-level commissions, tier bonus, teamwork share, spot/safety bonuses, deductions, and final payout.
Dispute window: 14 days from statement date; HR/Operations resolves within 10 business days.

Controls and Safeguards
Verification: Sales paid only for bookings with confirmed payment and recorded concierge ID.
Fraud detection: Automated flags for unusual patterns (duplicate transactions, abrupt sales spikes) trigger manual review.
Behavioral guardrails: Commissions withheld for safety violations, customer complaints upheld on review, or falsified sales.
Audit trail: All calculations and logs retained for 12 months.

Implementation Roadmap
Configure POS/app to tag concierge sales and produce monthly export.
Finalize tier thresholds, pool funding percentage, and fixed bonus amounts.
Pilot for one month with one station; collect feedback.
Train concierges and leads; distribute one-page explainer and sample payslip.
