Ops testing plan
Objectives
Validate endtoend operational readiness for launch zones (airport, city), confirming processes, systems, people and partner integrations under realistic conditions.
Surface failure modes, timing gaps and human error; verify escalation, communications and incident playbooks.
Produce evidence (logs, recordings, checklists) to support go/nogo decisions and remediation prioritisation.

Scope
Geographic: Addis Ababa airport kiosk + 2 pilot city zones.
Functions: booking flow, dispatch, driver/concierge handshake, luggage custody, payments, refunds, customer support, incident response, vehicle provisioning and thirdparty supplier handoffs.
Systems: rider app, driver app, dispatch backend, payments gateway, telematics, POS at kiosk, CCTV/safe access logs, CRM, and monitoring dashboards.
People: drivers, concierges, kiosk attendants, ops controllers, oncall legal/PR, incident manager, finance for refunds.

Test types and examples
Smoke tests: basic booking ? acceptance ? pickup ? dropoff for each tier (Economy, XL, Express).
Functional scenarios: scheduled airport pickup with luggage checkin; city short trips with extra luggage; corporate account invoicing flow.
Stress/volume tests: ramp bookings in a zone to simulate peak (rush hour) and observe dispatch, surge, and driver acceptance.
Failure injection tests: simulated GPS outage, payments gateway latency/failure, driver noshow, kiosk safe jam, passport custody mismatch.
Incident drills / tabletop to live escalation: data breach notification flow; accident with injury; regulatory inspection at kiosk.
Edge cases: oversized luggage booked in nonXL; multistop routing changes; offline driver app reconciliations.

Timeline (3week pilot testing window)
Week 0: preparation — scripts, roles, environment flags, test accounts and data seeding.
Week 1: smoke + functional scenario runs (low volume); confirm logging and evidence capture.
Week 2: stress runs and failure injections; run at least two major incident drills.
Week 3: regression on remediated items, final acceptance runs, and formal signoff readiness review.

Pretest preparation checklist
Environment: enable feature flags for test mode and ensure test payment rails and fake cards; isolate test data from production where required.
Test accounts: create seeded rider, driver, concierge and supplier accounts with known attributes and balances.
Permissions: ensure oncall list and external counsel/PR standby; secure required airport permissions for kiosk tests.
Evidence plan: configure logs, CCTV retention, recording of voice channels, and a central evidence repository with immutable timestamps.
Safety & compliance: safety officers briefed; medical/airport security notified of live drills to avoid false alarms.

Roles and responsibilities (example RACI)
Test Lead (Owner): Ops Lead — overall coordination, go/nogo decisions.
Scenario Owner: Product Manager — authors scripts and acceptance criteria.
Execution Team: Dispatch controllers, drivers, concierges, kiosk staff — run scenarios.
Observers / Verifiers: QA Engineer, Security Lead, Finance Analyst, GC/CCO — verify logs, legal triggers, financial flows.
Incident Commander: designated senior ops on duty for live drills.
Recorder / PM: captures issues, timestamps, and evidence links.


Scenario script template (use per scenario)
Title / objective
Preconditions (test accounts, vehicle availability, airport permissions)
Step list (clear actor, action, expected outcome) with timestamps
Injects (timed faults to introduce) and expected detection/response time
Exit criteria (what constitutes pass)
Evidence to collect (logs, screenshots, CCTV clips, call recordings)
Posttest owner for remediation if fail

Key metrics and acceptance criteria
Functional pass rate: ? 95% of scripted steps succeed on first run.
Detection & escalation time: incidents detected and escalated within SLA (e.g., 5 min).
Endtoend booking to pickup median time within target (zone baseline).
Refund / dispute processing latency: initial acknowledgment within 24 hours; provisional resolution within 72 hours for test cases.
Data integrity: 100% match between app-recorded custody events and kiosk safe logs for passport tests.
Driver acceptance and supply: driver acceptance rate ? target (e.g., 70%) during stress runs.
System resilience: survive single point failures (payments or GPS) with graceful degradation and no data loss.

Failure injection catalog (examples)
Payments: simulate gateway timeouts and declined cards; test retry and rider messaging.
Connectivity: force driver app offline and test offline job reconciliation and later sync.
Telematics/GPS: jitter or mismatch; verify reroute logic and dispute logs.
Kiosk safes: simulated jam or forced open; validate dualcustody alarms, CCTV snapshot preservation and incident escalation.
Thirdparty supplier: simulate supplier (fleet lessor) late vehicle delivery; test contingency supplier activation.

Evidence capture and issue management
Use a central test tracker (issue ID, severity, owner, evidence links) and require timestamps for detection and remediation start.
Capture automated logs, screenshots, transaction traces, CCTV clips, voice call recordings and witness statements.
Classify issues by severity and route to remediation sprints with owners and SLA (Critical 24h, High 72h, Medium 2 weeks, Low next release).

Posttest review and remediation
Immediate debrief within 24 hours: test lead, scenario owners, and observers review critical failures and assign hot fixes.
Produce formal test report: scope, pass/fail by scenario, evidence bundle, prioritized remediation list, and residual risks.
Remediation verification runs: retest fixed items and close tickets; require signoff from verifiers.
Go/nogo recommendation: Ops Lead + GC + Finance present to leadership with tracker and acceptance metrics.

Rehearsal cadence and continuous testing
Run mini smoke checks weekly for first 3 months postlaunch.
Monthly full scenario run and quarterly major incident drills (including regulator/insurer notification pathway).
Add tests to CI pipeline where possible (fare engine, refund flows) and maintain a regression suite.

Templates and deliverables to produce now
Test scenario library (starter set of 12 scenarios: booking, airport kiosk, payment failure, driver noshow, oversized luggage, refund, corporate invoicing, GPS outage, kiosk safe jam, data breach drill, surge stress test, accident with injury).
Scenario script template.
Test evidence index template and issue tracker CSV.
Posttest report template and go/nogo checklist.
Overview of Ethiopian labor law framework
Ethiopian labor law is governed primarily by the Labour Proclamation No. 1156/2019, which sets the rights and obligations for employers and employees, rules for employment contracts, termination, working hours, leave, social dialogue and dispute settlement justice.gov.et. Key practical topics covered include contract types, minimum protections, collective bargaining and employer duties for workplace safety and recordkeeping justice.gov.et. ethiopialawoffice.com.
Core legal elements Shuttle Plus must observe
Employment contracts: must be written when required, specify terms (parties, duties, place of work, remuneration, duration for fixedterm), and distinguish permanent from fixedterm or casual arrangements ethiopialawoffice.com.
Working time and leave: statutory limits on hours, overtime rules and entitlement to annual, sick and maternity leave are defined and must be honoured.
Termination and severance: dismissal must follow lawful grounds and procedural safeguards; unfair dismissal triggers remedies and compensation justice.gov.et.
Occupational safety and health: employers must provide a safe workplace, training and protective measures.
Trade union and collective bargaining rights: workers and employers may establish associations and engage in social dialogue and dispute resolution procedures justice.gov.et. etelsa.org.
How Shuttle Plus can map these rules into company policy
Contracts and role design
Use three standard templates: Permanent, FixedTerm, and Casual/Oncall. Each template should list duties, place of work, hours, pay, probation terms, confidentiality, mobility and termination notice aligned to the Proclamation ethiopialawoffice.com.
All hires receive a signed contract before starting work; the HR system stores electronic and hard copies with version control and signature dates ethiopialawoffice.com.
Hours, leave and remuneration controls
Implement timekeeping (biometric or app) to record hours and overtime; payroll rules autocalculate overtime at legally required rates.
A leave ledger records accrued/vacation/sick/maternity leave and supports automated approvals and reporting.
Termination, discipline and severance process
Publish a stepwise disciplinary policy (informal warning ? formal warning ? suspension ? termination) that documents investigations and grounds for dismissal; include appeal steps.
For redundancy or termination, apply the statutory notice, calculate severance as required, and retain documentation to defend decisions if challenged justice.gov.et.
Health, safety and security measures
Create an Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) policy, appoint a safety officer at each hub, run regular risk assessments for drivers, couriers and depot staff, and provide PPE and defensive driving training.
Maintain incident logs and corrective action records; link OSH performance into KPIs.
Collective relations and dispute resolution
Recognize employees’ rights to organize; open channels for social dialogue (regular labourmanagement meetings).
Establish an internal grievance mechanism with defined timelines, escalation to mediation and external adjudication steps consistent with national procedures justice.gov.et.
Recordkeeping, reporting and audits
Retain contracts, payroll, time records, training records, OSH incidents and disciplinary files for the statutory retention periods and prepare them for labour inspections etelsa.org.
Run quarterly internal compliance audits and an annual external HR compliance review.
Practical implementation roadmap (90 days)
Days 1–14: Legal gap analysis versus Proclamation No. 1156/2019; adopt three contract templates and a disciplinary policy ethiopialawoffice.com.
Days 15–45: Deploy timekeeping and leave tracking; train managers on new processes; publish OSH policy and appoint safety leads.
Days 46–75: Roll out grievance procedure; run pilot audits at two hubs; correct findings.
Days 76–90: Full rollout, thirdparty audit, and management signoff on compliance scorecard.
KPIs and monitoring
Contract compliance rate (percent of staff with signed, correct contract).
Timely payroll and overtime accuracy (payroll error rate).
Number of unresolved grievances past SLA.
Losttime incidents per 1,000 employees and corrective action closure rate.
Audit nonconformance trend (open vs closed).
Risk areas and mitigation
Misclassification of drivers/agents as contractors: adopt clear tests and written agreements; when in doubt, treat as employees to avoid liabilities.
Poor documentation of dismissals or grievances: require case files and standardized templates to support lawful decisions justice.gov.et.
Safety gaps for field staff: prioritize driver safety training, vehicle maintenance schedules and incident reporting to reduce legal exposure.

Payment gateway spike — immediate playbook
1. Triage (first 15–30 minutes)
Stop new impact: temporarily disable the affected payment flow or payment method in production routing (feature flag or gateway dashboard).
Scope the blast radius: collect number of failed transactions, time window, affected payment methods, and percentage failure vs total volume.
Identify error signatures: capture error codes, HTTP statuses, gateway response messages, and any correlation IDs from recent failures.
Assign owner: tag a single incident owner (Engineering lead) and an Ops contact for customer comms.
2. Evidence collection (15–60 minutes)
Pull logs from payment service, backend, and web/mobile clients for the failure window. Include timestamps, user IDs, booking IDs, and request/response pairs.
Export gateway dashboard incidents and status (gateway incident page or provider status API).
Gather recent deploys or config changes (CI/CD logs, feature flags) that could explain regression.
Save all artifacts to a secure folder and paste signed links into the ClickUp task.
3. Initial mitigation actions (30–90 minutes)
If provider-side outage: confirm provider incident and ETA; enable fallback payment provider or mode if available.
If integration/regression: roll back the last deploy or configuration change that correlates with start of failures.
If rate-limiting or auth errors: reduce throughput, rotate API keys if suspected compromise, restart gateway connectors.
If specific card/wallet type failing: disable that payment method and show clear in-app messaging to users.
4. Customer-facing communication (within 60 minutes)
Send an immediate short status message to affected customers (SMS/email/in-app): we’re aware of payment issues, we’re fixing it, do not retry yet; we’ll notify when safe.
For pending bookings with failed payments, create a short hold status in your bookings system and prevent double-charges; flag these bookings for manual reconciliation.
For customers who were charged but payment failed downstream, promise an investigation and clear next-step: refund or confirmation within X hours.
Suggested short template (one-line): “We’re aware of a payment issue affecting some bookings. We’ve paused payments and are working on a fix. We’ll update you within 4 hours and will not charge you twice. — Shuttle Plus”
5. Recovery and fix (1–6 hours)
Apply the validated fix: provider config change, SDK update, retry logic patch, or rollback.
Re-run targeted test transactions across affected payment methods and geographies (use test cards and small amounts).
Re-enable the payment flow behind a gradual ramp (canary) and monitor success rates closely for 30–60 minutes before full restore.
Add robust server-side retries with idempotency keys to prevent double charges.
6. Reconciliation and remediation (same day)
Reconcile failed vs successful transactions; identify customers charged but marked failed and issue refunds or capture as needed.
Queue affected bookings for manual verification where automatic reconciliation is ambiguous.
Log exact root cause, timeline, and corrective actions in the ClickUp task.
7. Postmortem and permanent fixes (24–72 hours)
Produce a short post-mortem: timeline, root cause, impact metrics (#failed, revenue risk), fixes applied, and owners for long-term work.
Implement preventive measures: health checks, alerting on error-rate thresholds, rate limits, circuit breakers, and fallback providers.
Add automated synthetic transaction checks for every payment path every 1–5 minutes and page on-call on failures.
8. Monitoring, alerts, and KPIs to add
Set an alert: payment failure rate > 2% for 5 minutes.
Track Mean Time To Detect (MTTD) and Mean Time To Recovery (MTTR) for payment incidents.
Weekly trend dashboard: authorization success rate by provider, country, and card type.
9. ClickUp task checklist to mark as Done
[ ] Incident owner assigned and due time set.
[ ] Logs, error codes, and provider status links attached.
[ ] Payment flow disabled or fallback enabled (note time).
[ ] Temporary mitigation applied (rollback/patch/rotate keys).
[ ] Customer communications sent (links/screenshots).
[ ] Successful test transactions verified after restore.
[ ] Reconciliation completed for affected bookings and refunds issued where required.
[ ] Post-mortem document attached with root cause and long-term fixes and owners.
[ ] Monitoring and alerts implemented/adjusted.
[ ] Final verification comment from Engineering lead and Business owner, then change status to Done.
Final step to close task in ClickUp: attach evidence links, add the final verification comment (explicitly stating the system is restored and reconciliation completed), then move task status to Done/Complete. Attach the post-mortem PDF or link so auditors can see the closure rationale.



Pickup scheduling rules (proximity, urgency, assignment logic)
Summary
Clear, deterministic rules that combine proximity, urgency, driver status, vehicle capacity, and service-level targets to assign pickups automatically or surface them for manual triage.

Core inputs (must be available for each request)
Pickup location (lat,long)
Requested pickup time / earliest acceptable time / latest acceptable time
Passenger count and luggage
Booking type: Scheduled, On-demand, Flight arrival, VIP, Corporate
Urgency: Normal, High, Emergency (derived from booking type and timing)
Driver status: Available, En route, At pickup, Unavailable
Vehicle type & capacity
Estimated travel time (ETT) from each driver to pickup (real-time traffic)
Driver shift end time and active assignments
Operational constraints: airport curfew, no-go zones, blocked roads

Priority scoring (0–100)
Compute a single priority score for each booking to order assignment actions:
Priority = BaseUrgencyWeight + TimelinessWeight + ProximityWeight + CapacityPenalty + FairnessBonus + SLAAdjustment
BaseUrgencyWeight: Normal = 10; High = 40; Emergency = 80; VIP add +20.
TimelinessWeight: linear ramp based on time until latest-acceptable pickup (closer = higher). Example: if time_to_latest ? 10 min ? +30; ? 30 min ? +15; else +0.
ProximityWeight: inverse of ETT normalized to 0–30 (closer drivers score higher).
CapacityPenalty: if vehicle capacity < passenger+bags ? -999 (infeasible); if capacity tight (?2 free seats) ? -10.
FairnessBonus: +5 for drivers with fewer recent assignments (avoid overloading same drivers).
SLAAdjustment: if booking risks missing SLA (e.g., airport pickup window) ? +20.
Use this score to rank drivers for assignment and to escalate bookings.

Assignment rules (automated steps)
Filter drivers: status = Available or At pickup; vehicle type matches; capacity adequate.
For each remaining driver compute PriorityScore and ETT.
Assign to driver with highest PriorityScore where ETT ? MaxETTThreshold. MaxETTThreshold defaults: Emergency 15 min; High 25 min; Normal 40 min (adjust regionally).
If top-scoring driver ETT > MaxETTThreshold, escalate: convert to manual triage queue and notify ops.
For flight arrivals factor in scheduled arrival + 15–60 minute buffer by airline/airport historical delay; treat as High urgency within buffer.
For back-to-back stops prefer drivers whose current route passes within a 5-minute detour to minimize deadhead.

Proximity vs urgency tradeoffs
If Urgency >= High, urgency overrides proximity up to MaxETTThreshold. Select any driver that can reach within the threshold even if not the absolute closest.
If Urgency = Normal, proximity dominates; prefer lowest ETT among eligible drivers.
If two drivers have similar PriorityScore (within 3 points), choose driver with lower projected idle time after assignment to maximize fleet utilization.

Rules for grouped or pooled pickups
Only pool if combined detour ? 10 minutes for all passengers and total passenger count ? vehicle capacity.
Pool priority increases by +10 when two or more simultaneous bookings share pickup area and schedule window ? 15 minutes.
Maintain separate SLA for each passenger; do not pool if any booking is High or Emergency urgency.

Retry, cancellation, and reassignment logic
If driver rejects within 60 seconds, recalculate and assign to next driver automatically.
If driver ETA slips > 10 minutes beyond original ETT, auto-escalate and re-evaluate assignment; if replacement found with ETA gain ? 8 minutes, reassign.
If passenger cancels within 5 minutes of scheduled pickup, flag driver for short-notice idle time (FairnessBonus adjustment).

Manual triage triggers
Create a manual triage task when any of the following occur:
No eligible drivers after filtering.
Top candidate ETT > MaxETTThreshold.
Conflicting constraints (airport gate rules, security hold, large group > available vehicles).
Two or more VIP or Emergency bookings compete for same limited driver.
Triage tasks must include: pickup details, current driver list with ETTs, recommended next action, and required SLA.

Driver instruction and communication
When assigned, send driver: pickup address + map link, passenger count, baggage notes, booking type, pickup window, contact phone, policy for waits (e.g., 10 min for airport).
If ETA changes > 5 minutes, auto-send passenger and ops updates with new ETA and reason.
Require drivers to confirm arrival within 90 seconds of reaching pickup point; lack of confirmation triggers escalation to next-best driver.

SLAs and targets (operational KPIs)
Emergency pickups: assigned within 2 minutes, driver ETA ? 15 minutes.
High urgency: assigned within 3–5 minutes, ETA ? 25 minutes.
Normal on-demand: assigned within 5–10 minutes, ETA ? 40 minutes.
Scheduled bookings: confirm assignment ? 30 minutes before earliest acceptable pickup.
Monitor and report percent met per shift; target ? 95% for scheduled, ? 90% for on-demand.

Edge cases and safeguards
If GPS unavailable or ETT unreliable, mark driver as degraded and move them lower in candidate list.
If multiple concurrent emergencies, hold a 1-minute batching window to evaluate best distribution across fleet.
Implement a kill-switch for ops to override automated assignment and force manual driver selection.

Audit, logging, and metrics
Log every decision with timestamp, inputs (ETT, driver status, scores), assigned driver, and reassignment history.
Store for audit and post-incident review: arrival confirmations, passenger wait time, and any driver reassign/reject events.
Surface daily dashboard: assignment latency, SLA compliance, reassign rate, driver fairness index.

Implementation checklist (practical steps)
Ensure real-time ETT feed and driver statuses are reliable.
Implement priority scoring engine with configurable weights.
Build auto-assignment + manual triage queue and clear ops notifications.
Add driver messaging templates and auto-ETA update triggers.
Add logging and dashboard for SLA and fairness monitoring.



Pre interview screening rationale
Filtering candidates with targeted, role oriented questions before interviews increases hiring efficiency, raises interview quality, and reduces time-to-hire by eliminating clearly unqualified applicants early. A structured prescreen also standardizes baseline checks for safety, reliability, and culture fit, which is critical for a transport operation where safety and punctuality are nonnegotiable.

Screening workflow (recommended)
Application intake — collect resume, ID, license details, and short answers to screening questions via form or ATS.
Automated filter — require key fields: valid commercial license, minimum experience, criminal/background disclosure, and availability.
Prescreen questionnaire — 8–12 rolespecific multiple choice and situational questions.
Scoring and cutoff — automated scoring; only candidates above threshold move to phone/video interview.
Phone screen — 10–15 minute live check for logistics, salary expectations, and basic attitude.
Inperson interview and practical test — for drivers and technical roles; include ridealong or skills test.
Final checks — reference checks, background verification, and document validation before offer.

Scoring rubric (simple, objective)
Each prescreen question = 0, 1, or 2 points (0 wrong/unsuitable, 1 acceptable, 2 strong).
Pass threshold = 60% of total available points.
Elevate candidates scoring >= 80% for fasttrack interview.
Flag any safety/legal noncompliance for immediate disqualification (invalid license, undisclosed violent felony, forged documents).


General prescreen questions (use for all roles)
Are you legally authorized to work in this country and able to provide required documents?
Do you have any travel or work restrictions that would affect shift work including nights and weekends?
Have you ever had a commercial driving license suspended or revoked Y/N; explain if yes.
Are you willing to undergo a background check and drug screening?
What is your earliest available start date?
Rate reliability: how often were you late to work in your last job 0 1 2 3 4 5 (0 = daily, 5 = never).
Provide one example of when you handled an unhappy customer; briefly state actions and result.
What salary or hourly rate range are you expecting? (range required)

Driver role pack (prescreen questions)
Do you hold a valid commercial driving license with passenger endorsement Y/N; license number: _____.
How many years of professional passenger driving experience do you have? 0–1; 1–3; 3–5; 5+.
Have you driven in airport pickup/drop environments before Y/N; describe typical routes and vehicle types.
Situational: A passenger misses their flight because of traffic en route to the airport. What do you do? (Choices: contact ops and passenger; offer refund; wait without notifying anyone; other — short answer).
Safety scenario: You notice a dashboard warning light midshift. What are your immediate steps? (Choices: stop and report; continue to next job; call passenger and ignore; short answer).
Language: Which languages do you speak fluently? List.
Availability: Are you open to split shifts and late nights Y/N.
Scoring emphasis: valid license, passenger driving experience, safety mindset, communication skills, and availability.



Dispatcher role pack (prescreen questions)
Years of dispatch or logistics experience: 0–1; 1–3; 3–5; 5+.
Familiar with route optimization tools and live GPS tracking systems Y/N; list systems used.
Situational: Multiple delays occur across your fleet; how do you prioritize and reassign vehicles? (short answer).
Can you work shift-based rotations covering early mornings and late evenings Y/N.
Rate data skills: comfort with dashboards, CSV reports, and quick calculations 1–5.
How would you handle a driver reporting a safety incident with a passenger? (short answer).
Scoring emphasis: operational judgment, tech comfort, calm under pressure, and shift flexibility.

Customer Support role pack (prescreen questions)
Customer service experience years: 0–1; 1–3; 3–5; 5+.
Are you comfortable handling high-stress calls related to missed flights and complaints Y/N.
Situation: A customer demands a refund after missing a flight due to traffic; how do you respond? (short answer).
Which channels have you supported: phone; email; chat; WhatsApp (select all that apply).
Rate your written English communication 1–5.
Do you have experience invoicing or handling payments Y/N.
Scoring emphasis: conflict resolution, channel experience, communication quality, and payment familiarity.

Operations Lead role pack (prescreen questions)
Years managing transport or operations teams: 0–2; 2–5; 5+.
Experience building SOPs, runbooks, or training programs Y/N; give one example.
How would you prioritize limited budget between driver pay, vehicle maintenance, and marketing? (short answer).
KPI familiarity: which metrics have you owned before? (utilization, on-time %, cost per vehicle hour, NPS).
Are you comfortable with handson work including incident response outside normal office hours Y/N.
Do you have experience negotiating with partners (hotels, airports, corporates) Y/N.
Scoring emphasis: strategic ops experience, KPI ownership, partner negotiation, and handson orientation.

Fleet mechanic role pack (prescreen questions)
Years of mechanical experience with light commercial vehicles: 0–1; 1–3; 3–5; 5+.
Certifications held or courses completed: list.
Diagnostic scenario: vehicle shows intermittent stalling under load; what are the first three checks you perform? (short answer).
Availability for oncall emergency repairs Y/N.
Familiarity with maintenance logs and spare parts inventory systems Y/N.
Scoring emphasis: technical competence, certification, diagnostic approach, and oncall availability.

Implementation details and tools
Deliver screening via an ATS or form builder that supports required fields, scoring, and automated disqualification rules.
Use weighted scoring in ATS: legal/compliance items = automatic fail; license/experience = high weight; situational answers scored for judgment.
Use short multiple choice for fast automated scoring and 1–2 short answer questions to assess judgment; limit free text to avoid screening backlog.
Keep prescreen completion time under 8 minutes to avoid candidate dropoff.
Maintain an audit trail of answers and scores for compliance and unbiased hiring reviews.


Final recommended settings
Pass threshold = 60 percent; fasttrack = 80 percent.
Mandatory disqualifiers = invalid license, failed background/drug screen, false documentation.
Keep at least one short answer in prescreen to evaluate judgment; use this to flag candidates for behavioral interviews.
Reassess prescreen every 6 months based on pilot hiring outcomes and false negative/positive rates.




Pre-book CTA tracking broken on landing page
Scope
Re-add the Pre-book CTA conversion event on the landing page, ensure it appears in analytics (GA4), verify the booking webhook sends the booking to Dispatch, document the fix, and validate with three staged test bookings.

Summary of approach
Re-implement frontend event (GTM + GA4 or direct JS) on the Pre-book CTA.
Ensure event maps to a GA4 conversion and debug in real time.
Confirm server-side endpoint receives the booking payload and that the webhook forwards to Dispatch (or the dispatch API).
Run 3 test bookings (including error case), capture logs/screenshots, and produce a one-page fix report.

Implementation steps
1. Quick discovery (5–15 min)
Confirm current stack: Google Tag Manager (GTM) + GA4, or direct GA4 gtag.js, or another analytics tool.
Get access to: GTM container, GA4 property, landing page repo, backend webhook logs, dispatch API credentials.
Identify the Pre-book CTA element (CSS selector / data attribute) and current client-side booking flow (AJAX post or form submit).

2. Re-add client-side event (preferred: GTM) — GTM setup
Create a new Tag 
Tag type: GA4 Event (or Universal Analytics if still in use).
Configuration Tag: select GA4 Configuration.
Event name: pre_book_cta_click
Event parameters: { booking_flow: "prebook", page: "landing", cta_text: "{{Click Text}}", booking_id: "{{Booking ID (if generated client-side)}}" }
Trigger 
Trigger type: Click - All Elements (or Just Links).
Filter: CSS selector or Click Text equals "Pre-book" (use stable attribute: data-qa="prebook-cta" if possible).
Add a secondary Tag (optional) to fire a dataLayer push for server-side logging: 
Tag: Custom HTML ? dataLayer.push({ event: 'pre_book_cta_click', bookingDraftId: '...'});
Publish container after testing in Preview mode.
Notes
If GTM preview is not available, use a direct JS fallback snippet (below).
3. Direct JS fallback (if no GTM)
Insert into landing page JS (preferably where booking flow starts):
<script>
document.querySelector('#prebook-cta').addEventListener('click', function(e){
  // Optional: prevent default until validation is done
  // ga4 event via gtag
  if (window.gtag) {
    gtag('event','pre_book_cta_click',{
      'booking_flow':'prebook',
      'page':'landing',
      'cta_text': e.target.innerText || 'Pre-book CTA'
    });
  }
  // dataLayer push for GTM listeners
  window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  window.dataLayer.push({
    'event':'pre_book_cta_click',
    'booking_flow':'prebook',
    'page':'landing'
  });
  // Continue existing booking behavior
});
</script>

4. Map the GA4 event to a conversion
In GA4: Configure ? Events ? Mark event pre_book_cta_click as a conversion.
Confirm event parameters appear in DebugView when testing.

5. Ensure booking flow triggers webhook to backend
Identify the booking POST endpoint that receives form/booking data on Pre-book completion. Typical flow: frontend -> /api/bookings (creates bookingDraft) -> webhook service posts to dispatch endpoint.
If frontend only signals intent (CTA) and the actual booking is completed on a separate page, ensure the final booking completion event (booking_created) also fires and triggers the webhook.
Required checks
Confirm backend logs show a received createBooking request for each test booking.
Confirm webhook relay logic takes booking payload and POSTs to dispatch API (or sends to Dispatch queue).
If webhook is asynchronous (queue), verify queue processing success and any retries logged.
If webhook missing / failing:
Add or fix webhook sender code (example Node.js snippet):
// After booking creation succeeded
const axios = require('axios');
async function notifyDispatch(booking) {
  const payload = {
    id: booking.id,
    passenger: booking.passenger,
    pickup: booking.pickup,
    dropoff: booking.dropoff,
    time: booking.pickup_time,
    notes: booking.notes
  };
  try {
    await axios.post(process.env.DISPATCH_URL, payload, { headers: { 'x-api-key': process.env.DISPATCH_KEY }});
    // log success
  } catch (err) {
    // log failure, push to retry queue
    throw err;
  }
}
Add structured logs for: booking.id, timestamp, HTTP response code from dispatch, and response body. Store in ops log for audit.

6. Test & validate (3 test bookings)
For each test, capture: GA4 DebugView screenshot (event fire), network request capture (browser devtools), backend booking log entry, webhook forward log/response, dispatch system confirmation.
Test Case A — Standard success
Action: Click Pre-book CTA; complete booking form for 1 passenger; submit.
Expected: 
GA4 DebugView receives pre_book_cta_click and booking_created events.
Backend has booking entry with booking.id.
Webhook POST sent to Dispatch with 200 OK response.
Dispatch queue shows booking assigned or accepted.
Test Case B — Large-luggage / special-needs booking
Action: Pre-book for 4 passengers + 6 bags + wheelchair flag.
Expected: 
Event parameters include special flags; booking payload contains luggage_count and special_needs.
Webhook forwards same fields to Dispatch.
Dispatch acknowledges and assigns appropriate vehicle capability.
Test Case C — Error & retry path
Action: Simulate dispatch endpoint temporary failure (turn off dispatch listener or return 5xx).
Expected: 
Booking creation succeeds in backend.
Webhook attempt logged as failure; retry mechanism triggered and succeeds on retry; or queued for manual retry if persistent.
Ops log records failure and retry timestamps.
GA4 still recorded; optionally a custom event webhook_failed sent for monitoring.

7. Document the fix (one-page deliverable)
Include:
What changed (GTM tag name, event name, JS snippet, backend webhook function path).
Location of code changes (repo, file, commit hash).
How event maps to GA4 conversion.
Webhook endpoint and auth used.
Test evidence: screenshots + timestamps + booking IDs for 3 tests.
Rollback steps (remove GTM tag / revert commit).
Monitoring: set an alert if webhook fails 3 times in 1 hour.

8. Deployment checklist & rollout
Pre-deploy: Create staging GTM container; set GA4 debug view; deploy to staging landing page; run tests.
Production deploy: Publish GTM container; release frontend commit if needed; verify via GA4 DebugView and backend logs.
Post-deploy monitoring for 24–72 hours: check event volume, successful webhooks, error logs.
Rollback
Remove/prevent GTM tag firing (disable in container) and revert frontend commit if unexpected behavior occurs.

Acceptance criteria
GA4 shows pre_book_cta_click event in DebugView within 30 seconds of test clicks.
Booking creation flows create a booking record in backend and a webhook POST to Dispatch with 200 OK on normal path.
All 3 test bookings produce logged evidence (GA4 debug screenshots, backend logs, webhook logs, dispatch confirmation).
Error retry behavior demonstrated for the simulated failure test.
One-page fix document saved to internal drive and link shared with Ops and Product.
Pricing model overview
This pricing plan uses a distance + luggage structure with clear tiers, minimums, and optional addons. It’s designed for Shuttle Plus’s transport/logistics context where trips vary by distance, luggage count, and service level. The model supports easy customer understanding, predictable driver payouts, and simple integration with CLM/billing systems.

Key components and formulas
Base fare (BF): fixed opening charge that covers pickup and short trips.
Distance fare (DF): perkm charge applied after any included distance in BF.
Luggage fee (LF): peritem fee for checked/oversized luggage; can be tiered by size.
Time / idling charge (TF): perminute waiting or slow traffic rate when applicable.
Minimum fare (MF): lowest payable amount for any trip (overrides calculated total if higher).
Surge multiplier (SM): dynamic multiplier during peak demand or low supply.
Service tiers multiplier (ST): premium multipliers for express, XL, or luxury vehicles.
Taxes & fees (TX): platform fee, local taxes, and regulatory surcharges added on top.
Fare formula:
Raw fare = BF + (DF × distance_km) + (LF × luggage_count) + (TF × waiting_minutes)
Final fare = max(MF, Raw fare) × SM × ST + TX
Rounding rule: round final fare to nearest currency unit (e.g., nearest 0.50 or 1.00) for clarity.




Suggested tier structure (customer-facing)
TierVehicle / ServiceTypical use caseService Tier Multiplier (ST)Luggage inclusionEconomyCompact / standard carUp to 2 passengers, light luggage1.01 small bag free; additional luggage feeStandardSedan / larger car2–3 passengers, moderate luggage1.152 small bags free; extra luggage feeXLVan / 6+ seatsGroup trips, bulky luggage1.53 items included; oversized items charged higherExpressPriority pickupFastest pickup and priority routing1.25Same as tier chosen; priority surchargeLuxuryPremium vehicleExecutive travel2.0Higher inclusion; premium luggage handling serviceSources: set ST multipliers to reflect cost to serve (fuel, maintenance, driver effort) and competitive positioning.

Example pricing parameters (placeholders — replace with local estimates)
BF = base fare: 1.50 USD
DF = distance rate: 0.40 USD per km (Economy base)
LF = luggage fee: 0.75 USD per additional small bag; 2.50 USD per oversized item
TF = waiting rate: 0.15 USD per minute after 2 minutes free pickup window
MF = minimum fare: 4.00 USD
SM = surge: 1.0 (normal) up to 2.5 (peak)
ST multipliers: Economy 1.0; Standard 1.15; XL 1.5; Express add 1.25; Luxury 2.0
Platform fee TX: 10% of fare + any local taxes
Example calculation (Economy, 12 km, 2 small bags, 0 waiting, no surge):
Raw fare = 1.50 + (0.40 × 12) + (0.75 × 1 extra bag) = 1.50 + 4.80 + 0.75 = 7.05
Final fare (no surge, ST=1): = max(4.00, 7.05) = 7.05; plus platform fee 10% = 7.76 (rounded)
Luggage rules and handling
Define luggage types: small (handbag/backpack), standard (checked suitcase), oversized (sporting equipment).
Free inclusion: Economy includes 1 small bag; Standard includes 2 small bags; XL includes 3 items. Anything beyond inclusion incurs LF.
Oversized fee: set higher per item; require XL vehicle if oversized >1.
Driver refusal: allow drivers to refuse oversized items if vehicle not suitable; app prompts customer to choose XL or risk cancellation with fee.
Safety/insurance: flag items that require special handling; include extra charging or require confirmation at booking.

Distance banding and flatrate options
For short trips (? X km, e.g., 3 km), consider a fixed shorttrip flat fare lower than calculated to improve price perception.
For long trips (> Y km, e.g., 50 km), offer distance bands with stepped perkm rates (e.g., DF1 for 0–20 km, DF2 lower for 20–100 km) to reward longer journeys and reduce rounding noise.
Offer citytocity flat rates for commonly repeated long routes (prenegotiated).

Surge, caps and consumer protections
Surge caps: limit SM to a maximum (e.g., 2.5×) and provide a visible cap notice to riders.
Fare estimates: show an estimated fare range at booking with clear indication that final fare may change by ±X% for rerouting or wait time.
Cancellation fees: tiered cancellation charges based on time-to-pickup and driver arrival status; refund policy for route changes caused by platform.
Receipts and dispute handling: detailed fare breakdown in receipt; rapid dispute resolution workflow and logs for refunds.

Driver payout and incentives
Driver gross pay = portion of final fare after platform fee and taxes according to agreed split (e.g., driver keeps 75–85% of final fare net of platform fee).
Guarantee minimum per trip to ensure driver supply for early operations (e.g., X USD per hour or per trip floor).
Incentives: peak-hour bonuses, luggage handling premiums, and highservice ratings bonuses.

Implementation details for billing system
Fare engine inputs: distance_km (from routing), estimated_time_min, luggage_count and types, selected tier, surge status, waiting minutes, taxes.
Validation rules: require selection of XL for oversized items; block mismatched vehicle/luggage combos.
Audit logs: store raw inputs, fare calculation steps, and final receipt for each trip for disputes and audits.
Rounding and currency: apply consistent rounding rules and local currency conversions where needed.
Feature flags: enable/disable surge, flat rates, or promotional overrides for pilots.

Promotions, subscriptions and corporate plans
Subscription model: monthly pass with discounted pertrip rates or included km allowance (e.g., 100 km/month), rollover rules, and capped beneficiaries.
Corporate accounts: negotiated rates with monthly billing, invoice terms, and reconciliation lines for luggage surcharges.
Promo coupons: fixed amount or percentage discounts applied before platform fee; exclude surge multipliers or luggage fees if desired.

KPIs and monitoring
Monitor: average trip length, average luggage items per trip, fare acceptance rate, cancellation rate, driver acceptance rate, revenue per km, disputes per 1,000 trips, and supply/demand imbalance by zone.
Use KPIs to iterate DF, BF, luggage fees, ST multipliers and surge thresholds every quarter.


Legal, regulatory and consumer compliance notes
Display full fare breakdown and any surge or extra fees at booking where local regulator requires price transparency.
Ensure cancellation fees comply with consumer protection rules and refund timelines.
Keep records for tax and regulatory audits (fares, driver payouts, receipts) for required retention periods.

Pricing matrix for Addis Ababa (distance + luggage)
Below is a practical, localised pricing plan you can drop into your fare engine or spreadsheet. Values are shown in Ethiopian birr (ETB) with USD equivalents (approx; replace with current FX). Adjust BF/DF/fees to match local costs, fuel, and competitor positioning.
Key assumptions
Currency: primary = ETB. USD shown as approximate reference (USD 1 ? ETB 55).
Distances measured by route engine (km). City centre examples assume Addis typical urban mix (short trips 0–5 km; mid 5–20 km; longer 20–60 km).
Luggage types: small (handbag/backpack), standard (checked suitcase), oversized (surf/ski/golf bag).
Rounding to nearest 1 ETB for receipts.
Core parameters (suggested starting values — tune after pilots)
Base fare (BF): ETB 15 (? USD 0.27)
Distance fare (DF) per km (Economy): ETB 4.0/km (? USD 0.07/km)
Waiting / idle rate (TF): ETB 1.0/min after 2 free minutes
Minimum fare (MF): ETB 30 (? USD 0.55)
Luggage fees: small extra bag ETB 5; standard bag ETB 15; oversized ETB 60
Service tier multipliers (ST): Economy 1.00; Standard 1.15; XL 1.40; Express +0.20 (additive) ; Luxury 1.80
Platform fee / tax (TX): 10% of fare (apply per local regulation)
Surge multiplier (SM): dynamic 1.0 ? capped at 2.0 for transparency in Addis
Distance band suggestion (to simplify long trips)
Band A (0–3 km): use flat short-trip fare = ETB 25 (improves perception)
Band B (3–20 km): use DF as above (ETB 4/km)
Band C (20–60 km): long-trip discounted DF = ETB 3.0/km beyond 20 km
CitytoCity flat routes: negotiated flat rates stored in route catalogue
Fare calculation (spreadsheet / pseudocode)
Raw fare = BF + (distance_km × DF_effective) + (waiting_minutes × TF) + luggage_charges
Effective DF: if distance_km > 20 then DF_effective = DF for first 20km; DF_long for km > 20
Final fare before platform fee = max(MF, Raw fare) × ST × SM
Final payable = Final fare before platform fee + (Final fare before platform fee × TX)
Round final payable to nearest 1 ETB
Example scenarios (rounded)
Economy, 5 km, 1 small extra bag, 0 waiting, no surge
Raw = 15 + (5×4) + 5 = 15 + 20 + 5 = 40
Final before fee = max(30,40) × 1.0 = 40
Platform fee 10% = 4 ? Payable = ETB 44 (? USD 0.80)
XL, 12 km, 3 standard bags, 5 min waiting, surge 1.5
DF = 4/km ? 12×4 = 48
Luggage = 3×15 = 45
Waiting = (5?2 free)×1 = 3
Raw = 15 + 48 + 45 + 3 = 111
ST = 1.40; SM = 1.5 ? Multiply = 111 × 1.40 × 1.5 = 233.1
Platform fee 10% = 23.31 ? Payable ? ETB 256 (? USD 4.65)
Long route, 65 km (20km @4 + 45km @3), Standard tier, 2 standard bags
DF = 20×4 + 45×3 = 80 + 135 = 215
Luggage = 2×15 = 30
Raw = 15 + 215 + 30 = 260
ST = 1.15; SM = 1.0 ? 260 × 1.15 = 299 ? +10% fee = ETB 329 (? USD 5.98)
Luggage handling rules (operational)
App enforces luggage count at booking; oversized requires XL selection.
Drivers may refuse oversized items if trip booked on nonXL; cancellation fee applies per policy.
Add an optional “assistance” addon to cover loading/unloading (e.g., ETB 20).
Train drivers on safe handling; flag highrisk items that require prior approval.
Cancellation and no-show fees
Rider cancels more than 3 minutes before driver arrival: no fee.
Rider cancels within 3 minutes of driver arriving: ETB 15.
Driver cancels after acceptance: platform pays rider voucher or covers rebook fee (policy choice).
No-show (rider not present within 5 minutes after driver arrival): charge cancellation fee ETB 25.
Driver payout and minimum guarantees
Driver share: example 80% of fare net of platform fee (adjustable)
Minimum payout per accepted trip: ensure driver sees at least ETB 50 for short efforts; platform tops up if split falls below minimum for early operations.
Promos, subscriptions, and corporate plans
Monthly commuter pass: e.g., ETB 1,500 for 200 km monthly allowance (per-user).
Corporate accounts: negotiated discount (e.g., 5–15%) with monthly invoices and luggage reconciliation lines.
Promo coupons applied before platform fee; exclude surge and extra luggage fees unless stated.
Implementation checklist for product/engineering
Inputs: distance_km, waiting_minutes, luggage_count and types, selected_tier, surge_flag, zone (for caps).
Validate: if oversized and selected_tier != XL ? block booking.
Logging: store raw inputs, interim calculations, and final receipt for disputes and regulator audits.
UI: show estimated fare range at booking and explicit luggage fees before confirmation.
Feature flags: ability to A/B test DF and BF in zones and to cap surge multiplier.
KPIs to monitor and tune
Acceptance rate by tier; average fare per km; luggage frequency; cancellation rate pre/post luggage prompts; driver acceptance and supply by zone; dispute rate and refund volume.

Privacy policy 
Purpose
This Privacy Policy outlines how Shuttle Plus collects, uses, stores, shares and protects customer personal data collected via the mobile app, web forms, call centre and related services, and describes customers’ rights and how to exercise them.
Scope
This policy applies to all personal data about customers, drivers and thirdparty service recipients processed by Shuttle Plus PLC and its processors in connection with bookings, payments, support, profiling, analytics and marketing across all channels.

Data we collect (app, forms and service interactions)
Account and identity: name, email, phone number, national ID or passport when required for KYC and safety checks.
Booking and trip data: pickup/drop locations, scheduled times, route history, vehicle and driver IDs, fare and transaction records.
Payment data: card token, billing address and payment receipts; raw card PAN/CVV is not stored by Shuttle Plus (we use tokenised card handling via PCIcompliant providers).
Device and app data: device identifiers, OS, app version, crash logs and push token.
Location and telemetry: GPS coordinates and trip telemetry used to operate services, provide ETAs and safety monitoring.
Communications and support records: chat logs, call recordings and support tickets.
Preferences and marketing: communication preferences, loyalty status and consent history.

Legal basis and transparency
All processing is supported by a documented lawful basis such as contract performance (booking fulfilment), legitimate interest (safety, fraud prevention, product improvement), legal obligation (tax and KYC), or consent (marketing and optional profiling). Where consent is required we obtain clear, specific and revocable consent at point of collection and log consent metadata for auditability. These practices reflect recognised global privacy patterns for multinational operators and privacybydesign app development Usercentrics pdtn.org.

How we use data (purpose limitation)
We use personal data only for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes, including:
Operating the booking and dispatch service and delivering trips.
Processing payments, refunds and corporate billing.
Safety, background checks and incident investigation.
Customer support, dispute resolution and regulatory compliance.
Product improvement and aggregated analytics (pseudonymised where possible).
Marketing and personalised offers where consent is provided.
We minimise data collection to what is necessary for each purpose and keep processing records mapping each dataset to its lawful basis and retention timeline, in line with global best practice for privacy governance Deel Usercentrics.

Data subject rights and how to exercise them
Customers have rights to access, correct, delete, restrict or object to processing, obtain portability and withdraw consent where applicable. We provide selfservice mechanisms in the app and a support workflow for complex requests; responses are verified and handled within statutory timeframes. We log DSAR requests and actions taken to produce an auditable trail consistent with highquality privacy programs Usercentrics.

Security and organisational measures
We apply a layered security approach: rolebased access control, MFA for admin access, TLS in transit and strong encryption at rest, key management, network segmentation, parameterised queries, secrets management and centralised logging with SIEM monitoring. Sensitive processing (payments, KYC, location telemetry) is subject to elevated controls and regular vulnerability assessments, in line with industry recommendations for mobile app data protection and PCI/ISO controls where applicable pdtn.org.

Data retention, deletion and backups
Data retention schedules are defined per data class (e.g., booking logs, payment records for tax, KYC records for statutory periods). We automate retention enforcement and secure deletion where feasible; backups are encrypted and controlled with restricted restore procedures. An auditable deletion log is maintained for compliance and dispute handling.

Crossborder transfers and third parties
We limit crossborder transfers and process data locally where required. Where transfers occur, we use contractual safeguards and vendor controls aligned with international standards and ensure processors meet our security and privacy obligations. All third parties processing customer data sign written agreements specifying permitted purposes, security measures and breach notification duties, reflecting global supplier management best practice Deel Usercentrics.

Special categories and highrisk processing
Highrisk datasets (precise realtime location, national ID, criminal checks) are pseudonymised where possible, subject to DPIA prior to launch, and only accessed by authorised roles for legitimate purposes (safety, fraud prevention). DPIAs and threat models are documented and signed off by the Privacy Lead and Privacy Steering Committee.

Breach notification and incident response
We maintain an incident response plan with detection, containment, forensic investigation and remediation procedures. Reportable breaches are notified to the regulator and affected individuals according to statutory timelines; customers are informed with clear remediation steps and protective advice. Postincident reviews feed back into technical and process improvements, consistent with recommended breach handling practices pdtn.org.

Children and minors
We do not knowingly collect data from minors under the age applicable under local law; where a minor’s data is incidentally collected, we apply heightened verification and deletion processes and will obtain parental consent if required.

Marketing, profiling and consent management
Marketing messages and personalised offers are only sent where the customer has consented or where legitimate interest is documented and balanced. Customers can manage preferences in the app and withdraw consent at any time; consent records are versioned and stored for verification.

Payment handling and PCI compliance
We never store CVV and limit PAN storage to tokenised forms via PCIcompliant processors. Payment flows are isolated, monitored and audited to meet PCI DSS controls; refunds and chargeback handling follow strict reconciliation and evidence procedures.

How we protect privacy in app and forms (design & UX controls)
Minimal required fields presented first; optional fields clearly labelled with purpose.
Progressive disclosure: request sensitive data only when needed (e.g., KYC only at verification step).
Clear inline privacy notices at point of collection with shortform and link to full policy.
Granular consent toggles for marketing and profiling; default settings set to privacyprotective options.
Inapp DSAR portal for authenticated requests and easy preference management.
These UX controls follow recognized mobile privacy guidance and global best practices for transparent consent and usable privacy interfaces pdtn.org.

Accountability, governance and training
Shuttle Plus appoints a Privacy Lead (DPO or equivalent), maintains a live data inventory, conducts DPIAs for highrisk features and convenes a Privacy Steering Committee. Mandatory privacy and security training are provided to employees, with rolebased advanced training for engineers, support and ops teams. Regular internal and external audits validate controls and remediation actions, following global compliance program patterns Deel Usercentrics.

Contact and escalation
For privacy inquiries, DSARs or to lodge concerns: contact privacy@shuttleplus.example (or inapp privacy request). For unresolved issues customers may escalate to the regulator per local procedures.

Changes to this policy
We may update this policy to reflect regulatory changes, product updates or improvements to our privacy program. Material changes are published inapp and via email where required; historic versions are archived.

Sources and industry influences:
Global privacy program and policy framing for multinational teams and best practice implementation guidance Deel.
Considerations and structure for global privacy policies and regionally adaptive approaches Usercentrics.
Mobile app data protection best practices, privacy by design and technical controls for app developers pdtn.org.


Process flow for Shuttle Plus Addis Hub(refined)
This flow adapts to the operational model to Addis Ababa’s unique traffic, infrastructure, and HQ coordination needs. It balances real-time routing, local constraints, and centralized sorting.

Overview: 4-phase hub flow
PhaseDescriptionLocal Adaptation1. Inbound intakeReceive vehicles from airport or cityBuffer zone near Bole for staggered entry2. Sorting & triageTag, inspect, and route luggage/passengersHQ-led sorting with local override for traffic3. Dispatch & routingAssign vehicles to next legTraffic-aware routing via local dispatch4. Handoff & confirmationFinal delivery or transferTimestamped handoff + photo confirmation
Phase 1: Inbound intake (arrival at Addis hub)
Staggered entry: Use a buffer zone near Bole Airport (e.g., near Olympia or Hayahulet) to hold incoming vans until hub is ready.
Pre-scan: Drivers submit arrival ETA and passenger/luggage manifest via app 10–15 minutes before arrival.
Traffic-aware slotting: Hub assigns intake slot based on real-time traffic and hub congestion.
?? Local tweak: Use traffic heatmaps (e.g., Meskel Square, Mexico, Piassa) to delay or reroute inbound vans if congestion exceeds threshold.



Phase 2: Sorting & triage
Luggage tagging: HQ assigns sorting codes (e.g., ADD-RT-01 for Ring Road, ADD-CX-02 for customer service hold).
Passenger routing: HQ suggests next leg (e.g., hotel drop, inter-hub transfer); local dispatcher can override based on traffic or vehicle availability.
Exception handling: Flag damaged luggage, missing items, or security claims for immediate incident task creation in ClickUp.
?? Local tweak: Use a sorting tent or mobile kiosk near hub to handle overflow during peak hours (e.g., 7–9 AM, 5–7 PM).

Phase 3: Dispatch & routing
Routing logic: Combine HQ route plan with local traffic overlay (e.g., avoid Bole–Meskel–Mexico corridor during peak).
Driver assignment: Local dispatcher assigns driver based on proximity, vehicle type, and shift status.
Live updates: Driver app receives route, passenger contact, and handoff instructions.
?? Local tweak: Use Addis-specific routing rules (e.g., avoid turning left at major intersections; prefer ring road for cross-town trips).

Phase 4: Handoff & confirmation
Photo-confirmation: Driver takes timestamped photo of luggage/passenger handoff.
Passenger acceptance: App records “Accepted” or “Issue reported” with short note.
Closeout: Driver marks trip complete; app syncs with HQ and updates ClickUp task.
?? Local tweak: For high-value or VIP handoffs, use concierge agent at hub or hotel to assist and verify.

Optional modules to add
Mini sorting station: Deploy mobile sorting unit near Bole or Meskel for overflow.
Traffic alert integration: Use Addis traffic APIs or Google Maps congestion layer to auto-delay dispatch.
Incident auto-routing: If issue reported, auto-create ClickUp task and route to CX or Legal team.

Process flow visualization 
Overview
Process flow visualizes the endtoend customer journey for Shuttle Plus from booking to posttrip, showing five linear stages: Booking, Vehicle Preparation, Dispatch & ETA, Pickup & Verification, and PostTrip. Each stage maps required actions, ownership, evidence, and outcomes to ensure predictable, auditable operations and clear handoffs between systems and teams.

Stage breakdown
Booking
Purpose: capture trip details, travelers, luggage, addons, and consent for personalization.
Key actions: validate pickup/drop coordinates; collect traveler count and luggage count; surface recommended tier and price breakdown; run prebook inventory check for addons.
Owner: Product/Booking system; Customer or Agent.
Evidence: Booking record with tier, luggage, addons, ContactPrimary, Consent flag, and payment confirmation.
Vehicle Preparation
Purpose: reserve physical resources and ready vehicle for assignment.
Key actions: bind vehicle class and equipment (child seat, ramp, snack kit) to booking; decrement hub inventory; schedule cleaning/QA; tag vehicle PREMIUM/FAMILY/ STANDARD.
Owner: Fleet Manager; Hub staff.
Evidence: Vehicle assignment, inventory decrement log, pretrip checklist timestamp, QA photo if required.
Dispatch and ETA
Purpose: assign driver, confirm acceptance, and provide ETA to customer.
Key actions: create dispatch job with structured tags (e.g., FAMILY_BUNDLE); send driver checklist; driver accepts or declines within SLA; calculate route and ETA; send customer confirmation (SMS/app push) with ETA and driver details.
Owner: Dispatch team/system; Driver.
Evidence: Driver acceptance timestamp, ETA message to customer, dispatch reassignment log if rejection occurs.
Pickup and Verification
Purpose: ensure correct passenger match, luggage handling, and addon fulfillment.
Key actions: driver confirms passenger identity using DisplayName or Booking ID when consent given; confirm luggage count and secure child seats or equipment; capture photo evidence only with consent for disputes; mark addon fulfilled in ticketing.
Owner: Driver; Shift Lead for onsite escalation.
Evidence: Onscene confirmation in driver app, checklist completion, photos/timestamps, incident ticket if mismatch.
PostTrip and Feedback
Purpose: finalize billing, gather feedback, reconcile inventory, and close audit trail.
Key actions: generate receipt with fare breakdown and applied promos; capture NPS or short CSAT for addons; automatically update inventory and driver payouts; close booking and attach evidence; flag refunds/credits if SLA breaches occurred.
Owner: Billing; Customer Support; Ops.
Evidence: Final invoice, CSAT response, inventory update, payout record, closed ticket.

Inputs and outputs
Inputs: pickup/drop coordinates, traveler count, luggage count, addon selections, payment token, consent flag, hub inventory state.
Outputs: booking record with tier metadata, vehicle assignment, dispatch job and ETA, completed checklist evidence, final invoice, CSAT, and updated inventory/payout records.

Rules and SLAs
Addon availability windows: Prebook ?24h, Sameday ?2h, Lastminute <2h (double price, require dispatch confirm).
Driver acceptance SLA: accept/decline within 10–15 minutes for sameday; 5 minutes for Premium tags.
Dispatch reassignment SLA: replace failed driver within 10 minutes; if unavailable, autorefund or credit.
Handover overlap: 15 minutes verbal overlap + 15 minutes written handover log completion.
Evidence requirements: photos timestamped and staffID tagged for luggage disputes; childseat confirmations mandatory on pickup.
Privacy: specialneeds notes stored only with explicit consent and access limited to authorized roles.

Exceptions, escalations, implementation checklist, and KPIs
Exceptions & escalation: mismatched passenger or missing equipment ? driver escalates to Shift Lead within 5 minutes; unresolved onscene mismatch ? immediate reassign or refund and incident ticket created; highimpact incident ? escalate to Operations Manager with RCA.
Implementation checklist: update booking UI to capture luggage/travelers; model addon SKUs with inventory binding; add dispatch tags and driver checklist items; implement autorefund rules and fraud throttles for lastminute purchases; train staff and run 2week pilot in one hub.
Primary KPIs: Ontime pickup %, Addon fulfillment rate %, Driver acceptance SLA median, Refunds per 1,000 bookings, CSAT/NPS for addon trips. 
Push Notification Integration Plan
A compact, implementation-ready plan to add reliable push alerts to Shuttle Plus tools (driver app, concierge app, ops dashboard, and admin tools). Covers event taxonomy, channels, payload design, priority/SLA, routing, throttling, security, monitoring, and rollout steps.

Objectives
Deliver timely, actionable alerts to the right user with minimal noise.
Ensure high-delivery reliability for critical operational SLAs (lost luggage, safety incidents, payment failures).
Provide traceable audit logs for alerts that affect payroll, compliance, or customer outcomes.
Support multi-channel fallbacks (push ? in-app ? SMS/voice) for high-severity incidents.

Event taxonomy (examples and severity)
Critical (P0) — Safety incident, lost/stolen luggage, active dispute, payment outage. Requires immediate delivery and escalation.
High (P1) — SLA breach imminent (e.g., handoff not acknowledged within 15 min), vehicle breakdown, chargeback flagged. Rapid delivery with retry and escalation.
Medium (P2) — Shift coverage gaps, low-stock consumables, scheduled maintenance reminders. Non-urgent; batched where possible.
Low (P3) — Daily summaries, tips, recognition messages, non-critical status updates. Deliver opportunistically.

Channels and fallbacks
Primary: Native push (APNs for iOS, FCM for Android) for driver/concierge apps.
Secondary (in-app): Persistent in-app notifications and an Alerts center for drilldown and evidence.
Tertiary: SMS or automated voice (for critical alerts when push fails or device offline).
Ops/Desk: Webhooks or messages to Ops Slack/Teams channel and Ops dashboard action feed.
Audit: Immutable event log stored in DB for payroll/claims/reconciliation.

Payload design (minimal, actionable, localized)
Fields: alert_id, event_type, priority, title, body, timestamp, owner_id, owner_role, location (lat,long,zone), related_ids (booking_id, trip_id, staff_ids), actions[], ttl_seconds, evidence_urls[], signature.
Actions[]: quick actions appended to payload (e.g., ["Acknowledge","Assign Replacement","Open Incident","Start Navigation"]).
Localization: title/body in recipient language (Amharic/English) selected server-side; include fallback language.
Example JSON
{
  "alert_id":"ALRT-20251104-0001",
  "event_type":"lost_luggage",
  "priority":"P0",
  "title":"Lost luggage reported — Aster T.",
  "body":"Unresolved luggage for booking BKG-1024 at Gate 4. Please acknowledge and attach evidence.",
  "timestamp":"2025-11-04T12:02:00Z",
  "owner_id":"CS-YK",
  "owner_role":"concierge",
  "location":{"lat":9.026, "long":38.760, "zone":"Gate 4"},
  "related_ids":{"booking_id":"BKG-1024","trip_id":"TRIP-881"},
  "actions":["Acknowledge","Open Incident","Attach Photo"],
  "ttl_seconds":3600,
  "evidence_urls":["https://evidence.shuttleplus/..."],
  "signature":"<HMAC-SHA256>"
}

Routing, ownership, and escalation
Owner assignment: Determine primary owner by zone/shift (concierge or driver) using routing rules; include fallback owner (shift lead) and Ops.
Escalation flow: Unacknowledged P0 ? escalate to shift lead after 5 min ? Ops Manager after 15 min ? Head Ops after 60 min.
Auto-reassign: If owner offline/unavailable (no heartbeat), auto-reassign to next available owner in same zone.
Action trace: Every alert status change (acknowledge, reassign, resolve) writes an immutable audit event with user ID and timestamp.

Delivery guarantees, retry, and throttling
Critical alerts: At-least-once delivery with immediate retries (0s, 10s, 60s) to push channel; if not delivered within TTL, send SMS and create Ops dashboard ticket.
Idempotency: Use alert_id to deduplicate repeated deliveries.
Throttling: Per-user rate limit (e.g., 5 critical alerts/minute) and per-event-group suppression windows to prevent notification storms.
Batching for low/medium: Batch P2/P3 alerts into digest windows (e.g., 15–60 minutes) to reduce noise.

Security and validation
Signing: All server-originated alerts include HMAC signature; clients validate signature before showing or acting.
Authentication: Use per-device auth tokens; enforce token revocation on logout or role change.
Least privilege: Only expose actions allowed by the recipient’s role.
PII minimization: Send minimal passenger data in push payloads; require app to fetch full details via authenticated call for sensitive info.

Monitoring, observability, and reporting
Metrics: delivery rate, ack latency (median & P95), retry rate, fallback rate (SMS/voice), alert storm events, and unacknowledged counts by SLA bucket.
Dashboards: Ops dashboard tile for active critical alerts and owner lag; weekly report for alert volumes and false-positive rates.
Audits: Exportable CSV for payroll/reconciliation (alerts that triggered spot bonuses or affected payouts).
Health checks: Synthetic end-to-end tests for push lifecycle and webhook processing every 5 minutes; alerts for failures.



Implementation roadmap (6 weeks)
Week 1: Finalize event taxonomy, payload schema, routing rules, and escalation SLAs.
Week 2: Build alert service APIs (create, update status, fetch, list) and audit log; implement HMAC signing.
Week 3: Integrate with FCM/APNs, implement retries, TTL, and idempotency.
Week 4: Implement in-app Alerts center, quick actions, and action handlers.
Week 5: Add SMS/voice fallback, Ops webhooks, and dashboard feed.
Week 6: Pilot P0/P1 flows with one station for 2 weeks, tune thresholds, then roll out fleet-wide.

Quick governance checklist
Define SLA owners and escalation contacts per station.
Approve suppression rules and rate limits with Ops and HR.
Document alert types that can trigger financial actions (spot bonuses, deductions).
Add privacy review for payload content and retention policies.




Quick checklist to close the URGENT: Van 12 maintenance task
Assign owner and ETA
Assign the task to the Fleet Lead or the person who will manage the job.
Set a firm due date and time (e.g., today by 16:00).
Immediate containment actions (same day)
Remove Van 12 from active rotation (add tag/status "Out of Service").
Arrange tow/inspection: call approved vendor; book slot; add vendor name and ETA in task comment.
Record vehicle odometer, last maintenance date, and symptom notes in the task description.
Evidence and attachments (supporting, not closing)
Attach inspection booking confirmation, vendor estimate, vehicle photos, and any mechanic notes to the task.
Upload invoices or repair receipts once available. Attachments support closure but do not close the task by themselves.
Work execution and verification steps
Mechanic inspects and provides repair plan — attach report and estimated timeline.
Fleet Lead authorizes repairs (comment + manager name/time).
Repair completed; mechanic uploads final receipt and photos of fixed issues.
Fleet Lead verifies vehicle is safe and roadworthy (test drive note + timestamp).
Close with a clear acceptance statement (required to mark Done)
Fleet Lead or Manager adds a final comment: “Verified: Van 12 returned to service, inspection done, receipts attached, vehicle status updated in fleet sheet.”
Change task status to Done / Complete (or check the task checkbox). This is the formal closing action.
Update records and communication (post-close)
Update fleet spreadsheet/asset register with maintenance date, cost, and next due date.
Notify Ops/Dispatch that Van 12 is back in rotation (comment + mention team).
If downtime caused service impact, add a short post-incident note and any customer remediation actions.


Suggested ClickUp fields and structure for this task
Task name: URGENT: Van 12 scheduled maintenance overdue
Assignee: Fleet Lead (email)
Priority: Urgent
Status workflow examples: Open ? In Progress ? Inspection ? Repair ? QA ? Done (or use Open ? In Progress ? Done)
Custom fields (if available): Vehicle ID, Last service date, Estimated cost, Downtime hours, Vendor contact
Attachments: booking confirmation, vendor report, invoice, before/after photos
Checklist (visible in task): 
Mark Van 12 out of service
Book tow/inspection (vendor + time)
Attach inspection report
Approve repairs (manager signoff)
Complete repairs and attach invoice
QA verification + test drive
Update fleet sheet and notify Ops
Change status to Done

Practical “close-the-loop” template actions to paste into the task
Comment when booking tow: “Tow booked with [Vendor] for [date/time]. Booking ref: [ref]. — [Name, time].”
Comment when inspection uploaded: “Inspection report uploaded: [link]. Recommended actions: [list]. — [Name, time].”
Final verification comment (required before status change): “Verified by [Manager name] at [time]: repairs completed, vehicle inspected and test-driven; back in rotation. Receipt attached: [link].”
Then change status to Done.

How teammates will find the task after closure
Search by task name, vehicle ID, or tags (e.g., “Van 12”, “Maintenance”, “Out of Service”).
Create and save a filtered view or Saved Search for recent maintenance (Status = Done; Tags contains Maintenance) for audits.
Keep a CSV or sheet export of closed maintenance tasks monthly for fleet reporting.

Automation and guardrails (optional, useful for recurring fleet work)
Auto-change status to “Inspection” when Fleet Lead is assigned.
Auto-reminder if task in In Progress > 48 hours (email or Slack).
Auto-create a follow-up task for next scheduled maintenance when task moves to Done.
Use a checklist template so every maintenance task uses the same steps and makes closure consistent.

Final summary
Attachments are necessary evidence but not sufficient. To mark the Van 12 urgent task complete you must: assign an owner, perform containment, attach inspection/repair evidence, document manager verification in the task comments, then change the task status to Done (or check the task checkbox). Add a final verification comment, update fleet records, and notify Ops so the task remains auditable and searchable.



R&D report templates — Shuttle Plus branding
Below are five ready-to-use R&D report templates with consistent headers, footers, and brand-aligned layout rules.

Title: concise and descriptive
Subtitle: one-line purpose statement
Logo: left-aligned; clearspace = arrow height

Global formatting rules (applies to all templates)
