Color palette: Cyan accent, White/light-gray text on dark backgrounds, Dark/black primary backgrounds for exported PDFs.
Typography: modern sans-serif for headings and body; monospaced for code.
Version control: include Version, Date, Author, Approver, and Change log on first or header page.
File naming convention: ProjectName_ReportType_v{major}.{minor}_YYYYMMDD (example: ShuttlePlus_RnD_TechReport_v1.0_20251022).
Accessibility: use high contrast; include alt text for images; supply raw CSVs for all charts.
Export rules: PDF for distribution; editable doc for internal collaboration.




Real-time Location Sharing — Overview
A lean, app-based location-sharing plan that uses Google Maps Platform (free tier limits) to provide live driver location, ETA updates, and one-touch passenger tracking links. 
Goals: accurate ETAs, low-latency location updates, minimal user friction, privacy-safe sharing, and clear fallbacks when location or connectivity fails.

Architecture and data flow
Driver app (mobile) publishes GPS pings to backend every X seconds using secure HTTPS.
Backend ingests pings, smooths points, computes ETA via Google Distance Matrix or Directions API, and stores minimal recent history (sliding window).
Passenger receives either: (A) real-time in-app map tile with embedded Google Maps SDK using a session token, or (B) short-lived tracking link (web view) showing driver location and ETA.
All map tiles and routing use Google Maps SDK/Static Maps + Directions/Distance Matrix as needed.
Auth & tokens: short-lived JWT session per booking; passenger link includes opaque session ID that expires.
Fallbacks: SMS link with limited lifetime; periodic ETA SMS when live tracking unavailable.

Implementation steps (developer-ready)
Google Maps setup
Register project, enable Maps SDK for Android/iOS, Directions API, Distance Matrix API, and Maps JavaScript API.
Create separate API keys for client SDKs (restricted by package name or SHA-1) and server-side calls (restricted by IP).
Monitor free-tier quotas; plan caching and rate-limiting to avoid overage.
Driver app location publishing
Frequency: 5–15s when en route (configurable by speed/battery), 30–60s idle.
Payload: {booking_id, driver_id, lat, lng, heading, speed, timestamp}.
Transport: HTTPS POST to /v1/location-updates with JWT auth and exponential backoff for connectivity issues.
Backend processing
Ingest updates into an append-only, in-memory buffer per booking (keep last N points, e.g., 50).
Smooth GPS jitter using a simple Kalman or low-pass filter and drop obvious outliers.
Compute ETA on major location change or every 30s using cached Directions/Distance Matrix results, with route re-check threshold (e.g., >200m deviation).
Publish processed location to a realtime channel (WebSocket or server-sent events) keyed by booking_id.
Passenger delivery options
In-app: authenticated WebSocket/SSE subscription to booking channel; render driver marker and ETA via Google Maps SDK.
Web link: Generate short-lived tracking URL (e.g., /track/{session_id}) that renders a public web view with embedded Google Maps and subscribes to SSE for live updates.
SMS fallback: when link cannot be opened, send periodic ETA SMS at key checkpoints (30m, 15m, 5m).
Realtime transport & scaling
Use a lightweight pub/sub or managed WebSocket layer (e.g., Pusher, Ably or self-hosted with Redis + socket cluster) to fan out location updates to passengers.
Throttle updates to clients (UI-level) — show animation between points rather than every ping to reduce bandwidth.
Rate control and cost management (Google APIs)
Cache distance matrix results for common origin-destination pairs for short TTL (1–5 min).
Only call Directions API when route deviates or ETA stale; use Distance Matrix for cheaper ETA checks when possible.
Batch server-side calls where multiple bookings use same OD pair.

Mobile UI / UX patterns
Driver app: single toggle “Share location” per booking, status badge (Sharing/Stopped), power-saving mode, small map preview, upload indicator.
Passenger in-app: prominent ETA chip (time + distance), driver card (name, vehicle, plate, live status), “Share my ride” button to invite guest, panic button visible but guarded.
Web tracking link: minimal chrome, map center on driver marker, ETA badge, estimated arrival timeline with distance bands (30/15/5 min), “Open in app” button for deeper actions.
Visual smoothing: animated marker with heading, breadcrumb fade-out for recent route, capacious marker for low-accuracy pings.
Accessibility: readable high-contrast CTA, voice-read ETA for visually impaired on request.

Privacy, security, and compliance
Data minimization: store only last N location points and derived ETA; purge location history after booking closed + retention window (e.g., 7 days) for disputes.
Consent: driver-enable toggle and passenger informed opt-in via booking confirmation; explicit acceptance for share-by-link.
Short-lived tokens: session tokens expire quickly (recommended 15–60 minutes) and single-use tracking links auto-revoke after expiration or trip completion.
Transport security: TLS for all endpoints, HSTS, strict CORS.
Access control: server enforces booking ownership checks before opening tracking channel.
Logging & audit: record who accessed tracking (driver, passenger, guest links) with timestamps; mask PII in logs.
Legal: surface privacy notice at booking and in the app; follow local data protection requirements for Ethiopia where applicable.
Error handling, testing, rollout, and KPIs
Error handling: graceful fallback when GPS unavailable (show last known location + “searching for driver”); when Google API quota exhausted, switch to simplified map tiles + periodic SMS ETAs.
Testing: device field tests in Addis Ababa traffic patterns, simulated low-signal scenarios, and high-concurrency load tests for concurrent tracking sessions.
Rollout: release in phases — pilot 5% drivers, measure stability, then 25% and full fleet. Keep feature gate for drivers and bookings.
KPIs to measure: tracking success rate; mean location latency; ETA accuracy (predicted vs actual arrival delta); user engagement with tracking; cost per tracking session (Google API calls); incidents where tracking unavailable.
Monitoring & alerts: API quota thresholds, unusual location update gaps, backend queue depth, and websocket connection failures.
Return and Refund Policy — Shuttle Plus
Purpose
Define clear, fair and operationally actionable rules for refunds, credits and service recovery when trips are delayed, cancelled, interrupted or otherwise fail to meet agreed service levels.

Scope
Applies to all Shuttle Plus passenger bookings (single rides, subscriptions, corporate accounts, prebooked airport transfers) and to all sales channels (app, web, call centre, corporate portal). Covers delays, cancellations (by customer or company), noshows, ontrip interruptions, double bookings and payment disputes.

Guiding principles
Be transparent and simple to understand.
Prioritise fast resolution and customer experience (refunds, credits, reassignment).
Protect company from abuse while honouring statutory consumer protections and contractual SLAs.
Differentiate remedies for controllable company failures versus force majeure or thirdparty events.

Definitions
Booking: confirmed reservation in system with booking ID.
Scheduled pickup window: confirmed pickup time or window shown at booking.
Delay: vehicle arrival later than scheduled pickup window.
Cancellation by customer: customer-initiated cancellation via app/portal or support.
Cancellation by company/driver: driver or Shuttle Plus cancels confirmed booking prior to pickup.
Noshow (customer): customer does not appear within the required wait period after driver arrival/notification.
Force majeure: events outside reasonable control (extreme weather, governmental orders, major traffic incidents, ATC closures, strikes).

Refund and Credit Rules
1. Delays before pickup
Minor delay (? 15 minutes beyond scheduled window): no automatic refund; customer offered option to wait, rebook immediately without fee, or receive a small goodwill credit (ETB X or percentage).
Significant delay (> 15 minutes and ? 60 minutes): customer may choose between a full refund of fare, immediate rebooking on next available vehicle at no extra charge, or a service credit equal to 50% of fare plus priority rebooking.
Major delay (> 60 minutes): customer entitled to full refund or free alternative transport arrangement (if available) and a service credit equal to 100% of fare plus apology communication.
2. Cancellation by company or driver (pretrip)
If Shuttle Plus/driver cancels anytime before pickup: customer offered immediate full refund OR priority rebooking at no extra cost; if rebooking is unavailable within a reasonable timeframe (user choice threshold e.g., 30 minutes), an additional goodwill credit (flat ETB amount or % of fare) applies.
Repeated cancellations (? 2 cancellations for same customer within 30 days) trigger escalation and compensation review; potential credit of one free VIP upgrade or subscription discount for highvalue customers.
3. Cancellation by customer
Free cancellation window: customers may cancel up to X minutes before scheduled pickup (e.g., 15–30 minutes) without fee; full fare refund issued to original payment method or retained as credit per customer preference.
Late cancellation (within X minutes of pickup or after driver en route): charge noshow fee as defined in pricing schedule (e.g., a percentage of fare or flat fee) unless customer provides verifiable flight delay proof or exceptional circumstances; system may convert fare to partial refund/credit per case.

4. Noshows
Customer noshow after driver arrival and waiting period: driver records arrival time and photos/GPS; booking closed and noshow fee charged (defined in fare rules). Partial refunds considered if evidence shows driver did not arrive at agreed location/time.
Driver noshow at pickup window: treat as “cancellation by company” and apply rules under section 2.
5. Ontrip failures and interruptions
If trip is terminated by company/driver for operational reasons (vehicle breakdown, safety): offer immediate replacement vehicle; if replacement not available within a reasonable time, provide prorata refund for unused leg plus a goodwill credit.
If driver behaviour, safety violation or other gross misconduct causes trip failure: full refund for trip and additional compensation (credit or voucher) and disciplinary action to follow.
6. Airport transfer specific rules
Flight delays/arrivals: customer must update flight details; Shuttle Plus monitors scheduled flights and offers rebooking at no charge for reasonable inbound flight delays (e.g., up to 4 hours). For long diversion/cancellation of flights, full refund or rebooking applies.
Missed return transfers due to late flight: apply same policy; require flight evidence for latearrival exceptions.
7. Force majeure
Where delay or cancellation is proven to be caused by force majeure, Shuttle Plus will endeavour to rebook or refund based on operational feasibility; refunds may be processed but company may limit additional compensation when event is outside reasonable control.




Refund Mechanics
Refund method and timing
Refunds to card/wallet: processed to the original payment method within X business days (recommend 5–10 business days) depending on payment provider; inform customer of expected timeline.
Inapp credits/vouchers: instant issuance available for faster resolution; credit expiry defaults to 12 months (or as per local law); customers may request cash refund where law requires.
Partial refunds: calculated prorata and rounded to nearest currency unit; fees charged by payment processors are handled per policy (company may absorb or pass through depending on case).
Evidence and verification
Eligibility for refunds may require booking ID and verification info (driver logs, GPS, timestamps, photos, flight numbers). For customer cancellations due to flight disruption, require flight status evidence when applying late cancellation exemptions.
All refund decisions and evidence logs stored in case file for audit and disputes.

Corporate Accounts and Subscriptions
Corporate contracts: apply SLAspecific refund/credit rules defined in the master service agreement (MSA). SLAs can include monthly service credits when ontime pickup falls below thresholds.
Subscription plans: refund policy for subscriptions follows subscription terms; prorata refunds allowed within defined coolingoff window; nonused subscription rides may convert to credits per plan rules.

Chargebacks and Payment Disputes
Customers disputing charges via card issuer: require internal review within 5 business days; hold remediation/refund where evidence supports customer claim pending issuer resolution. Maintain documentation to contest illegitimate chargebacks.
Reconciliation: finance to reconcile refunds, credits, disputes against ledger and report monthly chargeback rates and reasons.

Service Credits and SLA Compensation
SLA credit model (corporate & premium): use transparent credit formulas (e.g., for every 1% below target ontime rate, issue X% credit on monthly invoice up to cap). Define calculation method, claim window and proof required.
Singleride SLA credits: apply automatic credits where system detects breach of service thresholds (e.g., pickup >60 minutes).

Exceptions and Denials
No refunds for customercaused delays where driver arrival is confirmed within agreed location/time and wait period elapsed.
No refunds for events outside company control where reasonable mitigation offered (e.g., reroute or wait).
Suspicion of fraud or abuse triggers review; if abuse proven, account remediation actions (suspension, forfeiture of credits).

Dispute Resolution
Customers may escalate refunds via inapp support; unresolved disputes escalate to a dedicated Refunds Team within 7 business days.
Final escalation to a Neutral Review Panel (internal) within 21 days; corporate customers may follow contract dispute procedures (MSA) and arbitration clauses if applicable.

Communication and Transparency
Policy displayed inapp at booking, in terms and conditions and on the website.
On any refund/credit decision, customer receives clear explanation: reason, amount, method (card or inapp credit), timeframe and dispute instructions.
Provide templated messages for agents to ensure consistent tone and legal compliance.

Operational Processes and Roles
Frontline (Support Agent)
Receive refund request; check booking, driver logs and GPS; make provisional offer (credit or full refund) within X minutes (target < 60 mins for simple cases).
Escalate to Refunds Team for complex claims or disputes.
Refunds Team
Verify evidence, apply policy, authorise refunds/credits, log decision and notify customer; aim to resolve within 3 business days for complex cases.
Finance
Process payments to payment gateway and reconciliations; publish weekly refund reports; monitor chargeback trends.
Operations
Investigate root causes for frequent delays/cancellations; implement corrective actions and driver performance management.

KPIs and Monitoring
Refund resolution time (median).
Percentage of bookings refunded or credited.
Ontime pickup rate and cancellation rate (company vs driver).
Chargeback rate and reason categories.
Customer satisfaction after refund/credit interaction (NPS for support).

Recordkeeping and Compliance
Retain refund case files (evidence logs, correspondence, decision) per statutory retention period and for audit.
Ensure all refund practices comply with applicable consumer protection laws and payment provider rules.

Templates (short examples)
Booking delayed — immediate credit offer: "Apologies — your driver is delayed by [X] minutes. We can rebook immediately at no charge or issue an instant ETB [Y] credit to your account. Which do you prefer?"
Driver cancelled — full refund: "We apologise — your booking [ID] was cancelled by our driver. You have been issued a full refund to your card. It should reflect in [5–10] business days. We have credited ETB [Z] to your account for the inconvenience."
Customer late cancellation denied: "Your cancellation request was received after the free cancellation window. The noshow fee of ETB [A] applies. Please contact support if you believe this is incorrect and provide flight or other proof."

Implementation Roadmap (60 days)
Days 1–7: Finalize policy text, define parameter values (wait times, thresholds, credit amounts) and legal review.
Days 8–21: Configure inapp cancellation windows, automated refund triggers and support templates; train support.
Days 22–40: Implement autocredit mechanics, reconciliation flows and finance reporting.
Days 41–60: Pilot policy for a sample of bookings; monitor KPIs and refine thresholds; full rollout.




Royal Genie concept overview
The Royal Genie is a whiteglove, personalised concierge service deployed by Royal Caribbean for toptier suite guests. It provides bespoke trip planning, priority access, escorted embarkation/debarkation, expedited luggage handling, reservations and ondemand special requests to create a VIP endtoend experience Royal Caribbean Cruises. Independent descriptions and guest guides summarise it as a dedicated ambassador model (butler + concierge) that anticipates needs and removes operational friction for premium guests Royal Caribbean Blog voyagerinfo.com.
Core service attributes to adopt
AttributeWhy it matters for Shuttle PlusPersonal concierge assignmentSingle point of contact increases perceived value and reduces friction for premium customersTrip orchestrationCoordinated pickups, priority boarding, luggage handling, and event/reservation booking improve reliabilityProactive communicationsRealtime ETA, driver match, pretrip checks and followups boost trust and NPSPriority operational queuesPriority for dispatch, support and incident handling reduces customer pain during peak periodsCurated experiencesAddons (airport meet & greet, corporate accounts, bespoke routes) create upsell and loyaltyHow Shuttle Plus can adapt Royal Genie
Service model
Offer a tiered VIP program (e.g., Royal, Elite, Concierge) where the top tier receives a named “Royal Genie” (a dedicated concierge) plus priority fleet and support.
The Genie role combines a human concierge (customer success / account manager) with a tech layer (VIP routing, priority dispatch, driver pairing, privileged support channel).
Customer journey features
Pretrip: proactive confirmation, driver bio, vehicle photo, optional luggage assistance and priority boarding instructions.
During trip: priority dispatch and live concierge monitoring; Genie can reroute, upgrade vehicle or coordinate multistop journeys.
Posttrip: personalized followup, issue triage, bespoke offers and retention outreach.
Operational mechanics
Dedicated contact: assign a named Genie per account or geographic cluster for highvalue customers.
Priority queues: implement a VIP queue in dispatch and support systems to preemptively assign highestperforming drivers and faster incident resolution.
Luggage & meet services: partner with hub staff or contracted porters for assisted pickup/drop services at hubs or designated points.
Escalation protocol: Genies have a rapid escalation path to ops leads for onthespot decisions (reroutes, credits, vehicle swaps).
Technology integration
VIP profile flags in CRM and dispatch system; Genie dashboard showing live trips, customer preferences, and SLA timers.
Autonotifications and twoway chat linking Genie, passenger and driver; privileged routing rules for priority dispatching.
DSAR and privacy adjustments for VIP data: explicit consent and additional security for sensitive itinerary/location data.
Feasibility and impact comparison
OptionUpfront costOperational complexityRevenue/Retention impactMinimal VIP (digital flags, priority queue)LowLowMediumNamed Royal Genie per account (human + tech)MediumMediumHighHighFull whiteglove (meet & greet, luggage, escorts)HighHighVery HighRecommendation: start with Minimal VIP to validate demand, then pilot Named Royal Genie for top 1–3% customers and corporate accounts before expanding to full whiteglove.

Pilot design (90 days)
Phase 0 (Days 1–7): Design offering, pricing tiers and SLAs; select pilot segments (e.g., corporate clients, premium subscribers).
Phase 1 (Days 8–30): Build VIP flags in CRM/dispatch, create Genie dashboard wireframe, train 3person Genie team; define SOPs for priority dispatch and escalations.
Phase 2 (Days 31–60): Run closed pilot with 50 customers: deliver pretrip concierge, priority pickup and a direct Genie contact; collect qualitative feedback.
Phase 3 (Days 61–90): Evaluate KPIs, refine scripts and tech, assess driver incentives and partner needs (porters); prepare scale plan for next 6 months.
KPIs and success criteria
Operational: VIP ontime pickup rate ? 95%; median incident resolution time for VIPs < 15 minutes.
Business: VIP retention uplift vs control cohort +20% within 3 months; willingnesstopay conversion for tiered pricing ? 10%.
Experience: Net Promoter Score for VIPs ? +50; average Genie touchpoints per trip and satisfaction rating ? 4.5/5.
Risks and mitigations
Perceived unfairness by regular customers ? clearly communicate tiers and value, test price elasticity.
Driver capacity and fairness ? design driver incentives for VIP trips; limit VIP dispatch during extreme peak or add surge pricing.
Privacy and data sensitivity ? store VIP preferences and itinerary with strengthened access controls and explicit consent; align with PDPP and company data policy.
Cost escalation ? phased rollout; monitor ROI per account and automate friendly parts of the Genie role to scale.
Quick next steps
Validate customer willingness to pay with short survey of top customers and leads.
Build minimal VIP flags and priority queue in dispatch (MVP technical task).
Recruit/train 2–3 Genies and run a 60day closed pilot for corporate clients.
Measure KPIs, refine offers and then decide whether to scale to full Royal Genie services.

Seasonal Ad Planning Overview
Brief set of highimpact, operationally realistic campaign ideas and execution notes for holiday and travel peak periods that align with Shuttle Plus’s operational strengths: reliable airport transfers, lastminute bookings, partnerships with hotels, and trust-building through safety and speed.

Highvalue Campaign Concepts (6)
1. LastMinute Lift (48hour flash)
Offer: Guaranteed pickup within 60 minutes or ride free credit.
Creative hook: “Missed your bag? Need a fast transfer? We’ll be there.”
Target: Mobile users within 10 km of airport, lookalike of frequent flyers.
Ops note: Reserve a surge fleet and dedicated dispatcher channel.
2. Holiday Family Bundle
Offer: Fixed-price family transfer (2 adults + 2 kids + luggage) with childseat option.
Creative hook: “One fare, one easy family trip to the airport.”
Target: Families in suburban areas with early-morning departures.
Ops note: Prebook slots and require drivers to confirm childseat availability before assignment.
3. Partner Hotel CrossSell
Offer: Copromoted discount code given at checkin or via hotel newsletter.
Creative hook: “Stay + Shuttle: Seamless arrival and worryfree departures.”
Target: Hotel guests and concierge lists.
Ops note: Create QR code check-in flow and partner reporting dashboard.
4. Winter Comfort Addons
Offer: Paid add-ons (heated seats, priority boarding into vehicle, water + snack kit).
Creative hook: “Warm, quick, comfortable — add a little calm to your trip.”
Target: business travelers and premium segments.
Ops note: Bundle with driver checklist and physical kit inventory.
5. Group & Event Routing
Offer: Prearranged group transfers with simplified booking and single point-of-contact.
Creative hook: “Group travel made easy — one manager, one invoice.”
Target: conference planners, wedding venues, tour operators.
Ops note: Sales outreach and template contracts plus dedicated ops lane.
6. Trust & Safety Campaign (reassurance)
Offer: Promoted incident-free guarantee and visible safety checks (driver background, vehicle sanitization, luggage security).
Creative hook: “We keep your travel safe — see our checks.”
Target: riskaverse travelers and families during peaks.
Ops note: Create short explainer videos and checklist cards for drivers.

Channel, Timing, and Budget Guidance
Digital (Search + Meta + YouTube): primary channel for immediate conversions. Use short flightdate targeting windows and dynamic countdown ads for urgency.
App push & SMS: highest ROI for lastminute offers and reengagement of frequent users; limit to 1–2 messages/day.
OTA/Hotel Partnerships: cobranded emails and inroom collateral 7–2 days before departure.
Offline (airport kiosks, concierge): good for trust and lastminute upsell; rotate creative weekly during peaks.
Timing: start awareness 3–4 weeks before major holidays, scale to conversion push 7–2 days out, and deploy lastminute flash within 48 hours of peak travel days.
Budget split (example): 40% digital acquisition, 20% partnerships, 15% app/SMS, 15% airport/kiosk, 10% contingency for surge capacity.

Creative Assets & Messaging Checklist
Core assets: 
6–10s and 15–30s video cuts for social and kiosk screens.
Static banners: hero image + 1line CTA + promo code.
SMS templates: short, nameaware, one CTA.
Email templates: hero, offer details, FAQs, contact/incident link.
Landing pages: booking widget prefilled by promo code and departure date.
Driver script and passenger receipt language for addons and guarantees.
Legal + terms: oneclick link to T&Cs on all landing pages and receipts.
Localization: language and cultural variations for major passenger segments.

Operations Readiness (capacity, SOPs, inventory)
Fleet capacity model: map expected bookings by 1hour windows; preallocate spare vehicles (10–20% depending on peak).
Staffing: staggered shifts with overlap at expected peak hours; designate surge leads and rapidresponse team for incidents.
Inventory: kits for addons (water, snack, child seats) at each hub and kiosk; track via daily checklist.
Handover & escalation: fast path in incident ticketing for promo passengers with service credits or refunds to avoid public complaints.
Partner ops: single partner POC and weekly reconciliation reports during campaign.

Measurement, KPIs, and Iteration
Primary KPIs: CAC by campaign, conversion rate (ad click ? booking), revenue per ride, average response time for lastminute requests, ontime pickup %.
Secondary KPIs: upsell attach rate (addons), customer satisfaction (postride NPS), complaint rate per 1,000 rides.
Reporting cadence: daily during peak windows, weekly executive summary.
A/B tests to run: CTA copy (discount vs guarantee), creative length (6s vs 15s), channel mix (app push timing).
Postseason retrospective: collect ops failures, promo leakage, partner performance; update SOPs and inventory assumptions for next season.




Security escalation
Immediate containment (first 0–60 minutes)
Assign incident owner now and set task due within 2 hours.
Preserve evidence immediately: stop vehicle, secure dashcam device and SD card, take time-stamped photos of vehicle interior and luggage area, and collect driver statement (record audio or typed note with timestamp).
Isolate involved assets: mark vehicle as “Pending Investigation” in fleet sheet and remove from rotation.
Stabilize passenger: ensure safety, offer a calm point of contact, record their statement, collect ID and witness names, and confirm whether they want Police involved.

Evidence collection & chain of custody
Dashcam: remove and copy raw footage; create checksum or filename with timestamp; store original SD card in sealed bag; upload a copy to secure storage and paste signed URL into task.
Photos/videos: request passenger originals (not screenshots) and instruct driver to take dated photos now; preserve EXIF if possible.
Logs and metadata: export booking logs, driver GPS trace, agent shift log, vehicle manifest, and CCTV if available; include server timestamps.
Witness statements: capture contact info, short written statements, and timestamps.
Chain-of-custody note: log who handled each evidence item, when, and where; attach to ClickUp task.

Notifications and escalation (within 60 minutes)
Notify Legal and Ops Manager immediately (email + SMS/WhatsApp) with subject line: URGENT Security: BKG-{id} — Possible theft — action required. Include incident ref, booking ID, passenger name, brief summary, and evidence links.
If passenger requests police or if theft is suspected, support and accompany the passenger to file a police report; obtain police report number and officer contact.
If third-party property (hotel, partner) might be involved, notify partner liaison.

Investigation steps (0–24 hours)
Owner compiles an incident packet: incident summary, timeline, evidence links, driver statement, witness notes, dashcam clip, and booking metadata.
Forensics: have Legal/Investigator review footage and statements; mark any tampered evidence.
Quick verification: cross-check GPS and timestamp to confirm who had custody of passenger items and when.
If evidence suggests driver misconduct, immediately suspend driver from passenger-facing duties pending review and record action in task.

Customer communication templates
Immediate acknowledgement (SMS/email — send within 30 minutes): “We’re very sorry. We’ve opened an incident for booking {BKG}. Our team is preserving evidence and investigating now. We’ll update you within 6 hours. — Shuttle Plus Ops”
If police involved: “We will cooperate with authorities. Please provide the police report number when available; we’ll attach it to your case. — Shuttle Plus Legal”
After initial findings: “Investigation update: [summary]. Next steps: [repair/compensation/legal]. Expected resolution time: [X hours/days].”

ClickUp task actions & required updates (make task auditable)
Task title: URGENT: Security escalation — Booking BKG-{id} — {PassengerLastName}
Fields to fill immediately: IncidentRef, BookingID, PassengerContact, DriverName, VehicleID, ReportedAt, AssignedOwner, Status=Investigation.
Attach: dashcam signed URL, passenger photos, driver statement, booking logs, GPS trace, CCTV link, police report (when available).
Checklist (must be completed before closing): 
Evidence secured and uploaded.
Chain-of-custody logged.
Legal + Ops notified (timestamped).
Police report obtained (if filed).
Forensics/review completed and conclusion logged.
Customer updated and remedy agreed or legal path initiated.
Driver action recorded (suspension/coaching/escalation).
Final approval by Legal to close.
Comments: Owner must post hourly updates until first 6 hours, then every 24 hours.

Decision matrix & remedies
If evidence confirms theft by third party while in our custody: Offer immediate remediation (compensation or replacement) pending Legal confirmation; escalate to police and insurer.
If evidence confirms driver involvement: Suspend driver, escalate to Legal for termination or prosecution, notify insurance, and prepare settlement for passenger.
If evidence is inconclusive: Continue investigation, keep passenger informed, consider interim goodwill compensation subject to final findings.

Closure criteria (what marks task Done in ClickUp)
All checklist items completed and documented.
Legal signoff attached as comment or PDF.
Police report attached (if involved) or formal investigation summary attached.
Customer communication and agreed remedy recorded and evidence of execution (refund receipt, compensation transaction, or signed acceptance).
Final verification comment by Ops Manager: “Verified resolution and documentation complete. Closing incident.” Then change Status to Done.

Short-term guardrails to prevent recurrence
Immediately require drivers to use sealed luggage tags or photo-confirmation at handoff for next 7 days.
Enable automatic shorter retention of dashcam clips in secure archive for faster retrieval.
Add a mandatory “handoff photo” step in the app: driver takes a timestamped photo when handing luggage to passengers.



Shift Attributes Overview
AttributeRecommendationWhy it mattersExample valueShift pattern3 fixed 8hour shiftsSimplest for operations, predictable handoversDay 07:00–15:00; Swing 15:00–23:00; Night 23:00–07:00Coverage modelPrimary + backup per roleEnsures resilience during incidents1 lead + 1 deputy per shiftHandover duration15 minutes overlap + 15 minute written logReduces information loss at shift change07:00–07:15 overlap, 07:15–07:30 log reviewRotation frequency2–4 week rotation (optional)Balances fairness and circadian stability4-week rotation preferredOncall escalationTiered, documented contact chainRapid response for outages or safety incidentsTier 1 driver lead, Tier 2 ops manager, Tier 3 founder
Shift Pattern and Hours
Three shifts, each 8 hours: Day 07:00–15:00; Swing 15:00–23:00; Night 23:00–07:00.
Shift start/end rule: shift begins with a 15-minute overlap for verbal handoff and ends with a 15-minute buffer for documentation and immediate cleanup.
Weekly hours per person: 40 hours (5 shifts) or 48 hours (6 shifts) depending on local labor rules and preferred roster; aim for average 40 hours.

Staffing and Roles per Shift
Core roles to staff each shift 
Shift Lead — responsible for decisions, escalations, incident triage.
Operations Coordinator — dispatch, bookings, driver assignments.
Driver Onshift Pool — number depends on demand; schedule based on forecasts.
Fleet Technician (on-call or overlap) — for vehicle issues or immediate repairs.
Customer Experience Rep — handle incoming customer queries and refunds.
Backup coverage 
Assign 1 deputy for Shift Lead; rotate deputy weekly for development.
Maintain an oncall list for each critical role with contact times and SLA expectations.

Handover Procedure
Verbal overlap (15 minutes): incoming and outgoing leads discuss active incidents, highrisk passengers, maintenance items, and key KPIs.
Written handover log: concise template fields — Date/Shift; Active incidents; Outstanding actions; Vehicle statuses; Driver exceptions; Notes/Next steps.
Handoff checklist: 
Confirm location and status of all vehicles.
Review unresolved incidents and action owners.
Confirm staffing and breaks for upcoming shift.
Verify key system health checks completed.
Signoff by outgoing and incoming lead (name + timestamp).

Rotation and Rostering Options
Fixed shifts (stable assignment) — best for consistency and fatigue management; people keep same shift long term.
223 rolling roster — popular for fairness: two days on, two off, three days on; repeats to cover 24/7 with built-in rest.
4on/4off — blocks of 4 shifts then 4 days off; simple but can produce long runs.
Recommended default: 4week rotation where teams remain on one shift for 4 weeks then rotate to the next shift, minimizing circadian disruption.
Sample weekly roster (Day/Swing/Night labels across staff):
Week 1–4: Team A — Day; Team B — Swing; Team C — Night.
Week 5–8: rotate Team A ? Swing, Team B ? Night, Team C ? Day.



Operational SOPs and Tools
Shift dashboard: live view of vehicle locations, active bookings, incident list, key KPIs (ontime rate, vehicles available, active incidents).
Incident ticketing: every incident must have tickets created, owner assigned, photos and timestamps attached, and closure comments.
Escalation matrix: times and phone numbers for Tier 1, Tier 2, Tier 3; expected response SLAs.
Break scheduling: mandatory break windows built into rosters; ensure deputy covers during breaks.
Handover repository: central log (Google Sheet / ClickUp list) with each shift’s handover entries, searchable by date.

KPIs, Reporting, and Continuous Improvement
Realtime KPIs per shift 
Vehicles available %
Ontime pickups %
Active incident count
Avg response time to incidents
Daily shift report: one paragraph summary + KPI snapshot posted to shared channel at shift end.
Weekly review: aggregate trends, repeat incidents, staffing shortfalls; feed into roster adjustments.
Retrospective cadence: monthly ops review with representatives from each shift to resolve systemic issues.

Quick Implementation Checklist
Define Teams A/B/C and assign primary/deputy for each role.
Publish fixed shift hours and overlap windows to all staff.
Create handover log template and central repository.
Configure shift dashboard and incident ticketing access for all shift leads.
Implement rotation rules and publish 8week roster.
Train staff on handover procedure and escalation matrix.
Start 2week pilot, collect feedback, then lock schedule for 4 weeks.


Shuttle Plus legal & compliance budget template — phased (0–90 days; 3–12 months)
This is a practical, actionable budget template tailored to Shuttle Plus (transport/logistics platform). No hard costs included — replace placeholders with your local estimates. Each line shows: category, what it covers, priority (H/M/L), suggested owner, and phasing / notes.

Phase A — Immediate (0–90 days) — set up, risk closure, and evidence
People and specialist counsel
What: GC/CCO retainer (parttime or hire), contract lawyer/paralegal support, external counsel on demand for transport/regulatory advice.
Priority: H. Owner: GC. Phase: immediate hire/retainer. Notes: favor flexible retainer by the hour.
Contract remediation and CLM quick fixes
What: project to patch top 20 contracts (LD, termination, insurance, force majeure), new template pack.
Priority: H. Owner: GC + Procurement Lead. Phase: immediate execution; CLM procurement can be staged.
Insurance validation and proof collection
What: review company policies (motor/public liability, fleet, cyber, D&O), obtain supplier insurance certificates.
Priority: H. Owner: Finance Lead + GC. Phase: immediate verification and short gap fill.
Incident response and tabletop exercise
What: IRP templates, insurer notification templates, one tabletop (supplier delay + accident).
Priority: H. Owner: GC + IT Lead + Ops Lead. Phase: run within 6–8 weeks.
Regulatory and licensing check
What: confirm transport licenses, municipal permits, fleet compliance; engage local counsel if needed.
Priority: H. Owner: Ops Lead + GC. Phase: immediate mapping and renewals where due.
Vendor due diligence / KYC for key suppliers
What: KYC of fleet lessors, fuel/logistics partners, payment processors; require insurance/KYB evidence.
Priority: H. Owner: Procurement Lead + CCO. Phase: prioritized for top 10 suppliers.
Training (priority modules)
What: driver onboarding (safety/HSE), data protection for app staff, incident reporting.
Priority: M–H. Owner: CCO + HR Lead. Phase: basic modules live; manager briefings.
Evidence repository & remediation tracker setup
What: central folder, immutable copies, remediation tracker and PM support.
Priority: H. Owner: Project Manager (PM) appointed by GC. Phase: Day 1–7.
Contingency reserve (short term)
What: a dedicated fund for emergency legal actions, immediate claims or retainer topups.
Priority: H. Owner: Finance Lead. Phase: hold immediate.

Phase B — Steady state & scale (3–12 months) — controls, monitoring, and capability build
CLM and GRC tooling
What: contract lifecycle management, automated alerts, licence calendar, remediation dashboard.
Priority: H. Owner: CCO + IT Lead. Phase: procurement and integration months 2–6.
Full training program and LMS
What: full suite (antibribery, data privacy, competition, HSE), role tagging and reporting.
Priority: H. Owner: CCO + HR Lead. Phase: roll out in months 2–4; annual refresh.
Ongoing external counsel retainer and specialist panels
What: transport/regulatory, employment, IP/cyber panels for crossborder work.
Priority: M. Owner: GC. Phase: maintain retainer for escalation.
Audit, monitoring and testing
What: quarterly spot audits, semiannual focused audits (data protection, contracts), penetration testing.
Priority: H. Owner: CCO + Internal Audit / External Experts. Phase: schedule across months 3–12.
Insurance program optimization
What: adjust limits; add fleet/motor, public liability; cyber improvements; broker fees.
Priority: H. Owner: Finance Lead + GC. Phase: renewals and midterm checks.
Customer remediation & reserves
What: dedicated fund for refunds, service credits, safety incident remediation.
Priority: M–H. Owner: Finance Lead + Ops Lead. Phase: ongoing.
Contractual risk transfer (bonds/escrow/parents)
What: performance bonds, escrow for critical software/IP, parent guarantees where needed.
Priority: M. Owner: GC + Procurement Lead. Phase: applied per-contract basis.
Data protection and product DPIAs
What: DPIAs for location/telemetry features, data retention tooling, crossborder transfer mechanisms.
Priority: H. Owner: IT Lead + CCO. Phase: DPIAs months 1–4; remediation ongoing.
Recruitment and headcount
What: hire fulltime GC or CCO if growth profile justifies, paralegal, compliance analyst.
Priority: M. Owner: CEO + GC. Phase: months 3–9 depending on growth.
Continuous improvement and contingency (12month reserve)
What: litigation reserve, arbitration retainer, unanticipated regulatory fines.
Priority: H. Owner: Finance Lead. Phase: maintained.

Suggested allocation posture (relative guidance only)
Earlystage / Lean profile (small startup): prioritize 0–90 day spends (people + contracts + insurance + contingency) — approximate weighting by category:
People & counsel 25–35% ; Contract fixes & CLM quick wins 15–25% ; Insurance & contingency 20–30% ; Training & tools 10–15% ; Audits & incident response 5–10%.
Growth profile (scaling operations, entering new cities): heavier on tooling, audits, staff and insurance — approximate weighting:
People & counsel 20–25% ; CLM/GRC & IT integration 15–25% ; Insurance & contingency 20–25% ; Training & audits 15–20% ; Incident response & remediation 5–10%.
Use these percentages to convert into actual currency once you decide the total legal/compliance budget envelope.

Contingency sizing guidance
Short term reserve (0–90 days): hold at least one to three months of expected legal burn for emergency counsel/retainers and immediate settlements.
12month reserve: size for potential motor liability event(s) or regulator fines — practical approach is to estimate the maximum deductible plus a conservative incident remediation quantum; if uncertain, set aside a percentage (e.g., 10–20%) of the total legal/compliance budget for the year.

Suggested owners (summary)
GC — lead legal strategy, contract remediation, external counsel.
CCO — training, GRC tooling, audits, remediation tracking.
Finance Lead — insurance, contingency, customer remediation funds.
Ops Lead — permits, fleet compliance, supplier contingency.
Procurement Lead — vendor due diligence, contract negotiations.
IT Lead — DPIAs, access controls, incident response.
HR Lead — training for people, employee file compliance.
Project Manager — run tracker, gather evidence, enforce cadence.

Deliverables and milestones to cost/track
Day 7: onepage heatmap and remediation tracker (fund immediate actions).
Day 30: top20 contracts patched; supplier insurance evidence for top 10.
Day 60: DPIA outputs and incident playbook updated.
Day 90: tabletop run; 90day report; contingency fund draw decisions.
Months 3–12: CLM procurement and integration; LMS rollout; quarterly audits; insurance renewal alignment.

Shuttle Plus Pilot Partnership Brief
Project: Shuttle Plus 90 Day Pilot for Reliable Airport Transfers
Value proposition
Dependable service for your guests and staff that reduces missed flights and late arrivals.
Predictable pricing and simple billing that removes payment friction for customers.
Branded, white label experience that preserves partner identity and improves guest satisfaction.
Data and insights delivered at the end of the pilot to inform longterm transport decisions.

Pilot offer summary
Duration: 90 days.
Coverage: One dedicated route serving your location and the main airport with scheduled departures and ondemand pickups.
Fleet: 2 leased vans with professional drivers and a spare for coverage.
Booking options: Simple online booking link, phone reservations, and driver app or WhatsApp confirmations.
Pricing model: Fixed perride rate for direct bookings; invoiced monthly for corporate or bulk bookings.
Service level: 90 percent ontime target; incident response within 2 hours; dedicated operations contact.

What Shuttle Plus will deliver
Operational setup within 14 days including permits, insurance, driver vetting, and vehicle readiness.
Daily operations with morning readiness checks, realtime trip tracking, and endofday reconciliation.
Customer experience kit including branded booking confirmations, driver briefings, and postride satisfaction surveys.
Weekly performance reports covering utilization, ontime performance, incidents, and revenue.
Final pilot report at Day 90 with KPI outcomes, unit economics, recommended pricing, and a proposal to scale.
Key pilot KPIs and targets
Utilization per vehicle: 60–75 percent of operating hours.
Ontime performance: 90 percent pickups within ETA window.
Customer repeat rate: 15–25 percent during pilot.
Breakeven status: Achieve or exceed breakeven utilization by Day 60.
Safety incidents: Zero major safety incidents; any incident triggers immediate review.
Partner commitments
Provide access to partner pickup area and any site rules for guest pickups.
Promote pilot to guests or employees through at least one channel (reception desk, booking email, staff memo).
Facilitate introduction to your accounting contact for monthly invoicing if choosing billed model.
Share feedback and participate in two pilot review meetings at Day 30 and Day 90.
Pricing and commercial terms
Introductory pilot fee covers vehicle lease, insurance, drivers, technology, and operational overhead. Pilot fee example: $12,500 for 90 days payable as agreed.
Perride pricing options available for mixed use; partner discounts for block bookings or prepaid packages.
Liability and insurance: Shuttle Plus carries commercial insurance and complies with applicable permits and licensing.
Next steps and commitment
Start date can be scheduled within 14 days after agreement signature and initial payment.
To confirm the pilot, sign the brief and return a purchase order or confirmation email.
Shuttle Plus will mobilize vehicles, drivers, and the booking system immediately upon confirmation.

Shuttle Plus Service Agreement Template for Hotels and Travel Agents
Note: This is a template for negotiation and internal review. Do not sign until legal counsel has reviewed and the Parties have completed the annexes and operational schedules.

1. Parties
This Service Agreement (the “Agreement”) is made on [Date] between:
Shuttle Plus PLC, a company incorporated under the laws of Ethiopia with registered address at [Address] (“Provider” or “Shuttle Plus”); and
[Hotel / Travel Agent Name], a company/establishment with registered address at [Address] (“Client”).
Collectively “Parties” and individually a “Party”.

2. Purpose and Scope
2.1 Purpose: Provider will supply ground transportation services (passenger shuttle, airport transfers, ondemand rides and related concierge services) to the Client’s customers, guests and staff under the terms of this Agreement.
2.2 Scope: Services covered by this Agreement are described in Schedule A (Service Catalogue) and include booking, dispatch, vehicle provision, driver services, meet & greet (if selected), luggage handling, billing and reporting.

3. Term and Renewal
3.1 Term: This Agreement commences on [Start Date] and continues for an initial term of [12/24] months unless earlier terminated under clause 13.
3.2 Renewal: The Agreement will automatically renew for successive [12] month periods unless either Party provides written notice of nonrenewal at least [60] days before the thencurrent term expiry.

4. Service Levels and Performance
4.1 Service Levels: Provider will meet service levels set out in Schedule B (SLA), including but not limited to ontime pickup percentage, average wait time, reservation acknowledgement SLA and incident resolution SLA.
4.2 Reporting: Provider will deliver monthly performance reports with KPI metrics, booking volumes, cancellations, refunds and incidents.
4.3 Remedies: If Provider fails to meet the SLA, Client is entitled to service credits calculated under Schedule B, subject to Client submitting a claim within [30] days of the relevant period.

5. Booking and Operations
5.1 Booking Channels: Bookings may be made via the Provider’s app, API, web portal or call centre. Client will use agreed booking channels and data formats (see Schedule C — Technical Integration).
5.2 Reservation Rules: Minimum lead time, cancellation windows and noshow policies are set out in Schedule D (Booking and Refund Rules).
5.3 Priority and VIP Requests: Client may tag bookings as VIP; such bookings will receive priority handling and will be billed according to the rate card (Schedule E).
5.4 Changes: Operational changes (routes, peak windows, vehicle types) require mutual written agreement and reasonable lead time for operational adjustments.

6. Pricing and Payment
6.1 Fees: Client will pay the Provider according to the rate card in Schedule E. Rates may include perride fares, waiting time charges, meet & greet fees and monthly service or retainer charges.
6.2 Invoicing: Provider will issue monthly invoices with lineitem detail and supporting reports. Payment due within [30] days of invoice date unless otherwise agreed.
6.3 Taxes: All fees exclude applicable taxes, duties or levies which will be billed in addition where required by law.
6.4 Late Payment: Interest on overdue amounts will accrue at [X]% per month or the maximum lawful rate, plus recovery costs. Provider may suspend services for amounts overdue by more than [30] days after notice and opportunity to cure.


7. Drivers, Vehicles and Safety
7.1 Standards: Provider will supply licensed drivers and roadworthy vehicles maintained in accordance with applicable laws and Provider’s vehicle maintenance program.
7.2 Background Checks: Provider will perform driver vetting and records retention consistent with local law and industry best practice; Client may require additional checks for securitysensitive services.
7.3 Insurance: Provider maintains thirdparty liability and passenger insurance as set out in Schedule F. Provider will provide certificate of insurance on request.
7.4 Safety Incidents: Provider will notify Client of any safety incident affecting a Client booking within [24] hours and provide incident reports within [72] hours.

8. Data Protection and Privacy
8.1 Compliance: Each Party will comply with applicable data protection laws (including Ethiopian PDPP where applicable). Provider will process personal data only to the extent necessary to perform Services and as specified in Schedule G (Data Processing Addendum).
8.2 Data Sharing: Client will supply passenger data required for bookings (name, contact, flight details etc.). Provider will use that data solely for booking fulfilment, safety and invoicing unless separate consent is obtained for marketing.
8.3 Security: Provider will implement technical and organisational security measures (encryption in transit and at rest, RBAC, logging) as described in Schedule G.
8.4 Retention and Deletion: Personal data retention periods and deletion procedures are detailed in Schedule G; on termination, Provider will return or securely delete Client personal data per the Addendum.

9. Confidentiality
9.1 Obligation: Each Party will keep confidential all Confidential Information of the other Party and use it only to perform obligations under this Agreement.
9.2 Exceptions: Confidentiality obligations do not apply to information in the public domain or required to be disclosed by law.
9.3 Duration: Confidentiality survives termination for [3] years (or longer if required for trade secrets).


10. Warranties and Representations
10.1 Each Party warrants it has the authority to enter the Agreement.
10.2 Provider warrants that Services will be performed with reasonable care and skill and in compliance with applicable laws and regulatory licences.
10.3 Except as expressly provided, no further warranties (express or implied) apply.

11. Liability and Indemnities
11.1 Limitation of Liability: Except for liability arising from gross negligence, wilful misconduct, fraud, death or personal injury, each Party’s aggregate liability under this Agreement is limited to the greater of (a) the fees paid or payable in the preceding [12] months or (b) ETB [X].
11.2 Excluded Damages: Neither Party is liable for indirect, special or consequential losses (including loss of profit, reputation or business) except as required by law.
11.3 Indemnity: Each Party indemnifies the other against thirdparty claims arising from its breach of the Agreement, wilful misconduct or negligence. Provider indemnifies Client for claims arising from the acts or omissions of Provider’s drivers in the provision of Services.

12. Insurance
Provider maintains and shall maintain during the Term: passenger liability, public liability, employer’s liability and commercial motor insurance with minimum limits specified in Schedule F. Provider will provide proof of insurance on request.

13. Termination
13.1 For Convenience: Either Party may terminate on [90] days’ written notice.
13.2 For Cause: Either Party may terminate for material breach if the breach remains uncured after [30] days’ written notice.
13.3 Immediate Termination: Immediate termination permitted for insolvency, repeated safety breaches, fraud or material regulatory noncompliance.
13.4 Effect: On termination, Parties will settle outstanding invoices, return confidential information and cooperate on a winddown plan for active bookings.

14. Force Majeure
Neither Party is liable for failure or delay resulting from causes beyond reasonable control (acts of God, war, strikes, government actions, severe weather). The affected Party will notify the other and take reasonable steps to mitigate.

15. Compliance with Law and Conduct
Each Party will comply with all applicable laws, regulations and licences. Provider will ensure drivers comply with hospitality and customer service standards agreed in Schedule A and with Client property rules when operating on Client premises.

16. Intellectual Property

Schedule B — Service Level Agreement and Credit Calculation Model
1 Service Levels Overview
This Schedule B defines the key service levels Shuttle Plus will meet for Client bookings under the Agreement, how performance is measured, and the credit model applied when Service Levels are missed. Metrics below apply to standard prebooked passenger shuttle and airport transfer services unless otherwise specified in a Statement of Work.
2 Definitions
Booking: confirmed reservation with unique booking ID.
Scheduled Pickup Time: the confirmed pickup time or start of pickup window shown to the passenger.
Ontime Pickup: vehicle arrives and is ready to board within the scheduled pickup window or within the tolerated grace period defined in Section 4.
Late Pickup: arrival after the tolerated threshold.
Cancellation by Provider: Provider or assigned driver cancels a confirmed booking prior to passenger pickup.
Completed Trip: trip started and finished without Providerinitiated termination.
Availability: proportion of time the relevant booking and dispatch systems accept and confirm bookings (for integrated API customers).
SLA Period: calendar month used for measuring performance and calculating credits.
3 SLA Metrics and Targets
Ontime Pickup Rate (OTP) — Target: ? 95% (measured per booking)
Average Time to Pickup (ATP) — Target: ? 15 minutes from scheduled pickup (for ondemand) or within scheduled window for prebooked transfers
Cancellation Rate (Provider cancellations / total bookings) — Target: ? 1.5% monthly
Incident Resolution Time (VIP/customer escalations) — Target: median < 30 minutes; highseverity incidents (safety) resolved or escalated within 2 hours
Booking System Availability (for API / integrations) — Target: ? 99.5% uptime per month (excludes scheduled maintenance)
Refund/ Credit Processing Time — Target: simple cases resolved within 3 business days; complex cases within 10 business days
Measurement: metrics computed from booking system logs, driver telematics and support case system; timestamps normalized to local timezone.
4 Measurement Rules and Tolerances
Ontime pickup measured from the scheduled pickup time to the driverreported arrival time and corroborated by GPS and driver checkin photos when required. A standard grace period of 5 minutes applies to scheduled pickup windows unless alternate window is contractually agreed.
For airport transfers, scheduled pickup alignment uses ETA from flight data where applicable; rebook rules apply for delayed flights.
Availability excludes force majeure events and agreed scheduled maintenance windows communicated in advance (minimum 72 hours notice for maintenance > 30 minutes).
Data sources: primary measurement uses system logs (dispatch events); in conflict cases, a reconciliation process uses secondary evidence (driver GPS, call recordings). Provider’s measurement is prima facie; Client may dispute with evidence within 30 days.
5 Credit Calculation Principles
Credits are restorative (applied to future invoices) and not cash refunds except where otherwise agreed. Credits are the sole financial remedy specified in this Schedule except in cases of gross negligence, fraud or other liabilities excluded under main Agreement.
Credits are calculated per affected booking or as monthly aggregate depending on metric. Credits are capped monthly at 100% of fees invoiced to Client for the affected service line that month.
6 PerBooking Credit Table (automatic triggers)
Provider Cancellation (pretrip): credit = 100% of the booking fare plus ETB 250 goodwill credit per affected booking.
Late Pickup: 
Delay > 15 minutes and ? 60 minutes: credit = 30% of booking fare.
Delay > 60 minutes: credit = 100% of booking fare + ETB 150 goodwill credit.
No Replacement/Failed Reassignment after Breakdown: credit = prorata refund for unused journey portion + ETB 200 goodwill credit.
Safetyrelated cancellation (driver misconduct/unsafe vehicle): credit = 100% of fare + ETB 300 goodwill credit; plus priority complaint handling.
Credits under this table are applied automatically when system data indicates an SLA breach and supporting evidence meets policy rules; otherwise Client submits claims under Section 9.
7 Monthly Aggregate SLA Credit Model (corporate invoices)
When Client has an ongoing corporate account invoiced monthly, aggregate SLA credits are applied per the monthly performance shortfall formula:
Compute monthly metric shortfall for each KPI:
Shortfall% = max(0, (Target% ? Actual%)) / Target%
Assign weightings to SLAs (sample):
Ontime Pickup Rate weight = 50%
Cancellation Rate weight = 25%
Booking System Availability weight = 15%
Incident Resolution (VIP) weight = 10%
Calculate Weighted Shortfall:
Weighted Shortfall = ? (Shortfall% × KPI weight)
Credit = min( Monthly Invoice Amount × Weighted Shortfall × Credit Multiplier , Monthly Cap )
Sample parameters:
Credit Multiplier = 1.0 (default)
Monthly Cap = 25% of monthly invoice for that service line
Example:
Monthly Invoice: ETB 200,000
OTP target 95% actual 90% ? Shortfall = (95?90)/95 = 5.26% ? Weighted = 5.26% × 50% = 2.63%
Cancellation target 1.5% actual 3% ? Shortfall = (1.5?3)/1.5 = negative ? treat as Shortfall = (3?1.5)/1.5 = 100% ? Weighted = 100% × 25% = 25% (note: cap individual metric shortfall at 100%)
Availability target 99.5% actual 99% ? Shortfall = (99.5?99)/99.5 = 0.50% ? Weighted = 0.50% × 15% = 0.075%
Incident Res target median <30 actual median 45 ? Shortfall: map to a % scale (use defined conversion table in Annex) ? assume 50% ? Weighted = 50% × 10% = 5%
Weighted Shortfall ? 2.63% + 25% + 0.075% + 5% = 32.705%
Credit = min(200,000 × 32.705% × 1.0 , 200,000 × 25%) = min(65,410, 50,000) = ETB 50,000 credit applied to next invoice.
Notes:
The example demonstrates how a single metric (high cancellation rate) can dominate weighted shortfall; Parties can agree alternate weighting or permetric caps to reflect commercial priorities.
8 Exclusions and Limitations
No credits for SLA breaches caused by: force majeure events, Clientcaused delays or misinformation, thirdparty provider failures beyond Provider’s reasonable control (e.g., municipal road closures), or when Client fails to follow booking instructions.
Credits do not constitute admission of liability. Credits are the exclusive monetary remedy for SLA breaches except where gross negligence, fraud or statutory consumer law requires otherwise.
Credits are not transferable to third parties except by mutual written agreement.
9 Claim Process and Dispute Resolution
Automatic Credits: Provider will autoapply booking level credits when system detects qualifying breaches; Client will receive a monthly credit report itemising all automatic credits.
Manual Claims: Client may submit a claim for uncredited SLA breaches within 30 days of the incident via the agreed claims portal/email with booking ID and supporting evidence. Provider will acknowledge within 3 business days and resolve within 10 business days.
Disputes: If Client disputes Provider’s measurement, Parties will escalate to the Steering Committee for joint review. If unresolved within 30 days, dispute follows clause 18 (Dispute Resolution) of the Agreement.
10 Reporting and Transparency
Provider will furnish monthly SLA report including KPI calculations, raw measurement data for Client bookings, incidents, autoapplied credits and outstanding claims. Reports delivered within 7 business days from month end.
Provider will maintain a realtime dashboard for Client with rolling 30day KPI visibility where API integration exists.
11 Governance and Review
SLA Review: Parties will review SLA targets, weightings and credit multipliers at each 12month renewal or earlier by mutual agreement.
Continuous Improvement: Recurrent SLA failures require joint remediation plan within 30 days and may trigger corrective actions such as operational changes, staffing adjustments or revised pricing.
12 Audit Rights
Client may audit Provider performance data relevant to SLA claims once per year (or more frequently if there is a material dispute) subject to confidentiality restrictions. Audit scope and costs to be agreed in advance; if audit shows Provider underreported breaches by >10%, Provider bears audit cost.
13 Annex: Measurement Conversion Table (Incident Resolution %
Provide a conversion table mapping incident resolution medians to a % shortfall for use in formula (example):
Median ? 30 minutes ? 0% shortfall
Median 31–45 minutes ? 25% shortfall
Median 46–90 minutes ? 50% shortfall
Median > 90 minutes ? 100% shortfall
(Parties to finalise exact buckets and mapping during commercial negotiations.)
14 Acceptance
This Schedule B is agreed in principle and will be finalised with numeric parameter values (grace periods, ETB amounts, weights and monthly caps) before signature. Draft parameters proposed by Provider may be adjusted to match Client priorities.
— End of Schedule B —

Detailed Functions of Shuttle Plus
Booking and Customer Interaction
Reservation System: Customers book via call center, Telebirr app, or bots, providing name, passport number, pickup location, and travel ticket details.
Sorting and Planning: HQ sorts bookings based on urgency, proximity, and feasibility for multiple pickups.
Customer Notification: Sends pickup time, vehicle ID, agent name, and other details via app or SMS.
Pickup and Luggage Handling
Pickup Process: Team 1 agents visit customer locations (e.g., doorstep) with continuous video recording.
Luggage Processing: Luggage is weighed, wrapped, and locked with custom zipties (lock pass codes provided to customers).
Real-Time Tracking: Customers track vehicles via the Telebirr app.
Airport Operations
Luggage Transfer: Team 1 hands over luggage to Team 2 at the airport after customers provide lock codes.
Security and Screening: Team 2 manages security checks. If luggage fails, customers are notified to either allow lock breaking or store luggage at kiosks.
Baggage Claim and Boarding: Boarding passes are sent online; baggage claims are available at kiosks.
Technology and Systems
Telebirr App and API: Facilitates bookings, real-time tracking, and notifications.
Web Apps: Includes customer-facing apps (e.g., Bolt) and backend systems for operations management.
Tablets: Used by agents for customer signatures and displaying terms/conditions.
Vehicle Tracking: GPS-enabled tracking for real-time location updates.
Database: Stores frequent user data and lock pass codes.
Dashboards: Provide operational insights for fleet and performance management.
Pricing and Tiers
Pricing Tiers:
Distance-Based: Charges based on pickup location distance.
Luggage-Based: Fees based on weight or size of luggage.
Number of Travelers: Pricing varies by passenger count.
Groups: Discounts or special rates for group bookings.
VIPs: Premium services with priority handling.
Payment: Processed via Telebirr app or other payment methods.
Add-Ons and Special Services
Last-Minute Requests: Accommodates urgent bookings.
Special Needs: Support for accessibility requirements.
Family Plans: Bundled services for families.
Monthly Subscribers: Subscription plans for frequent users.
Hotel Partnerships: Pickup/drop-off services for hotel guests.
Operational Support
Fleet Management: Oversees vehicle maintenance, car branding, and modifications.
Driver Management: Includes driver recruitment, training, uniforms, and incentives (e.g., 1% per "Scan Me" action).
Exception Handling: Manages issues like failed security checks or customer disputes.
Feedback System: Collects and analyzes customer feedback for service improvement.

Infrastructure
Kiosks: Located at airports for baggage claim and storage of unprocessed luggage.
Office: Central hub for operations and customer service.
Call Centers: Low-priority support for customer inquiries.
Marketing and Branding
Ads and Car Branding: Promotes Shuttle Plus through advertisements and branded vehicles.
Wraps: Custom vehicle wraps for visibility.
Incentives: Offers like 1% rewards per "Scan Me" action to encourage engagement.
Compliance and Training
Insurance and Licenses: Ensures legal compliance for operations and vehicles.
Training: Regular programs for agents and drivers to maintain service quality.
Recruitment: Hires for operational, tech, and support roles.
Non-Priority Areas
Call Centers: Secondary to app-based interactions.
Arrival Services: Not a primary focus compared to pickup and delivery.
Shuttle-Only Services
Shuttle Service: Dedicated shuttle option for customers not requiring full luggage handling.
