Summary of Ethiopian Personal Data Protection Framework
Ethiopia enacted the Personal Data Protection Proclamation (PDPP) in 2024, establishing a comprehensive regime for the collection, processing, storage and crossborder transfer of personal data and recognizing the right to privacy in the digital context justice.gov.et MetaAppz. The PDPP scopes controllers and processors, requires legal bases for processing (consent, legitimate interest, contract, legal obligation), mandates data subject rights (access, rectification, erasure, objection), and designates a regulator to supervise enforcement and sanctions MetaAppz techhiveadvisory.africa.
Sources: justice.gov.et MetaAppz techhiveadvisory.africa.

Key Legal Obligations Relevant to Shuttle Plus
Lawful basis and transparency: collect only the personal data necessary for services (booking, KYC, routing, payments) and provide clear privacy notices explaining purpose, retention and rights MetaAppz techhiveadvisory.africa.
Data subject rights: implement mechanisms for access, correction, deletion and objection; respond within statutory timeframes MetaAppz.
Security and DPIAs: apply technical and organisational measures (encryption, access control, logging) and conduct Data Protection Impact Assessments for highrisk processing such as location tracking or profiling MetaAppz techhiveadvisory.africa.
Recordkeeping and breach notification: maintain processing records and notify the regulator and affected data subjects when breaches present risk to rights and freedoms MetaAppz techhiveadvisory.africa.
Crossborder transfers: restrict outbound transfers unless adequate safeguards or regulator approval exist; document transfer legal basis MetaAppz.
Supervisory authority and sanctions: expect oversight, administrative fines and corrective orders for noncompliance justice.gov.et cipit.org.
Sources: justice.gov.et MetaAppz techhiveadvisory.africa cipit.org.

Major Global Practices and Their Relevance
GDPR (EU): strong rights framework, lawful bases, DPIAs, strict crossborder transfer rules and heavy fines; best practice model for consent language, data minimisation, DPIAs and recordkeeping—useful benchmark for shaping PDPPcompliant procedures and privacy notices techhiveadvisory.africa.
CCPA/CPRA (California): focus on consumer rights, optouts for sale of personal data and verifiable request processes—useful for customerfacing request workflows and marketingconsent management.
PCI DSS: mandatory security controls for payment card data (encryption, segmentation, logging) that Shuttle Plus must apply to payment flows.
Industry frameworks: ISO/IEC 27001 for ISMS, NIST CSF for cybersecurity, and Binding Corporate Rules or Standard Contractual Clauses where available for international transfers; these provide operational controls that satisfy both PDPP security expectations and crossborder adequacy requirements.
Applying these global practices raises customer trust, simplifies multijurisdiction compliance and provides defensible technical controls if Ethiopian regulators align expectations with international norms techhiveadvisory.africa.

How Shuttle Plus Should Map PDPP and Global Practices into Operations
Privacy governance 
Appoint a Data Protection Officer or privacy lead; establish a Data Protection Policy and a steering committee linking legal, IT, product and operations.
Data inventory and lawful basis mapping 
Create a data map (what, why, retention), tag highrisk processing (realtime GPS, profiling) and record lawful bases for each processing activity.
Technical and organisational controls 
Encrypt PII at rest and in transit; apply rolebased access, least privilege, MFA, secure logs and automated retention/erasure. Implement PCI DSS for payments and ISO 27001 controls for the ISMS.
Data subject rights and customer UX 
Build selfservice portals and support workflows to handle access, correction and deletion requests with verification and audit trails.
Contracts and third parties 
Update vendor contracts to include processor obligations, security measures and subprocessor rules; require audit rights and data export safeguards.
Crossborder transfers 
Avoid unnecessary transfers; when required use documented safeguards (SCCstyle clauses, local approvals) and vendor questionnaires.
DPIAs and incident response 
Run DPIAs for new features (realtime tracking, profiling). Maintain an incident response plan with breach notification timelines aligned to PDPP.
Training, audits and records 
Mandatory privacy training for staff; keep processing records, DPIAs and training logs for inspections.
These measures align with PDPP obligations and global best practices to reduce regulatory, operational and reputational risk MetaAppz techhiveadvisory.africa.

Practical 90day Implementation Checklist (Prioritized)
Days 1–14
Appoint privacy lead; run legal gap analysis against PDPP and PCI DSS MetaAppz.
Start a full data inventory for customer PII and payments.
Days 15–45
Publish a concise privacy notice; implement consent/optout controls in apps.
Configure technical basics: TLS, encryption keys, access controls, logging.
Days 46–75
Run DPIAs for GPS tracking and payment processing; remediate findings.
Update vendor contracts and require processor security attestations.
Days 76–90
Deploy selfservice data subject request workflow and incident response playbook; conduct tabletop breach exercises and internal audit; prepare regulatorready documentation techhiveadvisory.africa.
Sources referenced for legal expectations and best practice mapping: MetaAppz techhiveadvisory.africa.

Key Risks and Recommended Mitigations
Risk: Unauthorised access to location or payment data ? Mitigation: encryption, segmentation, strict RBAC, session logging and MFA.
Risk: Improper crossborder transfer ? Mitigation: localise sensitive processing where feasible; use contractual safeguards and regulator approvals for transfers.
Risk: Nonresponsive subjectrights handling ? Mitigation: SLA for requests, verification processes and audit trails.
Risk: Vendor weakness (ridehailing/telemetry providers) ? Mitigation: vendor security assessments, contractual obligations and periodic audits.
Adopting international standards (ISO 27001; PCI DSS) strengthens technical posture and demonstrates good faith compliance to Ethiopian regulators techhiveadvisory.africa.



Tablet app security notes
Device and OS hardening
Use modern, supported tablet OS versions and apply security updates automatically.
Enforce device enrollment (MDM/EMM) to control installed apps, disable sideloading, restrict developer options, and enforce screen lock complexity.
Enable fulldisk encryption at OS level (Android File-based Encryption or iOS Data Protection) so storage is protected if device is lost or stolen.
Require boot integrity protections where available (Secure Boot / Verified Boot) to reduce risk of compromised firmware.

Data at rest and local storage
Encrypt all sensitive data (signed PDFs, raw signature strokes, photos, form JSON) using strong symmetric encryption (AES256GCM) before writing to disk.
Use platform key stores (Android Keystore, iOS Keychain) to store encryption keys or to wrap (encrypt) dataencryption keys; do not persist raw keys in app storage.
Keep only minimal, necessary data on device; avoid storing full customer PII when a reference ID will do.
Implement automatic secure deletion (zeroize) of ephemeral data after successful sync and retention window expiry.

Data in transit and server interactions
Use TLS 1.2+ with modern cipher suites for all network calls; pin certificates or use Mutual TLS for highsecurity endpoints.
Sign upload payloads (HMACSHA256) with a serverissued key and include a nonce/timestamp to prevent replay.
When syncing offline captured signatures, include the device ID, user ID, timestamp, GPS (if allowed), and a serververifiable hash of the signed document (e.g., SHA256) to preserve nonrepudiation chain.


Signature capture integrity and audit trail
Capture vector signature data (stroke points, pressure, timestamp) and/or a flattened image; store raw stroke data so signatures can be validated or replayed for verification.
Calculate and store a cryptographic hash of the final signed PDF or payload and record the hash in the server audit log.
Include immutable audit metadata with each signature: signer_id, signer_device_id, app_version, gps (if permitted), timestamp, staff_id, booking_id, and photo evidence hashes.
Generate a tamperevident certificate of completion (PDF metadata or separate signed JSON) that contains the hash and a server signature (RSA/ECDSA).

Key management, signing, and verification
Use asymmetric keys for document signing and certificate generation: keep private signing keys in a hardened HSM or cloud KMS (e.g., AWS KMS, Google KMS, Azure Key Vault).
Devices should never hold the private signing key; instead, send a signed digest to the KMS/service for signing or use shortlived delegated signing tokens.
Rotate keys on a regular schedule and have an emergency keyrevocation plan.
Publish verification endpoints or a keylookup service so auditors can validate certificates of completion against current public keys.

Authentication, authorization, and least privilege
Require strong operator authentication for tablet users (SSO with 2FA/biometric where available).
Enforce rolebased access control: only authorized roles can sign, override, or submit disputed records.
Use perdevice credentials and allow remote wipe/lock for lost devices.

Offline, sync, and conflict handling
Design an encrypted local queue for offline signatures and evidence, with guaranteedonce delivery semantics and local deduplication by event_id.
Use serverissued nonces or sequence numbers to prevent replay and to validate order during sync.
On sync conflicts, surface a clear reconciliation UI for ops with original payloads, hashes, and timestamps.

Privacy, consent, and legal controls
Ask explicit consent before capturing signatures, photos, or GPS; show short purpose text in the signing UI.
Minimize captured PII; use references and tokenized IDs for server lookups.
Store retention policies and automated deletion schedules aligned with local law and company policy; log deletions in audit trail.

Monitoring, testing, and compliance
Log security events (failed auths, key errors, sync failures) to a centralized, immutable monitoring system with alerting for anomalies.
Perform threat modeling and periodic pen testing (devicelevel and applevel).
Validate cryptographic choices against platform guidance (Android Cryptography, iOS CryptoKit) and industry standards (NIST recommendations where applicable).
Maintain a documented incident response and key compromise plan.

Implementation checklist (practical)
Enroll tablets in MDM and enforce passcodes, encryption, app restrictions.
Implement AES256GCM for local payloads and use platform keystore to wrap keys.
Use TLS 1.2+ with cert pinning; sign uploads with HMAC and include nonces.
Capture raw stroke data + PDF; compute SHA256 hash and request server KMS signature.
Store immutable audit metadata and provide a certificate of completion signed by server keys.
Build offline queue with dedupe by event_id and secure sync logic.
Enable remote wipe, key rotation, and regular security testing.

Tablet security checklist for Ops (provisioning and daily use)
A onepage operational checklist you can use when provisioning, issuing, or returning Shuttle Plus signature tablets.

Preprovisioning (before device receives to staff)
[ ] Purchase devices with modern OS support (Android 11+/iPadOS 15+).
[ ] Record device serial, model, IMEI, and assigned staff_id in asset CSV.
[ ] Securely order and store provisioning tokens / MDM enrollment URLs.

MDM enrollment and baseline config
[ ] Enroll device in company MDM/EMM before handing to staff.
[ ] Enforce screen lock (PIN/complex passcode) and biometric where available.
[ ] Disable developer options, USB debugging, and sideloading.
[ ] Require OS autoupdates and app autoupdates via MDM.
[ ] Configure remote lock & full wipe capability; test one device wipe.

OS, patches, and boot integrity
[ ] Confirm device on latest security patch level and enable autoinstall.
[ ] Enable Verified Boot / Secure Boot where supported.
[ ] Schedule weekly compliance checks from MDM (patch and config drift).

App install and permissions
[ ] Install only approved apps via MDM (driver app, signing app, MDM client).
[ ] Restrict camera, microphone, location permissions to necessary apps only.
[ ] Lock kiosk mode for public/shared tablets where applicable.
[ ] Disable background app installs and thirdparty app stores.

Data at rest protections
[ ] Ensure fulldisk or filebased encryption enabled (Android Filebased, iOS Data Protection).
[ ] Verify app encrypts sensitive files (AES256GCM) before local write.
[ ] Confirm keys used to encrypt local data are stored/wrapped by platform keystore.

Key, token, and secrets handling
[ ] Use perdevice credentials; do not share account credentials across devices.
[ ] Store only shortlived access tokens on device; rotate tokens via MDM.
[ ] Do not embed private signing keys on device; use server/KMS signing flow or delegated shortlived signing tokens.

Network and transport security
[ ] Enforce TLS 1.2+ for all endpoints; enable certificate pinning where practical.
[ ] Block insecure HTTP traffic via MDM network rules.
[ ] Whitelist backend API endpoints and restrict by IP range where possible.

Signature capture & audit integrity
[ ] Capture raw stroke data + timestamp and compute SHA256 on device before upload.
[ ] Include device_id, user_id, booking_id, GPS (optin), and photo_hash in signed payload.
[ ] Request server to sign the digest with KMS and attach certificate of completion to stored PDF.

Offline mode and sync
[ ] Implement encrypted offline queue with dedupe by event_id.
[ ] Configure automatic retry/backoff and reliableonce delivery semantics.
[ ] Test sync conflict resolution and surface manual reconciliation UI to Ops.

Logging, monitoring, and alerting
[ ] Send security events (failed auths, wiped devices, key errors, sync failures) to central log/alerting.
[ ] Create alert for repeated failed sign attempts or large volumes of offline queued data.
[ ] Weekly dashboard: count of offline queues, unsynced signatures, and device compliance rate.

Incident response and lost/stolen devices
[ ] Immediate action on loss: remote lock + remote wipe via MDM; rotate tokens for station.
[ ] Reassign tag/asset in CSV and mark device as lost with timestamp.
[ ] For suspected compromise: revoke device tokens, require reprovisioning, and rotate signing keys if indicated.

Deprovisioning and data sanitation
[ ] Before returning device to pool: run MDM wipe, verify factory reset, and confirm removal from asset CSV.
[ ] Revoke old device credentials and delete local backups of signed documents.
[ ] Reassign tag/NFC and update master mapping for audit.

Validation tests (must pass before golive)
[ ] Confirm MDM enrollment, remote wipe, and policy enforcement.
[ ] Capture test signature, compute hash, upload, and validate server KMS signature.
[ ] Simulate offline capture and successful sync.
[ ] Verify audit record (signature certificate) contains device_id, timestamp, and photo_hash.

Quick operational notes
Keep retention policy: signed PDFs + raw payloads retained in audit store for 12 months.
Train staff: “Ask consent” script before capturing signatures/photos; show short purpose text in UI.
Maintain CSV: tag_serial ? device_id ? staff_id ? assigned_date.
Run monthly spot checks on 10% of devices for compliance and data integrity.




Tablet signature apps — quick research
A concise, actionable briefing on free or freemium tablet apps for digital signatures and terms, how they compare, integration notes (APIs/webhooks), auditability, and a short rollout checklist.

Top free / freemium options (quick compare)
ToolCore strengthTablet supportAPI / integrationDocuSignMarket leader; mobile/tablet apps and strong complianceiPad and Android tablets; dedicated mobile appsREST APIs, webhooks, developer docs DocuSign.SignaturelySimple UX, affordable for SMBsMobile/web-first, works on tabletsAPI for sending templates; good for basic workflows Blogging Wizard.signNowStrong workflow templates, team featuresMobile/tablet apps; offline signingAPI + SAML/SSO for teams; good for scaled templates/workflows Blogging Wizard.Aggregators / listsGood for scouting alternatives and niche free toolsVaries by vendor; useful for discoveryUse to find lightweight/tagged free tools for pilots nearhub.us.Sources: DocuSign product page; roundup articles covering best eSignature apps DocuSign Blogging Wizard nearhub.us.

Key integration and technical notes
APIs & webhooks: If you need automated send/request/receipt flows (e.g., pre-fill booking, attach signed receipt), pick a provider with REST APIs and webhook callbacks to capture signed events and PDFs (DocuSign, signNow provide mature APIs) DocuSign Blogging Wizard.
Deep-linking / mobile UX: For tablet kiosks, use provider SDKs or host a URL that opens the signing session full-screen; provide fallback HTML for devices without app install.
Offline signing: Some apps offer offline signature capture and later sync; verify device SDK support and conflict resolution behavior before rolling out.
Template & field control: Use templating for recurring forms (handoff receipts, waivers) to ensure the same fields (name, id, timestamp, staff_id) are always captured.
(Technical claims supported by product overviews and comparison summaries DocuSign Blogging Wizard.)

Auditability, security, and legal considerations
Audit trail: Ensure the solution attaches an immutable audit log (signer IP/device, timestamps, certificate of completion, and signed PDF) for payroll, disputes, and compliance. DocuSign and enterprise-grade tools include certificates of completion by default DocuSign.
Authentication options: Prefer multi-factor or phone verification for high-value transactions; SMS or email OTPs are commonly supported.
Data residency & retention: Check where signed documents and logs are stored and retention policies—important for compliance in regulated markets.
Legal enforceability: eSignatures are generally enforceable when signer intent and consent are demonstrable and an audit trail exists; confirm local legal advice for region-specific rules.
(Recommendations reflect standard eSignature provider features and best practices DocuSign Blogging Wizard.)

Testing, rollout, and operational checklist
Pick 2 vendors (one market leader, one lightweight) and list required fields for each form.
Prototype: create template for “handoff + luggage tag receipt” and test tablet signing UX in both online and offline modes.
Integration: wire webhooks to your ops system to capture completed PDFs, signer metadata, and trigger payroll/invoice flows.
Audit test: confirm the provider’s certificate contains signer device, timestamp, IP, and document hash.
Security test: validate token/key handling, role-based access, and retention settings.
Pilot: deploy to 5–10 stations for 2 weeks, collect staff feedback on speed, offline reliability, and dispute handling.
Scale: refine templates, enable SSO for staff accounts, and set archival/retention rules for finance/ops.

Quick recommendations
If you need robust compliance, enterprise features, and best-in-class APIs: evaluate DocuSign first DocuSign.
If you want a simple, low-cost pilot with easy templates and quick setup: test Signaturely or signNow for a small team pilot Blogging Wizard.
Use a short pilot (2 weeks) with 5 stations and require completed-PDF webhook delivery and audit-trail verification before broader rollout.



Telebirr App and API Notes —  Future Payments Doc Review
A compact, audit-ready briefing to review Telebirr integration for future payments: core API capabilities, security & compliance, data mapping, testing, webhooks, error handling, monitoring, and rollout checklist.

1. Sources and quick references
Ethio Telecom / Telebirr developer portal (merchant integration, getting started) developer.ethiotelecom.et.
Community and how-to guides summarizing integration steps and common pitfalls zoromia.com Studocu.

2. Integration options and core flows
Typical integration paths: hosted checkout (redirect to Telebirr UI), server-to-server API (create payment, confirm, reconcile), and in-app SDKs for mobile apps. Use hosted checkout to reduce PCI scope; use server-to-server when you need tighter control and offline reconciliation developer.ethiotelecom.et zoromia.com.
Core payment flow: create payment request (amount, merchant ID, order ID), present payment to customer (app/checkout), receive synchronous confirmation or asynchronous webhook, verify transaction signature, reconcile and settle in your ledger developer.ethiotelecom.et zoromia.com.

3. API surface and webhooks (what to expect)
Endpoints you’ll commonly use: Create Payment, Query Payment Status, Refund, and Merchant Account/Balance endpoints. Implement idempotency for Create Payment to avoid duplicate charges developer.ethiotelecom.et zoromia.com.
Webhooks: Telebirr will send asynchronous notifications for payment success, failure, chargebacks, and refunds. Webhook payloads must be validated (signature or shared secret) and your endpoint should respond 200 quickly; use an internal queue to process heavier reconciliation tasks developer.ethiotelecom.et Studocu.

4. Security, authentication, and best practices
Auth: API keys or signed tokens; store secrets in a vault and rotate regularly. Use TLS everywhere and restrict API keys by IP or service when possible developer.ethiotelecom.et.
Validate all incoming webhooks by verifying signatures or shared secrets; reject and log unverified callbacks. Keep an immutable audit log of all request/response pairs used for reconciliation and dispute resolution developer.ethiotelecom.et Studocu.
Idempotency: enforce idempotency keys on create-payment calls and de-duplicate webhook processing using event IDs.

5. Data mapping and ledger design
Minimal fields to capture per transaction: merchant_order_id, telebirr_transaction_id, amount_net, currency, customer_phone, status, payment_method, timestamp, fees, refund_id, and settlement_date. Store raw payload JSON for auditability developer.ethiotelecom.et.
Map add-ons/line-items at booking level so you can calculate staff commissions and incentive distributions from the same canonical record.

6. Error handling and reconciliation
Classify errors: transient (network/timeouts), permanent (insufficient funds/invalid account), and operational (duplicate order, mismatched amounts). Retry transient failures with exponential backoff and alert for repeated failures.
Daily reconciliation: match Telebirr settlement reports to your internal transactions, flag mismatches (amount, missing tx, refunded) and keep a 12month audit trail for payroll and finance disputes developer.ethiotelecom.et.

7. Testing and sandbox
Use Telebirr sandbox/test environment to validate flows, idempotency, and webhook handling; create test cases for success, failure, timeout, and duplicate events. Validate error paths end-to-end including refund flows and chargeback handling developer.ethiotelecom.et zoromia.com.

8. Compliance, limits, and operational considerations
Check merchant onboarding requirements, KYC, transaction limits, settlement cadence, and fee schedule with Ethio Telecom; these affect cashflow and reserve planning developer.ethiotelecom.et.
Plan for offline fallback: accept bookings and mark as pending until payment confirmation arrives; avoid releasing service before confirmed settlement where refunds are costly.

9. Monitoring, alerts, and SLA
Monitor: API error rate, webhook delivery success, settlement delays, chargeback rate, and sudden revenue drops. Surface alerts to Ops and Finance with owners and SLAs.
Typical SLA rules: webhook retried within 24 hours; unresolved settlement mismatches triaged within 48 hours; high-severity payment outages escalated immediately.

10. Rollout checklist (minimum viable launch)
Obtain merchant credentials and API access with Ethio Telecom developer.ethiotelecom.et.
Configure secrets in vault, implement signed webhook endpoint, and enable TLS.
Build Create Payment, Query, and Refund flows with idempotency keys.
Integrate webhooks and validate signatures; queue processing for reconciliation.
Map transaction schema to bookings and incentive engine.
End-to-end tests in sandbox for success/fail/refund/duplicate scenarios zoromia.com Studocu.
Pilot with limited users/stations; reconcile daily and iterate.
Broaden rollout once pilot shows stable webhook delivery and matched settlements.



Telebirr API Integration Spec
A concise, audit-ready one-page spec for integrating Telebirr payments into Shuttle Plus. Includes endpoints, required headers, sample payloads, idempotency rules, webhook handling, error classification, and a minimal implementation checklist.

Overview
Integration modes: Hosted checkout for PCI scope reduction; Server-to-server API for full control and reconciliation.
Primary goals: Create payment, confirm payment, handle asynchronous webhooks, support refunds, keep immutable audit logs, and map payments to bookings/add-ons for commission calculations.

Authentication and Security
Auth method: API key or signed token provided by Telebirr.
Transport: TLS only.
Secrets storage: Use a secrets vault; rotate keys periodically.
Webhook verification: Validate signature or HMAC on every callback; reject requests failing verification and log raw payload.
Audit log: Store raw request and response JSON for each transaction with timestamps and processing status.

Core Endpoints and Sample Payloads
Create Payment 
Purpose: Create a payment request and return a payment URL or client token.
Required fields: merchant_order_id, amount_net, currency, customer_phone, callback_url, metadata (booking_id, staff_id, add_on_ids).
Sample request
{
  "merchant_order_id": "SP-ORD-20251104-0001",
  "amount_net": 1200,
  "currency": "ETB",
  "customer_phone": "+251912345678",
  "callback_url": "https://ops.shuttleplus.com/webhooks/telebirr",
  "metadata": {"booking_id":"BKG-1024","staff_id":"CS-YK","line_items":["SNACK-01","PRIOR-01"]}
}
Expected immediate response: payment_id, payment_url or client_token, status=PENDING, created_at.
Query Payment Status 
Purpose: Confirm final state of a payment (success, failed, refunded).
Sample request
GET /payments/{payment_id}
Authorization: Bearer <API_KEY>
Expected response: payment_id, merchant_order_id, amount_net, status, telebirr_txn_id, fees, settled_at.
Refund Payment 
Purpose: Initiate a refund tied to telebirr_transaction_id or payment_id.
Sample request
{
  "payment_id": "PAY-0001",
  "telebirr_txn_id": "TB-20251104-9988",
  "amount": 300,
  "reason": "Customer cancellation",
  "metadata": {"refund_ref":"R-20251104-01"}
}
Expected response: refund_id, status=PENDING or COMPLETED, processed_at.
Merchant Balance and Settlement Reports 
Purpose: Pull settlement and fee reports for reconciliation.
Sample response fields: settlement_date, total_settled, fees_total, transactions_count, raw_report_url.

Idempotency and Error Handling
Idempotency keys: Required on Create Payment and Refund endpoints. Use a deterministic key pattern: merchant_order_id + operation_type. Store keys and responses to prevent duplicates.
Error classification 
Transient: network timeouts, 5xx errors — retry with exponential backoff.
Permanent: insufficient funds, invalid account — surface to user and ops.
Operational: duplicate order, mismatched amounts — open manual reconciliation ticket.
Retries: Apply exponential backoff for transient errors, cap retries, alert ops if repeated failures.

Webhooks and Asynchronous Flows
Events to expect: payment_success, payment_failed, payment_refunded, chargeback, settlement_report_ready.
Webhook handling best practices 
Validate signature/HMAC.
Respond 200 immediately upon valid receipt.
Enqueue heavy work (reconciliation, payroll triggers, notifications) for async processing.
De-duplicate using telebirr_event_id.
Log raw payload for auditability.
Idempotency for webhooks: store processed telebirr_event_id; ignore duplicates.

Data Mapping and Reconciliation
Canonical transaction record fields: merchant_order_id, payment_id, telebirr_txn_id, amount_net, currency, fees, status, customer_phone, booking_id, staff_id, line_items, created_at, settled_at, raw_payload.
Daily reconciliation: match Telebirr settlement report to internal payment records; flag mismatches for manual review. Keep 12 months of raw payload and reconciliation notes.

Testing, Sandbox, and Monitoring
Sandbox testing: test success, failure, duplicate, refund, and chargeback flows.
Monitoring: webhook delivery success rate, API error rate, settlement lag, chargeback rate.
Alerts: automated alerts to Ops and Finance for webhook failure spikes, failing reconciliation counts, or settlement delays.

Minimal Implementation Checklist
Obtain merchant credentials and sandbox access from Telebirr.
Implement Create Payment, Query, Refund endpoints with idempotency keys.
Securely store API keys and webhook secrets.
Build webhook endpoint with signature validation and de-duplication.
Map payment payloads to booking lines and staff IDs for commission logic.
Run end-to-end tests in sandbox for all event types.
Implement daily reconciliation job and exception queue.
Pilot with limited stations and monitor webhook reliability and settlement accuracy.




Terms and Conditions 
Please read these Terms and Conditions carefully. They explain your rights and responsibilities when using Shuttle Plus transfer and concierge services. Where these Terms reference airline rules, those are included to ensure safe and lawful transfers between flights and airport facilities.

1. Service summary and acceptance
Shuttle Plus provides prebooked and ondemand shuttle, private transfer, meetandgreet, and related concierge services (the “Services”).
By booking or using the Services you accept these Terms and any booking confirmation, fare rules, and the policies displayed at booking.
The booking confirmation (email, SMS or inapp) is the contract for that trip and contains your pickup time, meeting point, driver details, vehicle type, fare, and any special requests.

2. Booking, fares, payments and confirmations
Bookings: You must provide accurate passenger names, contact number, pickup/dropoff addresses, flight numbers (if applicable), passenger count, luggage count, and any special requirements (wheelchair, child seat, pet, etc.).
Fare quoted: The fare shown at booking is payable to confirm the booking. Fare components (base fare, taxes, tolls, surcharges, extraservice fees) are itemized in the confirmation. Local taxes and airport fees may apply.
Payment methods: We accept the payment methods shown at checkout. If a thirdparty payment gateway is used, their terms apply to the transaction.
Price changes: For bookings paid at time of booking, the fare is fixed. For reservations held without payment, quoted fares may change and are not guaranteed until paid.
Currency and conversion: All prices are shown in the currency selected at booking. Cardholder bank conversion fees are the user’s responsibility.
Receipts: A digital receipt is issued after payment and should be retained for expense and reimbursement purposes.


3. Cancellations, refunds and no-shows
Customer cancellations: 
Free cancellation window and any cancellation fees are shown on the booking confirmation. If cancelled outside the free window, a cancellation charge may apply.
For group or specially commissioned bookings (large vehicles or airport meetandgreet services) longer notice periods and higher cancellation charges may apply; these are stated at booking.
Operator cancellations and reassignments: Shuttle Plus may reassign the booking to an equivalent vehicle or partner operator if the original vehicle or driver is unavailable. We will notify you and provide options (refund, rebook, or upgrade if available).
Noshows: If a passenger does not appear at the agreed pickup point within the published pickup window and the driver follows the meetandgreet and waiting procedure in the booking confirmation, a noshow fee may be charged.
Refunds: Refunds (where applicable) are processed to the original payment method within the timeframe stated in the confirmation or applicable refund policy. Administrative processing times of payment providers may apply.

4. Airport, airline coordination and flightrelated rules
Flight monitoring: If you provide your flight number, Shuttle Plus will monitor the flight for schedule changes and attempt to adjust pickup timing. You must still keep your contact details up to date.
Delays and missed connections: We aim to accommodate reasonable flight delays. If you miss a flight, we will assist within available options but are not responsible for missed onward flights or airline penalties. Airline rebooking and passenger liability follow each airline’s terms.
Airline carry-on, checked luggage and oversized items: Shuttle Plus follows standard airline luggage categorization for planning capacity but is not responsible for airline baggage allowances, fees, or lost/damaged airlinechecked baggage. If luggage exceeds vehicle capacity, you must request an appropriate vehicle at booking or accept additional charges.
Airline baggage liability: Airlines retain primary liability for checked baggage loss or damage during flight. For incidents occurring during a Shuttle Plus transfer (loading, transit, unloading) see the “Liability and insurance” section below.
Security, customs, and restricted items: Passengers must comply with airport security and customs regulations. Shuttle Plus may refuse transport of hazardous, illegal, or restricted items and will notify authorities if required.

5. Passenger responsibilities, conduct and special needs
Accurate information: Provide true and complete passenger and booking information. Changes must be communicated promptly. Incorrect details that cause failure to meet schedules may incur fees.
Identification: Passengers must carry valid photo ID and any required travel documents. Drivers may request identification prior to boarding.
Conduct: Passengers must behave respectfully. Abusive, threatening, intoxicated or dangerous behavior is prohibited. Shuttle Plus reserves the right to refuse or terminate service for such conduct. No refund will be given for terminated journeys due to passenger misconduct.
Safety and seatbelts: Use of seatbelts is mandatory where provided. Child restraint laws and airline guidance prevail; child seats must be requested at booking and may incur extra charges.
Pets and service animals: Service animals are allowed with prior notice and documentation. Pets may require advance approval, fees, and carriers. Unapproved animals may be refused.
Luggage: You are responsible for labeling and securing your luggage. For group bookings, state luggage counts in advance. Shuttle Plus is not responsible for items left in vehicles beyond the driver’s normal duty to check and return items promptly when notified.

6. Liability, insurance and claims
Our liability: Shuttle Plus operates as a transportation service provider and uses reasonable care to deliver Services. Subject to applicable law: 
We accept liability for proven direct loss or damage caused by Shuttle Plus’s negligence, up to an amount equivalent to EUR 1,000 (or local currency equivalent) per passenger per incident, unless a higher limit applies under mandatory local law.
We are not liable for indirect, incidental, special or consequential losses (including missed flights, onward travel costs, loss of earnings), except where required by law.
Baggage and personal property: For loss or damage to property during a Shuttle Plus transfer (loading, transit, unloading), liability is limited to proven direct loss and must be reported immediately to the driver and within 24 hours using our incident reporting process. Receipts or proof of value are required for claims.
Security incidents and theft: If an act of theft or assault occurs, notify local authorities and Shuttle Plus immediately. We will cooperate with official investigations. Shuttle Plus is not responsible for criminal acts by third parties, but will assist with evidence, CCTV requests where available, and incident reporting.
Insurance: Vehicles and drivers engaged for Shuttle Plus operations carry the minimum insurance required by local law; this may include thirdparty liability coverage. For higher value risk items or commercial passenger liability, passengers or corporate customers should arrange additional insurance as desired.
Force majeure: Shuttle Plus is not liable for delay or failure to perform due to events beyond our reasonable control (severe weather, natural disaster, strikes, government restrictions, airport closures, terrorism, or other force majeure events). In such cases we will offer rebooking or refund according to availability and safety considerations.

7. Data, privacy and communications
Data collected: To provide Services we collect booking and contact information, flight details, pickup/dropoff locations, payment details, device and location telemetry during trips, driver notes, and incident logs.
Purpose: Data is used to confirm bookings, operate transfers, monitor safety, process payments, comply with legal obligations, and improve services. We may share data with partner operators, payment processors, hotels, or authorities where necessary and lawful.
Analytics and marketing: With consent, we may use contact details to send ride confirmations, ETA notifications, receipts, service updates, and promotions. You can opt out of marketing communications as instructed in each message.
Retention: We retain booking and incident records for the period required by law and for operational audits.
Data subject rights: Subject to local law, you may request access to or correction of your personal data. Contact privacy@shuttleplus.com for requests or see our Privacy Policy for details.

8. Service changes, disruptions and refunds
Operational changes: We may modify pickup times, meeting points, vehicle make/model, or driver assignment for operational reasons; we will notify you and provide alternatives. If the change materially reduces service and you do not accept alternatives, you may request a refund.
Service suspension: We may suspend services for safety, regulatory, or operational reasons. Refunds for suspended services follow the cancellation and refund rules in Section 3.
Refund eligibility: Refunds are processed after investigation of the event. For validated service failures (missed pickup when Shuttle Plus is at fault, gross service shortfall) partial or full refunds may be issued at our discretion and as set in the refund policy.

9. Complaints, claims and dispute resolution
Immediate on-trip issues: Tell the driver or call the emergency/operations number shown in your confirmation; we aim to respond and resolve quickly.
Formal complaints: Submit within 7 days of incident to ops@shuttleplus.com with booking ID, description, and supporting evidence (photos, receipts). We will acknowledge within 48 hours and aim to resolve within 14 business days.
Claims for loss/damage: File within 24 hours for lost items; attach proof of ownership/value. We may require police reports for theft claims.
Dispute escalation: If unresolved, parties may seek mediation. If necessary, disputes will be subject to the governing law and jurisdiction in Section 10.

10. Governing law, thirdparty terms and changes to these Terms
Governing law and jurisdiction: These Terms are governed by the laws of the country where the booking is fulfilled (for Shuttle Plus operations in Ethiopia, Ethiopian law applies) and the competent courts of that jurisdiction, unless otherwise agreed in writing.
Airline and thirdparty rules: Airline terms regarding checked baggage, flight changes, denied boarding, and security remain the passenger’s responsibility. By using our Services, you agree Shuttle Plus may exchange necessary booking and flight information with airlines, hotels, or local authorities to support your transfer.
Thirdparty providers: Where Shuttle Plus uses partner operators, ground handlers, or subcontractors, those partners’ policies may also apply; Shuttle Plus remains the primary contact for customer service unless otherwise stated at booking.
Changes to these Terms: We may update these Terms. Material changes will be posted on our website and communicated to customers with active bookings. Continued use after notice constitutes acceptance of the updated Terms.

Free cancellation windows and fees are shown at booking—read them.
We monitor flights if you supply flight numbers but are not responsible for airline changes.
Report lost items immediately; file claims within 24 hours.
For emergencies, call the ops priority number in your booking confirmation.
For privacy or data requests, contact privacy@shuttleplus.com.

THE CANVAS — stickynote wall system for Shuttle Plus
Below is a practical, stepbystep plan to capture every Shuttle Plus idea, process, and responsibility on a single physical wall (“THE CANVAS”) so anyone can read it, understand the endtoend flow, and act. It uses crisp color coding, clear hierarchy, department lanes, evidence tags, and a simple maintenance routine.

1. Physical setup and materials
Wall size: minimum 2.5m × 1.5m (larger if you have more details).
Sticky notes: 3 sizes — Small (50×50mm) for microtasks, Medium (76×76mm) for process steps, Large (100×150mm) for major pillars or policies.
Colors: at least 6 colors (see color map below).
Extras: thin black marker, finetip for small notes, colored pens, masking tape for lanes, legend card, string/pins for linking, roll of clear tape, camera for daily capture.
Mounting: use horizontal rows (lanes) taped to the wall; leave a 30–40cm title/header row at top.

2. Color coding (single source of truth)
Yellow — Core Processes (bookings, dispatch, pickup, dropoff, billing)
Blue — People & Roles (Driver, Dispatcher, Ops Lead, Concierge, HR, Customer Care)
Green — Systems & Tech (App, API, GTM, GA4, Telematics, Tablet, Cameras)
Pink — Safety, Compliance & Incident (first aid, accident ops, chainofcustody, insurance)
Orange — Fleet & Vehicle (vehicle mods, maintenance, wraps, scale, tablet spec)
Purple — Customer Experience & Product (T&Cs, checkout copy, concierge kit, service tiers)
White (or pale) — Notes / Questions / Unknowns / Blockers (use small notes for quick capture)



3. Hierarchy and layout (how to arrange THE CANVAS)
Top header row (large notes): Company Vision, Core Service Offerings, Key KPIs (ontime %, incident rate, NPS).
Second row (large notes): Major Domains — Admin & HR | Operations | Fleet | Tech | Customer | Safety & Compliance. These are column headers (vertical lanes below each).
Under each domain lane: stack medium notes vertically for major processes (e.g., under Operations: Booking flow ? Dispatch ? Driver assignment ? Pickup ? Incident handling ? Posttrip ops).
For each process step: use medium sticky on the left as the step title, and attach small stickies to its right to represent subtasks, owners, systems, rules, and risks.
Use string or thin tape to show crosslane links (e.g., Booking ? Tech webhook ? Dispatch). Add a small tag at intersection points with a short label (“webhook”, “GA4 event”, “MDM policy”).

4. Departments and essential content to add (starter checklist)
Admin / HR (Blue) 
Onboarding flow (documents, equipment issue, training, DVIR training)
Offboarding checklist, payroll SOP, recruitment screening.
Roles matrix: who signs what; training cadence.
Operations (Yellow) 
Booking intake: web/app flow, required fields, flight monitoring.
Dispatch flow: Unassigned ? Assign ? En route ? Waiting ? In transit ? Completed.
Incident response quick steps (first 0–10 min), OPS priority escalation.
Shift handover & daily standup checklist.
Fleet (Orange) 
Vehicle mod checklist (wraps, cameras, tablet, telematics, scale).
Maintenance schedule, DVIR steps, spare parts inventory.
Vehicle assignment rules (capacity, certs).
Tech & Systems (Green) 
Booking system endpoints, webhook chain, GTM/GA4 events (prebook CTA), dispatcher dashboard endpoints.
Tablet spec & MDM; telematics provider; dashcam export process.
Monitoring alerts and key logs to check daily.
Customer Experience (Purple) 
Checkout summary, T&C onepage, concierge kit contents, SLA by tier.
Refund/cancellation rules, lostandfound flow, complaint timeline.
Safety & Compliance (Pink) 
Accident ops procedures, chainofcustody steps, evidence hashes, storage location.
First aid card, local emergency contacts, data retention policy.
Crossfunctional items (White small notes) 
Vendor contacts, legal holds, insurance references, airport liaison names.

5. Tags, icons and quick metadata on each sticky
Owner: write initials in top right corner of each sticky (e.g., AB).
SLA / target: small circle on bottom left: green (ok), amber (watch), red (blocked).
Status dot: small filled dot top left: New / In progress / Review / Done (use drawn symbols: N / ? / ? / ?).
Evidence tag (for anything that needs logs or recordings): small ?? icon + reference ID (e.g., EV-0001).
System tag for automation points: small ?? and API name (e.g., /api/bookings).
Priority number: top center (1–3) for urgency.

6. How to write each sticky (one idea per sticky)
One action or fact only. Short headline (5–8 words).
Extra context on a small white sticky attached to the main note if needed.
Example: Medium (Yellow) “Booking: Prebook CTA” + small green sticky “GA4 event pre_book_cta_click” + small white sticky “Submit webhook to /api/bookings”.

7. Visual linking and flow mapping
Use thin colored string for directional flow: green string for “data flow”, red string for “escalation / human flow”, black for “log/record/chainofcustody”.
Place arrows (tape or drawn) along strings to indicate direction.
Numbered steps: small circular tags 1?2?3 sequence where multistep workflows exist (e.g., Booking 1: click ? 2: complete form ? 3: payment ? 4: booking_created event).


8. Readability rules (so a viewer can scan quickly)
Topleft corner = immediate issues (P1/P2) — place red small notes there.
Use consistent shorthand (create a legend card on THE CANVAS).
Limit text per sticky: headline only on the sticky; attach small white note for details, links, or file IDs.
Reserve the rightmost column for “Action pool / Backlog” — things to prioritize into the wall.

9. Hierarchical drill pattern (how a viewer can read)
Start at top header (vision & KPIs) ? choose domain column ? read major process medium notes top to bottom ? expand with attached small notes and white context notes ? follow strings across lanes to see integrations and handoffs ? check owner initials and SLA dot for immediate followups.

10. Daily practice & maintenance
Daily 10minute standup at THE CANVAS: update status dots and move stickies as items progress.
Weekly tidy: consolidate completed stickies into an “Archive” board or photograph and store digitally.
Monthly snapshot: photograph THE CANVAS and upload to shared drive + update any digital trackers (Jira/Trello) with changes.
Change control: only Ops Lead (or delegated) can remove medium/large sticky notes; others add small white notes or comments.

11. Converting from physical to digital (later)
Photograph THE CANVAS every day; use a white photo backdrop and good lighting.
Feed images into Miro/Mural or Trello by creating cards matching sticky color, owner, and tags.
Tag each digital card with evidence ref IDs and link to drive files (dashcam exports, incident reports, T&C docs).

12. Legend / sample key (place on THE CANVAS top right)
Color legend with short text lines.
Symbols: Owner initials; SLA dots; Evidence ??; System ??; Priority numbers.
Read order: 1. Top header 2. Domain lanes 3. Left?Right flows 4. Backlog column.

13. Starter fill list (first 60 stickies to place)
Put these first to make THE CANVAS instantly informative: 
Vision + KPIs (3 large)
Booking flow core steps (5 medium + param smalls)
Dispatch states + SLA thresholds (4 medium)
Driver tablet spec & MDM (1 medium + 2 smalls)
Vehicle modification checklist (1 medium + 6 smalls)
Incident ops quick card (1 medium + 4 smalls)
Chainofcustody steps (1 medium + 5 evidence sample smalls)
T&C checkout summary (1 medium)
Concierge kit contents + first aid card (1 medium + 6 smalls)
Prebook CTA tracking (1 small + GA4 event)
Webhook flow: booking_created ? backend ? dispatch (3 smalls)
Driver training & refresher schedule (1 medium)
Ops contact & airport liaison (1 medium)
Backlog / Ideas column (5 smalls)

14. Example micro layouts (to paste on the wall)
Booking lane example (vertical): 
[Medium yellow] Booking: Prebook CTA 
[Small green] GA4 event: pre_book_cta_click (?? /api/gtm)
[Small white] Test plan: 3 test bookings (IDs)
[Small green] Webhook: /api/bookings -> backend
Incident lane example: 
[Medium pink] Incident: Accident ops (P1) 
[Small white] First 0–10 min checklist
[Small green] Evidence: Dashcam export EV-0001 (??)
[Small blue] Owner: Hana T. (Ops Lead)

15. Practical tips to avoid clutter
One idea per sticky. If a sticky becomes crowded, split it.
Reserve a small box on the wall labeled “Archive Today” for completed stickies — move them there at day end and photograph.
Use abbreviations consistently (create a 1column shorthand list on legend).

16. Quick rollout plan (30–90 minutes to set up)
0–10 min: mount lanes & legend; place header notes.
10–30 min: populate starter 60 stickies using the Starter fill list.
30–60 min: add owners, SLA dots, and link strings between top 10 integrations.
60–90 min: run 10minute team walkthrough to validate reading order and update missing owners.



Organizational Canvas Structure (CEOs to frontline)
Design THE CANVAS as a topdown org map that flows vertically from strategy to execution, then horizontally into department lanes. Place the CEO / Vision at the very top (Large note). Under that, create one horizontal band of department headers (Medium notes): HR, Marketing & Sales, Product & CX, Operations, Fleet & Maintenance, Tech & Data, Safety & Compliance, Finance & Legal. Under each department header, create role rows (small/medium notes) that descend from strategic functions to frontline roles.
Top: CEO / Vision / KPIs (Large note)
Next row: Department headers (Medium notes) — HR | Marketing & Sales | Product & CX | Operations | Fleet & Maintenance | Tech & Data | Safety & Compliance | Finance & Legal
Under each header: Role rows (Small notes) in order: strategic ? tactical ? frontline. 
Example under Operations: Ops Lead ? Dispatchers ? Kiosk Agents ? Concierge ? Drivers.
Rightmost column: Backlog / Projects / Archive / Crosshub items (Medium frame).

Color coding, shapes and sticky sizes
Keep the same color language so anyone scanning knows department, type and priority at a glance.
Color by department (medium/large stickies): 
HR — Blue; Marketing/Sales — Purple; Product & CX — Teal; Operations — Yellow; Fleet — Orange; Tech & Data — Green; Safety & Compliance — Pink; Finance/Legal — Gray.
Sticky sizes: 
Large (policy/vision/KPI cards)
Medium (process blocks and major SOPs)
Small (tasks, owners, blockers, evidence IDs)
Shapes & markers: 
Owner initials (top right); SLA dot (bottom left: green/amber/red); Priority number (top center); Evidence lock icon ?? if recordings/data required; Gear ?? for automation points.

Safety & Compliance (Pink)

Small: Local emergency numbers; Police/insurer contact templates; Evidence hashes list.
Finance & Legal (Gray) 
Medium: Fare rules & refund matrix; Partner contracts template; Insurance cover matrix
Small: Payment reconciliation steps; VAT/tax notes; Legal escalation flow.

Frontline role rows and practical sticky examples
Create a dedicated horizontal strip for frontline roles across lanes so the viewer sees who executes what.
Drivers (under Fleet & Ops): DVIR checklist; Tablet quickstart; Incident first response; Evidence preservation steps (?? EV-ID)
Dispatchers (Ops/Tech): Assign shortcuts; Autoassign rules; SLA timers; Reassign protocol; Map view pin conventions
Kiosk Agents (Ops/Product): Checkin script; Flight monitoring checklist; Meet & greet protocol; Passenger verification steps
Concierge (CX/Safety): VIP kit checklist; Medical escalation; Passenger assistance log; Claims handoff
Sales / Account Execs (Marketing/Sales): Corporate SLA sheet; Onboarding checklist for corporate clients; Pricing exceptions approval flow
Each frontline sticky should list: Owner, Trigger (when it runs), Inputs (booking/flight/phone), Outputs (assigned driver, confirmation), and Evidence (if recordings/logs required).

Handoffs, flows and visual linkage (how to show transitions)
Make handoffs explicit with connectors and microtags.
Use colored string or arrow connectors: 
Green string = data/automation flow (webhook, API)
Red string = escalation/human flow (incident, medical)
Black string = evidence/log flow (recording export, hash, storage)
At each handoff sticky, attach a small white tag listing: Who acts next, Timeout/SLA, Primary system (e.g., Dispatcher app / Telematics / MDM), and Fallback.
Mark “touchpoints” with ?? for automation and ?? when recordings must be preserved. Example: Booking_created (Yellow sticky) ? ?? /api/bookings (Green sticky) ? Dispatcher assign (Yellow sticky).

Practical workshop & maintenance playbook
Run a short session to populate and keep THE CANVAS alive.
Setup (30–60 min): Place top vision/KPIs and department headers. Populate each lane with starter stickies (use the Starter Fill list we created earlier).
Team session (60–90 min): Each department adds/states 8–12 stickies (processes, owners, blockers). Facilitate crosslane handoffs and mark evidence points.
Daily standup (10 min): Move SLA dots, update blockers, snap photo.
Weekly tidy (30 min): Archive completed stickies to the Backlog/Archive frame; update digital Miro board.
Owner rules: Department head can move medium stickies; frontline owners update small task stickies.



Overview
Below are practical alternative ways to arrange THE CANVAS beyond a purely organizational (CEO?drivers) layout. Each approach explains what it reveals, when to use it, a quick layout recipe (how to place lanes/cards), color & size guidance, the key elements to capture, and the primary audience or owner. Pick the approach that matches the outcome you need (clarity of handoffs, customer experience, risk control, scaling plans, etc.).

1) EndtoEnd Process Flow (linear service flow)
What it reveals: Exact stepbystep customer & ops journey from lead/prebook ? posttrip reconciliation.
When to use: To eliminate handoff gaps, simplify SOPs, or train dispatch/kiosk staff.
Layout recipe: One long horizontal timeline from left (prebook) to right (posttrip). Above timeline: systems & triggers; below: owners and SLAs.
Color & size: Yellow for process steps (medium); Green for tech integrations (small); Blue for owners/roles (small).
Key elements: Inputs, outputs, decision gates, SLA timers, fallbacks, evidence points.
Audience / owner: Ops Lead, Process Designer.

2) Customer Journey Map (personacentric)
What it reveals: Experience, emotions, touchpoints and pain points across stages for a named persona (e.g., business traveler).
When to use: To prioritize CX improvements, design concierge flows, or tune product tiers.
Layout recipe: Vertical swimlanes per journey stage (Discover ? Book ? Pretrip ? Pickup ? Intrip ? Posttrip). In each stage: customer thoughts, ops touchpoints, tech events, metrics.
Color & size: Purple for CX touchpoints; Yellow for ops steps; Pink for pain/risks (small highlight stickies).
Key elements: Persona card, emotional curve (emoji or color), moments of truth, opportunities.
Audience / owner: Product & CX, Growth.

3) Service Blueprint (process + backstage systems)
What it reveals: Visible customer actions and the backstage systems/processes that support them (apps, APIs, telematics, vendors).
When to use: To align product, tech, and operations; to identify automation opportunities.
Layout recipe: Top row customer actions, next row frontstage (Kiosk/Driver/Concierge), then backstage systems, bottom row partners/vendors. Vertical lines show exact touchpoint mapping.
Color & size: Green for systems; Yellow for frontstage; Orange for fleet/hardware; White for partners.
Key elements: Touchpoint mapping, supporting APIs, SLA expectations, handoff owners.
Audience / owner: Tech Lead + Ops Lead.

4) ValueStream Map (efficiency & lead time focus)
What it reveals: Cycle times, wait times, waste, and value vs nonvalue tasks across a flow (ideal for continuous improvement).
When to use: To reduce lead time, cut rework, or optimize dispatch capacity.
Layout recipe: Linear value stream lanes with metrics under each step: cycle time, wait time, % value add. Highlight bottlenecks in red.
Color & size: Yellow for valueadding steps; Gray for nonvalue; Red tags for bottlenecks.
Key elements: Takt time, CT/WT, inventory queues, improvement ideas (Kaizen).
Audience / owner: Ops Improvement / COO.

5) Capability / Function Map (what you need to scale)
What it reveals: Core capabilities (booking engine, dispatch, fleet ops, incident response, B2B sales) and maturity/readiness per capability.
When to use: For roadmap planning, org design, and investment prioritization.
Layout recipe: Grid — rows are capabilities, columns are maturity levels or “people / process / tech / metrics.”
Color & size: Teal/Green for tech readiness; Blue for people readiness; Orange for fleet readiness.
Key elements: Capability owner, required hires, systems, compliance gaps, time to market.
Audience / owner: CEO, Head of Strategy, HR.

6) Ecosystem / Partner Map (external relationships)
What it reveals: Airports, hotels, travel agencies, insurers, telematics vendors, printing/install vendors, payment providers and contract terms/SLAs.
When to use: To manage risk, negotiation, and partner SLAs.
Layout recipe: Central Shuttle Plus node ? concentric rings: Tier 1 partners (critical), Tier 2 (support), Tier 3 (optional). Add contract expiry & SLA tags.
Color & size: Orange for operational partners; Purple for commercial; Gray for legal/insurance.
Key elements: SLA summary, renewal date, contact owner, integration type.
Audience / owner: Partnerships / Legal / Ops.

7) Risk & Compliance Wall (safety critical)
What it reveals: All safety, legal, insurance, and privacy risks with controls, residual risk score, and mitigation owners.
When to use: For audits, safety reviews, ART preparedness, and insurance renewals.
Layout recipe: Columns for Risk, Likelihood (H/M/L), Impact (H/M/L), Control, Owner, Status. Use large pink notes for highpriority risks.
Color & size: Pink for risks; Red for critical; White for mitigations.
Key elements: Evidence links, incident history, control effectiveness, next remediations.
Audience / owner: Compliance, Safety Manager.

8) Roadmap / Initiative Timeline (quarterly or 90day view)
What it reveals: Which projects, hires, and integrations land by when, and who is accountable.
When to use: For quarterly planning, investor updates, and resource allocation.
Layout recipe: Horizontal timeline with swimlanes per department; place initiatives as timeboxed cards; add milestones and Go/NoGo gates.
Color & size: Department colors; timeline bars (long cards) for multimonth projects.
Key elements: Deliverables, acceptance criteria, dependencies, risks.
Audience / owner: Exec team, PMO.

9) Incident / WarRoom Board (operational incident focus)
What it reveals: Active incidents, current status, owners, immediate actions, evidence, and communications.
When to use: During multivehicle incidents, major outages, or serious safety events.
Layout recipe: Columns: Active Incidents, Triage (0–10 min), In Progress (containment), Investigating, Resolved, Lessons. Include evidence column with EVIDs and hashes.
Color & size: Red for P1; Amber for P2; Green for resolved. Large pink for critical incident SOP.
Key elements: Incident owner, log timeline, evidence export links, comms templates.
Audience / owner: Ops, Safety, Legal.

10) Hypothesis / Experiment Wall (growth & product)
What it reveals: Hypotheses, experiments, metrics, and outcomes to iterate product features or marketing tests.
When to use: When testing CTA variants, pricing experiments, or driver incentive programs.
Layout recipe: Columns: Hypothesis ? Experiment design ? Run (dates) ? Metrics ? Result ? Next action. Tag experiments with primary KPI.
Color & size: Purple for hypotheses; Green for live experiments; White for learnings.
Key elements: A/B variants, sample sizes, metrics tracked, owner.
Audience / owner: Growth, Product.

Implementation & hybrid suggestions
Hybrid walls: Combine two approaches (e.g., Customer Journey + Service Blueprint) by stacking one visual above the other or using foldable sections on the same wall.
Rotating views: Keep THE CANVAS main frame (org or vision) and swap a secondary frame (Risk, Roadmap, Experiments) monthly.
Layering: Use transparent acetate overlays for temporary experiments or quarterly roadmaps so the baseline wall remains stable.
Digital sync: Mirror the physical approach in Miro/Figma with matching colors, tags, and owner fields to keep audit trails and export CSVs.

Visual & legend rules (short checklist)
One idea per sticky; consistent shorthand; owner initials topright; SLA dot bottomleft; tag icons for ??, ??, VIP.
Keep a permanent “Legend + Read Order” poster (A3) pinned beside THE CANVAS.
Use strings or color connectors with a small inline label for flows (green=data, red=escalation, black=evidence).
Reserve an Action Pool / Backlog column on the right; Archive completed cards daily.




Tier Attributes Comparison
AttributeTier A (Standard)Tier B (Family / Group)Tier C (Premium / Priority)Primary driverDistanceNumber of travelers; luggageTime sensitivity; comfortPrice modelBase fare per km + per travelerBase fare + group flat fee; perbag surchargePremium multiplier (1.25–1.75×) + service feesEligibility1–3 travellers; up to 2 bags each3–6 travellers; up to 4 total bags1–4 travellers; priority pickup; addons includedLuggage ruleStandard allowance per travelerBundled allowance; extra bag surchargeHigher included allowance; priority handlingDistance bandsShort/Med/Long with banded perkm ratesSame bands; group flat offsets perkm costSame bands; faster response SLA in each bandDispatch tagSTANDARDFAMILY_GROUPPREMIUM_PRIORITYResource bindingSingle vehicleLarger vehicle or 2 vehicles; child seats reservedPremium vehicle, driver seniority, priority dispatch
Purpose and Scope
Purpose: implement a tiered pricing and fulfillment system that automatically assigns fare rules, luggage allowances, and vehicle resources by distance, number of travelers, and luggage count.
Scope: booking UI/API, dispatch, driver app, kiosk, billing, customer communications, and operations for Shuttle Plus across all hubs.

Tier Definitions and Eligibility Rules
Inputs required at booking: pickup/drop coordinates, number of travellers, declared luggage count, desired addons, and travel date/time.
Distance bands (example): 
Short: 0–10 km
Medium: 10.1–30 km
Long: 30.1+ km
Tier selection rules (auto): 
If travellers ? 4 or luggage ? 4 ? assign Tier B (Family / Group).
If customer selects priority, airport fasttrack, or paid premium addon ? assign Tier C (Premium).
Otherwise evaluate distance: for long distances with 1–2 travellers and minimal luggage, default to Tier A (Standard) but show optional upsell to Tier C.
Manual override: Shift Lead or Ops Manager may override tier with documented reason; overrides create an audit entry.

Pricing, Surcharges, and Discounts
Base fare formula (example): 
Base = BandBase + (PerKmRate × Distance) + (PerTraveler × Travelers)
Apply Tier multiplier: Tier A = ×1.0; Tier B = ×1.15 (group offset); Tier C = ×1.35 (priority services).
Luggage rules: 
Included: Tier A — 2 bags per traveler; Tier B — 4 total bags; Tier C — 3 bags per traveler.
Excess: charge PerBagSurcharge or force resource upgrade when excess exceeds vehicle capacity.
Lastminute pricing: if booking <2 hours before pickup, apply LastMinute Premium (e.g., +100% on addon SKUs, and optional double price for guaranteed resource).
Discounts & promos: promo codes can target tiers or distance bands; ensure promo logic does not create negative margins.
Billing metadata: every fare must save tier, distance band, luggage count, travelers, applied multipliers, and promo codes in the booking record.

Booking, Dispatch, and Resource Binding Flow
Booking intake: collect required inputs and show recommended tier with transparent pricing breakdown and luggage guidance.
Preconfirm validation: run capacity check — vehicle capacity vs travellers/luggage; if mismatch, suggest upgrade to Tier B or split booking.
Reserve resource: on confirmation, bind vehicle class and required equipment (child seats, ramp, extra trunk) to the job; decrement hub inventory.
Dispatch tagging: assign dispatch tag (STANDARD / FAMILY_GROUP / PREMIUM_PRIORITY) and set driver checklist items.
Driver acceptance: driver app displays tier, luggage count, travelers, and checklist; driver must confirm equipment and acceptance within SLA.
Failover: if driver rejects or cannot meet needs, dispatch reassigns within defined SLA or issues immediate refund/credit if no replacement available.
Ontrip checks: driver confirms passengers and luggage at pickup; if mismatch, follow failover and refund rules. Log photos if requested for disputes.

Special Cases: Splits, Multistop, & Accessibility
Split bookings: when travellers or luggage exceed singlevehicle capacity, offer 2-vehicle split quoting combined price and singleinvoice option; default to Tier B pricing for combined group.
Multistop trips: charge per scheduled stop beyond base route; reassess tier if stops increase distance or traveler count.
Accessibility & special needs: override standard luggage allowances; require resource binding to accessible vehicles and possible Tier C assignment; follow specialneeds validation and audit rules.

Operations, Inventory, and Driver Guidelines
Inventory mapping: track child seats, ramps, snack kits, and other equipment by hub; enforce minimum stock levels and autoreorder thresholds.
Driver pay & incentives: define supplements by tier (e.g., Tier B fixed supplement per group; Tier C priority premium + higher addon payout).
Checklists: driver checklist must include: confirm passenger count, confirm luggage count, secure child seats, verify vehicle capacity, and photograph trunk if requested.
Kiosk & phone scripts: provide clear prompts to collect luggage/traveller data and present tiered price options; require agent to record special requests and confirm inventory binding.

Monitoring, KPIs, and Governance
Essential KPIs: 
Tier distribution (% bookings by tier)
Ontime pickup % by tier
Addon fulfillment rate by tier
Refunds and fails per 1,000 bookings by tier
Average revenue per ride by tier and distance band
Alerts: trigger alerts for inventory shortfalls, high rejection rates for Tier B/C, or spike in lastminute doubleprice purchases.
Audit & review: weekly ops review of tier assignment accuracy and monthly pricing performance review. Retrospective for any unusual exception trends.
Change control: pricing or tier rule changes require Impact Assessment, 2week pilot, Ops Manager approval, and update to customer messaging templates.

Quick Implementation Checklist
Define distance bands and perkm rates; set tier multipliers and luggage rules.
Update booking UI/API to collect travellers and luggage and surface recommended tier and price breakdown.
Implement preconfirm capacity checks and resource binding in dispatch system.
Add tier tags and checklist items in driver app; configure driver incentives.
Configure billing to store tier metadata and support lastminute pricing rules.
Train agents and drivers on kiosk/phone scripts and checklist.
Start 4week pilot in one hub; monitor KPIs and tune multipliers/inventory thresholds.




Tools Training Integration
A compact, operational training plan to integrate Shuttle Plus tools (driver app, concierge app, POS, incident log, dashboard, and alerts) into onboarding and continuous coaching so staff use them correctly, consistently, and in ways that improve safety, sales, and auditability.

Training objectives
Ensure every user can reliably complete core tasks in the correct sequence with the right data captured.
Reduce tool errors that affect payouts, handoffs, or SLA breaches.
Drive consistent language and conduct when using tools with passengers.
Build an audit trail mindset: every action must be traceable, concise, and evidence-backed.

Target audience and prerequisites
Audience: Drivers, concierges, shift leads, station managers, and ops desk agents.
Prerequisites: 30–60 minute product intro, account provisioning, device check (battery, network, permissions), and basic digital literacy verification.

Core curriculum (modular, 30–60 minute modules)
Module A Tools Essentials — App Navigation and Authentication
Goals: Log in, verify identity, manage device permissions, switch language.
Hands-on: Sign in, view schedule, update availability, change password.
Module B Booking, Sales, and POS Workflow
Goals: Find bookings, add line items, process payments, attach receipts.
Hands-on: Simulated sale, add-on upsell script, POS retry and cash fallback, record sale under staff ID.
Module C Trip Execution and Handoffs
Goals: Mark ETA pings, arrive, capture luggage tag, take chain-of-custody photos, confirm handoff.
Hands-on: Full booking lifecycle from assigned ? completed with photo evidence.
Module D Incident Logging and Dispute Handling
Goals: Create incident, attach photos/audio, assign owner, set SLA, escalate.
Hands-on: Log lost luggage case, tag owner, set SLA, simulate escalation.
Module E Alerts, Acknowledgement, and Quick Actions
Goals: Receive and respond to P0–P2 alerts, use quick actions (Acknowledge, Assign, Attach Evidence), and understand escalation timers.
Hands-on: Respond to a staged P0 alert within SLA and reassign.
Module F Performance, Incentives, and Audit Trail
Goals: Read pay statements, view commission line items, understand what triggers withholdings, and how to dispute.
Hands-on: Review a sample payslip, open a dispute, and practice evidence submission.

Delivery methods and timeline
New hires: 2 full days (Modules A–D day 1; E–F day 2) with written assessment.
Refresher for existing staff: 60–90 minute micro-sessions weekly for 6 weeks (rotate modules).
On-shift micro-coaching: 3-minute spot checks per driver/concierge per shift with coaching checklist.
Train-the-trainer: 1 day for shift leads to coach and certify staff.

Training materials and artifacts
Pocket cards: One-line scripts and button flows (Amharic + English).
Step-by-step checklists: App actions for Booking ? Handoff ? Complete with screenshots.
Role-play scenarios: 3 scripted scenarios with scoring rubric for language, tool accuracy, and SLA communication.
Video shorts: 2–4 minute screen-recorded demos per module for self-study.
Assessment: Practical scenario test (pass/fail) and a 10-question quiz.
Certification badge: Digital certificate after passing assessments; require recertification every 6 months.

Coaching, scoring, and quality control
Spot audit form: 8-item quick scorecard (Greeting, Verification, Tagging Photo, POS Accuracy, Handoff Confirm, Incident Log if needed, TL Feedback, Time to Complete).
Monthly quality review: Random sample of 20 trips per staff; thresholds for remediation (e.g., <85% requires 1:1 coaching).
Incentive tie-ins: Good conduct, tool accuracy, and timely incident logging contribute to teamwork scorecard and spot bonuses.

Escalation and support pathways
In-app Help: Contextual help per screen with 1-touch “Contact Lead” and “Request Walkthrough” buttons.
Ops Hotline: Dedicated shift-lead contact for live coaching; SLA for response 10 minutes.
Knowledge Base: Short searchable articles and video links; update log for new releases.
Bug and Feedback Loop: Simple in-app “Report Issue” that creates a ticket for product and ops to triage weekly.

Metrics to track training effectiveness
Tool usage adoption (daily active users by role)
POS success rate and failed-payment recovery rate
Handoff confirmation rate and chain-of-custody completeness
Incident logging accuracy and average time to assign owner
Reduction in payroll disputes linked to tool errors
Passenger satisfaction delta after training

Quick rollout plan (30 days)
Week 1: Finalize materials, pocket cards, and short videos.
Week 2: Train-the-trainer for all shift leads.
Week 3: Onboard new hires and run first wave of refresher sessions.
Week 4: Run spot audits, collect feedback, tune materials, and publish knowledge base.

Analysis — where these providers win and why it matters for Shuttle Plus
Product segmentation wins revenue: Blacklane and Sixt command higher yields by separating luxury, business, and economy products. Shuttle Plus can increase ARPU by formalizing 2–3 tiers (Economy shared; Private standard; Corporate/Luxury) and tying SLAs to each tier.
Experience differentiators build loyalty: Welcome Pickups’ local-host style converts one-off tourists into repeat customers; GetTransfer’s marketplace gives price choice. In Ethiopia, a culturally informed arrival experience (Amharic/Oromo greeting, SIM-card info, local tips) will create memorable differentiation.
Distribution and partners scale reach cheaply: MyTransfers, Mozio, and aggregator models show growth without owning all assets. Shuttle Plus can rapidly scale regionally through vetted franchisees or API partnerships with hotels, travel agents, and OTAs.
Operational predictability sells trust: GO Airport Shuttle and SuperShuttle visibility (schedules/pooling) reduce customer anxiety. Implementing published pickup windows, SMS/WhatsApp ETAs, and driver IDs increases perceived reliability.
Vertical bundling raises margins: Rightway and Sixt bundle ancillary services (parking, rentals, corporate billing). Shuttle Plus should design bundled offers for hotels, event organizers, airport parking lots, and airlines (e.g., meet-and-greet + luggage handling).
