Monthly QA audits and mystery-rider program.


Driver meet-and-greet script (concise, audit-ready)
Purpose: Ensure a consistent, welcoming arrival experience that doubles as a safety and service checklist.
Driver arrival actions (before meeting passenger)
Be at the agreed pickup point at least 5 minutes early; confirm vehicle clean, fuel level, and luggage space.
Display Shuttle Plus ID badge and vehicle plate; enable interior lights if dark.
Meeting script — quick, professional flow (English, then short Amharic and Oromo options)
Greeting (driver approaches, stands respectfully beside vehicle)
English: “Good [morning/afternoon/evening]. Welcome to Addis Ababa. I’m [Name] from Shuttle Plus. May I help you with your luggage?”
Amharic: “Selam/Endemin neh? Ene [Name] new, Shuttle Plus. Be-meskelihu bemeleshu?”
Oromo: “Akkam jirtu? Ani [Name] dha, Shuttle Plus irraa. Bo’oo kee si gargaaruu nan danda’aa?”
Passenger confirmation
English: “Are you [Guest name]? I have a booking for [Hotel/Address]. Is that correct?”
Follow with: “Do you prefer the air-conditioning/fan on or off?”
Quick ID & safety line
English: “Please fasten your seatbelt; I’ll do the same. If you need WiFi or phone charging, it’s [location].”
Add: “If anything is wrong with the ride, tell me now or contact Shuttle Plus support.”
Service extras & local help
English: “Would you like a short local orientation (SIM, currency exchange, or directions) when we arrive?”
If yes, give a 30–60 second summary tailored to arrival needs.
Luggage & departure
English: “I’ll load your luggage. Please take anything you need from carry-on.” (Driver places luggage securely; confirms number of bags.)
En route communication
English: “Estimated travel time is [X] minutes. I’ll call ahead to confirm your arrival if needed. Enjoy the ride.”
Close with a polite line in passenger’s preferred language.
Script notes (short)
Keep each line under 8–12 seconds when spoken.
Use the passenger’s preferred language when known.
Log pickup time, vehicle plate, and any special requests in the app within 2 minutes.

10-point professionalism checklist (for onboarding, QA, and audits)
Punctuality — Arrive on location ?5 minutes early; record actual arrival time in app.
Uniform & ID — Clean, branded uniform; visible Shuttle Plus ID and name tag every shift.
Vehicle Presentation — Interior vacuumed; windows clean; no odors; water bottle for guest optional.
Safety First — Conduct visible safety checks (seatbelt reminder, secure luggage, functioning lights).
Clear Identification — Verbally confirm passenger name and destination before loading luggage.
Respectful Greeting — Use polite language, appropriate eye contact, no prolonged personal talk; use Amharic/Oromo/English as appropriate.
Concise Local Help — Offer up to two practical tips (SIM, currency, hotel check-in) only if passenger accepts.
Privacy & Discretion — Do not ask personal questions; avoid discussing other customers or internal company matters.
Issue Escalation — If passenger is dissatisfied or there’s an incident, log exact details in the app and notify operations within 5 minutes.
Professional Close — Confirm drop-off point, assist with luggage offload, say thank you, and note any feedback in the app.

Tracking apps 
Below is a concise, operational comparison of popular tracking apps prioritizing free tiers and offline/low-bandwidth suitability. 

AppPlatformFree features (key)Offline / low-connectivity supportBest forGoogle Maps (Location sharing)Android, iOS, WebReal-time location sharing; duration controls; share linkLimited offline: map tiles can be cached, live sharing needs connectivitySimple, ubiquitous sharing with Google accountsApple Find MyiOS/macOSDevice & person sharing; lost-device mode; offline Find via Apple crowdStrong offline device-finding via Bluetooth relay (Apple network)Apple device ecosystem; lost-device recoveryLife360 (free tier)Android, iOSLocation history (limited), basic place alerts, family circlesWorks with intermittent connectivity (updates on reconnect)Family location, driving basicsGlympseAndroid, iOS, WebTemporary location shares with expiration; no sign-up requiredMinimal data; recipients see last known when offlineShort-lived, privacy-focused sharesMaps.me / OsmAnd (with sharing plugins)Android, iOSOffline maps, manual location export/share; limited live trackingStrong offline maps and navigation; live tracking depends on connectivityOffline navigation + occasional sharing
Quick notes on selection criteria
Prioritize ecosystem fit: Apple Find My for iOS-heavy fleets; Google Maps for cross-platform ubiquity.
Offline-first needs: pick apps that support offline map tiles (Maps.me, OsmAnd) and local caches; for live tracking during connectivity gaps, pair device-local logs (SQLite export) with opportunistic upload.
Privacy and consent: free apps may trade features for data collection; check permissions and retention policies before deployment.
Scalability: consumer apps are fine for small teams; for fleet-scale tracking, consider mobile SDKs with local-first sync (Realm, Couchbase) or a custom lightweight agent.

Operational recommendations for Shuttle Plus
Pilot approach: run a 30-day pilot with two groups — drivers using Google Maps sharing and a second group using Life360 — measure update frequency, battery impact, and offline behaviour.
Edge buffering: implement a simple device policy that logs GPS fixes locally (1 Hz) and batches uploads when connectivity returns.
Minimal replacement path: if consumer apps fail scale tests, migrate to a mobile SDK (Realm/Couchbase or a custom agent) that provides offline-first sync and deterministic reconciliation.
Data governance: retain only required location history per RPO/RTO and local regulations; expose a self-service purge for drivers.

Recommendation (short)
For immediate, free and low-friction rollout: start with Google Maps sharing for mixed-device crews and Life360 free tier for family-style tracking needs.
If offline robustness is critical now: evaluate Maps.me or OsmAnd for offline maps plus a small custom logger that uploads when online.



Tracking Solutions Mocks 
Below are concise mock designs for ops tracking, plus a short comparison of free or low-cost tools you can trial. Also  included are options that cover real-time vehicle tracking, booking & trip feeds, staff-tagged sales tracking, and lightweight alerting for SLA breaches.

Mock Designs (high-level tiles and data flow)
Live Fleet Map
Tile: active vehicles with colored status; click opens trip detail.
Data: GPS + last heartbeat; owner and ETA; exception flag.
Trip Feed
Tile: chronological feed of bookings with staff IDs, add-ons, payment status.
Actions: reassign, flag dispute, attach evidence, open incident.
Sales & Commissions Panel
Tile: daily add-ons (ETB) by staff; running 1% commission; tier progress bars.
Actions: approve commission exceptions; issue spot bonus.
Handoff Accuracy & Chain-of-Custody
Tile: handoffs processed vs exceptions; photo evidence link; reconciled logs.
Alerts: missing tag; mismatched passenger name; unresolved exceptions.
SLA & Alerts Center
Tile: SLA breach heatmap by owner; quick actions to assign owner or escalate.
Notifications: push, email, or SMS for critical alerts.
Staff Dashboard
Tile: on-shift vs rostered; punctuality; recent feedback scores; incident count.
Actions: message staff, view payroll preview, log spot bonus.

Data Flow and Integrations
Sources: Booking system, POS/app (staff-tagged sales), telematics/GPS, HRIS, incident logs, CRM feedback.
ETL: Lightweight middleware (Zapier/Make) or direct API; store normalized events in a small cloud DB (Postgres/BigQuery).
Presentation: BI tool or lightweight dashboard (open-source or free tier) with webhooks for actions.
Audit: Immutable event log for trips, sales, and payout calculations.

Roleplay Scoring Rubric (Trainer Use)
Scoring scale: 0–2 per item. Passing score: 8/10 or higher.
Greeting and tone (0–2)
0: No greeting or hostile tone
1: Greeting present but monotone or rushed
2: Warm, clear, makes eye contact, appropriate formality
Booking confirmation accuracy (0–2)
0: No confirmation or incorrect details
1: Partial confirmation, missed luggage or flight detail
2: Full confirmation: name, booking code, flight/hotel, luggage count
Information clarity and route ETA (0–2)
0: No ETA or route explained
1: ETA given but vague or inaccurate
2: Clear ETA, route, and expected stops
Handling of scenario specifics (0–2)
0: Did not address scenario or escalated incorrectly
1: Addressed partially, missed opportunity for recovery
2: Handled proactively and offered appropriate remedy
Cultural sensitivity and local knowledge (0–1)
0: Incorrect or insensitive information
1: Accurate and respectful, used local greeting when appropriate
Closing and readiness confirmation (0–1)
0: No closing or left passenger unsure
1: Closed with readiness confirmation and positive send-off
Trainer actions
Provide immediate verbal feedback with 2 strengths and 1 improvement point.
Log score in ops portal and notify for required coaching if score < 8.

Trainer Notes and Facilitation Tips
Start on time and set expectations for engagement.
Use live roleplays and rotate participants to keep energy high.
Call out real-world examples from company operations to ground theory.
Keep exercises practical and time-boxed; enforce strict rotations.
Praise specific behaviors during roleplay rather than general comments.
Use the rubric consistently; calibrate scoring with co-trainers before first cohort.

Rollout Plan and Schedule
Phase 1 Train-the-Trainer: 90-minute session for 2 lead trainers.
Phase 2 Cohort delivery: cohorts of 8–12 drivers over 2 weeks.
Phase 3 Assessment and certification: written quiz + roleplay within 48 hours of training.
Phase 4 Coaching: 1:1 coaching for scores < 8/10 within 72 hours.
Phase 5 Monthly refresher micro-training: 15 minutes, mandatory for all certified drivers.
Owner assignments
L&D manager: schedule and materials.
Ops lead: distribute glovebox sheets and check supplies.
Trainers: deliver sessions and upload scores.
IT: ensure ops portal accepts roleplay uploads and incident photos.

Measurement and KPIs
Pre/post measures: average ride rating, complaint volume, NPS, response time to escalations.
Targets first 30 days: increase average rating by 0.2 points; reduce complaints by 15%.
Training metrics: % certified within 7 days, average roleplay rubric score, quiz pass rate.
Reporting cadence: weekly for first month, monthly thereafter.

Vehicle Modification Checklist — Shuttle Plus
This checklist ensures each vehicle is safe, compliant, brandready, and techequipped for Shuttle Plus airport operations. Use it as an install & QA guide, procurement spec, and maintenance reference.

1. Vehicle identity and paperwork (Required before modifications)
Verify vehicle VIN, plate, model, year, and odometer; record in fleet system.
Confirm insurance, registration, and local compliance documents are current and stored.
Approve vehicle for modification by Fleet Manager (name, date, signature).

2. Exterior modifications and branding
Wraps / decals 
Spec: Full side and rear vinyl wrap or magnetic panels; high-visibility Shuttle Plus primary color + logo; reflective registration band on rear bumper.
Materials: 3–5 year cast vinyl (e.g., 3M 2080 series) with UV laminate.
Installation: professional wrap shop; seams and edges sealed; sample vehicle approved before fleet run.
QA: visual inspection for bubbles/peeling; photo record; check adhesion after 7 days and 30 days.
Exterior lighting & signage 
Add discreet rooftop light for VIP/corporate vehicles (low profile) if requested.
Ensure all exterior lights are fully functional; replace bulbs with OEMspec LEDs as needed.

3. Interior fitout and passenger comfort
Seat condition and anchorage: inspect for wear, loose bolts; torque to factory spec.
Floor matting: non-slip rubber mats for luggage zones; secure fasteners.
Luggage handling aids: reinforced cargo floor, cargo straps or nets for minibuses.
Accessibility: foldable ramp or secure anchor points for wheelchair restraint systems where required.
Hygiene kit: install sealed holder for sanitiser bottle, face masks, and a small firstaid kit (per Concierge kit standard).

4. Technology fit (tablet, GPS, telematics, cameras, scale)
Tablet per vehicle (driver device)
Minimum spec: 
OS: Android 11+ (preferred) or iOS equivalent.
Screen: 8–10" IPS, 1200×1920 or better.
CPU/RAM: Quad-core / 3+ GB RAM.
Storage: 32–64 GB with microSD slot.
Connectivity: 4G LTE with eSIM or physical SIM; WiFi; Bluetooth 5.0.
Battery: Removable or 6000mAh+ with vehicle dock charging.
Mount: robust swivel dash/tablet lock mount with charging passthrough.
Security: device encryption + MDM (mobile device management) agent preinstalled; kiosk mode for driver app.
Software requirements: 
Driver app (booking + navigation), offline caching, push notifications, SOS button, driver checklist, DVIR upload (photos).
MDM policy: enforce updates, remote wipe, app whitelist.
GPS / Telematics
Device options: Teltonika / Queclink / Meitrack models supporting LTE, 3-axis accelerometer, ignition sense, battery backup.
Required features: live GPS, speed, harsh braking/accel events, geofence support, remote firmware update.
Installation: hardwired with fused ignition tap; antitamper mounting; GPS antenna with clear sky view.
Telematics integration: stream to Fleet platform (Traccar/GpsGate or SaaS). API endpoint & auth documented.
Cameras (video telematics)
Camera types: 
Front-facing dashcam (1080p min, 30fps, WDR) with timestamped file export.
Cabin-facing camera (optional for security) with privacy masking; audio optional where permitted by law.
Rear/reverse camera for driver aid (720p acceptable).
Features: loop recording, Gsensor event lock, secure export, tamper detection, timestamp NTP sync.
Storage: local SD (32–128GB) + optional cloud upload for incident clips (premium vehicles).
Installation: professional mount, conceal wiring, access port for evidence export.
Onboard scale (luggage / load monitoring) — optional for minibuses
Purpose: detect overweight loads and for freight/luggage accountability on group runs.
Spec: floor scale pads or integrated cargobay weight sensor; IP65 rated; accuracy ±1–2% within 200–1000 kg range depending on vehicle.
Integration: output to tablet via Bluetooth or wired CAN/serial to telematics if needed.
QA: calibrate monthly and record calibration log.

5. Electrical, safety and mounting standards
Electrical 
All installs hardwired to fused auxiliary circuit; no loose USB adapters in cigarette lighter only for temporary use.
Provide an inline fuse and circuit diagram in vehicle file.
Add a battery isolation switch for long-term storage vehicles.
Mounting 
Use industry-standard mounts (RAM Mounts or equivalent) for tablets and cameras; ensure no obstruction to airbags.
All mounts bolted to OEM mounting points or to professionalfitted consoles.
Safety 
No loose cables in passenger footwells; cables routed under trim; use fireretardant sleeving.
Confirm driver visibility and airbag function unaffected by hardware.
Documentation 
Store installation photos, wiring diagram, serial numbers, and warranty docs in vehicle asset record.

6. Procurement & preferred models (recommended)
Tablet: Samsung Galaxy Tab A8 (or rugged variant) / Lenovo Tab M10; consider Rugged Android (e.g., Zebra ET40) for heavy use.
Telematics/GPS: Teltonika FMB120/FMB125 or Queclink GV300 for cost-effectiveness and Traccar compatibility.
Dashcams: Thinkware F200 PRO / BlackVue DR750X (or RoadHawk alternatives), or local approved models with exportable files.
Camera mounting & wiring: local certified installer; use marinegrade connectors for external devices.
Scale: SCALESPEC floor pads (local supplier) or Konig digital vehicle scales for minibuses.

7. Installation procedure (per vehicle)
Pre-install QA: confirm vehicle acceptance form, VIN, and hub assignment.
Stage hardware: verify serials, firmware versions, and accessory lists.
Install telematics (hardwired) and verify connectivity to fleet server (test ping + geofence).
Mount dashcam(s) and run wiring; test loop recording + event lock; export a 30s clip to confirm hashable file.
Mount and configure tablet: install MDM, driver app, set kiosk mode, mount dock, verify charging.
Install wraps/decals after tech installs to avoid adhesive undercuts; perform final exterior QA.
Calibrate scale if applicable.
Complete DVIR: inspection checklist, photos (interior/exterior/tech mounts), and driver acceptance signature.
Enter all serials, installation photos, and hashes for initial recordings into vehicle asset record.

8. Quality assurance & tests (post-install)
Connectivity: telematics online and reporting location; tablet shows driver app online.
Recording validation: capture a 60s front and cabin clip; compute SHA256 hash; upload working copy to evidence repo. Log filename, hash, and storage ref.
Geofence test: drive a short route across a test geofence and confirm event triggers.
Device resilience: power cycle vehicle, confirm devices start and resume recording/connection.
Wrap inspection: photo record full vehicle, seams, and VIN plate clearance.
Driver acceptance: driver to perform a DVIR on first shift; confirm checklist pass.

9. Maintenance, firmware and support
Routine checks: monthly device health check (storage capacity, GPS fix quality, firmware uptodate).
Dashcam storage: rotate and archive clips older than retention policy (e.g., 90 days) unless on legal hold.
Firmware updates: staged per-hub rollout; test on 1 vehicle before fleet update.
Spare parts: maintain a kit per hub — spare tablets (1 per 10 vehicles), GPS units (2), dashcams (2), mounting hardware.
Service vendor: nominate preferred local installer and emergency repair contact; maintain SLA for urgent replacements (24–48 hours).

10. Security, privacy and legal
MDM policy: enforce strong PIN, remote wipe, app whitelist, and device encryption.
Audio recording: comply with local laws — disable cabin audio where prohibited or ensure passenger notification stickers in vehicles.
Evidence handling: exported footage must be hashed (SHA256) and stored with chainofcustody metadata (see Incident SOP).
Data retention: follow company data retention schedule (e.g., 90 days standard; extend for incidents).

11. Estimated cost guidance (per vehicle, ballpark)
Tablet & mount + MDM: $180–$450 depending on ruggedness and MDM licensing.
Telematics/GPS unit (hardware + install): $60–$180 + $20–40 install labor.
Dashcam front + cabin (device + install): $150–$600 depending on model and cloud subscription.
Wrap (partial sides + rear): $250–$900 depending on size and material.
Scale (minibus pads): $400–$1,200 if required.
Contingency / labor: allocate 15–25% per vehicle.

12. Approvals and sign-off (completion)
Installer sign-off: name, company, date, firmware versions, serials.
Fleet Manager sign-off: hardware inventory verified, telematics live.
Driver acceptance: DVIR completed and driver trained on device use.
Ops Lead final: vehicle added to active fleet roster and maintenance plan.




Video and Privacy Consent Form 
Company: Shuttle Plus
Document: Video and Audio Recording Consent and Privacy Notice
Purpose of recording
Shuttle Plus records video and may record audio inside and outside company vehicles to enhance passenger safety, investigate incidents, support claims, improve service quality, and for training and compliance purposes.
What is recorded
Fixed and onboard cameras: front-facing dashcam, interior cabin camera, rear/side cameras, and event-triggered clips (Gsensor, panic button).
Metadata captured: date/time, GPS location, vehicle ID, driver ID, and incident flags.
Audio recording is disabled by default; audio will only be recorded with explicit consent or where legally required for incident investigation.
Legal basis and lawful use
Recordings are processed for legitimate operational and safety purposes, including security, evidence preservation, incident investigation, driver coaching, regulatory compliance, and lawful requests by authorities.
Retention and deletion
Non-flagged recordings: retained for 30 days then automatically deleted.
Flagged recordings (incidents, claims, legal holds): retained for a minimum of 2 years or as required by law or investigation.
Legal holds override scheduled deletion until released by Legal/Compliance.
Access, sharing, and disclosures
Access limited to authorized Shuttle Plus roles: Ops, Investigations, Legal, and designated managers.
Recordings may be shared with law enforcement, insurers, corporate clients, or courts when required by law or to investigate incidents or claims.
Any export is logged with requester ID, purpose, and timestamp; exported files will be watermarked with requester ID and date.
Security and integrity
Video and metadata are stored encrypted in transit and at rest. Checksums and audit logs are maintained to detect tampering. Originals are preserved as read-only evidence when flagged.
Your rights and requests
Subject to local law, passengers may request access to footage that directly identifies them; such requests will be reviewed and fulfilled according to applicable data-protection laws and operational constraints.
Requests for deletion, correction, or restriction will be considered but may be limited if recordings are subject to legal hold, ongoing investigation, or retention obligations.
To make a request, contact Shuttle Plus Data Protection Officer at: privacy@shuttleplus.co (or use the passenger support portal). Include booking reference, date/time, vehicle ID, and description.
Minors and vulnerable passengers
Guardians must provide consent for recording minors or vulnerable passengers when audio is enabled or when recordings are used in training or promotional material. Sensitive use requires explicit written consent.
Consent and opt-outs
Cameras are active while the vehicle ignition is on for safety and compliance reasons; passengers who do not consent to onboard audio may request audio remain off for their journey. Audio is off by default.
For promotional or training use beyond operational needs, Shuttle Plus will seek explicit written consent before public use of identifiable footage.
Complaint, disputes, and appeals
Complaints about recordings or privacy concerns may be submitted to privacy@shuttleplus.co. Complaints will be acknowledged within 3 business days and investigated with a formal response within 30 days.

Webapp Platform options
Firebase (Realtime Database, Firestore, Cloud Functions, Hosting, Auth) — fast to prototype, excellent client SDKs, builtin push and analytics. Free tier good for pilots but costs rise with high read/write or Cloud Function usage.
Supabase (Postgres, Auth, Realtime, Storage, Edge Functions) — SQL first, predictable pricing and easier data migrations; good for developer control and analytics. Free tier generous for dev/test.
Appwrite (selfhosted) — open source BaaS you run on your own infra; best if you want full data control and avoid vendor lockin. Requires ops work to scale.
Vercel / Netlify (frontend + serverless) — excellent for hosting web front ends and serverless functions; pair with managed DB for backend scale. Free tiers are generous for web hosting.
PlanetScale (serverless MySQL) or Neon (serverless Postgres) — highly scalable managed DBs built for branching and horizontal scale; free tiers for small workloads.
Hasura (GraphQL on Postgres) — instant GraphQL API, strong for realtime data and permission rules; combine with PlanetScale/Neon for scale.
AWS Amplify (Cognito, AppSync, Lambda) — enterprisegrade, scaleable but more configuration overhead; free tier limited and pricing can grow with usage.

Which to pick for a Shuttle backend (starter ? scale)
Prototype / MVP (0–5k daily users)
Fastest path: Firebase (Firestore + Cloud Functions) or Supabase (Postgres + Realtime).
Why: minimal infra work, builtin auth, SDKs, push integrations, and quick time to market.
Growth (5k–50k daily users)
Recommended: Supabase or Vercel + PlanetScale/Neon (frontend serverless + managed SQL).
Why: SQL structure for transactional bookings/payments, predictable query costs, better operational visibility.
Production at scale (50k+ daily users / complex routing)
Move to managed DB (PlanetScale/Neon), Hasura for realtime APIs, dedicated microservices (k8s or Fargate), and CDN + edge functions for low latency.
Why: separation of concerns, independent scaling of compute and DB, stronger observability and cost control.

Scalability considerations and antipatterns
Read/write explosion with client SDKs: avoid chatty client reads (polling) by using serverside aggregation, batched queries, and tight rules for realtime subscriptions.
Serverless function cost spikes: business logic in Cloud Functions/Edge Functions can become expensive under load — move heavy/recurring jobs to queue workers or containerized services.
Realtime at scale: WebSocket/realtime channels are powerful but costly. Gate who subscribes; use presence channels sparingly; aggregate telemetry serverside.
Single locked DB schema: design a normalized schema for bookings, payments, staff, and events; use CQRS/event sourcing for auditability if you need complex reconciliations.
Vendor lockin: Firebase makes prototyping fast but migrating away is heavier. If you expect rapid growth, prefer SQL-first stacks (Supabase + PlanetScale/Neon) or hostable options (Appwrite).

Recommended architecture for Shuttle Plus (practical, resilient)
Client apps (iOS/Android/web) ? Hosted on Vercel/Netlify; use client SDKs for auth and minimal UI reads.
API layer ? Lightweight edge functions for low-latency endpoints (Vercel/Cloudflare Workers) + REST/GraphQL gateway (Hasura or custom Node/Go service).
Primary datastore ? Managed SQL (PlanetScale/Neon) for bookings, staff, incentives, audit logs.
Event store / queue ? Kafka/RabbitMQ or managed queue (Google Pub/Sub, AWS SQS) for asynchronous jobs (reconciliation, payouts, reports).
Realtime / telemetry ? Timeseries or Realtime DB (Influx/Redis Streams or Supabase Realtime) for vehicle pings with short TTL and server-side aggregation.
Payments ? External gateway (Telebirr) webhooks to a reconciliation service writing canonical transactions into SQL.
Monitoring ? Metrics (Prometheus/Cloud Monitoring), error tracking (Sentry), and cost/usage dashboards.
Secrets & config ? Vault or cloud KMS; rotate keys and restrict access.

Cost control, observability, and migration path
Start with a free tier (Firestore or Supabase) and instrument everything: per-API metrics, read/write counts, function execution time, and storage growth.
Enforce per-device and per-station quotas early to limit runaway costs. Cache aggressively (Redis or CDN) for static/slow-changing reads (maps, driver profiles).
Plan migration path early: keep a canonical SQL view of bookings and payments (even if you prototype in Firestore), so you can move to PlanetScale/Neon + Hasura with minimal data-mapping work.
Add automated smoke tests and synthetic transactions to monitor payment/webhook reliability and geo-latency for core flows (booking ? payment ? dispatch ? handoff).

Quick decision checklist
Need fastest prototype with minimal ops: Firebase (Firestore + Functions).
Need SQL, predictable query patterns, and easier migration: Supabase + PlanetScale/Neon.
Need full control and lowest longterm infra cost: Appwrite selfhosted or containerized microservices with managed DB.
Must support realtime vehicle tracking at scale: separate telemetry store with short retention, aggregate serverside, and cap client subscriptions.

Why not to start Shuttle Plus? 

Strategic comparison (key attributes)
DecisionUpfront capitalMarket riskOperational complexityTime to revenueStart nowHighMedium–HighHighFaster if executed wellDelay / pilot firstModerateLowerManageableSlower; safer validationDon’t startNoneNoneNoneN/ASources: Starter Story OptimoRoute.

Short answer
It’s not inherently a bad idea to start Shuttle Plus, but it can be risky unless you validate demand, control costs, and build operations and compliance before scaling. Starting without those mitigations commonly causes failure in shuttle businesses Starter Story OptimoRoute.

Why it can work (opportunity)
Recurrent demand from airports, hotels, and employers creates repeat customers and predictable routes OptimoRoute.
With good routing, scheduling and technology you can lower per-ride costs and improve margins OptimoRoute.
Niche focus (e.g., premium airport transfers, corporate contracts, longterm parking feeders) gives defensible positioning and steadier revenue.

Why it can fail (main risks)
Capital intensity: vehicles, maintenance, insurance, and driver payroll create high fixed costs before steady revenue arrives Starter Story.
Thin margins and price sensitivity: fuel, vehicle depreciation, and competition from rideshare or existing shuttles squeeze profitability Starter Story.
Operational complexity: reliable scheduling, dispatch, realtime tracking, incident handling, and driver management are hard to do well and scale.
Regulatory and insurance requirements: permits, commercial licenses, and liability insurance add cost and administrative burden.
Dependence on third parties: airport agreements, parking lots, and map/SMS/payment providers can add single points of failure OptimoRoute.
Demand variability: travel seasonality, flight delays, or sudden drops in travel reduce utilization and cash flow OptimoRoute.

Practical tests to reduce risk (pilot plan)
Run a 3month pilot on 1–2 highyield routes using leased vans and parttime drivers to validate load factors and pricing.
Sell 30–90 day corporate or hotel contracts upfront to secure predictable revenue before buying vehicles.
Instrument metrics from day one: revenue per vehicle hour, utilization, average fare, CAC, churn.
Use route optimization and simple automation to minimize driver idle time and fuel use OptimoRoute.
Build a minimum compliance checklist: insurance, permits, driver background checks, vehicle maintenance log.
Test fallback plans for key integrations (payments, maps, SMS) and a manual dispatch procedure.

Decision guide — when to start vs delay
Start now if: you have committed initial capital, at least one contract (hotel/corporate), experienced ops personnel, and a clear pilot route.
Delay (pilot first) if: you lack contracted customers, need to prove unit economics, or cannot meet regulatory/insurance requirements immediately.
Don’t start if: you have insufficient runway, no path to early contracted revenue, or you can’t ensure minimum operational safety and compliance.


One recommended next step
Run a single-route pilot with 2–3 leased vans, one contracted partner (hotel or corporate client), and a simple booking + dispatch MVP for 90 days. Measure unit economics and break-even utilization before scaling OptimoRoute.

90 Day Pilot Overview
Goal: Validate unit economics and operational reliability on one highyield airport route and secure repeat customers or one contracted partner within 90 days.
Scope: 2–3 leased vans, parttime drivers, minimal booking + dispatch MVP, manual fallback processes.
Success criteria: breakeven utilization or better; at least one recurring contract or enough prebooked rides to cover fixed pilot costs.

Prelaunch (Days 0–14)
Route and partner selection 
Choose one route with predictable demand and clear pickup/drop points.
Secure one partner contract or referral source (hotel, travel agency, tour operator).
Regulatory and compliance 
Obtain necessary commercial permits and insurance for pilot vehicles.
Complete driver background checks and statutory documents.
Fleet and staffing 
Lease 2 vans with maintenance plan; hire 3 drivers on short contracts; assign one operations lead.
Prepare spare driver list for coverage.
Technology minimums 
Deploy booking form or light app webflow, simple driver app or WhatsApp workflow, and a basic dispatch dashboard.
Integrate one payment method and test SMS/notifications.
Training and runbooks 
Create driver checklist, vehicle inspection form, incident reporting form, and manual dispatch SOP.
Run 2 full-day simulations including booking ? pickup ? incident handling.
Communications 
Prepare customer message templates for booking confirmation, delays, and cancellations.
Prepare driver briefing sheet and escalation contacts.

Launch and Operation (Days 15–90)
Daytoday operations 
Morning readiness check: vehicle inspection, driver brief, daily route plan.
Realtime monitoring: track active trips, ETA accuracy, driver status, and delays.
Endofday reconciliation: fares collected, cash handling log, fuel and mileage entry, incident log.
Weekly cadence 
Weekly operations review with data: utilization, ontime performance, incidents, maintenance needs.
Weekly sales outreach to secure corporate or hotel block bookings.
Midpilot adjustments 
At Day 30: review pricing and schedules; adjust frequency or pickup windows to improve load factor.
At Day 60: test small scaling actions if metrics trending positive (add 1 van or extend hours).
Customer experience focus 
Follow up all rides with a short satisfaction survey; escalate complaints within 24 hours.
Offer simple loyalty incentive for repeat bookings during pilot.

KPIs and Targets
Utilization rate per vehicle: target 60–75 percent of operating hours filled.
Breakeven utilization: calculated per vehicle hour; target reached by Day 60.
Revenue per vehicle hour: target >= operation cost per vehicle hour.
Average fare per trip: track to confirm pricing and elasticity.
Customer repeat rate: target 15–25 percent repeat within 90 days.
Ontime performance: target >= 90 percent pickups within ETA window.
Net promoter score proxy: target >= +20 from pilot feedback.
Cost of acquisition per customer: target less than firsttrip gross margin.
Incidents per 1,000 trips: target near zero; any safety incident triggers immediate review.

Sample 90 Day Pilot Budget (estimates in USD)
Vehicle lease and insurance: $4,500 total; Breakdown: 2 vans at $1,500/month each for 3 months; commercial insurance $1,500.
Drivers and staffing: $3,600; Breakdown: 3 drivers at $1,200/month pro rata for pilot.
Fuel and maintenance reserve: $1,200.
Technology and communications: $900; Breakdown: booking webflow, SMS credits, payment fees.
Contingency and incident reserve: $800.
Marketing and partner incentives: $1,000; referral commissions and partner onboarding bonuses.
Miscellaneous permits and legal: $500.
Total estimated pilot cost: $12,500.
Budget note: convert to local currency and adjust for Addis Ababa market rates; prioritize leased vehicles and short contracts to reduce upfront capital.

Immediate next steps (take now)
Confirm pilot route and secure one partner agreement.
Book 2 leased vans with insurance and schedule driver hiring.
Deploy booking + dispatch MVP and prepare driver runbooks.
Start Day0 simulation and begin live operations within 14 days.

Shuttleplus idea 
THIS IS HOW IT WORKS.
A customer calls to our HQ or use one of our modern methods(bots, app) to reserve a pick-up 24 hours before departure. The customer will provide information (name, passport number, pickup locations, travel ticket etc). after the information is collected at our HQ, it will then be sorted based on urgency, proximity and feasibility regarding multiple pickup locations from multiple customers. 
After the sorting and planning, a notification is send to the customer for the pickup time, vehicle id, agent name and all other necessary information. Then the agent(team one) will proceed to the pickup location(usually doorstep). When picking up luggage, a video recording is always on. Then luggages will be weiged, wrapped and locked with custom locks(zipties with codes?). the customer only will have the lock codes. 
After agents collect the luggage from different clients, they will proceed to the airport. All this time the cameras are ON. And at any time customers can see the location of the vans in real-time with our app. Once the agents are at the airport, customers are asked to provide the codes for locks. Once provided, agents will proceed to the gates of the airport. At the gate, another team of agents (team two)will collect the luggages and proceed to screening and security. 
If the luggage pass security, then baggage claim and boarding pass will be collected. The boarding pass can be sent online to respective customers. The baggage claim can be collected at our kiosk around the airport gate. 
If luggages fail to pass security, customer is notified. If customer agreed, agents can break locks at the security for further investigation. If customer is not willing, the luggages will be stored at the kiosks to be processed by the client later.

Competitive landscape (who your competitors are)
Local/regional shuttle and transfer operators (schedules, airport pickups) such as Shuttle Africa and similar national shuttle players shuttleafrica.com.
Established regional airport shuttle firms and independent airport transfer operators (example: EZ Shuttle in South Africa) that offer online booking, tracking, and multiple vehicle options Tracxn.
Global luggage-concierge, baggage-tracking and airport mobility innovators (companies and airport tech vendors that partner with airlines and airports to digitize baggage flows) valcon.com Addepto.
Ondemand ride-hailing (Uber/bolt) and shared-shuttle hybrids that compete on price, convenience, and availability for early/late flights prked.com.
Sources: market examples and case studies cited below shuttleafrica.com Tracxn valcon.com Addepto prked.com.

How you beat them — focused strategies that win in Addis and scale regionally
Own punctuality with measurable SLAs — guarantee and overdeliver on pickup-on-time metrics; publish a simple refund/compensation policy for missed pickups.
Differentiate on trust and dignity — consistent uniforms, vetted agents, identity/consent flows, tamper-evident luggage handling and a transparent chain-of-custody visible to the customer.
Laser-focus on customer segments where value is highest (elderly, medical transfers, corporates, families) and build packaged pricing, concierge scripts, and dedicated vehicle types for each.
Build an ironsimple MVP booking + dispatcher experience and integrate a lightweight automation (maps + SMS + ClickUp webhook) to remove dispatch friction; iterate from real trips.
Secure a small set of B2B partners (3–5 hotels, a travel agent or two, corporate clients) to guarantee utilization in launch months.
Use a data-driven ops loop — collect time-to-pickup, handoff success, and NPS per driver; publish internal leaderboards and tie small incentives to improvements.
Make safety visible — encrypted in-vehicle recording with clear retention policy and insured procedures; use third-party audits to validate protocols.
Localize pricing and product: distance + luggage + passenger tiers; special flat-fee for airport peak hours; family bundles and subscription plans for hotels/corporates.
Run a lean pilot and instrument everything; don’t over-automate dispatch until you have real demand patterns to train your rules/AI.
Negotiate exclusive or prioritized operational windows with one airline or airport partner to anchor credibility and operational predictability.

Global best-practice inspirations and case studies (what to copy)
Digital baggage-lifecycle pilots that pair handheld scanning, QR/AI tracking and operator dashboards — these show the value of end-to-end visibility and reconciliation for operators and airports valcon.com Addepto.
Airport-scale mobility pilots (autonomous people movers and integrated porters) demonstrate that convenience features (ride-to-gate, assisted carts) raise perceived value for premium travelers Airports Council International - ACI World.
Regional shuttle players who survived by offering reliable, bookable, trackable services with professional branding and simple SLAs — these are the practical commercial models to emulate shuttleafrica.com Tracxn.
Studies comparing ride-hailing vs shuttles underline that reliability for early flights and families is the differentiator; position Shuttle Plus as the “guaranteed, caring” option against variable ride-hail supply prked.com.
Citations: digital luggage pilots and luggage-tracking case studies; Incheon mobility ideas; Shuttle Africa and EZ Shuttle examples; ride-hailing comparison valcon.com Addepto Airports Council International - ACI World shuttleafrica.com Tracxn prked.com.

Brutal critique — limitations, risks, and where you must prove value quickly
Regulatory dependency: early-checkin and any airport handoff requires signed agreements and airport operational access; without them your luggage-handling promises are aspirational.
Liability and insurance exposure: recording, locked luggage, and chain-of-custody create complex insurance, privacy, and legal obligations; insurers may require costly coverage or operational changes.
Cost structure risk: labor, vehicle costs, kiosk space, and insurance can push unit economics negative if pricing, utilization, or average trips/day per vehicle are misestimated.
Operational complexity: multi-touch handoffs (house ? vehicle ? airport Team Two ? screening) multiply failure modes and customer anxiety points.
Trust friction: first-time users will resist giving a third party custody of checked luggage unless identity and accountability feel incontrovertible.
Tech overreach risk: building sophisticated AI/routing before you have stable data will waste effort; initial manual + rules + instrumentation is better.
Reputation fragility: one public incident (lost luggage, security breach, video misuse) can destroy premium positioning quickly.
Scalability constraints: human-heavy handoffs and kiosk reliance scale with cost; converting to a profitable model requires automation or volume partnerships.

Room for correction and prioritized fixes (what to do first)
Lock in legal/airport approvals and insurer sign-off before any live luggage custody promise.
Build a razorsimple, proven shuttle MVP (no early-checkin) to validate demand, utilization, and per-trip economics.
Finalize privacy/recording policy, and set technical retention and access controls before recording goes live.
Build the unit-economics model now with conservative utilization; run sensitivity analyses for low-utilization scenarios.
Harden exception SOPs (security fails, lock-code mismatch, accident) with legal-approved scripts and escalation paths.
Train and test agents with dry-runs; instrument every trip for data and learn fast.

Competitive advantages Shuttle Plus can lock in (if executed)
Premium trust brand in Ethiopia combining dignity + security + documented chain-of-custody.
Specialized service for high-value segments (elderly/medical/corporate) that general ride-hailing struggles to serve reliably.
Potential first-mover advantage on a coherent early-checkin vision in your market after you prove shuttle ops.
Local operational knowledge and tailored SOPs — culturally relevant service that global players rarely match.
Opportunity to create B2B recurring revenue (hotels, corporates) that stabilizes fleet utilization.

50 brutal questions and concerns you must answer (use these as a live checklist)
Who signs off at Ethiopian Airports to allow off-airport baggage acceptance and what exact paperwork do they require?

What is expected average luggage weight and handling time per pickup in Addis neighborhoods?

If airport security refuses a luggage handoff, how do you resolve the customer’s itinerary and manage costs?
Who can legally break a ziptie/lock if authorities require inspection?
What is your data-retention policy for onboard video and how do you comply with local privacy law?
What is the precise consent text you’ll use and where will you store signed consent evidence?
How will you ensure continuous encryption of video data in vehicle and at rest?
Who can request footage and what logged justification is required?
What SLA will you offer for pickups (5/10/15 minutes)? Will you refund if missed?
What tech fallback exists if a tablet or network goes down mid-shift?
How will dispatch handle multiple same-window pickups in congested areas?
How do you price peak-hour airport windows (early morning/late night) and handle surge?
What is your churn model for drivers and how will you retain trained staff?
How will you vet background and criminal checks for all agents and drivers?
What training and quality audits occur weekly to keep service consistent?
What is the escalation tree and phone list for field incidents?
How do you plan to manage refunds, credits, and customer compensation?
What reporting will you provide to hotels/partners on bookings and performance?
How do you prevent and detect agent theft or collusion with bad actors?
What physical evidence will you keep per trip (photos, weight logs, tag IDs) and where?
How will you micro-audit weighing accuracy and scale calibration?
What privacy-safe way can customers view chain-of-custody for their luggage?
How will you integrate with airline flight status feeds to auto-reschedule pickups?
How will you handle no-shows and cancellation policies?
What is your minimum viable vehicle equipment list and vendor sourcing plan?
Which third-party platforms (Telebirr, SMS vendor, maps) are regulated in Ethiopia and have hidden costs?
What is your customer acquisition cost by channel (hotel referrals vs ads vs partnerships)?
What is the expected lifetime value (LTV) of a frequent user and the acceptable CAC?
How will you pilot and measure early-care check-in feasibility later without jeopardizing shuttle ops?
Who owns the customer relationship if a hotel books the ride (you or hotel)?
How will you price corporate clients and track billed rides vs prepaid credits?
How do you handle international customers with high-value items, declarations, customs issues?
How will you manage multi-lingual support in high-pressure pickup situations?
What regulatory reporting does ECAA require for off-airport baggage handling?
What is your plan if an airport or airline denies any future kiosk access suddenly?
How will you contain reputational damage after an incident and manage press?
Who will audit your security and operational compliance quarterly?
What is the minimum telemetry you need to detect route deviations or suspicious stops?
How do you scale kiosks cost-effectively (shared kiosk, airline co-located, or third-party storage)?
How will you measure and improve the “emotional curve” you promised (anxiety?relief)?
What KPIs will you publish internally and what thresholds trigger corrective action?
How will you fund initial negative cash flow while utilization ramps?
What exit or pivot strategies exist if early-checkin never obtains regulatory buy-in?
If you scale to other Ethiopian airports or East Africa, what centralized ops center vs local autonomy mix will you use?
Use these questions as a gating checklist; don’t launch promises until answers are clear and documented.

Build the shuttle-only MVP and proof operating economics for 30–60 days before starting early-checkin outreach.
Lock a pilot hotel and one corporate client for guaranteed weekone volume.

Daily Ops Overview
Purpose
Provide a single operational reference that links and coordinates the Shuttle Plus SOPs for reservation intake through airport handoff, ensuring reliable, dignified, and safe shuttle-only service.

1. Scope and hours
Scope: Door-to-airport shuttle service (pickup, secure luggage handling, transport, and airport handoff) for Addis Ababa launch.
Operating hours: 24/7 via three 8hour shifts (Shift A: 06:00–14:00; Shift B: 14:00–22:00; Shift C: 22:00–06:00).
Coverage note: Dispatch hub in Addis HQ; Bishoftu expansion handled later.

2. Core daily workflow (high-level sequence)
Step 1: Reservation intake (app/web/phone) ? validation ? payment flag.
Step 2: Sorting & dispatch (AI-assisted + ops review) ? agent & vehicle assignment.
Step 3: Confirmation & notifications (push/SMS/voice) to customer.
Step 4: Pre-departure checks (agent checklist) and vehicle readiness.
Step 5: Doorstep pickup (identity check, video consent, weigh/wrap luggage).
Step 6: Secure transit (real-time tracking, in-vehicle recording).
Step 7: Airport arrival and Team Two handoff (code validation, kiosk if needed).
Step 8: Post-ride closure (feedback prompt, incident log if any, reconcile trip).



3. Key SOPs referenced (one-line linkable index)
Reservation Intake SOP — data required, auto-fill, payment hold, cancellations.
Sorting & Dispatch SOP — urgency, proximity rules, VIP handling, manual override.
Notification Schedule SOP — confirmation, 60/30/10-minute reminders, ETA.
Agent Pre-Departure Checklist — uniform, tablet, scale, zipties, camera check.
Pickup Protocol SOP — greeting script, ID verification, video consent language.
Weighing & Wrapping SOP — calibrated scale steps, tag issuance, ziptie code generation.
Lock Codes SOP — generation, secure delivery, emergency override rules.
In-Vehicle Monitoring SOP — camera policy, retention, encryption, incident flagging.
Airport Handoff SOP — Team Two briefing, QR/code validation, kiosk fallback.
Exception Handling SOP — missed pickup, security fail, lock break, accident.
Feedback & KPI SOP — ClickUp feedback flow, NPS capture, critical flagging.
Shift Handover SOP — checklist, unresolved items log, sign-off.

Below is all sops in detail…
Reservation Intake SOP
Purpose
Define how bookings are accepted, validated, and recorded.
Scope and owner
Covers app, web, phone bookings. Owner: Dispatch Coordinator.
Required information and validation steps
Collect: full name, contact, pickup address, flight number, airline, departure time, luggage count, special needs.
Verify flight time against current date and flag suspicious entries.
Hold payment or record payment intent before assignment.
Create booking record with unique Booking ID and schedule in dispatch board.
Outputs and artifacts
Booking record with Booking ID; confirmation message sent to customer; pre-populated agent checklist.
KPI and acceptance
Booking-to-confirmation time under 2 minutes; missing-data rate below 3 percent.
Templates and links
Booking data template; confirmation message text; link to Booking Form.

Sorting and Dispatch SOP
Purpose
Match bookings to the right vehicle and agent efficiently.
Scope and owner
Applies to automated suggestions and human verification. Owner: Dispatch Coordinator.
Core rules and priorities
Match by urgency (flight buffer), proximity, vehicle capacity, luggage load, VIP status.
AI proposes top 3 assignments; dispatcher chooses or overrides with reason logged.
Reserve buffer windows for airport traffic peaks.
Operational steps
Review incoming queue every 5 minutes; accept AI suggestion or apply manual override; assign Booking ID, Agent, Vehicle, and ETA.
Outputs and artifacts
Dispatch log entry for each assignment; override audit trail.
KPI and acceptance
Assignment latency under 5 minutes; manual override rate under 15 percent.
Templates and links
Dispatch decision log; override reason form.

Notification Schedule SOP
Purpose
Define multi-channel customer notifications to reduce anxiety and no-shows.
Scope and owner
All bookings. Owner: Customer Support Lead.
Timing and channels
Immediate confirmation on booking.
Pre-pickup reminders at 60, 30, and 10 minutes.
Agent en route notification at driver departure with live map link.
Failure or exception alerts via SMS and app push.
Content and personalization
Include Booking ID, vehicle ID, agent name and photo, estimated pickup window, contact number.
KPI and acceptance
Delivery rate above 99 percent for critical notifications; customer opt-out honored.
Templates and links
Notification copy library; escalation message samples.

Agent Pre-Departure Checklist SOP
Purpose
Ensure vehicle and agent readiness before leaving for pickups.
Scope and owner
All driver and luggage concierge departures. Owner: Field Operations Lead.
Checklist items
Agent uniform, ID badge, NFC badge check.
Tablet powered and synced; Booking queue loaded.
Vehicle: fuel, tires, lights, first aid kit.
Equipment: calibrated scale, zipties, wraps, spare locks, camera functioning.
Emergency contact numbers and SOP quick card present.
Outputs and artifacts
Pre-departure checklist ticked in tablet app; issue flagged to Ops if any fail.
KPI and acceptance
100 percent checklist completion before departure; equipment failure resolved within shift.
Templates and links
Tablet checklist file; equipment trouble ticket form.

Pickup Protocol SOP
Purpose
Standardize customer interactions and secure collection of luggage.
Scope and owner
Team 1 doorstep operations. Owner: Luggage Concierge Lead.
Greeting and consent flow
Agent greets by name, shows ID and app photo.
Read consent script for video recording and luggage handling; capture digital signature.
Optionally perform live video identity match on request.
Weighing and handling steps
Weigh each bag on calibrated scale; record weight to booking.
Apply branded wrap and unique ziptie; generate ziptie code linked to Booking ID and customer.
Safety and dignity actions
Offer assistance without rushing; respect privacy and medical needs.
Outputs and artifacts
Pickup record with photos, weight entries, ziptie codes, and customer signature.
KPI and acceptance
Pickup completion time within assigned window; recorded consent present for every pickup.
Templates and links
Agent greeting script; digital consent form.

Weighing Wrapping and Locking SOP
Purpose
Guarantee tamper-evident, traceable luggage handling.
Scope and owner
Applies to all luggage handled at pickup. Owner: Ops Manager.
Material and calibration rules
Use calibrated mobile scales; perform daily zero-check.
Use approved recyclable wrap and coded zipties; log batch numbers.
Process steps
Weigh and photograph bag; attach tag with Booking ID and ziptie code; record on booking.
For high-value items, note description and advise customer to declare if necessary.
Code and unlock rules
Generate customer-only unlock code and link to Booking ID; store encrypted for the minimum retention period.
Outputs and artifacts
Luggage manifest per trip; ziptie code ledger.
KPI and acceptance
Zero mismatch between recorded weight and final kiosk reconciliation in pilot baseline.
Templates and links
Weighing log sheet; ziptie code generation tool spec.

Lock Codes and Handoff SOP
Purpose
Manage secure code generation and airport handoff process.
Scope and owner
From ziptie creation to Team Two handoff. Owner: Airport Operations Lead.
Code lifecycle and delivery
Generate time-bound release codes tied to Booking ID.
Deliver code to customer via in-app secure channel and confirm at handoff.
Handoff verification steps
Airport agent scans ziptie/QR and requests customer code.
Confirm customer identity and log code match.
Update booking as Handed Off with timestamp and agent initials.
Exception and override rules
If mismatch, follow Security Fail SOP; only authorized manager may perform supervised override with audit trail.
Outputs and artifacts
Handoff log; code usage audit trail.
KPI and acceptance
Handoff code success rate above 98 percent in pilot.
Templates and links
Handoff log template; override request form.

In-Vehicle Monitoring SOP
Purpose
Define camera use, data storage, and incident flagging for safety.
Scope and owner
All operational vehicles. Owner: Tech Lead and Legal.
Recording policy and consent
Cameras record pickup through handoff; customers consent captured at pickup.
Recordings encrypted during transit and stored for retention period defined by Legal.
Access and incident handling
Only authorized personnel can request footage with logged justification.
For incidents, tag video with incident ID and attach to incident report.
Data retention and deletion
Retain recordings for specified days, then auto-delete unless flagged for incident or legal hold.
KPI and acceptance
All trips have complete recording; authorized access logs present for any retrievals.
Templates and links
Video access request form; retention schedule.

Airport Handoff and Kiosk SOP
Purpose
Standardize Team Two reception and kiosk exception handling.
Scope and owner
Airport-side operations. Owner: Airport Agent Lead.
Team Two reception steps
Receive pre-brief from Team One with ETA, Booking ID, ziptie codes, and passenger notes.
Prepare kiosk area for arrivals and store temporarily if required.
Kiosk exception handling
If security requires re-screen, notify customer and follow Security Fail SOP.
Provide claim tag and record location if luggage stored for owner pickup.
Outputs and artifacts
Handoff confirmation; kiosk storage log with timestamps and custody notes.
KPI and acceptance
Handoff-to-screening transfer time minimized; kiosk retrieval times under target SLA.
Templates and links
Kiosk intake form; Team Two briefing template.

Exception Handling and Security Fail SOP
Purpose
Provide clear, auditable steps for failed security, lost codes, lock breaks, and accidents.
Scope and owner
All exceptions. Owner: Ops Manager and Legal.
Triage matrix and escalation
Classify incident severity: Minor (delay, non-critical mismatch), Major (security fail, police involvement), Critical (accident, injury).
Route to Level 1/2/3 escalations per severity and log all actions in ClickUp.
Specific flows
Security fail: notify customer, offer options (lock break with consent, kiosk storage), document decision.
Lock break: require customer authorization; if unavailable, follow legal hold procedure.
Accident: secure scene, call emergency services, record video evidence, notify insurer and Exec.
Outputs and artifacts
Incident report with timestamps, evidence, customer consent, and resolution steps.
KPI and acceptance
Exception resolution time targets per severity level; incident reporting completeness at 100 percent.

MVP Booking Page:
Purpose
A minimal, production-ready web booking page that accepts shuttle-only reservations, shows a live map for dispatcher testing, and feeds bookings into your ClickUp/dispatch workflow.
Key requirements (must-have)
Responsive single-page form (mobile-first)
Required fields collected and validated: Full name; Phone (with country code); Pickup address; Pickup zone (dropdown); Preferred pickup time/date; Flight number; Airline; Luggage count; Number of passengers; Payment option (placeholder).
Auto-generate a unique Booking ID on submit.
Store submissions to a simple backend (Google Sheet, Airtable, or Firebase) with timestamp.
Live map embed for dispatcher (read-only) showing submitted pickup pin (Google Maps embed or Leaflet with OpenStreetMap).
Confirmation screen + email/SMS stub (or onscreen confirmation) showing Booking ID and next steps.
Admin/dispatcher UI to view, assign, change status, and export bookings (simple table view).
Basic validation & UX: required field markers, phone format check, date-time picker, confirmation modal.
Privacy/consent checkbox referencing your pickup video & handling policy.
Optional but strongly recommended (MVP+)
File upload for ID/photo (for VIPs) — optional.
Agent photo upload placeholder (for later).
Simple webhook to post to ClickUp API or Zapier to create a task per booking.
SMS confirmation via Telebirr/third-party (deferred if no API keys).
Technical choices (fastest to implement)
Frontend: plain HTML + Bootstrap/Tailwind or a simple no-code landing page builder (Carrd, Webflow) with embedded form.
Form storage: Google Forms ? Google Sheets (fastest); Airtable (better table + API); Firebase Realtime DB (most flexible).
Live map: Google Maps embed (requires API key), or Leaflet + OSM (no-cost).
Dispatcher dashboard: Google Sheet view + Google Data Studio / Airtable grid, or a tiny web admin using a simple no-code tool (Glide, Retool) if you want clickable status updates.
Integrations: Zapier or Make for automations (ClickUp create-task, SMS, Slack).

booking_id (auto)
created_at (ISO datetime)
name (string)
phone (string)
pickup_address (string)
pickup_zone (enum: Home, Hotel, Office, Other)
pickup_datetime (ISO datetime)
flight_number (string)
airline (string)
luggage_count (integer)
passengers_count (integer)
payment_method (string: Telebirr / Cash / Other)

status (enum: New / Assigned / En Route / Picked Up / Handed Off / Closed / Exception)
assigned_agent (string)
notes (text)
Dispatcher view minimal spec
