Roleplay Scenario 1 Customer Complaint Late Pickup
Situation: Customer calls angrily because the driver arrived 25 minutes late, missed their international flight, and demands a refund and compensation for missed flight fees.
Trainer notes: Evaluate tone control, fact-gathering, refund policy application, escalation judgment, and ability to offer interim remedies. Score use of brand voice and SLA communication.
Required evidence to collect: Trip ID, booking confirmation screenshot, driver ETA logs, timestamped messages, any photos or receipts customer offers for additional losses.
Expected agent actions:
Open ticket and set severity P2; gather trip ID and timestamps; apologise and acknowledge impact.
Check driver logs and ETAs; determine root cause (traffic, driver no-show, misassignment).
Offer immediate remedy per policy (full fare refund and travel credit if within policy) while informing customer that compensation for third-party costs requires escalation and evidence.
If evidence suggests company fault and high impact, escalate to Ops for manager review and potential goodwill compensation.
Communicate next update time and close follow-up loop.
Exemplar agent response transcript:
Opening: "Hello, this is [Name] from Shuttle Plus. I’m sorry this happened and I appreciate how stressful missing an international flight must be."
Fact-gathering: "Can I confirm your Trip ID and the scheduled pickup time? Also please share any messages or screenshots you have."
Immediate remedy: "I will open an incident and issue a full fare refund now. For flight fees I will escalate to our Ops Lead; please upload any receipts and I will include them in the escalation."
Closing: "We will update you by [time within SLA]. Thank you for your patience."

Roleplay Scenario 2 Lost Item
Situation: Customer messages that they left a laptop in a shuttle three hours after trip close. Customer provides a photo and partial description but no Trip ID.
Trainer notes: Evaluate retrieval workflow, evidence matching, coordination with driver, tone, speed of initial response, and retention protocol. Score ability to escalate to Lost-and-Found policy correctly.
Required evidence to collect: Photo of item; approximate pickup/drop-off times; pickup and drop locations; customer contact details; any unique identifiers on device.
Expected agent actions:
Ask for approximate trip time and locations; search CRM by phone/email for matching trips; set ticket severity P2.
If Trip ID found, contact driver immediately to check vehicle and log search attempt; if Trip ID not found, request customer confirm timeframe and escalate to Dispatch to query telemetry.
Secure item if found per Lost-and-Found SOP and notify customer with retrieval options and hold period.
Document chain of custody and store item in secure location until claim verified.
Exemplar agent response transcript:
Opening: "Hi, I’m [Name] from Shuttle Plus. Thanks for letting us know; I’ll do my best to help recover your laptop."
Fact-gathering: "Can you tell me the date and approximate time of your trip and the pickup and drop locations? Also please confirm the phone number used for the booking."
Next steps: "I’ll search our records now and contact the driver. If we find the item we’ll secure it and provide pickup instructions within [SLA]. Please keep an eye on this ticket for updates."
Closing: "If we locate it we’ll hold it for [hold period] and require ID to release."

Roleplay Scenario 3 Aggressive or Threatening Customer
Situation: Customer on chat uses aggressive language and threatens to come to the depot after a dispute about a fare adjustment. No physical violence yet.
Trainer notes: Evaluate de-escalation language, safety protocol adherence, escalation to Safety/Ops when threats occur, and documentation quality. Score ability to transition from negotiation to safety measures.
Required evidence to collect: Chat logs, timestamps, fare adjustment details, any prior interactions, customer identity confirmation.
Expected agent actions:
Use calm, measured language; do not mirror aggression; acknowledge concern and set boundaries.
If language includes a threat to harm people or property or the agent feels unsafe, classify as P0 and escalate to Safety/Ops immediately, notify supervisor, and record all chat logs.
Offer to pause negotiation and provide contact details for formal review; do not engage in bargaining under threat.
If threat is non-violent but persistent, inform customer the account may be suspended pending review and escalate to Ops for risk assessment.
Exemplar agent response transcript:
Opening: "I understand you are upset. I want to help resolve this but I cannot continue the conversation if there are threats. Please allow me to review your case and I will escalate to my supervisor now."
Safety step: "For your safety and ours, I am escalating this to our Safety team who will contact you within [SLA]. If you are in immediate danger, please contact local authorities."
Documentation: "I will attach this chat to INC-[ID] and our Safety Lead will review it. We will follow up with the next steps within [time]."

Trainer Guidance for Roleplays
Score each roleplay on Tone, Fact-gathering, Policy adherence, Escalation judgment, and Closure clarity using a 1–5 scale.
Required passing: no critical failures (P0/P1 mishandled) and average ?3.8 across criteria.
Run each scenario under timed conditions: initial response within 2 minutes, resolution plan within 10 minutes for non-P0 cases.
Include immediate debrief with concrete improvement points and a short written corrective action if performance is below standard.

CS — Roleplay Scenarios and Exemplar Responses.docx.
CS — Rubric and Scoring Sheet.xlsx for trainer use.
CS — Ticketing Examples.xlsx with sample populated tickets for the three scenarios.


Dispatch and Operations Control (Training Module)
Overview
Objective: Deliver efficient booking fulfillment, optimize fleet utilization, and triage incidents in real time while maintaining clear audit trails.
Duration: 6 hours classroom + 2 shift-shadow practicals.
Passing criteria: ?85% on written assessment; satisfactory performance in two supervised shifts (no critical failures).
Materials needed: Dispatch SOP deck, live dashboard access or simulator, escalation matrix, shift handover template, fault-reporting forms, call/chat scripts, performance dashboard.

Learning outcomes
Execute the end-to-end dispatch workflow from booking confirmation to trip closeout.
Prioritize and triage incidents quickly using company rules and escalation matrix.
Manage dynamic routing and surge events to maximize on-time performance and utilization.
Perform accurate data entry and audits to maintain a reliable operational record.
Conduct clear shift handovers and use communication templates that preserve evidence and reduce rework.

Hourly lesson plan and activities
Hour 1 — Role, KPIs, and system orientation
Topics: Dispatch role in the operational chain; KPIs (OTD, first-response time, incident resolution SLA, cancellations); overview of dashboard, common screens, and key fields.
Activities: Slide walkthrough; quick system tour or simulator scenarios; KPI baseline exercise.
Hour 2 — Booking intake, confirmation, and exceptions
Topics: Booking validation rules; confirmation templates; special requests handling (group, oversized luggage, meet-and-greet); manual booking entry standards.
Activities: Live booking entry drills; validation checklist practice.
Hour 3 — Priority triage and incident management
Topics: Triage levels (P0–P3) and response SLAs; escalation matrix; evidence and logging requirements; passenger-facing messaging.
Activities: Triage tabletop exercises with 4 staged incidents; roleplay Dispatch-driver-customer flows.
Hour 4 — Dynamic routing, reassignments, and surge management
Topics: Reassignment rules; route optimization basics; handling traffic, weather, and airport delays; surge pricing and dispatch overrides.
Activities: Live simulation of surge event; decision-logging practice.
Hour 5 — Shift handover, audits, and data hygiene
Topics: Handover checklist; critical logs to include; common data-entry errors and corrections; reconciliation with finance (cash trips).
Activities: Prepare a full shift handover packet from sample logs; peer audit exercise.
Hour 6 — Communication, escalation scripts, and stress scenarios
Topics: Templates for SMS/call/chat; calming language for escalations; when and how to involve Safety or Legal.
Activities: Timed escalation drills; scoring and debrief.
Practicals — Two supervised shift-shadow sessions
Each trainee completes two 4-hour supervised shifts handling real-time events with trainer oversight; trainer uses scoring sheet and debriefs immediately after shift.

Core SOPs and Checklists (copy-ready)
Dispatch Start-of-Shift Checklist
Confirm roster and vehicle assignments; log in to dashboard; verify API/telemetry connections; review overnight incidents; check pending refunds and exceptions.
Booking Validation SOP
Verify passenger name, flight number/time, pickup point, contact number; confirm vehicle type and accessibility needs; apply fares and discounts per fare matrix; send confirmation SMS within 3 minutes.
Priority Triage Rules (P0–P3)
P0: Active safety incident, violence, medical emergency — immediate dispatch of Safety and notify Ops Lead, response within 2 minutes.
P1: Vehicle disabling defect, major collision, passenger injury — notify Fleet Maintenance and Safety, contact passenger, response within 10 minutes.
P2: Customer complaint with evidence request, late flight/major delay — reassign vehicle if needed, respond within 30 minutes.
P3: Billing dispute, cosmetic issue, minor lost item — log, acknowledge within 4 hours, resolve within 72 hours.
Escalation Matrix (names/roles to populate)
P0: On-duty Ops Lead ? Safety Lead ? CEO on-call.
P1: Dispatch Supervisor ? Fleet Manager ? Legal (if injury).
P2: Customer Service Lead ? Ops Lead.
P3: CS Agent ? Finance for refunds.
Reassignment and Reroute SOP
Reassign when ETA > threshold or vehicle unavailable; inform driver with reason and ETA; notify passenger with updated ETA and driver details; log reassignment reason code.
Evidence Logging Standard for Dispatch
Accepts attachments only via app/email inbox; tag evidence with ticket ID, timestamp, uploader name; do not alter original files; attach to incident ticket and back up to central folder.
Shift Handover Template (required fields)
Active incidents; unresolved exceptions; vehicles out of service (plates, reason); pending refunds/chargebacks; driver absences; high-priority customer alerts.

Templates and Scripts
Booking Confirmation SMS
"Shuttle Plus: Booking confirmed for [Name]. Driver [Name], Vehicle [Plate]. Pickup [Time] at [Pickup Point]. Contact [Phone]."
Reassignment Notification to Passenger
"Update: Your Shuttle Plus driver has changed to [Name], Vehicle [Plate]. New ETA [HH:MM]. We apologise for the inconvenience."
Driver Instruction Template (in-app)
"Reassign: Trip [ID]. New pickup [Point]. Reason: [Vehicle defect/Traffic]. ETA updated to [HH:MM]."
Incident Acknowledgement to Customer (first contact)
"We received your report for [issue]. We are investigating and will update within [SLA]. Please attach any photos or videos to this ticket."
Escalation Call Script (for P0/P1)
Opening: "This is [Name] from Shuttle Plus Ops. We are responding to [incident]. Are you safe now?"
Immediate action: confirm injuries, advise next steps, inform about evidence preservation, notify that Safety/Fleet is en route.

Assessments
Written assessment (25 questions) — mix of MCQ, scenario-based decision-making, and short-answer requiring logging of correct reassignment reason codes. Passing 85%.
Practical simulation exercise — staged surge + two simultaneous incidents; trainee must prioritize, assign resources, and produce a validated decision log.
Shift performance rubric — metrics: average response time, correct escalation, minimal reassignment friction, audit accuracy. Trainer sign-off required.
Sample evaluation criteria:
Response timeliness to P0/P1 incidents: meet SLA 100% in practicals.
Data hygiene: no incorrect booking edits in sample audit.
Communication clarity: customer notification templates used appropriately.

Tools, Dashboards, and Data Hygiene
Required dashboard views: Active trips, Pending assignments, Unresolved incidents, Vehicle status (Available/In-service/Out-of-service).
Logging rules: always enter full reason codes from dropdowns; avoid free-text for status changes; attach evidence files directly to ticket; include timestamp and operator initials on manual notes.
Audit cadence: daily sample audit of 10 closed tickets for compliance; weekly review of P0–P1 incidents with Safety and Fleet.

Trainer guidance and rollout notes
Trainer profile: experienced Ops Lead or senior dispatcher with minimum 12 months on role and documented incident handling experience.
First cohort: pair each trainee with a mentor for the first 2 supervised shifts; run live-sim drills in low-traffic windows before live shift.
Deliverables for module folder: Dispatch — Training Module v1.0.pdf; Dispatch — Shift Handover Template.xlsx; Dispatch — Triage Scenarios.docx; Dispatch — Practical Simulation Log.xlsx; Escalation Matrix.pdf.
Version control: changelog.txt with author, date, and changes.
Key metrics to track post-training: mean first-response time, incident closure SLA compliance, reassignments per 100 trips, customer complaints citing dispatch.

Three Realistic Triage Scenarios with Trainer Notes and Expected Decisions
Scenario 1 — Engine Overheat En Route to Pickup
Situation: Driver reports vehicle engine overheating while en route to an airport pickup with ETA 12 minutes; passenger waiting at pickup point.
Trainer notes: Confirm driver safety first, gather exact location, assess nearest spare vehicle availability, check maintenance ETA for the disabled vehicle, prepare passenger communication.
Expected decisions and actions: 
Instruct driver to stop in a safe location and switch on hazard lights.
Classify as P1 if the vehicle is disabled or risk to passenger/time; notify Fleet Maintenance and assign "mechanical defect" reason code.
Immediately reassign the pickup to nearest available vehicle; update passenger with new ETA and driver details.
Log incident, attach driver photo of dash if available, and schedule vehicle tow/repair.
If reassignment not possible within threshold, offer passenger alternative transport or refund per policy and escalate to Ops Lead.
Scenario 2 — Passenger Medical Emergency During Trip
Situation: During inbound trip to airport a passenger becomes unresponsive and displays possible seizure symptoms. Driver requests immediate guidance.
Trainer notes: Emphasize life-safety first, clear and calm instructions, documenting time and actions, and rapid escalation to emergency services if available. Validate role boundaries for drivers.
Expected decisions and actions: 
Classify as P0 and initiate P0 escalation: notify Safety Lead and Ops Lead immediately.
Instruct driver to stop in safe location and call emergency medical services; if on-airport, notify airport operations/security.
Ask driver to ensure airway/breathing if trained and safe to do so; request any bystander assistance.
Capture time, witness names, photos of scene (only if safe), and attach to incident ticket.
Keep passenger contact informed and arrange follow-up (hospital details, responsible person) and preserve any video/evidence for authorities.
Scenario 3 — Two Simultaneous Late Pickup Complaints and One Minor Collision
Situation: During peak hours Dispatch receives two P2 late-pickup complaints from separate customers and one P1 minor collision reported by a driver; collision has no injuries but vehicle disabled.
Trainer notes: Reinforce prioritization rules, resource allocation, customer communication templates, and logging discipline. Ensure trainees demonstrate ability to handle concurrent incidents.
Expected decisions and actions: 
Prioritize P1 (collision) first: allocate nearest fleet support and reassign any impacted bookings from the disabled vehicle.
For the two P2 late pickups, verify ETAs and reassign nearest available vehicles; if ETAs exceed wait thresholds, proactively offer alternatives or compensation per policy.
Inform all affected customers with clear ETA updates and apology templates.
Log all actions with timestamps and reason codes; open separate incident tickets for the collision and each customer complaint.
Escalate collision to Fleet Maintenance and Safety Lead for vehicle tow and evidence collection; schedule post-incident audit of decisions.

Implementation Notes
Import the CSV rows into your shift handover spreadsheet and adapt field names to your system.
Use the triage scenarios in timed tabletop drills; score trainees on decision speed, communication clarity, and logging accuracy.
Add the assessment and answer key to the Dispatch module folder as Assessment — Dispatch v1.0.pdf and update changelog after first cohort.

Drivers Training Module (Full Lesson Plan)
Overview
Objective: Safe, punctual service with consistent brand experience and complete incident evidence capture.
Duration: 4 hours classroom + 2 ride-alongs (each 2–3 hours).
Passing criteria: ?85% on written quiz; ride-along scores of “Satisfactory” or higher on all critical items.
Materials needed: Slide deck, demo videos, vehicle for ride-alongs, printed pre-trip checklist, phone/tablet for evidence capture, quiz handouts, scoring sheets.
Learning outcomes
Perform a complete pre-trip inspection every shift.
Deliver consistent, courteous passenger onboarding and offboarding.
Execute accessibility assistance safely and respectfully.
Capture and preserve incident evidence to company standards.
Follow emergency and escalation procedures with correct communication.
Hourly breakdown
Hour 1 — Company standards and expectations
Topics: KPIs, shift punctuality, brand voice, payment/tipping rules, device policy, redlines (seatbelts, no phone while driving).
Activities: Slide presentation; 10-minute group discussion on real incident examples.
Deliverable: Signed driver code of conduct.
Hour 2 — Vehicle pre-trip and defensive driving
Topics: Pre-trip checklist walkthrough; common fault indicators; basic daily maintenance reporting; defensive driving and airport routing protocols.
Activities: Live demo using vehicle; trainee practice on checklist in pairs.
Deliverable: Completed sample pre-trip checklist.
Hour 3 — Customer handling and accessibility
Topics: Pickup confirmations, safe loading, luggage policy, wheelchair and mobility device securement, lost-and-found, escalation thresholds.
Activities: Roleplay onboarding/offboarding and accessibility scenarios; quick quiz on protocols.
Deliverable: Roleplay rubric scores.
Hour 4 — Incident reporting and evidence capture
Topics: Incident SOP; photographic standards; chain of custody; immediate safety steps; communication templates to Ops and customers.
Activities: Hands-on practice photographing staged damage; short video capture exercise; fill sample incident report.
Deliverable: Sample incident report submission.
Ride-alongs — Practical assessment
Two rides per trainee with different trainers or shifts.
Focus areas: punctuality, checklist use, safe driving, customer handling, evidence capture when simulated incidents occur.
Feedback: Debrief after each ride using scoring sheet.

One-Page Quick Reference Card for Drivers
Top priorities
Seatbelts on for all passengers; do not move until secured.
Safety first; if immediate risk, stop service and call for help.
Preserve evidence; photograph before clearing scene.
Pre-shift must-dos
Complete pre-trip checklist and initial in-app vehicle report.
Mount device securely and confirm POS working.
Confirm shift schedule and assigned vehicle.
Pickup script
"Shuttle Plus — Driver [Name] here. Vehicle [Plate]. Meet at [Pickup Point]."
If delay > wait-time threshold notify Dispatch with ETA.
Accessibility quick steps
Ask preferred method of assistance; secure mobility device with tie-downs; use lap belt.
Incident immediate steps
Ensure safety of all people.
Move to safe position if possible.
Take photos: wide exterior, close damage, plate/VIN, interior.
Fill short incident report and submit within 15 minutes.
Notify Dispatch with short template.
Evidence photo checklist
Wide scene shot; close-up of damage; plate/VIN; interior context; 30–60s video if safe.
When to escalate to Dispatch
Medical emergency, threat or violence, major damage, passenger injury, vehicle disabling defect.
Contact templates
Driver arrival SMS: "Shuttle Plus: Driver [Name] arrived. Vehicle [Plate]. Meet at [Pickup Point]."
Incident quick notify: "INCIDENT: [Time] [Location] Damage Y/N Injury Y/N Evidence attached. Need assistance."
Redlines
No phone use while driving; no transporting intoxicated passengers who are violent; do not admit fault in collisions.
Trainer tip
If unsure, stop and notify Dispatch. Better to pause than to lose evidence or escalate risk.


Trainer Guidance and Next Steps
Convert the pre-trip checklist and ride-along scoring sheet into fillable Excel or Google Sheets for shift logs.
Record short demo videos for pre-trip walk, wheelchair securement, and evidence capture; include in module folder.
Run first cohort with experienced trainer shadowing every ride-along; collect feedback and update module v1.1 in changelog.



Finance and Revenue Control — Training Module
Overview
Objective: Ensure accurate transaction capture, timely reconciliation, robust fraud controls, and clear revenue reporting that protect cash flow and customer trust.
Duration: 2–3 hours classroom + 2 supervised reconciliation sessions.
Passing criteria: ?90% on written assessment; zero critical errors in two consecutive supervised reconciliations.
Materials needed: POS/payment logs, reconciliation spreadsheet template, refund/chargeback matrix, sample disputed transactions, access to finance system.
Learning outcomes
Reconcile daily payments and cash-outs to bank and POS records with documented variance explanations.
Apply refund and chargeback procedures consistently and defensibly.
Detect and escalate suspected fraud or revenue leakage.
Maintain audit-ready records and produce compact daily/weekly revenue summaries.
Coordinate with CS, Dispatch, and IT to resolve transactional exceptions.

Lesson plan and activities
Hour 1 — Basics and KPIs
Topics: daily cash-out, settlement cycles, reconciliation KPIs (variance %, chargeback rate, time-to-reconcile).
Activity: walkthrough of sample day’s payment flow; KPI calculation exercise.
Hour 2 — Reconciliation process and exceptions
Topics: matching trips to payments, handling offline/cash trips, payment gateway settlements, currency rounding and fees.
Activity: hands-on reconciliation of a sample CSV with injected errors; document variance reasons.
Hour 3 — Refunds, chargebacks, and fraud controls
Topics: refund approval matrix, chargeback dispute workflow, fraud indicators and telemetry sources.
Activity: review three dispute cases and draft dispute packets; flag suspicious patterns using sample data.
Practical sessions — Two supervised reconciliations
Tasks: complete end-of-day reconciliation for two different days, prepare variance report, process approved refunds, escalate unresolved items.
Feedback: reviewer signs off on remediation steps and documentation completeness.

Core SOPs and checklists
Daily Reconciliation Checklist
Export trip ledger; export payment gateway settlements; export POS/cash reports; match transactions; note unmatched items; compute variance and document reasons; prepare deposit file and sign-off.
Refund and Approval Matrix
Agent-level: refunds up to defined small amount with required evidence.
Supervisor-level: larger refunds or exceptions with manager approval.
Ops/Finance Lead: high-value reimbursements, flight-impact claims, or policy exceptions.
Chargeback Dispute SOP
Required attachments: transaction log, trip proof (driver logs, GPS), customer communication, proof of service delivery; submit dispute within card-network SLA; track dispute outcomes and update merchant reporting.
Cash Handling and Daily Cash-Out SOP
Cash reconciliation steps, dual sign-off on cash handover, secure deposit timing and receipts, discrepancy escalation protocol.
Fraud Detection and Escalation SOP
Monitor flagged patterns: repeated card declines then successful high-value trip, multi-account usage from same device, driver-off-trip cash collection anomalies; escalate suspected fraud to Security and Ops with evidence packet.
Audit and Record Retention Policy
Retain reconciliations, deposit slips, dispute records, and refund approvals per retention schedule; ensure files are searchable and backed up.



Templates and tools
Reconciliation variance template (fields): Date; Total trips; Expected settlement; Actual settlement; Variance amount; Top 3 variance reasons; Action taken; Owner; Sign-off.
Refund request form (fields): TripID; Customer; Amount; Reason code; Evidence attached; Approver signature.
Chargeback dispute packet checklist (items): Transaction ID; Merchant settlement report; Trip proof; Customer correspondence; Dispute submission date; Follow-up owner.
Cash-out sign-off form (fields): Driver/Depot; Total cash; Denominations; Signatures (collector and supervisor); Deposit reference.

Assessments and metrics
Written assessment: 20 questions covering reconciliation, refunds, chargebacks, and fraud indicators. Passing 90%.
Practical assessment: two reconciliations with injected exceptions; trainee must identify and resolve or properly escalate all exceptions.
Fraud detection exercise: review sample telemetry and flag top 5 suspicious cases with rationale.
Key metrics to monitor post-training:
Daily reconciliation completion rate and average time-to-reconcile.
Chargeback rate and dispute win rate.
Refund approval turnaround time.
Cash discrepancy frequency and value.

Trainer guidance and deliverables
Trainer profile: Finance Lead or senior accountant with payments and dispute experience.
Deliverables to add to module folder: Finance — Training Module v1.0.pdf; Reconciliation Template.xlsx; RefundRequestForm.xlsx; ChargebackChecklist.docx; CashOutSignoff.csv; Finance — Assessment v1.0.pdf; changelog.txt.
Rollout note: run first month with shadowed close-of-day by finance lead; review early exceptions weekly and refine reason codes and templates.
Fleet Maintenance and Cleaning Training Module
Overview
Objective: Keep Shuttle Plus fleet safe, reliable, and presentation-ready with minimal downtime through standardized inspections, fault reporting, and cleaning protocols.
Duration: 4 hours classroom + 1 hands-on inspection session per trainee; mechanic /technician shadowing for 2 shifts.
Passing criteria: ?90% on written assessment; correct completion of 5 consecutive pre/post-trip inspections; demonstrated fault triage and vendor coordination in practical exercise.
Materials needed: vehicle for inspections, maintenance checklist forms, fault-reporting app/template, basic tools, cleaning supplies list, vendor contact directory.

Learning outcomes
Perform accurate pre-trip and post-trip inspections and log defects correctly.
Triage defects by severity and apply the correct out-of-service rules.
Execute standard cleaning and hygiene procedures that meet brand presentation standards.
Coordinate with vendors and garages for scheduled and unscheduled repairs with clear handovers.
Maintain maintenance records, parts inventory, and downtime reporting for KPI tracking.

Hourly lesson plan and activities
Hour 1 Fleet policy and KPIs
Topics: Vehicle availability target, mean time to repair (MTTR), downtime reporting, warranty and service windows.
Activity: KPI calculation example and discussion of outage cost impacts.
Hour 2 Pre-trip and post-trip inspections
Topics: Inspection items, defect severity levels, immediate safety redlines, photo evidence standards for defects.
Activity: Live walkaround using pre-trip checklist, trainees record findings.
Hour 3 Fault triage and vendor coordination
Topics: Severity codes (A—safety critical; B—operationally impairing; C—cosmetic/low), removal-from-service rules, tow vs. local fix decision tree, vendor SLA expectations.
Activity: Triage tabletop with 6 fault examples; draft vendor work orders.
Hour 4 Cleaning standards and PPE handling
Topics: Interior and exterior cleaning schedules, approved chemicals and dilution ratios, fabric care, biohazard cleanup, PPE use, lost-and-found transfer to secure storage.
Activity: Practical cleaning station; stain removal demo; safe handling of biohazard spill kit.
Hands-on inspection session Practical graded on checklist completeness, correct defect coding, photo documentation, and safe handling. Mechanic shadow shifts to observe repair intake and parts handling.

Core SOPs and Checklists
Daily Pre-Trip Inspection Checklist (required every shift)
Items: exterior lights; tyres and pressures; brake condition; fluid levels; windshield/wipers; mirrors; seatbelts; horn; HVAC; fire extinguisher; first-aid kit; signage; interior cleanliness; securement of device mount and POS.
Post-Trip Inspection and Turnback Checklist
Items: report new defects; confirm cleaning complete; log fuel/charging level; report mileage; verify missing-item checks.
Defect Severity and Out-of-Service Rules
Severity A Safety critical — immediate removal from service; examples: brake failure, steering fault, airbag fault, fuel leak.
Severity B Operational — may be allowed for limited ops with mitigation and documented ETA to repair; examples: engine overheating warning, tyre tread near threshold.
Severity C Cosmetic — low urgency; schedule per maintenance calendar.
Fault Reporting and Repair Intake SOP
Required fields: Plate, VIN, fault code, severity, photos (wide + close-up), last known odometer, reporter initials, suggested action (tow/drive-to-garage), requested SLA. Attach to ticket and notify Fleet Manager.
Vendor and Garage Coordination SOP
Pre-approved vendor list; parts ordering workflow; quotes and approval thresholds; pick-up/drop-off check-in; required documentation for warranty claims.
Cleaning and Hygiene SOP for Vehicles
Interior: vacuum, wipe high-touch points with approved disinfectant, seat inspection, floor mats cleaned.
Exterior: wash, glass clean, tyre dressing where applicable.
Biohazard: PPE required, use biohazard kit, isolate vehicle, document incident, escalate to Safety if needed.
Parts Inventory and Reorder Policy
Minimum stock levels for critical parts; reorder triggers; receipt and quality check; logging batch numbers for traceability.

Templates and Quick Text
Fault Report Template (short)
"Plate: [XXX]; Fault: [description]; Severity: [A/B/C]; Location: [yard/road]; Odometer: [km]; Photos: [Y/N]; Suggested action: [tow/drive]; Reporter: [initials]."
Vendor Work Order Template
"WO#[ID]; Plate; Fault summary; Required parts; Authorised spend limit; Requested ETA; Contact person."
Cleaning Log Entry
"Date; Plate; Cleaner; Tasks completed (vacuum; wipe; disinfect; exterior wash); Sign-off."
Out-of-Service Notice (vehicle sticker text)
"OUT OF SERVICE — DO NOT OPERATE — Safety Critical Fault — Fleet Manager notified [Name/Date]."

Assessments
Written assessment 25 questions covering inspection items, severity coding, vendor workflow, and cleaning standards. Passing 90%.
Practical inspection test graded on checklist completeness, correct severity call, and evidence photos (3 required angles).
Vendor coordination exercise: trainee must create a correct work order and select appropriate vendor and approval route.
Cleaning practical: judged on cleanliness standard, correct chemical use, and PPE adherence.
Sample scoring rules
Inspection completeness: 40%
Correct severity and triage: 30%
Evidence and photo quality: 15%
Vendor/workorder accuracy: 10%
Safety and PPE adherence: 5%

KPIs and Reporting
Key KPIs to track post-training: vehicle availability %, MTTR, average downtime per incident, pre-trip checklist completion rate, overdue maintenance items, parts stockouts.
Reporting cadence: daily morning availability report; weekly maintenance summary; monthly vendor performance review.

Trainer Guidance and Implementation Notes
Trainer profile: senior fleet manager or lead mechanic with documented repair experience and vendor management background.
Equipment: basic diagnostics scanner, tyre gauge, fluid check kit, PPE, approved cleaning chemicals and dilution charts, biohazard kits.
First cohort: pair each trainee with a maintenance mentor for 2 weeks of ride-along/garage intake.
Integration: sync fault codes and reason codes with Dispatch and Safety to ensure cross-team visibility and automated alerts for Severity A events.
Versioning: store checklists as fillable spreadsheets to capture digital signatures and timestamps.

Written Assessment Fleet Maintenance
Format: 25 questions; multiple choice, short answer, and scenario decision items.
Passing: 90% or higher.
Multiple choice: Which item is a safety-critical defect requiring immediate removal from service?
A. Torn seat fabric B. Cracked brake disc C. Slight radio static D. Minor paint chip

A. Severity A B. Severity B C. Severity C D. Severity D
Short answer: List five mandatory checks on a daily pre-trip inspection.
Multiple choice: How should tyre pressure be recorded?
A. Pass/Fail only B. Numeric PSI/bar and noted deviation C. Worn or not worn only D. No record required
Short answer: Describe the immediate actions when a driver reports engine overheating en route.
Multiple choice: Which is required when submitting a fault report?
A. Plate only B. Plate and VIN only C. Plate, VIN, severity code, photos, reporter initials D. Verbal note to the mechanic
Short answer: Give three photo angles required for defect evidence.
Multiple choice: Who approves vendor spend above the agent-level threshold?
A. Any dispatcher B. Fleet Manager C. Cleaner lead D. Customer Service agent
Short answer: Define MTTR and why it matters.
Multiple choice: For a fuel leak observed during inspection, the correct immediate step is:
A. Continue operating B. Remove vehicle from service and notify Fleet Maintenance C. Clean it and continue D. Ignore and log later
Short answer: List the fields that must be included on a vendor work order.
Multiple choice: What is the correct storage policy for a biohazard-contaminated vehicle until cleaning?
A. Park in normal lot B. Isolate in designated bay and mark OUT OF SERVICE C. Leave on street for first responder D. Return to rotation
Short answer: Explain the reorder trigger concept for parts inventory and give one trigger example.
Multiple choice: How often should critical parts stock levels be reviewed?
A. Annually B. Monthly C. Daily D. Never
Short answer: Describe the documentation needed when a vehicle is towed to an external garage.
Multiple choice: Which PPE item is mandatory when handling a biohazard spill?
A. Nitrile gloves B. Sunglasses C. Wool gloves D. No PPE
Short answer: Provide a short triage rule to decide between tow or drive-to-garage.
Multiple choice: Which of the following is a cosmetic issue categorized Severity C?
A. Brake failure B. Deep tyre tread loss C. Minor seat tear D. Engine misfire
Short answer: List three KPIs fleet maintenance should report daily.
Multiple choice: When logging a defect photo, you must include:
A. Edited crop only B. Original file with metadata preserved C. Screenshot of the photo D. A hand-drawn sketch
Short answer: Outline the steps to process a warranty claim for a replaced part.
Multiple choice: What is the minimum acceptable documentation when receiving parts from a vendor?
A. Verbal confirmation B. Packing slip and quality check initials C. No documentation D. Driver note
Short answer: Explain how to mark a vehicle as available after repair and required verification.
Multiple choice: Which system action supports data hygiene for defect codes?
A. Allow free-text only B. Use predefined fault codes and dropdowns C. Delete old codes randomly D. Encourage inconsistent entries
Short answer: Describe three items to include in a post-repair quality check before returning a vehicle to service.

Written Assessment Answer Key Fleet Maintenance
B. Cracked brake disc
B. Severity B
Example checks: exterior lights; tyre condition and pressure; brake functionality; fluid levels (oil, coolant, brake); seatbelts and mirrors.
B. Numeric PSI/bar and noted deviation
Immediate actions: instruct driver to stop in a safe place, switch off engine if safe, assess for immediate hazards, notify Dispatch and Fleet, log location and request tow if overheating persists.
C. Plate, VIN, severity code, photos, reporter initials
Wide context shot; close-up of defect; plate/VIN shot (three angles).
B. Fleet Manager
MTTR means Mean Time To Repair and measures average time to restore a vehicle to service; it matters because it drives availability and cost.
B. Remove vehicle from service and notify Fleet Maintenance
Work order fields: WO ID; Plate and VIN; Fault description; Severity; Required parts; Authorised spend limit; Requested ETA; Contact person; Photos attached; Reporter initials.
B. Isolate in designated bay and mark OUT OF SERVICE
Reorder trigger: a predefined inventory level that when reached creates a reorder; example trigger: stock <= 2 units for a critical brake pad SKU.
B. Monthly
Documentation needed: tow receipt, tow company details, delivery time, receiving garage name, intake inspection notes, chain of custody for keys.
A. Nitrile gloves
Triage rule: If defect affects brakes, steering, fuel, or causes smoke/leak, tow; if only cosmetic or minor electrical issue and safe, drive-to-garage with logged mitigation.
C. Minor seat tear
Daily KPIs: vehicle availability percentage; number of vehicles out-of-service; count of Severity A incidents; average pre-trip checklist completion rate (any three).
B. Original file with metadata preserved
Warranty claim steps: retain replaced part and label with WO ID; collect invoice and vendor receipt; complete warranty claim form with photos and serial numbers; submit to OEM with purchase proof; track claim and log outcome.
B. Packing slip and quality check initials
Mark available steps: confirm repair completed and QA check passed; record repair WO ID in system; driver/test drive verification and log mileage; change status to Available and notify Dispatch.
B. Use predefined fault codes and dropdowns
Post-repair checks: verify repair items function (e.g., brakes tested); inspect affected area and adjacent systems; confirm no warning lights and perform short test drive; update maintenance log and attach photos.

Human Resources and Admin — Training Module
Overview
Objective: Deliver consistent, compliant onboarding and offboarding, accurate payroll and timekeeping, clear role expectations, and a scalable staff development pipeline that supports operational reliability.
Duration: 2–3 hours core workshop + role-specific onboarding workflows and 1-week supervised admin practice.
Passing criteria: ?90% on written assessment; correct completion of three simulated onboarding/offboarding flows without errors.
Materials needed: offer and onboarding templates, employee handbook, payroll/timekeeping system access, probation review templates, disciplinary checklist, training tracker spreadsheet.

Learning outcomes
Run a compliant, audit-ready onboarding and offboarding process with correct document capture and system provisioning.
Maintain accurate timekeeping and payroll inputs, manage leave requests, and process basic benefits administration.
Conduct probation reviews, performance documentation, and progressive disciplinary actions to policy.
Manage training enrollment, certification tracking, and maintain role descriptions and org charts.
Implement basic HR reporting (headcount, turnover, open roles, upcoming renewals) for leadership.

Lesson plan and activities
Hour 1 — HR fundamentals and compliance
Topics: required onboarding documents, ID verification, right-to-work checks (local rules), confidentiality agreements, basic labour compliance points.
Activity: review sample employee files and flag missing items.
Hour 2 — Onboarding, provisioning and first-week checklist
Topics: offer letter structure, role description, account provisioning checklist (IT, payroll, SSO groups), equipment issuance, induction schedule, training enrollment.
Activity: run a mock onboarding from offer acceptance to Day 5 checklist sign-off.
Hour 3 — Timekeeping, payroll inputs, and leave management
Topics: timesheet rules, overtime approval, payroll cutoffs, cash advances, statutory leave and company leave policies.
Activity: process sample timesheet anomalies and a leave request workflow.
Practical session — Offboarding, probation, and discipline
Topics: offboarding checklist (revoke access, equipment return, final pay), probation review template, progressive discipline steps and documentation.
Activity: simulate offboard and complete clearance form; conduct a mock probation review with scripted feedback.
Supervised admin practice — 1 week
Trainee performs actual onboarding/offboarding under mentor review, runs weekly HR report and maintains training tracker.

Core SOPs and Checklists
Onboarding Checklist (required fields)
Offer letter signed; ID and tax documents collected; emergency contact; bank details for payroll; role description; equipment issued record; IT access request submitted; welcome induction scheduled; probation goals documented.
Offboarding Checklist
Resignation/termination reason; revoke SSO and app access; collect company devices and keys; final payroll adjustments calculated; exit interview completed; update org chart and training tracker.
Payroll and Timekeeping SOP
Timesheet submission deadlines; approval hierarchy; overtime pre-approval rules; handling of cash advances and deductions; payroll sign-off and archival.
Probation Review SOP
30/60/90-day check-ins; measurable probation goals; documented feedback; pass, extend, or terminate decision process and approver matrix.
Discipline and Grievance SOP
Stepwise approach: verbal warning log; written warning with improvement plan; suspension; termination; grievance intake form and confidential handling; appeal routing.
Training and Certification Tracker SOP
Maintain central tracker with employee, role, training module, completion date, expiry (if applicable), and renewal reminders; integrate with payroll for certification-linked pay changes.
Records Retention and Confidentiality Policy
Storage rules, access controls, retention durations per document type, and secure disposal methods for sensitive records.

Templates and Quick Text
Offer Letter Template (key fields)
Role, start date, salary, probation period, benefits summary, equipment provided, reporting line, conditions (background checks), signature fields.
IT Provisioning Request Template
Employee name; role; systems required; SSO groups; hardware requested; manager approval; start date.
Probation Review Form (short)
Objectives, performance against metrics, behavioural feedback, required improvements, decision (pass/extend/terminate), signatures.
Exit interview script (one page)
Reason for leaving; highlights/improvements; feedback on onboarding and manager; equipment return confirmation.
Leave Request Acknowledgement Message
"Leave request for [Name] on [Dates] received and approved/declined. Manager: [Name]. Please ensure timesheet updated."

Assessments and Scoring
Written assessment: 20 questions across compliance, onboarding/offboarding steps, payroll rules, and probation/discipline procedures. Passing 90%.
Practical simulations: three scenarios (new hire onboarding, involuntary termination offboard, and probation extension decision). Trainee must complete all required forms and checklists without critical omissions.
Trainer review: spot-check of trainee’s HR files for accuracy and confidentiality handling.
Key HR metrics to track post-training:
Onboarding completion rate and time-to-productivity.
Offboarding completeness and access revocation time.
Payroll error rate and payroll reconciliation time.
Probation outcome distributions and time-to-decision.
Training completion and certification currency.

Trainer guidance and implementation notes
Trainer profile: HR Lead or Senior HR Generalist familiar with local labour law and payroll systems.
Systems integration: ensure IT and Finance integrations are documented for account provisioning and payroll handoffs.
First cohort: HR trainee shadows lead for 1 week of active onboarding and payroll cycles; monthly audit for first 3 months.
Confidentiality: use access-controlled folders and limit HR document access to authorized personnel; log accesses in a simple audit sheet.

IT App Support and Security — Training Module
Overview
Objective: Maintain stable customer and driver app experiences, resolve production incidents quickly, and enforce strong security and access controls that protect customer data and company assets.
Duration: 3–4 hours workshop + 2 supervised on-call shifts and one tabletop incident exercise.
Passing criteria: ?85% on written assessment; demonstrate correct triage and remediation in two supervised incidents; complete secure-access checklist without critical gaps.
Materials needed: access to support dashboard/ticketing system, staging environment, secure credential vault, incident runbook, sample logs, MFA devices, and role-based access control (RBAC) matrix.

Learning outcomes
Triage and resolve common app support issues (login, payments, GPS, push notifications) and escalate complex incidents appropriately.
Follow incident response runbook: evidence collection, impact assessment, stakeholder notification, rollback or mitigation, post-incident report.
Apply and audit basic application and device security hygiene: MFA, least-privilege access, secure onboarding/offboarding, and device management policies.
Use secure practices for logs, PII handling, bug reporting, and vulnerability disclosure.
Coordinate with Product, Security, and Ops for staged releases, hotfixes, and change control.

Hourly lesson plan and activities
Hour 1 — Role, KPIs, and system orientation
Topics: Support SLAs (first response, resolution times), mean time to acknowledge (MTTA), mean time to resolve (MTTR), priority mapping (P0–P3) for tech incidents, support dashboard overview.
Activities: Dashboard walkthrough; sample tickets review; KPI baseline exercise.
Hour 2 — Common issue triage and troubleshooting playbook
Topics: Authentication failures, payment processing errors, GPS/telemetry failures, notification delivery failures, app crashes and logs, session/token troubleshooting.
Activities: Live triage drills in staging; reproduce bug from logs; create bug report with steps-to-reproduce, impact, and severity.
Hour 3 — Incident response, logging, and communications
Topics: Evidence collection (logs, stack traces, request IDs), incident command roles for tech incidents, rollback vs. patch decisions, internal and external communications templates, post-incident reports.
Activities: Tabletop exercise simulating a P1 payment gateway outage; prepare incident timeline and communications.
Hour 4 — Security hygiene, access controls, and app hardening
Topics: RBAC and least-privilege; MFA enforcement; device management (MDM/EMM basics); secure storage of secrets (vault usage), HTTPS/TLS basics, OAuth flows and token lifetimes, basics of certificate pinning and HSTS; dependency and library patching policy.
Activities: Audit sample accounts for excessive privileges; configure MFA in lab; inspect app network calls for insecure endpoints.
On-call supervised shifts and one escalation tabletop
Two supervised shifts where trainees handle live low-to-medium incidents with mentor oversight; one full tabletop covering P0 data breach with cross-functional participation.

Core SOPs and Checklists
Support Start-of-Shift Checklist
Confirm dashboard access; verify alerting integrations; review active high-priority incidents; check recent deploys and feature flags; ensure access to vault and escalation contacts.
Ticket Triage SOP (Tech)
Gather: Trip/Request ID, device logs, app version, OS, network type, screenshots, timestamps, request ID/trace ID; reproduce in staging if possible; classify severity and assign owner.
Incident Response Runbook (Tech P0/P1)
Immediate steps: acknowledge incident; collect request/trace IDs and logs; capture scope (users impacted, geos); activate Incident Commander if P0/P1; notify leadership and CS/Dispatch with templated messages; apply mitigation (feature flag rollback, circuit breaker) where safe; maintain timeline; begin postmortem within 48 hours.
Evidence and Logging Standard
Preserve raw logs; never include PII in shared notes; always reference trace/request IDs; store logs in central, access-controlled system; redaction policy for PII in exported logs.
Secure Onboarding/Offboarding SOP (Access control)
Onboarding: request authorisation, assign role-based groups, enable MFA, create vault credentials, minimal permissions for first 30 days.
Offboarding: revoke access to systems and vaults, recover company devices, rotate affected secrets, confirm removal from groups and SSO, log actions with timestamp and approver.
Release and Change Control SOP
Feature flags for progressive rollout; pre-deploy smoke tests; rollback plan required for production changes; emergency hotfix approval flow with documentation and post-release verification.
Vulnerability Reporting and Patch Management
Track vulnerabilities in central board; apply critical patches within defined windows (critical: 72 hours, high: 2 weeks); maintain dependency inventory and run regular SCA (software composition analysis).

Templates and Scripts
Support Triage Template (ticket description)
"Issue summary; Affected users/percent; Steps to reproduce; Device OS and app version; Request/Trace IDs; Initial logs attached; Proposed immediate mitigation."
Incident Initial Notify (internal)
"TECH ALERT INC-T[ID] Severity [P0/P1]; Impact: [scope]; Immediate action: [rollback/mitigation]; Commander: [name]; ETA next update: [time]."
Customer/Driver-facing outage message (CS/Dispatch template)
"We’re aware of an issue affecting [login/payments/booking] and are working on a fix. We’ll update in [SLA] and apologise for the disruption."
Access Request/Approval Template
"Requestor; Role needed; Systems required; Business justification; Manager approval; Duration (if temporary)."
Post-Incident Report Outline
Summary; Timeline; Root cause analysis; Impact metrics (users, revenue, trips affected); Remediation steps; Action items and owners; Lessons learned; Preventive measures.

Assessments
Written assessment (20–25 questions) covering triage, runbook steps, evidence collection, and basic security controls. Passing 85%.
Practical: two live incident resolutions under mentor with scoring on triage accuracy, log collection, mitigation choice, and communication clarity.
Security audit practical: trainee performs a 15-minute RBAC and MFA audit on sample accounts and documents corrective actions.
Scoring emphasis
Correct severity and triage decisions: highest weight.
Evidence completeness (trace IDs, logs, app versions): high weight.
Communication clarity and timing to stakeholders: medium weight.
Security checklist completeness during audit: medium weight.

Tools, Dashboards, and Data Hygiene
Required tool access: support ticketing system, centralized log storage (ELK/Graylog/Splunk), monitoring/alerting dashboard, secret vault, SSO admin console, deployment/release dashboard, and staging environment.
Data hygiene rules: never paste raw PII in public channels; redact or reference tokenized IDs; attach evidence to ticket with access control; maintain retention policy compliance for logs and backups.
Monitoring cadence: daily health check of API latency, error rates, and payment gateway success rates; weekly dependency vulnerability scan.

Trainer Guidance and Implementation Notes
Trainer profile: Senior SRE, Lead Engineer, or Security Lead with production incident experience and familiarity with company stack.
First cohort: pair trainees with on-call mentors for 2–4 weeks, run mock incidents weekly for first month, and require sign-off before independent on-call duty.
On-call rotation: document escalation contacts and run regular handover notes; enforce no single-person knowledge silos by rotating duties.
Security partnership: integrate Security reviews into release process and maintain an internal vulnerability disclosure process and communication flow for external reports.

Sample Incident Runbook Payment Gateway Outage P1
Purpose
Rapid, coordinated response to a production payment gateway outage impacting customer transactions to restore payment processing, reduce revenue loss, and communicate clearly to stakeholders.
Severity and Criteria
Severity: P1 — payments failing for significant percentage of transactions or high-value payments, partial or total service degradation.
Trigger examples: payment API HTTP 5xx rate > 10% for 10+ minutes; payment provider returning systematic errors; synthetic transaction failures across regions.
Initial Response (first 0–10 minutes)
Acknowledge and create incident ticket with prefix INC-T and assign P1 severity.
Assign Incident Commander and declare incident.
Gather initial scope: error rates, affected endpoints, region, percentage of failed requests, recent deploys or config changes.
Notify stakeholders immediately: Customer Service Lead, Ops Lead, Finance Lead, Product Lead, and on-call Engineering and SRE. Use templated internal notify message.
Enable monitoring and capture traces: enable extended logging, preserve raw traces and request IDs for failed transactions.

Triage and Containment (10–30 minutes)
Identify root vector: recent deploy, third-party provider degradation, certificate expiry, rate-limiting or credential rotation.
Containment options (choose lowest-risk first): 
Rollback recent deploy or config change via feature flag.
Switch to payment provider failover endpoint if configured.
Apply temporary circuit breaker to degrade non-critical payment paths while preserving essential flows.
Mitigate customer impact: enable temporary manual payment acceptance where safe, or route to alternate provider. Document fallback clearly.
Communication Plan
Internal updates: every 15 minutes until stable, then every 30 minutes. Include incident ID, impact summary, actions taken, and ETA.
Customer-facing messaging: CS Lead sends templated message to affected customers: brief apology, scope of impact, expected next update, suggested workaround if any.
Finance notification: immediate alert for high-value transactions and reconciliation needs.
Resolution and Recovery (30–90 minutes)
Execute validated mitigation (rollback, failover, or config change).
Run synthetic transactions and monitor success rate until stable threshold reached.
Monitor for regressions for 60–120 minutes; keep extended logging on for one full business cycle if needed.
Close incident only after sustained success (e.g., <1% failure rate over 30 minutes) and stakeholder agreement.
Post-Incident Actions
Post-incident review within 48 hours: timeline, root cause, detection gap, remediation, and permanent fixes.
Action items assigned with owners and due dates (patch, improved monitoring, failover automation).
Customer remediation plan if financial impact occurred: refunds, manual settlement, or credits coordinated with Finance and CS.
Update runbooks and playbooks with lessons learned and add new synthetic checks if gap exposed.
Roles and Responsibilities
Incident Commander: overall decision authority and communications coordinator.
SRE Lead: triage root cause, run mitigations, supervise monitoring.
Engineering Owner: implement and validate code fixes or rollback.
Customer Service Lead: customer messaging and ticket templating.
Finance Lead: identify high-value transaction impacts and reconciliation needs.
Security/Compliance: advise if incident involves compromised credentials or data exposure.
Tools and Artifacts
Central ticketing system with incident template.
Monitoring dashboards (payment success rate, latency, error rates).
Centralized logs and trace storage with preserved request IDs.
Feature flag control dashboard and failover configuration.
Secure communication channels for incident team.

RBAC and MFA 15-Minute Audit Checklist
Prerequisite: auditor has read-only access to user and group listings, SSO admin console, and secret vault access logs.
Confirm admin accounts
List all accounts in admin or owner groups.
Flag any personal email addresses or generic shared accounts.
Check MFA enforcement
Verify MFA policy status for all admin and privileged roles.
Flag any privileged account without MFA or with deprecated MFA methods.
Scan for excessive privileges
Identify users with multiple high-level roles across systems.
Flag service accounts assigned human-level privileges.
Review active service accounts
List service accounts and confirm least-privilege usage.
Flag service accounts with long-lived keys or without expiry.
Validate temporary access
Check open temporary access tickets and their expiry dates.
Flag any temporary access without approver or without end date.
Secret and credential checks
Confirm rotation schedule for high-risk secrets and check vault logs for recent rotations.
Flag any shared credentials or secrets stored outside vault.
Onboarding and offboarding spot check
Pick 3 recently onboarded and 3 offboarded users and confirm access was provisioned and revoked per policy.
Flag mismatches or lingering access.
Audit logging presence
Verify audit logging is enabled for SSO and vault access.
Confirm last successful log entries and identify gaps.
Report summary
Create a one-page list of flagged items with recommended actions and owners.
Prioritize critical items: no MFA on privileged accounts, shared admin accounts, long-lived secrets.
Completion note: save checklist results to a secure ticket and assign remediation owners with target dates.



Marketing and Sales — Training Module
Overview
Objective: Grow demand reliably through consistent brand messaging, measurable campaigns, repeatable B2B outreach, and scalable referral/loyalty mechanics that feed bookings and partnerships.
Duration: 3 hours workshop + 4 hours tactical practicum (campaign build + outreach roleplay).
Passing criteria: ?85% on written assessment; produce one ready-to-run campaign brief and one vetted outreach sequence during practicum.
Materials needed: brand guidelines, creative assets, CRM/marketing automation access, campaign brief template, partner outreach scripts, reporting dashboard.

Learning outcomes
Communicate Shuttle Plus brand voice and visual standards consistently across channels.
Build measurable marketing campaigns from brief to launch with clear KPIs and test plans.
Run reproducible B2B outreach and partnership meetings with qualifying scripts and contracting checkpoints.
Operate referral and loyalty programs with fraud controls and tracking.
Interpret core marketing analytics (CAC, conversion funnel, LTV proxy) and convert insights into tactical optimizations.

Hourly lesson plan and activities
Hour 1 — Brand and positioning
Topics: brand voice do/don’t, logo and asset usage, photography style, customer personas, elevator pitch.
Activity: transform three sample social posts to brand-compliant versions; side-by-side critique.
Hour 2 — Campaign planning and measurement
Topics: campaign brief structure; audience segmentation; channel mix; budget allocation; A/B test plan; KPI cascade (impressions ? clicks ? conversions ? bookings).
Activity: complete a campaign brief for a “airport transfer promo” including primary KPI and 2 test hypotheses.
Hour 3 — Execution playbooks and partner outreach
Topics: creative production checklist; landing page and tracking setup; UTM standards; referral program mechanics; partnership qualification and contract triggers.
Activity: roleplay B2B outreach call and draft an outreach email sequence for hotels and travel agents.
Practicum — Campaign build + outreach
Tasks: produce campaign creative brief, draft 3-run ad copy variants, build 3-step email outreach for a target partner, set tracking KPIs and reporting dashboard. Trainer reviews and signs off.

Core SOPs and checklists
Campaign Brief Template (required fields)
Objective; target personas; primary KPI; offer; creative assets required; channels; budget; flight dates; tracking & conversions; test plan; success criteria; owner; launch checklist.
Creative Production Checklist
Ad sizes/resolutions; copy length variants; CTA consistency; brand colors & logo placement; localization needs; image alt text; approval sign-offs and delivery formats.
Landing Page and Tracking SOP
Build page with unique campaign URL; embed booking widget with conversion event; add UTM parameters; verify analytics goals; QA pixel and server-side event flows.
Paid Media Launch Checklist
Campaign naming convention; audience segments; bids & budgets; creative variants; daily monitoring threshold alerts; attribution window and conversion window settings.
Referral Program SOP
Eligibility rules; reward mechanics (credit vs. cash); fraud prevention rules (one reward per verified trip; payment verification); tracking and expiry; finance reconciliation cadence.
B2B Partnership Workflow
Partner qualification form; outreach sequence and CRM tagging; mutual pilot terms (duration, volume commitments); contract templates with SLAs and payment terms; onboarding checklist for partner accounts.
Brand Response and Crisis SOP for Marketing
Rapid response template; legal review trigger; social media takedown and escalation paths; incident comms owner.

Templates and scripts (copy-ready)
Campaign brief one-liner
"Drive 1,000 new airport bookings in Q1 through targeted hotel partnerships and paid search with a CAC target ? $12."
Example paid ad copy (3 variants)
“Arrive relaxed. Book Shuttle Plus airport transfer — reliable service, on-time guaranteed. Book now.”
“Flight tonight? Reserve Shuttle Plus for stress-free airport transfers. Use code AIR10 for 10% off.”
“Trusted by business travellers — Shuttle Plus: door-to-door airport transfers. Fast booking, fixed price.”
Partner outreach email sequence (3 steps)
Intro email: short pitch, value to partner (commission, guest convenience), ask for 15-min intro.
Follow-up: share one-pager, propose pilot terms, suggest calendar slot.
Close: success examples, contract template link, ask for signature or next steps.
Referral message for customers
"Refer a friend: give 10% off their first ride, get 10% credit after their completed trip. Code: REFER10."
B2B qualification script (phone)
Discovery: guest volume per month; typical arrival times; current transfer arrangements; interest in pilot (yes/no), decision-maker and contract timeline.

Assessments and practical deliverables
Written assessment: 20 questions on brand, campaign measurement, tracking, referral rules, and partnership contracts. Passing 85%.
Practical deliverable: each trainee must produce one campaign brief, 3 ad copy variants, landing page tracking checklist, and a 3-step partner outreach sequence. Trainer must approve.
Roleplay scoring: B2B call assessed for qualification accuracy, persuasive value props, objection handling, and next-step agreement.
Sample success metrics for trainee evaluation:
Campaign brief completeness: 40%
Tracking and measurement setup correctness: 30%
Creative and copy quality: 20%
Outreach roleplay (conversion to pilot): 10%

Analytics, dashboards, and KPIs
Core KPIs to instrument per campaign: Impressions; Click-Through Rate (CTR); Conversion Rate (booking/landing); Cost per Acquisition (CPA); Return on Ad Spend (ROAS) proxy; Booking retention and repeat rate from campaign cohort.
Reporting cadence: campaign daily monitoring for first 72 hours, weekly performance summary, monthly attribution review.
Attribution notes: use first-click vs. last-click as needed, maintain UTM discipline and server-side booking attribution to reduce mismatch.

Fraud controls and compliance
Referral fraud detection: require verified completed trip before honoring reward; tie referral to unique booking ID and phone verification; daily automated checks for duplicate referrers or suspicious patterns.
Promotion abuse controls: single-use coupon codes per account; expiration dates; per-account caps; manual review thresholds for large claims.
Data privacy: marketing must use hashed identifiers for lookalike audiences; do not upload PII to ad platforms without consent; follow local data retention and opt-out rules.

Trainer guidance and rollout notes
Trainer profile: Head of Marketing or senior marketer with campaign execution and partnership experience.
First cohort: pair with Sales mentor for partner calls; run two live pilot outreach sequences and one full small-budget paid campaign as hands-on exercise.
Creative approvals: maintain a single source of truth for brand assets; require legal review for any customer-facing compensation or liability language.
Version control: campaign briefs and creative assets versioned with changelog for audits.

Sample Campaign Brief Airport Transfer Promo
Campaign name: Airport Transfer Promo Q4 Launch
Objective: Acquire 1,000 new airport bookings in 60 days from targeted hotel partnerships and paid search with CAC ? USD 12.
Primary KPI: Bookings from campaign landing page.
Secondary KPIs: CAC, Conversion Rate, Revenue per booking, Repeat booking rate within 30 days.
Target audience: Business travelers aged 25–55; hotel guests at partnered properties; passengers with flights arriving between 20:00–06:00.
Offer: 10% off first booking with code AIR10; partner commission 10% per completed transfer.
Channels: Paid search (branded and non-branded), hotel email newsletter placement, partner landing page widgets, retargeting social.
Budget and timing: USD 6,000 test budget for 14-day pilot, scale if CAC ? 12; launch date 2025-11-10; test end 2025-11-24.
Creative requirements: Three headline variants, two hero images, 300x250 and mobile banner sizes, one 30s partner testimonial video.
Offer mechanics and fraud controls: Single-use promo per account; promo requires booking completion and ride confirmation; finance reconciles partner commissions weekly.
Landing page URL and UTM plan: base URL https://book.shuttleplus.com/airport-promo
Primary paid search creative A: https://book.shuttleplus.com/airport-promo?utm_source=google&utm_medium=cpc&utm_campaign=airport_promo_q4&utm_content=search_ad_A
Primary paid search creative B: https://book.shuttleplus.com/airport-promo?utm_source=google&utm_medium=cpc&utm_campaign=airport_promo_q4&utm_content=search_ad_B
Partner hotel email link: https://book.shuttleplus.com/airport-promo?utm_source=hotel_partner&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=airport_promo_q4&utm_content=hotelX_email1
Retargeting social: https://book.shuttleplus.com/airport-promo?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=rtg&utm_campaign=airport_promo_q4&utm_content=rtg_banner1
Tracking and instrumentation: Booking widget records full UTM set and promo code; server-side attribution stores UTM with booking ID; analytics goal triggered on booking confirmation page and server-side booking event.
Test hypotheses: H1 urgent CTA increases conversion; H2 partner landing widget with pre-filled hotel name increases conversion among hotel guests by 12%.
QA checklist before launch: UTM links validated; booking widget captures UTM and promo code; pixel and server-side events verified; creatives approved and responsive; budget pacing alerts configured.
Reporting cadence: Live dashboard updates hourly for spend and clicks; daily aggregated performance at 09:00 local; stakeholder review at day 7 for scale decision.
Roles and owners: Campaign owner Marketing Lead; Paid media lead; Partner success owner; Analytics owner.
Success criteria for scale: Pilot achieves ?1,000 bookings projected at scale with CAC ? USD 12 and conversion rate ?3.5% on landing page.


UTM Examples and Best Practices
UTM parameter usage rules: use lowercase; no spaces; consistent separators; map utm_medium to channel taxonomy; reserve utm_campaign for canonical campaign name; use utm_content for creative variant or ad ID.
Example canonical UTM pattern: ?utm_source=[platform]&utm_medium=[channel]&utm_campaign=[campaign_name]&utm_content=[creative_variant]&utm_term=[keyword]
Example values for this campaign: 
utm_source=google utm_medium=cpc utm_campaign=airport_promo_q4 utm_content=search_ad_A utm_term=airport+transfer
utm_source=hotel_partner utm_medium=email utm_campaign=airport_promo_q4 utm_content=hotelX_email1
utm_source=facebook utm_medium=rtg utm_campaign=airport_promo_q4 utm_content=rtg_banner1

Safety Security and Incident Response (Training Module)
Overview
Objective: Protect passengers, staff, and assets while ensuring rapid, lawful incident response and high-integrity evidence preservation.
Duration: 4 hours classroom plus 2 scenario drills and ongoing quarterly drills.
Passing criteria: ?90% on written assessment; successful completion of two timed scenario drills with correct escalation, evidence handling, and communication.
Materials needed: Incident command cards, evidence kits, demo video for evidence capture, sample incident forms, radio or secure comms simulator, ride-along access for field drills.

Learning Outcomes
Identify and classify incidents by severity and apply correct P0–P3 response rules.
Secure scenes and preserve physical and digital evidence with a documented chain of custody.
Coordinate with Dispatch, Fleet, Customer Service, and external authorities using standard protocols.
Execute incident command roles until handed over to authorities or Ops Lead.
Conduct after-action reporting and contribute to incident reviews and preventive actions.

Hourly Lesson Plan and Activities
Hour 1 Incident Basics and Triage
Topics: Definitions of incident types; P0–P3 criteria; immediate safety priorities; legal obligations for evidence and reporting.
Activity: Short quiz and discussion of recent real incidents and root causes.
Hour 2 Scene Security and Evidence Preservation
Topics: Secure perimeter, safe evidence collection sequencing, digital evidence capture, device handling, photo/video standards.
Activity: Hands-on evidence capture exercise with staged damage and timestamp verification.
Hour 3 Communication Protocols and Interagency Coordination
Topics: Incident command roles and responsibilities; escalation matrix; formal language for law enforcement and airport authorities; preserving chain of custody during transfers.
Activity: Roleplay Dispatcher Safety handoff and scripted call to law enforcement or airport operations.
Hour 4 Medical Response Basics and Crisis De-escalation
Topics: Life-safety priorities; CPR and first aid roles for trained personnel; behavioral de-escalation techniques for aggressive passengers.
Activity: Scenario practice with mannequin or trained actor and de-escalation roleplay.
Scenario Drills Two timed drills covering P0 medical emergency and P1 collision with evidence capture and coordination. Debrief after each drill with action log review.

Core SOPs and Checklists
Incident Initial Response Checklist
Ensure personal and public safety; call emergency services if needed; notify Dispatch and Safety Lead; secure scene; begin evidence log; collect witness details.
Scene Security SOP
Establish safe perimeter; control witnesses and bystanders; preserve vehicle positions and hazard markers; prevent evidence contamination.
Evidence Capture Standard
Sequence: wide scene overview; context shots; close-ups of damage; plate and VIN; interior scene; timestamped video walkthrough; collect device metadata intact.
Use device metadata, record device ID used for capture, and immediately upload to central ticket without editing.
Chain of Custody Form
Fields: incident ID; evidence description; collector name; collection time; device UID; transfer log with recipient signature and time.
Medical Response SOP for Drivers and Staff
If trained perform within scope; ensure airway breathing circulation; call emergency services immediately for P0; position patient safely; document actions and times.
De-escalation and Restraint Policy
Non-physical de-escalation first; verbal scripts for calming; only use physical restraint if trained and only to prevent imminent harm; escalate to law enforcement if threat persists.
Interaction with Authorities SOP
Provide factual summary; hand over evidence with chain of custody form; do not speculate or admit liability; designate single point of contact for follow-up.
After-Action Review SOP
Timeline: submit initial incident report within 30 minutes; complete full incident package within 72 hours; conduct multidisciplinary review within 7 days with corrective actions logged.

Templates and Scripts
Immediate Notify to Dispatch and Ops
"INCIDENT ALERT INC-[ID] Severity [P0/P1]; Location [lat,long or landmark]; Brief: [one-line]; Immediate action: [medical/tow/police]."
Law Enforcement Handoff Script
"This is Shuttle Plus Safety. We have INC-[ID]. Summary: [time, location, injuries Y/N, vehicle plate]. Evidence attached and chain of custody form ready."
Witness Intake Form Short Script
"Please state your full name, contact phone, and a short description of what you saw. We will record this in the incident file."
Chain of Custody Label Example
"INC-[ID] Evidence [type] Collected by [initials] at [ISO-8601 time]."
Staff Safety Communication Template
"STAFF ALERT: Incident INC-[ID] at [Location]. Avoid area until cleared. Safety Lead en route."

Assessment and Evaluation
Written assessment 30 questions covering triage, evidence standards, legal boundaries, and communication protocols. Passing 90%.
Practical assessment two scenario drills evaluated on: safety decisions, correct severity classification, evidence integrity, communication clarity, and timeliness.
Chain of custody audit sample for each trainee during drill to ensure correct documentation and transfers.
Scoring rubric highlights
Safety decisions correct and immediate: weighted highest.
Evidence capture standard met: angle, metadata, upload integrity.
Communication with authorities and internal teams: accuracy and brevity.
Documentation completeness and timeliness: all fields correct within 15 minutes of incident.

Trainer Guidance and Implementation Notes
Trainer profile: Safety Lead or Ops Lead with incident management experience and at least one formal incident response certification.
Equipment: evidence kits per vehicle including gloves, evidence bags, labels, disposable camera or verified mobile capture device, chain of custody forms, scene markers, PPE.
First cohort: pair trainees with an experienced Safety Mentor for three real-world shadow shifts and supervised incident logging.
Quarterly drills: mandatory for all drivers and Ops staff with cross-department participation and recorded after-action reviews.
Legal coordination: establish a named legal contact for incident review and retention policy alignment.

Scenario Drill 1 Script P0 Medical Emergency with Multiple Passengers
Overview
Scenario summary Staff on a city route receives a report from Driver that a passenger has collapsed and is unresponsive, breathing irregularly. Vehicle is stopped on a roadside near a busy intersection with bystanders present.
Objectives
Demonstrate life-safety prioritization, correct P0 escalation, scene security, evidence and witness management, and interagency coordination.
Setup
Role players Driver, Unresponsive Passenger actor, Bystanders, Dispatch trainee, Safety Lead trainer. Equipment mannequin or actor, first aid kit, radio or secure comms, evidence kit, chain of custody forms, scene markers.
Timeline and Injects
T0 Driver calls Dispatch reporting unresponsive passenger and requesting instruction.
T+1 minute Bystanders crowd the scene; one bystander has a mobile video recording.
T+3 minutes Security or police ETA unknown in simulation; ambulance on route simulated T+7.
T+10 minutes Media inquiry simulated to test communication.
Expected Actions and Decision Points
Ensure safety Take immediate action to ensure driver and other passengers are safe. Move bystanders back and create a safe perimeter using scene markers while ensuring the patient is not moved unless immediate danger exists.
Life-Safety Steps If trained, dispatch instructs driver to check airway breathing circulation and commence CPR if indicated. Call emergency services immediately. If untrained instruct driver to follow dispatcher instructions and not to perform risky interventions.
P0 Escalation Tag incident as P0 and notify Safety Lead and Ops Lead immediately. Open incident ticket and begin evidence log at earliest safe moment.
Witness Management Ask bystanders for names and contact details, politely request that video files be preserved and uploaded to the incident ticket without editing, and record the uploader initials.
Evidence Capture Take photos of scene context after life-safety steps are concluded; capture vehicle position, passenger location, and any hazards. Record device UID used for capture and do not edit files.
Interagency Coordination Provide factual concise briefing to emergency services and to airport or local security if on controlled property. Designate a single Safety Lead as point of contact for responding authorities.
Media Handling Defer media inquiries to Safety Lead or PR. Do not disclose medical details beyond confirmation that emergency services responded and the incident is under investigation.
