Scenario Drill 2 Script P1 Vehicle Collision with Multiple Vehicles No Fatalities
Overview
Scenario summary Driver reports a multi-vehicle collision on an arterial road near the airport. One vehicle is disabled, minor visible passenger injuries, leaking fluids observed. Multiple drivers and passengers involved.
Objectives
Demonstrate correct P1 classification, scene preservation for accident reconstruction, coordination with Fleet and Dispatch, safe evidence capture around potential hazards, chain of custody for collected items, and timely after-action reporting.
Setup
Role players Drivers A and B, passengers, small fuel leak indicator, cones, evidence kit, camera, chain of custody forms, radio or secure comms, tow truck on-call simulated.

Timeline and Injects
T0 Driver reports collision and requests guidance.
T+2 minutes Another vehicle reports minor injury to a passenger complaining of neck pain.
T+5 minutes Fluid leak observed; potential environmental hazard declared.
T+10 minutes Tow truck arrival simulated for disabled vehicle.
Expected Actions and Decision Points
Safety and Scene Control Confirm immediate safety and request emergency services for injuries where required. Set up hazard markers and request drivers to switch off ignition where safe.
P1 Classification and Notifications Tag incident as P1 and notify Fleet Maintenance, Safety Lead, and Dispatch Supervisor. Open incident ticket and note all initial actions.
Evidence Capture Sequence Photograph full scene from multiple vantage points including vehicle positions, skid marks, damage areas, license plates, VIN where visible, and any debris. Capture short timestamped video walkthrough.
Hazard Mitigation Document fluid leak and request environmental or HazMat support if applicable. Keep bystanders clear and log PPE usage by responders.
Witness Statements Collect witness contact details and brief statements. Record who collected each statement and their device UID.
Vehicle Removal and Tow Document tow truck arrival and chain of custody for vehicle keys, vehicle storage location and responsible facility. Ensure transfer signature on chain of custody form.
After-Action Reporting Complete full incident package within 72 hours including photos, witness statements, evidence logs, tow receipts, and recommended corrective actions.
Scoring Sheet Safety Drill 2
CriteriaWeightScore 1–5NotesImmediate safety and hazard containment20%Single line noteCorrect P1 classification and stakeholder notification20%Single line noteEvidence capture completeness and metadata integrity20%Single line noteWitness statement collection and documentation15%Single line noteHazard reporting and environmental mitigation actions15%Single line noteTimeliness of opening incident ticket and initial logs10%Single line notePassing Criteria
Weighted score ?90% and no critical failures on hazard containment or evidence preservation.
Debrief Points
Verify chain of custody entries and witness statements completeness; check photo and video metadata; review timeliness of Fleet and Dispatch notifications; identify training gaps for hazard PPE or tow coordination.

Implementation Notes and Deliverables
Add these files to module folder as IncidentAssessment — Safety v1.0.pdf, DrillScript P0 Medical.docx, DrillScript P1 Collision.docx, SafetyDrill ScoringSheets.xlsx, and ChainOfCustody Formfillable.pdf.
Recommended drill cadence: initial certification for Safety staff, quarterly cross-department drills with Dispatch and Drivers, annual full-scale scenario with external agencies.
Trainer guidance: require Safety Lead sign-off for trainee certification; keep drill records and remedial action logs for audit.



Training Modules
Below are ready-to-use training module outlines for every Shuttle Plus department. 
Drivers
Objective: Safe, punctual, consistent customer experience and complete incident evidence.
Duration: 4 hours classroom + 2 ride-alongs.
Core contents: Expectations & KPIs; Vehicle pre-trip checklist; Defensive driving & urban airport routing; Passenger handling and accessibility; Fare, payments, tipping policy; Phone and in-vehicle device use policy; Incident reporting workflow; Evidence capture standards (photos, timestamps, forms); De-escalation and customer conflict; Emergency procedures.
Materials: Driver handbook PDF; printable vehicle checklist; incident report template (fillable); short video demos.
Assessment: Ride-along checklist score; scored roleplay on conflict de-escalation; written quiz on SOPs.
Follow-up: 30-day performance review; monthly safety briefings; quarterly refresher.
Dispatch and Operations Control
Objective: Efficient booking fulfillment, real-time problem triage, and on-time performance.
Duration: 6 hours classroom + shift shadowing.
Core contents: Dispatch flowchart; Priority triage rules; Shift handover checklist; Dynamic routing basics; Surge and traffic contingency plans; Communication templates to drivers/customers; Incident escalation matrix; Data entry standards and audit checks.
Materials: Dispatch SOP sheet; escalation contact list; screen walkthroughs of dashboard and app.
Assessment: Mock shift exercise handling simultaneous incidents; accuracy audit on sample bookings.
Customer Service (Contact Center and Frontline)
Objective: Consistent brand voice, fast resolution, net promoter improvement.
Duration: 3 hours classroom + call/chat roleplay sessions.
Core contents: Brand voice and scripts; Standard responses and templated replies; Refunds and policy exceptions matrix; Complaint intake and escalation; Evidence request checklist; SLA targets; Use of CRM and logging standards.
Materials: Script cheat-sheet; sample email/chat templates; soft-skills roleplay guide.
Assessment: Mystery-call evaluation; scored transcript reviews.
Fleet Maintenance and Cleaning
Objective: Reliable, compliant fleet ready for service every shift.
Duration: 4 hours classroom + hands-on inspection.
Core contents: Daily/weekly maintenance schedules; Pre- and post-trip inspection forms; Cleaning and PPE standards for vehicles; Minor troubleshooting checklist; Fueling and charging SOPs; Fault reporting and downtime logging; Vendor/garage coordination process.
Materials: Maintenance checklist (fillable); SOP for defect severity and downtime thresholds.
Assessment: Practical inspection test; logging accuracy audit.
Safety, Security, and Incident Response
Objective: Minimize risk to passengers, staff, and assets while preserving evidence and legal compliance.
Duration: 3–5 hours including scenario drills.
Core contents: Risk assessment basics; PPE and health protocols; Incident command roles; Evidence preservation and chain of custody; Reporting timeline and forms; Collaboration with law enforcement and airport authorities; CPR/first aid basics if needed.
Materials: Incident command card; evidence checklist; emergency contacts list.
Assessment: Scenario drill with timed evidence capture and escalation.
Cleaning and Hygiene (Customer-Facing)
Objective: High cleanliness standards that reinforce trust and brand.
Duration: 2 hours practical.
Core contents: Sanitation standards per vehicle zone; Approved cleaning agents and dilution ratios; Frequency schedule; Lost-and-found handling; Waste disposal; Documentation and sign-off.
Materials: Cleaning SOP; visual checklist for drivers/cleaning team.
Assessment: Spot checks and sign-off audits.

Human Resources and Admin
Objective: Efficient onboarding, labor compliance, and staff development pipeline.
Duration: 2–3 hours onboarding module.
Core contents: Hiring checklist; role descriptions and probation goals; payroll and timesheet procedures; leave and benefits process; disciplinary steps; training pathways and certification tracking.
Materials: Onboarding packet; probation review template; training tracker spreadsheet.
Assessment: Completion of onboarding checklist and required documents.
Marketing and Sales
Objective: Consistent brand messaging and measurable demand generation.
Duration: 3 hours workshop + tactical playbook.
Core contents: Brand guidelines and voice; Social media calendar process; Customer referral and loyalty programs; Partnerships and B2B outreach script; Performance metrics and campaign reporting.
Materials: Brand token file; campaign brief template; outreach email sequences.
Assessment: Review of a sample campaign plan and creative brief.
Finance and Revenue Control
Objective: Accurate transaction capture, reconciliation, and revenue protection.
Duration: 2–3 hours.
Core contents: Fare structure and adjustments; Payment reconciliation procedure; Refund and chargeback handling; Daily cash-out and audit logs; KPI dashboards for revenue.
Materials: Reconciliation template; refund approval matrix.
Assessment: Reconciliation exercise and sample exception handling.
IT, App Support, and Security
Objective: Stable app experience, secure data handling, and fast incident resolution.
Duration: 3–4 hours technical workshop.
Core contents: User support triage matrix; App troubleshooting steps; Logging and bug reporting template; Basic security hygiene for staff; Access control and device management; Backup and recovery basics.
Materials: Troubleshooting checklist; error-report template; access provisioning form.
Assessment: Live troubleshooting drill and simulated incident ticket.

Drivers module — Snapshot
Objective: Safe, punctual service with consistent brand experience and complete incident evidence capture.
Duration: 4 hours classroom + 2 ride-alongs.
Passing criteria: ?85% on written quiz; satisfactory ride-along scores on safety, customer handling, and evidence standards.
Lesson plan (hourly breakdown)
Hour 1 — Company standards, KPIs, and expectations; brand voice for drivers; payments and tipping policy.
Hour 2 — Vehicle pre-trip inspection (walkthrough), defensive driving principles, airport routing and hold-bay protocols.
Hour 3 — Customer handling: onboarding/offboarding, accessibility assistance, luggage handling, lost-and-found, de-escalation scripts and roleplay.
Hour 4 — Incident reporting, evidence capture (photo angles, timestamps, metadata), emergency procedures, chain of custody for evidence.
Ride-alongs — Two 2–3 hour practical sessions with graded checklist and post-ride feedback.
Core SOPs and checklists (copy-ready)
Vehicle Pre-Trip Checklist (fillable): lights; tyres; fluid levels; wipers; mirrors; seatbelts; fire extinguisher; first-aid kit; cleanliness; in-vehicle signage; device mount & charger; meter/POS functioning.
Passenger Pickup Protocol: confirmation call/text; approved pickup point; wait-time policy; safe loading zones; luggage placement policy.
Accessibility Assistance SOP: identify needs; secure mobility devices; wheelchair ramp procedure; verbal confirmation script.
Incident Reporting SOP: immediate safety steps; photographic evidence checklist; witness collection; incident form fields; submit to Ops within 15 minutes.
Evidence Capture Standards: wide exterior shot; close-up of damage; VIN/license plate; interior scene; timestamped phone photo; short 30–60s video walkthrough when possible.
Chain of Custody Form: who collected evidence; time; device used; transfer log entries.
Templates (ready text)
Driver arrival SMS: "Shuttle Plus: Driver [Name] arrived. Vehicle [Plate]. Please meet at [Pickup Point]."
Onboard safety script: "Welcome to Shuttle Plus. Please wear your seatbelt; I'll assist with luggage. Estimated time to airport is [X] minutes."
Incident intake (driver) short report: 5 fields — Time; Location; Parties involved; Immediate actions taken; Evidence attached (Y/N).
Assessment items
Written quiz (15 questions): mix of multiple choice and short answer covering KPIs, SOP steps, evidence standards, safety rules.
Roleplay rubrics: conflict de-escalation (tone, wording, escalation threshold); accessibility assistance (safety and dignity).
Ride-along scoring sheet: punctuality; vehicle inspection completeness; customer handling; navigation/routing; evidence capture when simulated incident occurs.
Trainer guidance and materials
Trainer brief: learning objectives, common failure points, redlines (non-negotiables: seatbelt enforcement, evidence preservation, no personal phone use while driving).
Presentation slides: 20-slide deck covering policies, SOPs, and examples.
Short demo videos: 90–120s clips for vehicle check, wheelchair securement, evidence photo examples.
One-page quick reference card for drivers (foldable) with emergency numbers, top 5 SOPs, and incident steps.
Implementation notes for your folder
File names suggested: Drivers — Training Module v1.0.pdf; Drivers — Pre-Trip Checklist.xlsx; Drivers — Quiz.pdf; Drivers — Ride-Along Scoring.xlsx; Drivers — Quick Reference Card.pdf.
Versioning: include a changelog.txt noting author, date, and changes.




KPI dashboard overview
A focused on-time KPI dashboard tracks punctuality of deliveries, tasks, or services and converts raw events into actionable insights so teams can improve reliability and customer satisfaction Tableau. A good dashboard is simple, shows trend + current state, highlights exceptions, and links to root-cause detail for action ProjectManager.

Recommended metrics (definitions and formulas)
On-time rate (primary) — % of items completed on or before target time.
Formula: (OnTimeCount / TotalCount) × 100.
Late rate — % of items completed after target.
Formula: (LateCount / TotalCount) × 100.
Average lateness — mean minutes/hours late for late items.
Formula: SUM(LateMinutes) / LateCount.
Average lead time / cycle time — mean time from start to completion for all items.
Formula: SUM(CompletionTime ? StartTime) / TotalCount.
On-time by segment — on-time rate broken down by region, carrier, route, team, product, or priority.
Trend (rolling) — 7/14/30-day rolling on-time rate to show direction.
Volume — count of items per period (to contextualize rates).
Top causes — categorical counts for reasons items were late (e.g., weather, stockout, resource).
Thresholds, targets and alert rules
Target on-time rate: e.g., 95% (adjust to business).
Warning band: 90–95% (requires review).
Critical: below 90% (automated alerts).
Alert rules: trigger when 3day rolling on-time < 90% or any operational segment falls >5 percentage points below target.
Data model and sources
Core fields needed per item: ItemID, StartTimestamp, TargetTimestamp, CompletionTimestamp, Status, Region, Team, Priority, CauseCode.
Derived fields: OnTimeFlag (CompletionTimestamp ? TargetTimestamp), LatenessMinutes (Completion ? Target in minutes if late).
Typical sources: order management, dispatch system, ERP, ticketing system, spreadsheets, IoT trackers. Ensure timestamps use the same timezone and consistent formatting.

Visual layout (simple, single-screen dashboard)
Top row: big KPI cards — On-time rate (current); Trend (7d rolling); Volume (period); Average lateness.
Middle row left: time-series chart (line) — daily on-time rate with rolling average. Middle row right: stacked bar or heatmap — on-time by region or team.
Bottom row left: table — segments sorted by worst on-time rate (with volume). Bottom row right: bar chart — top causes for lateness with counts.
Color rules: green ? target, amber warning band, red critical. Include quick filters: date range, region/team, priority.

Implementation plan and cadence
Quick win (1 week): agree metrics/targets, assemble sample data (last 30 days), build prototype in your BI tool (Power BI / Tableau / Google Data Studio).
Validate (1 week): review with operations, confirm definitions and edge cases.
Automate (2–4 weeks): connect live data sources, implement ETL (standardize timestamps, compute flags), add alerting.
Operate: daily checks by operations; weekly review with managers; monthly deep-dive for root-cause actions.

Roles, next steps and success criteria
Roles: Data owner (maintains source); BI owner (builds dashboard); Ops lead (drives improvements); Alerts owner (manages thresholds).
Next steps for you: provide a sample CSV or db access with the core fields listed above; confirm target on-time rate and priority segments.
Success criteria: dashboard reflects accurate on-time rate within 1 business day; alerts reduce days below target by measurable amount within 90 days.
